Peiris (2025).text: Peiris, Eshantha. Email to Annie Liu and Ian Peiris. April 28, 2025.

storytelling.text: Source: “The ubọ-aka serves as a medium of communication, transmitting the society’s folkways and traditions orally from one generation to another. The music conveys information, storytelling, proverbs, and idiomatic statements, allowing the listeners to learn about the mores and norms of the society.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.3] Definition: “The action or activity of telling stories, or a particular story; an instance of this.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “storytelling”)

slendro.text: English A: “The sound of the slendro scale, the sound of the pelog scale, they are the essence of sound, which is called angkus prana.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.4]) Balinese A: “Swara patut salendro, swara patut pelog, ika swara kaingkup dening sarira, marmanya ingaranan angkus prana.” (Geria (n.d.)) Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Iti swara ring pangider-ideran, inamet ring Swara Genta Pinara Pitu. Panca swara patut Pelog, panca swara patut Slendro. Iki inangge ring tabuh-tabuhan, mwang swara patut pitu. Apan Swapiaki wus pinarah ti denira Sang Kawi, marmanya hana Dasa Swara umungguh ring pangider-ideran. Mangkana wetnya.” (Bandem (1986), 42) English C (Chat GPT Translation): “These are the sounds in circular motion (swara ring pangider-ideran), embodied in the Seven Tones of the Sacred Bell (Swara Genta Pinara Pitu). The Panca Swara (Five Sounds) are aligned with Pelog, and the Panca Swara are aligned with Slendro. These are used in musical instruments (tabuh-tabuhan) and correspond to the seven musical tones. Since the system has been arranged by Sang Kawi (the sacred poet/sage), the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds) are positioned within the circular motion of sound. Thus, this is how it manifests.”  Balinese D: “Iti swara papatutan tiga, ring luhur swara patut Pelog, ring madya swara patut Pitu, ring sor swara patut Slendro. Tri swa-ra patutan iki kang inangge salwiring tatabuhan sami, mwang salwiring wirama katekatekeng sarwa Pupuh Kakidungan.” (Bandem (1986), 44) English D (ChatGPT Translation): “These sounds are arranged into three categories: These three divisions of sound are used in all musical instruments (tatabuhan) and serve as the foundation for all rhythms (wirama), as well as the various forms of sung poetry (Pupuh Kakidungan).”  Balinese E: “Menurut falsafah Prakempa bahwa bunyi (suara) mempunyai kaitan yang erat dengan konsepsi lima dimensi yang dinamakan Panca Mahabhuta, yaitu Pertiwi, Bayu, Apah, Teja dan Akasa. Bunyi dengan warnanya masing-masing menyebar ke seluruh penjuru bumi dan akhimya membentuk sebuah lingkaran yang disebut Lingkaran Pengider Bhvana. Pencipta dari bunyi itu bernama Bhagawan Wiswakarma dan ciptaan beliau mengambil ide dari bunyi (suara) 8 (delapan) penjuru dunia yang sumbernya berada pada dasar bumi. Suara-suara (bunyi) itu dibentuk menjadi 10 (sepuluh) nada yaitu 5(lima) nada yang disebut laras Pelog dan 5 (lima) nada disebut laras Slendro.” Bandem (1986) [p. 13] Balinese F: “laras yg digunakan pd perangkat gamelan gender wayang, angklung, jogéd bumbung, dan génggong” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 171, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\u97d3\u56fd\u306e\u96c5\u697d\u00a0Kank.text: Japanese A: “し 具 体 的 に お 聞 き し た い の で す が 、 た とえ ば 、 先 ⽣ は 韓 国 の 雅 楽 か ら 何 か 受 け られ た 影 響 は ご ざ い ま す か 。 私 は 先 ⽣ の 作 品 に そ れ を 感 じ る の で す が " … "全 く そ の 通 り で す 。 ⽇ 本 の 雅 楽 は 韓 国 か ら 伝 来 し た 部 分 と 中 国 か ら 伝 来 し た 部 分 が あ り 、 韓 国 の 雅 楽 と は 内 容 的 に 少し 質 が 違 い ま す ." (Yun (1984) - Japanese,51) English A: "For example, have you been influenced by Korean A-ak [Korean ceremonial court music]? I can sense its influence in your pieces. . ." "Exactly as you said. Japanese court music has parts that are imported from Korea and parts that are from China. But its contents are qualitatively different from Korean A-ak." (Park (2024) [1.3])

\ub18d\ud604 nonghyeon.text: Korean A: “이제 생각해 보아야할 문제는, 판소리에서 악조를 판별하는 데 있어서 구성음(출현음)을 중요 하게 볼 것이냐, 주요 선을 골격과 시김을 중요하게 볼 것이냐 하는 점이다. 그리고 이는 판소리 의 음악 특성이 고려되어야 한다. 궁중음악이나 양반들 풍류음악의 경우에는 음악 자체에 시김이 크게 강조되지 않는다. 농현 과 추성, 퇴성 등을 하지만, 농현의 깊이가 깊지 않고, 추성과 퇴성의 정도 역시 마찬가지이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 247] English A: “The crucial consideration is therefore whether to prioritize the constituent notes or the primary melodic structure and sigim[sae] in identifying the mode in pansori, taking into account the musical attributes of pansori. Sigim[sae] is not a significant focus in court or aristocratic entertainment music. [When looking at instrumental court music’s modal theory by comparison,] the vibration of string, called nonghyeon 농현 [string play], is the shallowest, and chuseong 추성 [a slow rise in pitch] and toeseong have similar qualities.” Kim (2024) [3.32] Korean B: “그의 글에 ‘g(찡)는 界面調에서와 같은 많은 弄絃(vibrato)을 하지 않는 다’33)라고 적고 있는 점으로 미루어, g음이 계면조의 떠는음에 해당함을 알 수 있고,” (Shin (2018), 255) English B: “She writes that “g (jjing) does not have as much nonghyeon (vibrato) as in Gyemyeonjo” (Lee 1969, 150), indicating that g correlates to Gyemyeonjo’s vibrating sound.” (Kim (2024) [3.17]) Korean C: “그러므로 여기서 나는 羽調와 界面調에 나오는 構成音을 찾아보고, 또 旋律型(Melodic Pattern), 音程, 弄絃(音色) 等을 比較하여 伽倻琴散調에 있어서 羽調와 界面調의 特性을 밝히려 한다.” (Shin (2018) 248) English C: “In order to distinguish the qualities of Ujo and Gyemyeonjo in gayageum sanjo, I will thus search for the constituent notes that are present in both modes and compare the melodic pattern, pitch, and nonghyeon (i.e., timbre). (Kim (2024) [3.2] and Footnote 29: [The term “timbre” (음색) in parentheses is added by the original author.]”) English D: a kind of sigimsae (Pyǒn (2012) 185) Korean D: 현악기 연주법의 하나. 현을 흔들어 연주하는 것으로 넓은 의미로 는 현재의 농현(흔드는 소리), 전성(구르는 소리), 퇴성(흘러내리는 소리) 이 모두 속하고 좁은 의미로는 농현(흔드는 소리)만을 가리킨다. (Pyǒn (2012) 186)

\uae30\ub300\ud55c \uc2dc\uac04 gidaehan.text:
기대한 + 시간 기대한: expected 시간: time 
 Korean A: “'하우프트톤'의 경우, 음과 양의 상대시 변화는, 미세한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 시작하며 기대한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 이르기까지 여러 단계가 있습니 다. 거기에는 순간에 영원이 반영되고, 영원을 순간으로서 포착한 수가 있어요. 그것이 동양인의 '시'(時)에 대한 사고방식으로서, 서양인의 '시'의 사고방식과는 전혀 다른 점이지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

socialization.text: Source: “Additionally, the ubọ-aka is a symbol of masculinity and manhood, reflecting the patrilineal nature of social organization among the Nri people. It also plays a role in socialization, as it is used for leisure and relaxation, and is associated with courtship and marriage, conveying love and expectations in married lives.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.3] Definition: “The process of forming associations with others; spec. the process by which a person learns to function within a particular society or group by internalizing its values and norms.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “socialization”)

extens\u00f5es.text: English A: “The move in bossa nova melodies toward more restricted and narrow melodic range helped to strip away the melodramatic qualities of the samba canção of previous decades.” (Stover (2024) [2.10]) Portuguese A: “Este afastamento da melodia bossa nova para extensões mais restritas e estreitas ajuda-a a se despir das qualidades melodramáticas do samba-canção das décadas anteriores.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Intervalo compreendido entre o som mais grave e o mais agudo que uma voz ou instrumento são capazes de produzir. Nas palavras de Parrel é" o conjunto de sons que o cantor pode emitir sem esforços fora os limites naturais da tessitura." (In: Moretzsohn; L. Da voz c sua classifi-cação. R.B. Mus., 1 (1): 39, 1934). (DM-MA)” (Andrade (1989), 208)

\uc791\ud488\uc77c\ub78c\u00a0Jagpum-ill.text: 작품: work 일람: list Korean A: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

muni.text: Sinhalese A: “tat jek kinaṃ takaṭa kaḍataka jeṃgu jeṃ takaṭa tat takaṭa – muni dakin” Peiris (2024) [12] English A: “[vocables. . .] – witness the Buddha.” Peiris (2024) [12]

\uacfc\uc815 gwajeong.text: Korean A: "동양의 전통음악에는 서양인이 갖고 있던 형식관은 없는 거지 요. 서양음악에는 곡을 조립해가는 과정에 대한 명확한 유형이 있습 니다. 그리고 그 유형을 벗어나서는 음악이 지속될 수가 없어요." (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "East Asian traditional music does not possess Western-style formalism. In Western music, there are clear process [プロセス] to assemble a composition based on clear models. Outside of these models, music cannot be sustained. " (Park (2024) [2.3])

cognition.text: Source: “But Geria gradually passes from Prakempa’s metaphysical style to a discourse on the play of tones and the concrete sensations they produce. Having sculpted these worlds as continuous, even a non-Balinese reader can connect the umwelt of precolonial Bali to an international emergent music theory based on earthly perception and cognition.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.6]) Definition: “The action or faculty of knowing taken in its widest sense, including sensation, perception, conception, etc., as distinguished from feeling and volition; also, more specifically, the action of cognizing an object in perception proper.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “cognition” 2a)

embellishment tones.text: Source: “Fundamentally, pansori is a performance-oriented, rather than composer-centric, genre. It privileges the performer’s artistic discretion in realizing embellishment tones, singing technique, vocal tone and timbre, as well as body gestures.” Lee commentary (2024) [5] Definition: “The action or process of embellishing or beautifying; decoration, ornamentation.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “embellishment”)

cantigas.text: Portuguese A: “Rodney Gallop, no seu admirável estudo sobre o Fado (380, abril de 1933 p. 208 e 209) estudando a rítmica do Fado (que aliás considera melhor em 4/4) cita justo um caso de síncopa no primeiro tempo que é tipicamente uma habanera americana, ida naturalmente por intermédio do Brasil. E reconhece outras cantigas portuguesas no mesmo ritmo citadas por Fernandes Tomás (“Velhas Canções e Romances”) como originárias do Brasil negróide.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 23] English A: “Rodney Gallop, in his admirable study on Fado, studying the rhythm of Fado (which he actually considers better in 4/4), cites precisely a case of syncopation on the first beat, which is typically an American habanera, naturally brought through Brazil. And he recognizes other Portuguese songs in the same rhythm mentioned by Fernandes Tomás (“Velhas Canções e Romances”) as originating from black Brazil.” Menezes (2024) ‘[1.10] Portuguese B: “Poesia cantada em versos. Ou ainda, segundo Mariza Lira:"pequena canção, Brasa, 10ada 193) Asca gas, pa Alfonso Cariar,são para cantar o amor, sentimentos religiosos, acontecimentos históricos e outros assuntos ligados à vivência do povo. (Antiguos cantos populares ar-gentinos, 1926, p. 17).” (Andrade (n.d.) 103)

\uc778\uac04\uc138\uacc4 ingansegye.text:
인간 + 세계 인간: human 세계: world 
 Korean A: “순수한 유 사체 로서 인간의 현세를 초월한, 그런 인간세계와 천상세계의 중간, 인간세계와 천상세계의 접촉이라고나 할까 또는 지옥이라고 하는 전혀 인간의 현실세계와는 유리되어 초월한 우주의 문제를 취급한 작품은 그밖에도 많습니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 159] English A: “The realm that is in between the mortal world and the celestial world, or perhaps a contact between the two worlds. There are many other compositions that deal with a topic that is separate from the real world, such as purgatory and a transcendent universe.” Park (2024) [5.3]

Chow commentary (2024).text: Chow, Sheryl Man-Ying. 2024. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4. (CHECK CITATION)

\ubd81 puk.text: English A: “Pansori 판소리 and sanjo 산조 are small-ensemble genres of Korean folk music with many shared characteristics.(1) Pansori consists of a dramatic narrative performance by a sorikkun 소리꾼, a vocalist-narrator, and a gosu 고수, a drummer who provides rhythmic accompaniment on a barrel drum called a puk 북.” (Kim (2024) [0.1])

nyendok.text: English: “Nyendok, to scoop (from sendok, spoon), evokes the opening 23 in the sangsih, which enters below the polos, scooping the composite pattern 235 upwards. NB. That feature notwithstanding, this ubitan telu pattern is much like gagelut and gagulet (IV.2 and 3) but Geria sets it in a gending twice as long (as the lower boxes show).” Tenzer (2024) [4.11] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\uc81c2\uc8fc\uc81c\ubd80\ubd84 je2jujeb.text:
제2 + 주제 + 부분 제2: second 주제: theme 부분: part 
 Korean A: “니시무라 시(時)에 대한 사고방식이 형식관(形式觀)에 반영된 예로서 서양에는 소나타 형식이 있습니다만, 소나타 형식이라고 하면 제1주제부가 있고 제2주제부가 있다. 이들은 대립된 구간(區間)이며 제2주제 부분은 제1주제와 다른 시간을 독자적으로 형성하 는 것이기 때문에 순간에 세계를 갖는 음양과는 전혀 다르다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157-158] English A: “The Sonata form might be one example that reflects the Western formalistic view of time. In Sonata form, there are primary and secondary theme areas. They are contrasting sections that independently develop [the sense of] time. Therefore, it is completely different from yin and yang, which contain an eternity in a moment.” Park (2024) [4.2]

prayer.text: Source: “Nri is a significant historic place in the history and mythology of the Igbo people as a cultural center, particularly because of the Nri priests and oracles’ leadership in odinaani (or odinala), which comprises Igbo religion and spirituality and related customs. The importance of the ubọ-aka for the Nri people in traditional practices, including prayer and meditation, is emphasized in Ezegbe’s dissertation (1977).” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.1] Definition: “A solemn request to God, a god, or other object of worship; a supplication or thanksgiving addressed to God or a god.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “prayer”)

diatonicism.text: Diatónico (Spanish) Source: “For Hába, “tonality” was coextensive with diatonicism, and thus contained non-tertian harmonies, if not chromatic notes (Hába 1927, 75). The generation of microtonal divisions followed from the “law of division” found in the sixth octave of the overtone series, but can also be found in much music of the past, as well as in folk repertoires.” Bauer commentary (2024) [3.2] Definition: “Based on or derivable from an octave of seven notes in a particular configuration, as opposed to Chromatic and other forms of Scale. A seven-note scale is said to be diatonic when its octave span is filled by five tones and two semitones, with the semitones maximally separated, for example the major scale (T–T–S–T–T–T–S). The natural minor scale and the church modes (see Mode) are also diatonic.” (Grove Music Online, “diatonic”)

kendang.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “yan swaraning kendang, wetu saking mega mendung, biyomantaragora ngaran, udantya ngaran, adalan ring luhuring lidah yan ring anggasarira,” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The sound of drums is borne from the great sky above, biyomantaragora, it is called udantya and located above the tongue, anggasarira.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.10]) Balinese C: “instrumen berbentuk bulat panjang, berongga, memakai pakelit di dalamnya, pd kedua ujungnya dibungkus dg kulit, berfungsi sbg pamurba irama dan mengatur cepat lambatnya lagu” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 152, Bidang Istilah Musik]

per\u00edodo.text: English A: “As Simha Arom explains in his work on polyrhythm in Central Africa (1994), there is no regular pattern or intermediate level (such as measures and downbeats) between the pulse level and the musical period. This period, often formed by the addition of rhythmic patterns of varying size, can be externalized through claps that mark the dance steps or by a guide instrument that plays what is known as a time-line.” (Stover (2024) [4.4]) Portuguese A: “Como explica Simha Aaron no seu trabalho sobre poliritmia na Africa central (1994), não há um padrão regular nem níveis intermediários (como compassos e tempos fortes) entre a pulsação e o período musical. Este período, formado muitas vezes pela adição de padrões rítmicos de tamanho variado pode ser externalizado através de palmas que marcam os passos da dança ou por um instrumento-guia que toca o que se conhece como "time-line".” (Ulhôa (1999))

pati.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug tan paselat, anunggal pati ngaran” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “If two adjacent keys are struck it is called pati [dead stroke].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8]) Balinese B: “tangkai (sabit, cangkul, dsb) yg berfungsi sbg pegangan.” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 26, Bidang Istilah Pertanian]

\u5fb4 zh\u01d0.text: Chinese: “《礼记·乐记》：“宫爲君，商爲臣，角爲民，徵爲事，羽爲物；五者不亂，則無怗懘之音矣。” Hanyu dacidian  (宫) English: Pentatonic pitch class 3 Synonymous terms: sol (sung jianpu 简谱), 5 (written jianpu 简谱), 六/合 (gongchepu 工尺谱) Lam (2024) Ex. 2.2 Lam (2024) Ex. 2.1

\u0442\u0430\u043d\u0446/tants.text: Bulgarian A: “Различни комбинации от кратки и протегнати части образуват редица неправилни и правилни тактове, всеки от които служи за основа на особен танц.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “Different combinations of short and elongated parts form a series of irregular and regular meters, each of which serves as the basis for a particular dance.” Goldberg (2024) [3.2]

gong.text: See gamelan gong kebyar  English A: “The final sound, the sound of gong, emerges from the fire in our body, it is under the tongue, the name is agora.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.10]) Balinese A: “Iki wekasing swara, lwirnya yan swaran gong, wetu saking ageni yan ring anggasarira, adalan ring sorning lidah, agora ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: (Bandem (1986), 60) Balinese C: “1 instrumen berbentuk bulat, sebelah sisinya berongga, bergaris tengah 70 sampai dg 100 cm, pencon diangkat dr permukaannya setinggi 6 cm dg lebar 6 cm, berfungsi memberi fase akhir lagu; 2 gamelan gong” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 145, Bidang Istilah Musik]

contorno mel\u00f3dico.text: English A: “In popular song, melody and lyrics closely influence each other. There are elements in the lyrics, especially their narrative or lyrical quality, that suggest different types of melody, and there are particularities in the melody, especially its melodic contour and the types of intervals used that define the character of the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Na canção popular melodia e letra interferem estreitamente uma sobre a outra. Existem elementos na letra, especialmente sua qualidade narrativa ou lírica que conduzem a diferentes tipos de melodia; existem particularidades na melodia, especialmente seu contorno melódico e tipos de intervalos empregados que marcam o caráter da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u5f62\u5f0f\u89b3 keishiki-kan.text: Japanese A: "日本の作曲家たちは、従来、作曲のマテリアルは、現代でも古い西洋の伝統的な形式観に何かしら沿っているのではないでしょうか。" (Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "Perhaps Japanese composers follow the old Western traditional formalism even though the compositional materials [マテリアル] might be modern." (Park (2024) [2.3])

\u30e2\u30cb\u30b9\u30c6\u30a3monisuti.text: Japanese A: "私の音楽はモニスティッシュです。というのは、私の音楽は複音楽的じゃないし、多応的な音楽ではありません。たとえばアロイス・ツインマーマン、彼のは多元的な音楽ですね。根源が違っている音楽的な要素が同時に流れて秩序を保ちつつ、対立しながら、ついにはそれらが和合して、皆楽的な大きな向上をするというものです." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) English A: "My music is monistic (monistisch). My music is not polyphonic or pluralistic. For example, Bernd Alois Zimmermann’s music is pluralistic. Elements from different roots flow together, maintain order, oppose, but ultimately come together to greatly elevate the music." (Park (2024) [2.1])

banyu marga.text: See gambang  English A: “Gambang style is called kesa mura; its sound is banyu maga.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.13]) Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang gagebug gambang, kesa mura. Banyu maga nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “As well as being an instrument, in Bali gambang also names an ensemble usually comprising four gambang and two bronze metallophones. Kesa mura means irregular and free, which likely connotes the fact that gamelan gambang music is not regulated by gongs and conventional gong structures. Banyu marga means flowing water, suggesting the continuous rippling texture of gamelan gambang music.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.12]) *Lexical field: Natural world (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u0442\u0440\u043e\u043f\u043b\u0438\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “И в сборниците на Куба и Кухач има български, македонски и др. песни, но и в тяхната автентичност може да се има толкова вяра, колкото в материалите от министерските сборници. Както в едните, той и в другите се срещат, макар рядко, песни с мерки 5/4 и 7/4, обаче само в бавно движение. Това са мерки, конто, може да се каже, се създават по изкуствен начин от записвачите, защото те не са основа на някакви известни народни танци. Напротив, мярката на пайдушката 5/16, двойната мярка 7/16 (ръченица и македонско хоро), 9/16 (тропливата игра или радомирското хоро), 11/16 (хайдушка игра) и др. там никак не се срещат.” Hristov (1925) [p. 35] English A: “There are also Bulgarian, Macedonian, and other songs in the collections by Kuba and Kuhač, but there can be as much faith in the reliability of this work as in the materials from the Ministry collections. In both sets of collections are found, though rarely, songs with the time signatures 5/4 and 7/4, but only at a slow tempo. These are time signatures that are created artificially, so to speak, by the transcribers, because they are not the basis for any known folk dances. To the contrary, the time signature of 5/16 (paidushkata), both 7/16 time signatures (rŭchenitsa and makedonsko horo), 9/16 (troplivata igra or radomirskoto horo), 11/16 (haidushka igra), etc., are in no way found there.” Goldberg (2024) [2.7] See also: игра/igra

par\u00e2metros musicais.text: English A: “One of the musical parameters most discussed by Mário de Andrade in Ensaio sobre a músical brasileira, and a key point that permeates his entire work, is the issue of rhythm.” (Stover (2024) [1.1]) Portuguese A: “Um dos parâmetros musicais mais discutidos por Mário no Ensaio Sobre a Música Brasileira, e um ponto chave que permeia toda sua obra é a questão do rítmo.” (Ulhôa (1999))

can\u00e7\u00e3o popular.text: English A: “A popular song is accompanied singing. The interference in the rhythm of the spoken word’s temporal organization does not pose any problem for monodic singing, but it becomes a complicating element for the performance of a song, precisely because it makes synchronization between the melody and the accompaniment difficult.” (Stover (2024) [4.1]) Portuguese A: “A canção popular é um canto acompanhado. A interferência do ritmo da palavra falada na organização temporal, não traz nenhum problema para o canto religioso monódico, mas se torna um elemento complicador para a performance da canção, exatamente por dificultar a sincronização entre a melodia e o acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\ub9c9 mak.text: Korean A: “그 곡은 4개월 정도였던가? 그 오페라는 1막짜리로서 1시간 걸리는 곡인데, 독일에서 납치당하기 전에 그 곡의 처음 10분 정도 가 되어 있었어요 그 다음의 50분 분량은 옥중에서 썼지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 161] English A: “The opera is in one act and takes about one hour to perform. Before I was kidnapped in Germany, the first 10 minutes’ worth was completed.” Park (2024) [6.2]

\uc0ac\uc124 sasul.text: Korean A: “흔히 판소리 우조를 설명할 때 씩씩하 며 위엄있다 하고, 계면조를 슬픈 느낌의 애원성이라고 하는 것은 사설의 분위기를 선율에서 그대로 표출하기 때문이다. 이러한 감정의 표출은 시김새를 통해 가장 잘 드러나며, 시김새가격해질수록 2도 및 3도의 순차 진행 보다는 4~5도 진행이 많이 이루어지면서 자연히 각 음의 비중이 차이를 보이게 된다.” Shin (2018) [p. 248] English A: “These descriptions reflect the mood of sasul 사설 [comparable to recitativo in opera], being the directly expressed in the melody. The intensity of emotions is most effectively conveyed through sigimsae, with the fourth and fifth degrees occurring more frequently than the second and third degrees; there is a distinct variation in the relative occurrences of each note.” Kim (2024) [3.32]

nyalimput.text: English: “Nyalimput— to stumble or trip—with its eight-beat gending, is, along with its relative Nyalimped (#14) the longest pattern in Geria’s ubit-ubitan collection, and it has a distinctive profile. The jutting dyad 63, shown in grey, occurs 11 times. It recurs at an interval of three subdivisions except thrice—and this is where the tripping happens.  At the two solid-boxed moments the distance is two, and in the dotted box it is four. Elsewhere 63s are equally spaced at a nice 3-against-4 cross-rhythmic gait, only to stumble again the next time around.” Tenzer (2024) [4.14] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

sivpada.text: English: “The Sinhala verses in both the däkum ata (Paragraph 9) and the upat kavi (Paragraphs 30–37) follow the cyclic format known as sivpada (Sin. quatrain), in which each line of poetry contains an approximately equal number of morae and ends with eli-väṭa (Sin. rhyming/assonant phonemes). As mentioned, the Sinhala däkum ata verses (Paragraph 9) contain eighteen morae per line.” Peiris (2024) [17]

mmonwu.text: Igbo A: “Ihea bu egwu (mmonwu) anyi na agu n’umuazi, “M ma emekwa ebere / Ebere, ebere / M ma emekwa ebere”.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “This is a (masquerade) folk song we sang when I was a child, “I will not have mercy / Mercy, mercy / I will not have mercy”.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

\u043f\u0435\u0448\u0440\u0435\u0444\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “На пръв поглед безмензурните ни песни приличат на персо-арабските пешрефи, защото и в тях думите се т в р д е протакат и при слушане изглежда, че и те са без такт. В същност пешрефите имат точно определен такт, който чрез биене на дайре и др. ударни инструменти се уяснява. При записване безмензурните песни за по-лесно изпълнение се подвеждат под някой определен такт.” Hristov (1925) (p. 39) English A: “At first glance our unmeasured songs resemble Persian-Arabic peşrevs, because the words in these songs are also quite protracted, and upon listening it appears as though they also lack meter. In actuality peşrevs have a precisely defined meter that is clarified through beating on the daire and other percussion instruments. When transcribing unmeasured songs for easier performance, they are misrepresented as having a particular meter.” Goldberg (2024) [4.1] (See also [5.3])

Waiguo wenxue (1990).text: Waiguo wenxue dacidian 外国文学大词典. Diao Shaohua 刁绍华主编 (ed.). Changchun: Jilin jiaoyu chubanshe 长春:吉林教育出版社, 1990.

sil\u00e1bica.text: English A: “Brazilian prosody is syllabic, verses being specified by their number of syllables (from one to twelve, generally, counted up to the last accented syllable); each type of verse has a fixed number of syllables, limited by an obligatory final tonic accent.” (Stover (2024) [3.3]) Portuguese A: “A prosódia brasileira é silábica, os versos sendo especificados pelo seu número de sílabas (de uma a doze, geralmente, contadas até a última sílaba acentuada); cada tipo de verso tem um número fixo de sílabas, limitados por um acento tônico final obrigatório.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u043c\u0430\u043a\u0435\u0434\u043e\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Вторият вид 7/16 такт се образува от втори вид 5/16 с прибавка в края на още една кратка част и служи за основа на обикновено хоро, което се играе във всички краища на България. В Македония е основата на македонското хоро.” Hristov (1925) [p. 47] English A: “The second type of 7/16 meter is formed from the second type of 5/16 with the addition of one more short part at the end; this meter also serves as the basis of an ordinary horo that is danced in all regions of Bulgaria. In Macedonia it is the basis for makedonsko horo.” Goldberg (2024) [5.14] See also: хоро/horo

Pedrell (1890).text: Pedrell, Felipe, Diccionario Técnico De La Música: Escrito Con Presencia De Las Obras Más Notables En Este Género Publicadas En Otros Paíases, Enriquecido Con Más De 11, 500 Voces Castellanas y Sus Correspondencias Italianas, Latinas, Francesas, Alemanas, É Inglesas Más Usuales ... Ilustrado Con 117 Grabados y 51 Ejemplos De Música y Seguido De Un Suplemento. 2. ed. Barcelona: I. Torres Oriol, 1890.

recipient.text: Source: “On the other side of the metaphor is the naming of a sensation from the perspective of the recipient of tickling, a gesture, as Adam Phillips (1993, 9) elaborates from Darwin, that seems to require an actant and a recipient (“It is the pleasure [the child] cannot reproduce in the absence of the other.”). And yet Geria writes: “Its sound is pangirik [tickling].” If we take this to mean that the sound tickles, the musician is then the tickler. Except, of course, the tickling is not enacted directly on the listener’s body, but rather on the body of the instrument (which is sometimes the musician’s own body, as in the case of singing) as a kind of intermediary substitute for the listener’s body.” (Wang commentary (2024) [2.5]) Definition: “A person who or thing which receives (in various senses); a receiver of something.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “recipient” 2)

dahana muka.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat tiga, dahana muka ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “if three are in-between the name is dahana muka [face aflame]); ” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug babarangan Anutasih ngaran. Yaning gage-Bus ges der pewayahau umbans taruns ngarang tan pa selat Anunggalpati ngaran. Yaning gebug selat siki Chandrapra-ba ngaran. Yaning gebug selat kalih Paduarsa ngaran. Yaning gebug selat telu Dahanamuka ngaran. Yaning gebug selat pat Anerang sasih ngaran. Yaning gebug selat lima Anerang Wisaya ngaran. Yaning gebug selat nem Gana wedana ngaran.” (Bandem (1986), 68)

m\u00e9trica possa.text: English A: “For there to be syncopation, the presence of metric structure is necessary, with the beats hierarchically arranged so that the configuration of metric strength can be challenged by the displacement of the strong beats.” (Stover (2024) [1.3]) Portuguese A: “Para existir a síncopa é necessário, portanto, a presença de uma estrutura de compassos com os tempos hierarquicamente colocados para que esta configuração de poder da métrica possa ser desafiada pelo deslocamento dos tempos fortes.” (Ulhôa (1999))

r\u00edtmo.text: English A: “One of the musical parameters most discussed by Mário de Andrade in Ensaio sobre a músical brasileira, and a key point that permeates his entire work, is the issue of rhythm.” (Stover (2024) [1.1]) Portuguese A: “Um dos parâmetros musicais mais discutidos por Mário no Ensaio Sobre a Música Brasileira, e um ponto chave que permeia toda sua obra é a questão do rítmo.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Toda e qualquer organização do movimento dentro do tempo. No geral consiste em agrupar valores de tempos combinados, por mcio de acentos. (Andrade, M. de. Pequena história da música, ba. cd., p.O que a gente pode afirmar, com força de certeza, é que os clementos formais da música, o som e o ritmo, são tão velhos como o homem. Este os possui em si mesmo, porque os movimentos do coração, o ato de respirar ja são clementos rítmicos, o passo já organiza um ritmo, as mãos percutindo já podem determinar todos os clementos do ritmo. E a voz produz o som.” (Andrade (1989), 440) Portuguese C: “(1) Sequência de sons fortes e fracos, dentro de intervalos e tempo determinados (2) (Bras.) [Música ameríndia]. - "O ritmo da música pareci, em regra, segue os compassos binário e ternário. Há também, nos fonogramas colhidos, compassos alternados, cuja regularidade não é conservada em todo o trecho.” (Cosme (1957), 101)

\u8907\u97f3\u697d fuku ongaku.text: Japanese A: "私の音楽はモニスティッシュです。というのは、私の音楽は複音楽的じゃないし、多応的な音楽ではありません。たとえばアロイス・ツインマーマン、彼のは多元的な音楽ですね。根源が違っている音楽的な要素が同時に流れて秩序を保ちつつ、対立しながら、ついにはそれらが和合して、皆楽的な大きな向上をするというものです." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) English A: "My music is monistic (monistisch). My music is not polyphonic or pluralistic. For example, Bernd Alois Zimmermann’s music is pluralistic. Elements from different roots flow together, maintain order, oppose, but ultimately come together to greatly elevate the music." (Park (2024) [2.1]) Japanese B: “複数の声部がそれぞれの旋律的独自性を保持しつつ動く音楽 形態。多声音楽。「多くの声（部）」を意味するギリシア語に由来する名称。同じく複数の声部からなるが、旋律の独自性が特定の1声部のみにしか与えられない*ホモフォニーとは区別される。” (Tomosha (2002), 648)

ubitan empat.text: English: “IV.2 through IV.5 can be discussed together since they are similar and all paired with the same oscillating two-note gending pattern. Gagelut and gagulet are assonant synonyms meaning hug, embrace, or even wrestle. The patterns are of a subtype called ubitan telu (telu = three) in which the two parts use a total of three tones, sharing an inner tone; hence embracing. These are indeed ubiquitous in the repertoire. Kabelit and kabelet, similarly related as words, mean stuck, stubborn, unmoving. They are of subtype called ubitan empat (empat = four) in which the two parts use two different but scale-adjacent tones each. When sounded the lower tone of the polos and the upper tone of the sangsih coincide, creating a dyad that protrudes from the texture to create a syncopated  3+2+3 cross-rhythm (the greyed notes). While the inner tones jostle, this prominent interval is “stuck” in its place.” Tenzer (2024) [4.6] English B: “To introduce some cross-cultural perspective, Example 3 reproduces my typology of ubit-ubitan patterns, based also on sensitivity to contour but differently than Geria (Tenzer 2000a, 225; Tenzer 2000b). I separate ubit-ubitan into two collections, ubit telu (ubit “three”, shown at left) and ubit empat (ubit “four”, shown at right). This is such a quotidian distinction for Balinese that Geria did perhaps not even consider invoking it. In ubit telu patterns, three contiguous scale-tone pitches are used, and the polos and sangsih parts always share the middle pitch. In ubit empat a fourth pitch is added such that each part has its own two pitches, and when the low part sounds its lower pitch, the high part always sounds its higher one. This generates dyads that protrude from the texture as cross-rhythms when patterns repeat. Aside from this, though, the collections of ubit telu and ubit empat patterns are identical from the standpoint of the contours of the lower three pitches in each.” (Tenzer (2024) [5.3])

tempo circular.text: English A: “In Brazilian music, there is a conflict between temporal process in the traditional European rhythmic conception, which would seek the simultaneity of linear time, and Amerindian and African concepts of circular time.” (Stover (2024) [1.5]) Portuguese A: “Na música brasileira ocorreria um conflito entre o processo de concepção rítmica europeia tradicional, que buscaria a simultaneidade de um tempo linear e a a concepção de um tempo circular ameríndio e africano.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u043d\u0435\u0440\u0430\u0432\u0435\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: unequal ionic rhythm, “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6]

njem.text: English A: “It seems to me that it is through traveling, That this music spread through Africa. Because when each community, collects their own/It is in their own unique style/They do not bring it back the way it is in another place, to make it available.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Ọ dị m ka ọ site na njem/Ka ihe a si gazuo Afrika/Maka ndị nke wete nke ha/Ọ dị n’ụdị ha/Ha agaghị eje wete ya otu ahu, wenata ya, ọ di.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

\u7d4c\u904e\u97f3 keika oto.text: Japanese A: “さてＡでは上段が下段に比較して細かい分割を行っているが、この両者の関係はかならずしも一概に決定し難く、ある一方の終止音が支配的である旋律中に、他の終止音が終止音としての意味を持たず、単に経過的に現れることも多く、また４度とか５度は、純粋にその音域を制限するものではなく、その上下に随時経過音が付加されうる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 2] Japanese B: “ * ⾮ 和 声 ⾳ （ 転 移 ⾳ ） の ⼀ 種 . ⾼ さ の 異 な る 2 つ の 和 ⾳ 構 成 ⾳ の あ い だ を 、 順次 進 ⾏ で う め る さ い に ⽣ じ る ⾮ 和 声 ⾳ .” Tomosha (2002) [p. 213] English A: “For now, in A, I have made narrower divisions in the upper analysis than in the lower, but the relation between the two is certainly hard to determine as a rule. On the other hand, for the part of the melody controlled by one of the ending notes, the other ending note does not function as the ending note but simply appears in passing [passing tone]. Also, fourths and fifths may not purely limit the range of notes, and extra notes might be added above or below.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.2, brackets added separately]

\uccad cheong.text: Korean A: “또한, 백대웅은 우조의 종류를 진우조, 평우조, 가곡성우조의 셋으로 정리하였다. 그 중 진우 조는 우조의 성격을 가장 분명하게 드러낸 것으로, 진우조에서는 특히 하본청과 상본청의 4도 골격(라-레)이 드러나며 분위기를 고조시키는데, 이는 청을 한 음 높이는 효과를 낸다고 하였 다.” Shin (2018) [p. 239] English A: “Furthermore, Baek assigns three subcategories to Ujo: Jin-ujo, Pyeong-ujo, and Gagokseong-ujo. Jin-ujo best expresses the nature of the Ujo; in particular, the fourth interval (la-re) between haboncheong and sangboncheong heightens the atmosphere with the impact of raising one step the tonic [cheong].” Kim (2024) [3.7] Korean B:  English B: 1, membrane 2. standard tone for instrument tuning 3. key 4. high tone 5, an oral sound for geomungo, gayageum, yanggeum, etc. (Pyǒn (2012) 86)

kabelet.text: English: “IV.2 through IV.5 can be discussed together since they are similar and all paired with the same oscillating two-note gending pattern. Gagelut and gagulet are assonant synonyms meaning hug, embrace, or even wrestle. The patterns are of a subtype called ubitan telu (telu = three) in which the two parts use a total of three tones, sharing an inner tone; hence embracing. These are indeed ubiquitous in the repertoire. Kabelit and kabelet, similarly related as words, mean stuck, stubborn, unmoving. They are of subtype called ubitan empat (empat = four) in which the two parts use two different but scale-adjacent tones each. When sounded the lower tone of the polos and the upper tone of the sangsih coincide, creating a dyad that protrudes from the texture to create a syncopated  3+2+3 cross-rhythm (the greyed notes). While the inner tones jostle, this prominent interval is “stuck” in its place.” Tenzer (2024) [4.6] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) See: kabelit

\u81ea\u7531\u306a\u97f3\u8a9e jiy\u016b.text: 自由: freedom, liberty 音: note 語: language, speech Japanese A: “これはヨーロッパの調性音楽が、次第に従来の長・短調組織からぬけだして、自由な音語を使うようになってから、もっともひろい意味での調性の中心になる音という意味に使われていたものを、伝統音楽のばあいに適用したものと解することができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “It is understood that Mr. Itō applied the word “central tone” as something commonly used in Japanese traditional music, in the same way European music used it in a free pitch language after it gradually began to pull away from its original major- and minor-key organization of tonal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4] “Literally 自由な音語, this is likely a translation of the German freitonal, and refers to the twentieth-century trends in Western classical music often called atonal or post-tonal in English.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 10]

structure.text: Source: “Maintaining the right balance between metrical regularity and the forces that challenge such regularity is key in many musical traditions, and, one might say, in artistic expressions in general: one needs a structure but also something that puts pressure on, or vitalizes, this structure.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [4]) Definition: “The quality or fact of being organized in a particular manner; definite or purposeful arrangement of parts within a whole.” (Oxford English Dictionary “structure” I.4.a)

avant-garde experimentalism.text: Source: “Yun’s Hauptton technique could be understood as his response to the high-modernist trend of 1950s and 60s Germany, in particular, dodecaphony and avant-garde experimentalism.” Park (2024) [1.4]

Minstrel.text: Igbo A: “ Na Gambia ị bụ a Minstrel, Dị ka ihe omimi Ọ dị ka onye…onye ma akwụkwọ rinne. Maka ọ ha ka a na-akuziri k’obodo si bido; “Kee onye, onye chiri mbu?” “Onye chiri, onye chiri ka a chichalu?”” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “ To be a minstrel (griot) in Gambia is a deep thing. It is like a person with great intellect, because it is the minstrel (griot) who knows the history of the community. “Who ruled the community first?” “Who ruled next?” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

bera pada.text: English: “This is followed by the singing of stanzas that consist of bera pada (drum vocable phrases)—except for the last two words of each stanza, which are Sinhala (Paragraph 12, Video 2).” Peiris (2024) [11] Video Example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pvYeLg0-jc&t=106s Sinhala B: “kaṁkāriyaṭa pera dina porottu padaya namin bera pada yak vādanaya karana atara meya paṁsalaka hēvisi vādanaya kirīmē di karanu labana purappaṭṭuva væyīmaṭa samānaya. ' muratæn padaya yanu murutæn pun̆ga avasthāvē vayana padayaki.”  English B (Google Translate): “A drum pada called Porotthu Padaya is played on the day before the Kankari, which is similar to the Purappattuwa played when playing the Hevisi in a Pansala. ' Murathana Pada is a verse sung during the Murathana Puga.” (Dissanayake 1985, 124)

Canon.text: Spanish A: “Desde antes de Juan Sebastián Bach, existía ya el canon por “aumentación” y “disminución,” pero afectaba únicamente la velocidad o la lentitud de un tema, haciendo más aprisa o más despacio una melodía, lo que nada tenía en el fondo que pudiera sugerir la metamorfosis como yo la entiendo: pues la modificación era fácilmente reconocible.”  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] English A: “Since before Johann Sebastian Bach, there already existed canon by “augmentation” and “diminution.” But canon affected only the speed or the length of a theme, made a melody quicker or slower, without having anything at its basis that could suggest metamorphosis as I understand it. Its modification was easily recognizable.”  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “Es una especie de fuga que se llama perpetua, por que las partes entran una despues de otra, repitiendo sin cesar el mismo canto.” Palatín (1990) [p. 46] Spanish C: “Según nuestros tratadistas antiguos significaba cosa de obligación ‘porque para que sea canon una operación, –decían,–es preciso que en ella se pueda formar el círculo músico, volviendo enlazadas las voces al mismo putno en que se dió principio…’” Pedrell (1890) [p. 65]

\u30aa\u30da\u30e9 opera.text: Japanese A: “先生が獄中で書かれたオペラのことですが、先生は健康も害されて、その オペラ自体は演奏される見通しすらない し、その作品自体が獄中から出れるかど うかもわからない、そういった中で、意 識を超越して一気にお書きになったとう かがったのですが。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 59] English A: “Regarding the opera you had composed while in prison [Die Witwe des Schmetterlings (Butterfly Widow)], at the time, you were in poor health, there was no perspective for its performance, and you weren’t even sure whether you could transport the score outside of the prison cell. How were you able to overcome senses [意識] and compose in these circumstances with one stroke?” Park (2024) [6.1] Japanese B: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English B: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) Japanese C: “舞台芸術の一種で、歌唱を中心に、作品全体が主として音楽によって表現されてゆく劇。登場人物は台詞を歌い、独唱あるいは重唱が歌唱の中心となるが、主として群衆の役を受けもつ合唱が加わることもある。作品によっては、登場人物が歌わずに、地の台詞を語る部分が含まれているものもある。これら歌唱に対して、声の伴奏、登場人物の性格、行動、感情、心理などの描写や表現、舞台上の雰囲気の酸出など、種々の役割をもった管弦楽が加えられる。” (Tomosha (2002), 108)

\uc0c1\uc2b9\uc131 sangseungseong.text: Korean A: “그러나 이보다 더 동적인 경우도 있고 더 정적인 경우도 있어요. 또 상승성(上昇性)을 갖는 경우와 하행싱 을 갖는 경우가 있습니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “But there are cases where it is more active or more static. Also, there are cases where it has a tendency upward and downward.” Park (2024) [4.1]

estrutura de compassos.text: English A: “For there to be syncopation, the presence of metric structure is necessary, with the beats hierarchically arranged so that the configuration of metric strength can be challenged by the displacement of the strong beats.” (Stover (2024) [1.3]) Portuguese A: “Para existir a síncopa é necessário, portanto, a presença de uma estrutura de compassos com os tempos hierarquicamente colocados para que esta configuração de poder da métrica possa ser desafiada pelo deslocamento dos tempos fortes.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc625\ud0c0\ube0c oktabeu.text: Korean A: “우조의 경우, 하청은 떠는 기능을 갖고 있지 않고, 반종지하는 음이다. 하본청은 전조와 변조 에 기능하는 음으로서 그 역할이 작지 않고, 옥타브 위에서는 우조 특유의 씩씩한 느낌을 주는 핵심적인 음이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238-239] English A: “In Ujo, hacheong is the note of a half cadence, without the capacity for vibration. It plays a significant role in transposition and modulation and, when used above the octave, contributes to the distinctive and energizing quality of Ujo.” Kim (2024) [3.6]

geleng pangasuh.text: English A: “Drum technique or style is called geleng pangasuh, its sound is meganada.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.12]) Balinese/Indonesian A: “Pukulan kendang atau tandang kakendangan, geleng pangasuh, meganada nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Geleng is a word for head that also suggests focus and concentration; and asuh is diligent. The term suggests the watchful leadership role of the drum in the ensemble. Meganada literally means big sound, but it is also the name of the demon-king Rahwana’s powerful son (of the Ramayana epic).” (Tenzer (2024) [2.11])

\uc694\uc18c yoso.text: Korean A: “이 음에는 장식음이 없습니다. 그러나 셋잇단음표 첫머리의 쉼표가 그걸 대신하는 역할을 하지요. 그에 이어 장식선율적인 요소 가 있지요. 이것은 좀더 발전한 '하우프트톤'의 자태입니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “There is no decorative tone for this. But the first rest of the triplet substitutes its role. It is followed by a melismatic element. This is a more developed figure of a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u0434\u0438\u0430\u0445\u043e\u0440\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Голям научен интерес представлява тя и по своята старинност, което личи от извънредно оригиналния ритъм, от разнообразните тоналности, от тоновия обем (амбитуса), който често е диахорд, а тъй също от съдържанието на думите.” Hristov (1925) (p. 34) English A: “It also represents great scholarly interest in terms of its age, which is indicated by the exceptionally original rhythm, by the diversity of tonalities, by the tonal range (ambitus), which is often a diachord, as well as by the content of the lyrics.” Goldberg (2024) [2.5] “In this context the term diachord refers to a melodic range spanning an interval of a second (see, e.g., Bukoreshtliev 1934, 3–4). Elsewhere, Hristov (1921, 176) and Dzhudzhev (1970, 255) use the word diachord with the same meaning.” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 4]

pangecet.text: Balinese A: “Di bawah ini adalah semua ubit-ubitan palegongan yang berpokok misalnya di dalam gagaboran atau di dalam lalonggoran dan kale, atau pangecet.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Below are palegongan-style ubit-ubitan for gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet contexts.” Tenzer (2024) [4.3] “Gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet are the names for different kinds of gong-cycle forms in dance pieces of the gamelan palegongan repertoire.” Tenzer (2024) [4.4]

orchestration.text: Source: “Carrillo wrote his first music theory treatises in the 1910s, which were pedagogical and mostly staid, devoted to subjects Jadassohn had written about such as canon and fugue, orchestration, and harmony.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.2] Definition: “The term ‘orchestration’ is often used to denote the craft of writing idiomatically for these instruments. ‘To orchestrate’ has also come to mean to score for orchestra a work written for a solo instrument or small ensemble.” (Grove Music Online, “Instrumentation and orchestration”)

\u97f3 oto.text: Japanese A: “核音の周辺の音は、結局核音からあまり簡単に飛躍しないところから見ると、この核音に従属する性質を持つと思える。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 6] English A: “When we see that the notes around a nuclear tone do not easily leap from the nuclear tone, we can hypothesize that their nature is subordinate to the nuclear tone.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3] Japanese B: “それは仏教的な哲学です。全くの無から何かの音が生まれるんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 56-57] English B: “From a complete void, some tones emerge. It is by coincidence.” Park (2024) [4.2] Japanese C: “流 れ る 線 の 中 に 重 要 な ⾳ が あ り 、 そ れを 囲 む ⾳ す べ て が 「 主 要 ⾳ 」 だ” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English C: “Within a flowing line [流れる線], there is one important tone [音]. With this tone in the center, I call all sounds that surround it Hauptton [主要音].” (Park (2024) [1])

\u0434\u0435\u043a\u043b\u0430\u043c\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “В безмензурните ни песни някои слогове са твърде много протегнати и правят декламацията неестествена. Друг съществен белег на тия песни са непрекъснатите сложни фиоритури (рулади).” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “In our unmeasured songs some syllables are quite elongated, making the declamation unnatural. Another essential characteristic of these songs is the continuous use of complex fiorituri (roulades).” Goldberg (2024) [4.1]

pitch class.text: Source: “In the marginalia shown in Example 9 [Insert Example 9 here], Carrillo examined Schoenberg’s Wind Quintet in terms of its tone row, re-notating three row permutations and identifying their pitch classes. Carrillo further observed, in two marginal comments, how these row permutations segregated even- from odd-numbered pitch classes, and thus WT0 from WT1. He used his observation to contrast Schoenberg’s compositional theory with his own.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.9] Definition: “The type of a pitch. Pitches belong to the same class if they have some relation – for example, the octave relation – of compositional or analytical interest. This relation is called an ‘equivalence’ because, in the context of a particular description of musical structure, pitches in the same class are interchangeable, or equivalent.” (Grove Music Online, “pitch class”)

\u043d\u043e\u0432\u0430 \u043c\u0443\u0.text: Bulgarian A: “В нашите основни училища се присажда чужда за българина, нова, негрееща неговото сърце музика.” Hristov (1925) (p. 35) English A: “New music is transplanted into our primary schools, music that is foreign to the Bulgarian and does not warm his heart.” Goldberg (2024) [2.8]

\u30aa\u30af\u30bf okut\u0101vu.text: Japanese A: “これは笛であるため、音程の跳躍がはなはだしいが、それを筝曲のばあいのように、オクターヴを同音と考えて見ると、案外旋律的な動きとなる.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 14] English A: “Because this melody is for a flute, the intervallic leaps are extreme, but as in the case with koto music, if you think of octaves as equivalent, its movement becomes surprisingly conjunct.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [9.2]

ontology.text: Source: “In brief, Li put forth a mystic ontology of Music, proposing that Music is a medium through which artists can create, access, and conquer an amorphous spiritual world, a world he called the “upper realm.” It is through the upper realm, he suggested, that souls can speak to one another. Romantic as it was, Li’s work staged an ontological intervention of Music, seeking to dismiss Ritual as the long-standing Confucian ontological core of Music in China.” Li (2024) [0.2] Definition: “Ontology is the study of the manner, matter and form in which things exist; so the ontologist might ask: what kind of thing is a musical sound or a musical work?” (Grove Music Online, “Philosophy of music”)

\u0434\u0430\u043a\u0442\u0438\u043b\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: dactylic rhythm, “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6]

\u30b3\u30f3\u30d4 \u30e5\u30fc\u30bf\u9.text: Japanese A: “しか し新し いメディアの音楽、たとえばコン ピュータ音楽、そういった創作では演奏 家とのつながりがないと思うのですが、 そういうことに関して、先生のご意見は ございませんか。簡単にいえば、コンピ ュータ音楽はどう思われますか。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 61] English A: “But compositions in new media, for example, computer music, do not have much relationship with the performers. What do you think about this aspect? In short, what do you think about computer music?” Park (2024) [7.2] Japanese B: “狭義には作曲、音響合成，演奏などの過程でコンピュータを用いた音楽の総称をいう。広義には音楽と情報処理にかかわる研究（音楽分析，音楽認知，インターフェイス研究など) や専用プログラム開発の研究までを含む。” (Tomosha (2002), 254)

ton/tom/to\u1e43.text: Sinhalese A: “tat-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? jit-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? ton-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? nam-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki?” Peiris (2024) [9] English A: “Unto whom is the syllable tat a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable jit a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable ton a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable nam a salutation?” Peiris (2024) [9] English A: “These four strokes (and associated timbres) are termed “seed syllables” (bīja akṣara) and they are named as follows: tat—a damped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 8; see also Video 4), dit (or dik or jit)—a damped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 9; see also Video 5), ton (or tom or toṃ)—an undamped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 10; see also Video 6), and nam (or naṃ)—an undamped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 11; see also Video 7).” (Peiris (2024) [4.1]) English B: mnemonic syllable for a drum stroke (Peiris (2025))

actions.text: Source: Tenzer (2024) Ex. 2 Lexical fields Definition: “Something done or performed, a deed, an act; (in plural) habitual or ordinary deeds, conduct.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “action” I.2)

\ubb34 mu.text: Korean A: ““이 곡은 무(無)에서 태어나서 무로 끝나지요. 그건 불교적인 철학입니다…” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 155] English A: “This piece is born within nothingness [無] and ends as nothingness. That is the Buddhist philosophy.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u793c\u4e50 l\u01d0 yu\u00e8.text: Chinese A: “周代以乐从属于礼的思想和制度。 先秦儒家以为制礼作乐始于周公。据东周的有关记载,大体上可信这是来自周初统治者借鉴胶礼,有所损益,因而形成的。礼乐思想的核心是区别君臣、父子、上下、亲疏、尊卑的规范。这种规范体现为对于一切礼仪和音乐 活动所规定的制度。作为音乐的制度,包括乐县、舞列、用乐等,都有等级森严的规定,都 是不许僭越的。这些规定,一方面贯彻在由 *大司乐进行的国子教育之中,一方面体现于祭祀、燕京等日常的*雅乐活动中。” Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (p. 225–26) Chinese B: “高诱注：“禮所以經國家，定社稷，利人民；樂所以移風易俗，蕩人之邪，存人之正性。”” Hanyu dacidian  (礼乐) Chinese C: “中国古代儒家的政治、伦理范畴。[…] 周代把礼乐作为学校教育的重要内容,列为“六艺”之首。孔子特别强调礼乐,认为“礼乐不兴,则刑罚不中”。他根据周代的制度,也把礼乐并列为重要的教育内容。” Lunli xue (1989) (p. 280-281) English: “The Confucian classic Yueji 樂記 (Book of Music), for instance, reads: “揖讓而治天下者，禮樂之謂也。” (The governance of all under Heaven through deference is what is meant by Ritual and Music.) I adopted Scott Cook’s translation here, from Cook 1995, 43.” Li (2024) (See also: Cook (1995))

trompong.text: English A: “Geria’s examples all apply to the trompong, an instrument forefronted in prestigious court gamelan—the palegongan, semar pagulingan, and the gong gdé. I show both the kepatihan (cipher notation) provided and my own modified 3-line staff for the trompong and, when needed, a single-line staff for jegogan. Geria notated his examples on particular pitches in a five-tone pélog, conventionally numbered 1,2,3,5, and 6. But they could be played at any transposition.” Tenzer (2024)  [3.1] English B: “Here Geria names musical instruments trompong (row of tuned gongs played by a single musician)” (Tenzer (2024) [2.1]) Balinese C: “Iti haraning Gagebug.Yaning gagebug gong, Kaget atangi ngaran Bhuhloka nada ngaran. Yaning gagebug trompong Sekar Tanjungsusun nga-ran, denya angembat silih asih. Ikang gagebug babarangan Sad-pada angaras santun ngaran, mwang babancangan, Tadah rasmi araning swara. Ikang gagebug rariyongan I Gajahmina ngaran.Ikang gagebug giying, Tuntun Rasmi ngaran. Ikang gagebug pemade mwang kantil, I Talutur mwang sadulur ngaran. Ikang gagebug gender rambat Ekatanu mwang aninglas ngaran.” (Bandem (1986), 68) Balinese D: “instrumen yg berupa deretan gong-gong kecil, terdiri atas sepuluh sampai empat belas buah gong, dimainkan oleh dua orang” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 173-174, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\u043c\u0435\u0440\u043a\u0438/myerki.text: See also мярка/myarka  Bulgarian A: “Елементите в горните тактове може да отбележим и с два пъти по-голяма стойност (1/8) ; ще имаме в такъв случай същите тактове (мерки), означени с осмини дроби.” Hristov (1925) (p. 38) English A: “We can also notate the elements in the above meters with doubled note values (eighth notes); in such a case we will have the same meters (time signatures) represented with eighth-note subdivisions.” Goldberg (2024) [3.3]

emotion.text: Source: Tenzer (2024) Ex. 2 Lexical fields Definition: “Originally: an agitation of mind; an excited mental state. Subsequently: any strong mental or instinctive feeling, as pleasure, grief, hope, fear, etc., deriving esp. from one's circumstances, mood, or relationship with others.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “emotion” 3a)

\ube44\ube0c\ub77c\ud1a0 bibeurato.text: Korean A: “자아, 장식음입니다. 장식음으로부터 시작해서 점점 흔들림이 커지고 경우에 따라서는 비브라토가 4도까지 갑니다. 시작되는 음에 힘을 집중하기 위해서 장식음이 있는 것으로 그 자체에 의미는 없습니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “Now, it is a decorative tone. Beginning from the decorative tone, the trembling grows larger and, at times, the vibrato gets as wide as a fourth. The decorative tone exists to concentrate on the tone’s beginning, and it is meaningless by itself.” Park (2024) [4.1]

performance.text: English A: “In music of the classical-romantic European tradition, the articulation of the phrase can be inferred from the written score, at least in its most obvious aspects, such as duration, metric placement, harmonic rhythm, cadences, melodic direction, and so on. However, much of the musical meaning only emerges during the moment of performance. In performance, and especially in the case of popular song, singers use their interpretative skills to articulate and highlight the emotional content of each song.” (Stover (2024) [5.11]) Portuguese A: “Na música de tradição européia clássico-romântica, a articulação da frase pode ser inferida na partitura escrita, pelo menos nos seus aspectos mais óbvios, como duração, colocação métrica, ritmo harmônico, cadências, direção melódica, etc. Entretanto, muito do significado musical só emerge durante o momento da performance. Na performance, e, principalmente no caso da canção popular, cantores usam sua habilidade interpretativa para articular e salientar o conteúdo emocional de cada canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u7ba1\u5f26\u697d\u66f2 kangengakkyoku.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) See also: 管弦 kangen

\uc591 yang.text: Korean A: “'하우프트톤'은 둘이 있는 경우도 많아요. 둘이 있으면 그것은 음양 관계를 갖지요. 예컨대 동(動)과 정(静)의 관계이기도 합니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1] Korean B: “태극(太極)이 나누인 두 가지 기운(氣運) 중 하나. 「악서」에 "선왕(先王)이 관(管)을 만든 것은 그것이 음(陰)과 양의 소리를 다 통달하기 때문이다"라고 하였다.” Song (2010) [p. 214]

\u043f\u0440\u0435\u0434\u043b\u043e\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Типична е следната песен с пайдушки такт с пет тактови предложения.” Hristov (1925) [p. 43] English A: “The following song with a paidushka meter [Example 3] is typical, with five-measure sentences [predlozheniya].” Goldberg (2024) [5.4] English: “In a survey of European rhythmic theory, Hristov ([1931] 1967, 180) indicates that Czech composer and theorist Karel Jirák defines a predlozhenie as an element of form composed of two or more two- or three-measure units.” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 21]

\ubc18\uc74c baneum.text:
반 + 음 eum  반: half 
 Korean A: “백대웅의 판소리 평조길은 계이름으로 설명하면 "레, 미, 솔, 라, 도"의 5음으로, "솔, 라, 도 레, 미"의 우조길과 구분된다. 각 음의 기능과 특징 설명에서, 상청을 '오선보에서 우조와 구별 되는 음으로 우조의 상청보다 반음(단2도) 높다'” Shin (2018) [p. 240] English A: “Baek distinguishes between the re, mi, sol, la, and do of Pyeongjo-gil and the sol, la, do, re, and mi of Ujo-gil. In his description of the functions and features of each pitch, Baek claims that sangcheong [in Pyeongjo] “is a different note from the one in Ujo on the staff, and is a half step (minor 2nd) higher than sangcheong in Ujo" (Baek 1982, 1995, 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.10]

folktales.text: Source: “Ezegbe also notes that there are folktales that warn against “over-indulg[ing] in playing ubọ-aka or other related instruments such as oja (flute), ụbọ-akwara (seven string harp) which are believed to possess the power of attracting spirits” (46).” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.4]

Shin (2018).text: Shin, Eun-joo. 2018. “Two Theories of Ujo and Pyeongjo in Pansori: Comparing Baek Daewoong’s and Lee Bohyeong’s Theories of Pansori Modes.”

rhythmic pattern.text: Source A: “The artistic act of a singer interpreting and directing a story through sound is not an undirected improvisation, but—as in music composition—is carried out within a framework of three musical elements: tone color, mode, and rhythmic pattern.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Source B: “As shown in Example 1, he paired many of these quatrains with stanzas of mostly non-lexical vocables, which model rhythm patterns that are to be played on a drum.” (Peiris (2024) [1,1])

b\u012bja ak\u1e63ara.text: English A: “These four strokes (and associated timbres) are termed “seed syllables” (bīja akṣara) and they are named as follows: tat—a damped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 8; see also Video 4), dit (or dik or jit)—a damped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 9; see also Video 5), ton (or tom or toṃ)—an undamped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 10; see also Video 6), and nam (or naṃ)—an undamped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 11; see also Video 7).” (Peiris (2024) [4.1])

\u97f3\u968e\u6cd5 onkaih\u014d.text: 音階 onkai+法 法: law, rule Japanese A: “このどちらもが、日本の音階と旋律法のヨーロッパとの違いはもちろん、アジア音楽の中での、特異性をきわめて明確に規定する要素なのであるが、ここではまず前者について考えて見よう。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] English A: “For both of these, the differences between Japanese musical [scalar] rules and those of Europe are of course the elements make Asian music seem so extremely peculiar.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1, brackets added separately]

Jianming yinyue (1985).text: Jianming yinyue cidian 志敏,国华编. Zhi Min, Guo Hua (eds.). Haerbin: Heilongjiang renmin chuban she 简明音乐辞典.哈尔滨:黑龙江人民出版社, 1985.

\ud53c\uc544\ub178 piano.text: Korean A: “피아노도 없고 책상도 없고, 연필과 종이만 있었어 요. 그리고 텍스트, 내가 그런 상태에서도 음표를 적지 않을 수 없었던 것은, 내가 죽어버리면 내 속에 남아 있는 음악도 나와 함께 죽어버린다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 161] English A: “No piano, no desk, only pencil and paper. And the text. The reason why I could not stop writing the notes even in that situation was that if I die then and there, the music in me also dies.” Park (2024) [6.3]

mystic.text: Source: “Rather than perpetuate the state’s instrumentalization of Music as a (bio-)political force regulated by Ritual, Li proposed a spiritual universality of Music that retools Daoist mysticism through European Expressionist thought (see, for example, Li 1930/1933, 55), yet does not submit Music to dao as the highest spiritual goal (Li 1930/1933, 3). Li’s fascination with the superposition of the mystic and artificial nature of the upper realm characterizes his music theory. This fascination also fuels the many rhetorical tautologies and paradoxes that thrive in the textual imagination it affords.” Li (2024) [0.2] Definition: “Relating to or dealing with spiritual or transcendental matters; relating to mystics or mysticism” (Oxford English Dictionary, “mystic”)

Modificaciones mel\u00f3dicas.text: Spanish A: “No conozco ningún ejemplo en el cual se hayan operado modificaciones melódicas, armónicas y rítmicas, sin alterar los modelos, y con mi “Ley de metamorfosis” pueden efectuarse cambios en la melodía, en la armonía y el ritmo, sin agregar ni suprimir ni una sola nota.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] English A: “I do not know any example in which melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic modifications have been used without altering the models. With my “Law of Metamorphosis,” changes in melody, harmony, and rhythm can be carried out without adding or removing a single note.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20]

\uc74c eum.text: Korean A: “'하우프트톤'은 둘이 있는 경우도 많아요. 둘이 있으면 그것은 음양 관계를 갖지요. 예컨대 동(動)과 정(静)의 관계이기도 합니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1] Korean B: “태극(太極)이 나누인 두 가지 기운(氣)의 하나. 『악서』에 "선왕(先王)이 관(管)을 만 든 것은 그것이 음(陰)과 양(陽)의 소리를 다 통달하기 때문이다"라고 하였다.” Song (2010) [p. 265]

\ud615\ud0dc hyeongtae.text: Korean A: “1975년 장사훈과 한만영이 발간한 『국악개론』에서 판소리 우조에 대해 가곡의 우조나 3음 음계 계면조와 같이 정악 스타일을 판소리에 도입한 것이라 하며, 평조에 대해서는 우조와 조성 의 차이가 아니라 창법과 선을 형태의 차이로 설명하고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 236] English A: “Chang and Han 1975 claim that pansori’s Ujo incorporates jeongak styles, similar to gagok’s Ujo or the three-note scale, Gyemyeonjo. They specify that pansori’s Pyeongjo is distinguished from Ujo by its vocal style and melodic structure [form], rather than tonality.” Kim (2024) [2.2, brackets added separately]

\u58f0\u97f5 sh\u0113ngy\u00f9n.text: Chinese A: “因為在包辦音樂的文人看來，音樂是應該受聲韻的支配，祇要那些詞句是和聲韻沒有違背，自可以依照同一樣受聲韻支配的音樂把他唱出來.” Li (2024) [1.5] English A: Tone pattern; “For the monopolizing literati understood that Music was governed by tone patterns. As long as the words and tone patterns harmonized, they could be sung with the same melody.” Li (2024) [1.5] Chinese B: “指乐调。指诗文的韵律. 指文词声律和文字音韵学上的声、韵、调等。借指诗歌或其他韵文。指说话或呼喊的声调。泛指和谐动听的声音。” Hanyu dacidian  (声韵, 1–6)

gending.text: English: “Geria’s cipher notation is given, as well as modified staff notation using two two-line staves with the ubit-ubitan above and the slower moving gending line below. On the ubit-ubitan staff the stems-down part is known as polos (basic). The stems-up part is the sangsih (different or complementary). As most Balinese music has an end-accented character, the staff notation places the beginning of a four-note group apart and unbeamed at the end of each pattern. The three tones that complete it on repeat are shown at the beginning.” Tenzer (2024) [4.2] “Gending has many meanings, including “composition” or “piece” or even “form”; here it refers to the slower-moving structural melodic lines that most Balinese would call pokok or bantan.” Tenzer (2024) [Footnote 8] English B: (Bandem (1986), 60) Balinese A: “Secara harfiah kata "tabuh" artinya logat, atau aturan ting- kah laku dan pelaksanaannya. Tabuh juga diberi arti sebagai lagu, gending, nyanyian atau pupuh (alinea : 35). Dewasa ini bagi ma- syarakat Bali, istilah tabuh diinterpretasikan sebagai or kestrasi (ke- indahan lagu) dan struktur atau komposisi lagu.” Bandem (1986) [p. 20]

level tone.text: Source: “Kirby’s observations about contour tones are consistent with a recent article comparing two unrelated ethnolinguistic cultures, Cantonese and Yoruba (West Africa), co-authored by myself, Edwin Li, and David Aina. We found many commonalities in text setting between the popular music of the two cultures. Moreover, we argue that a prevalence of level tones and their compatibility with global trends in music production may explain the similarity between the two disparate cultures (Li, Carter-Ényì and Aina 2024).” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [4]

\u043e\u0440\u0438\u0433\u0438\u043d\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “но корав народ с колкото славна, толкова и печална история, кален от векове сред бури и неволи, пази като съкровища, унаследени от векове, предавани от поколение на поколение, множество самобитни, безизкуствени творби на невидимото тоново изкуство музиката, която със своите оригинални метрични, ритмични и тонални особености е не по-малко интересна от новооткритите египетски археологически паметници.”” Hristov (1925) (p. 33) English A: “This small but tough nation with such a glorious and sorrowful history, tempered by centuries among storms and woes, guards like treasures, inherited for centuries, handed down from generation to generation, a multitude of self-originating, artless works of the invisible tonal art of music, which with its original metric, rhythmic, and tonal characteristics is no less interesting than the newly discovered Egyptian archaeological monuments.” Goldberg (2024) [2.1]

\ud310\uc18c\ub9ac pansori.text: English A: “Pansori 판소리 and sanjo 산조 are small-ensemble genres of Korean folk music with many shared characteristics.(1) Pansori consists of a dramatic narrative performance by a sorikkun 소리꾼, a vocalist-narrator, and a gosu 고수, a drummer who provides rhythmic accompaniment on a barrel drum called a puk 북.” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) Korean B: “한국음악학에서 판소리 악조에 대한 논의는 오랜 기간 여러 학자들에 의해 시도되었다. 그러 나 여전히 공통의 합의가 이루어지지 못하고, 여러 다른 악조론으로 음악을 분석하고 있다. 그 중 가장 대표적인 판소리 악조론은 백대웅과 이보형의 이론으로, 계면조에 대해서는 이견이 없 으나, 이들의 서로 다른 우조와 평조에 대한 해석이 후속 학자들에 의해 활용되고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 234] English B: “Although Korean musicologists have long debated the melodic modes in pansori, there is a lack of consensus regarding the identification of the pansori modes, which they have attempted to define based on different modal theories. The theories of Baek Daewoong (1974–2011) and Lee Bohyeong (b. 1937) are the representative views of pansori scales. While Baek and Lee concur on the criteria for Gyemyeonjo, they diverge on the modes for Ujo and Pyeongjo.” Kim (2024) [1.1] English C: a narrative musical form unique to Korea (Pyǒn (2012) 124)Korean C: 한 사람의 창자매가 고수동의 장단에 맞추어 긴 서사적인 이야기를 소리와 아니리로 엮어 발림(너름새)을 곁들이며 구연하 는 성악곡. 현재 '적벽가', 심청가', '춘향가', 홍부가, 수가 등 다섯 마당이 전해진다. (Pyǒn (2012) 124)

Maozedong wenyi (1993).text: Maozedong wenyi sixiang da cidian 毛泽东文艺思想大辞典. Feng Guimin 冯贵民, Gao Jinhua 高金华 (eds.), Xue Chunhua 薛纯华, Wu Guangzheng 吴光正, Wang Wensheng 王文生 (co-eds.). Wuhan: Wuhan chuban she 武汉:武汉出版社, 1993.

\u58f0\u697d\u304c\u00a0koe raku ga.text: Japanese A: “う で す 。 厳 格 な 雅 楽 の ⾳ 楽 の 組 み ⽅ と 、 哲 学 的 な 内 容 と 、 そ れ か ら 流 暢 に 流 れ る 線 的 な 美 し さ を 、 た と え ば 南 道 唱 と か 歌 曲 と い っ た 形 式 の ⼀ 連 の 声 楽 が あ り ま す が 、 そ う い う と こ ろ か ら た く さ ん 学 び ま し た 。 そ こ に 、 今 度 は 線 的 な 動 き ⽅ の ⾳ 楽 的 な 理 論 を ⼤ 系 づ け ま し た.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: “Yes. I learned a lot from A-ak’s strict organization and philosophical content, and vocal music’s smoothly flowing linear beauty, such as Namdo Chang and Gagok [가곡], or other vocal genres.Based on these, I organized my own musical theory of linear motion." (Park (2024) [1.4])

Escala diat\u00f3nica mayor.text: Spanish A: “Con lo visto será bastante para comprender que, como en la llamada escala diatónica mayor, hay del primer grado al segundo un tono; al metamorfosearse al duplo, habrá dos; y como del segundo grado al tercero de la escala diatónica hay también un tono, con la metamorfosis al duplo habrá del segundo grado al tercero dos tonos; del tercero al cuarto grados hay un semitono, y es evidente que al metamorfosearse al duplo habrá del tercer grado al cuarto un tono en vez de un semitono, etc.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22] English A: “This suffices to show how in the so-called diatonic major scale, there is a whole tone between the first and second scale degrees, which, when metamorphosed to the double, becomes two whole tones; how between the second and third degrees of the diatonic scale, a whole tone becomes two whole tones; how between the third and fourth degrees, a semitone becomes a whole tone; etc.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22] See also: Diatónico  Spanish B: “Según el sabio Monsier H. Helmholtz, las transformaciones de los antiguos modos provienen de la escala diatónica de siete sonidos, propuesta é inventada por Pitágoras en la extensión completa de una octavo.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 136, see also p. 158]

\u54e5\u6ca2 utazawa.text: Japanese A: “まず童唄、民謡の類は、すでにわれわれの出発点であった。長唄については上に述べた通り、この核音の支配が顕著にあらわれているが、譜２７は哥沢の例で、hとeとに現われた核音は、明瞭に旋律構造の骨格をなしている。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 8] English A: “First, our points of departure were children’s songs and folk songs. As I have said above about nagauta, nuclear tones strikingly control the melodies, but example 27 (Example 4) is an example of utazawa, and the pitches B and E clearly make up the skeleton of the melody’s construction as its nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [5.2] “Utazawa 歌沢 is a late-Edo-period song genre derived from the earlier hauta 端唄 genre. Both are genres of song accompanied by shamisen, the differences inhering mostly in performance style and affective subtleties.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 12] Japanese B: “芝派のうたざわを特に寅派の歌沢と区別して“かざ わ”と呼ぶ人があるが、この称呼は一般には用いられず、哥沢もやは り“うたざわ”と訓むのが普通である.” Tanabe (1975) [p. 35] English C: “Slow-paced style of shamisen music with vocal accompaniment (popular during the late Edo period)” (Japan Dict, https://www.japandict.com/うた沢#entry-1607470)

\u6bd4\u8f03\u97f3\u697d\u5b66 hikaku on.text: 比較: comparative 音楽学 ongakugaku musicology Japanese A: “核音の比較音楽学的意味については第４節でのべるが、西洋音楽一般についてはこれにあたるものを見ない。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 5] English A: “I will discuss the meanings of nuclear tones in comparative musicology in section 4, but in Western music, we do not generally see things like this.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3]

harmonia.text: English A: “In the Brazilian conception of song, the melody is the starting point for the composition, with the rhythmic and harmonic accompaniment acting as elements of melodic support. Harmony, in this conception, expands the expressive possibilities of melodic singing, with the accompanying instruments able to create other melodies in counterpoint to the main melody, responding to or opposing it.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “Na concepção brasileira da canção, a melodia é o ponto de partida para a composição, sendo o acompanhamento rítmico e harmônico elementos de suporte melódico. A harmonia, nesta concepção, amplia as possibilidades expressivas do canto melódico podendo os instrumentos acompanhantes criar outras melodias em contraponto à melodia principal, respondendo ou contrapondo-se a ela.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Estudo da combinação de notas soando simultancamente (acorde) e de seu encadcamento.É a ciência do acorde com suas características intrínsecas, dentro de uma perspectiva vertical, e das relaçoes que estabelecem entre si, dentro de uma perspectiva horizontal.Na música ocidental, a harmonia nasce com os intervalos de 4as, Sas e 8as paralelas sobrepostos ao cantochão (séc. X), nas experiências do órgano, discante e falsobordão, que na sua evolução desencadcaram o surgimento do tonalismo (meados do séc. XVI). A harmonia tonal, ou tonalismo, perdura cerca de três séculos, durante os quais passa por constantes evoluções.” (Andrade (1989), 254) Portuguese C: “Combinação de vários sons diferentes, ouvidos simultâneamente e formando acordes. Ciência dos acordes.” (Cosme (1957), 58)

bramana ngisep sari.text: English A: “Gerantang joged bumbung style is called bramana ngisep sari; its sound is pangirik.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.14]) See gerantang  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang gagebug gerantang joged bumbung, bramara ngisep sari. Pangirik nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Gerantang joged bumbung refers to an ensemble of gerantang accompanying ngibing, a flirtation dance. Bramana ngisep sari means “beetle sips flower essence”; pangirik is a tickling sensation. The juxtaposed and somewhat incongruous imagery of beetle, flower, and tickling cunningly reveals the potential of ngibing, which in yesteryear led to more than flirtation.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.13]) *Lexical field: Natural world (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

composi\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “In the Brazilian conception of song, the melody is the starting point for the composition, with the rhythmic and harmonic accompaniment acting as elements of melodic support. Harmony, in this conception, expands the expressive possibilities of melodic singing, with the accompanying instruments able to create other melodies in counterpoint to the main melody, responding to or opposing it.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “Na concepção brasileira da canção, a melodia é o ponto de partida para a composição, sendo o acompanhamento rítmico e harmônico elementos de suporte melódico. A harmonia, nesta concepção, amplia as possibilidades expressivas do canto melódico podendo os instrumentos acompanhantes criar outras melodias em contraponto à melodia principal, respondendo ou contrapondo-se a ela.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc791\uace1\uc758 \uc7ac\ub8cc jaggog-u.text: 작곡 jaggog composer 재료: material Korean A: “"일본의 작곡가들은 종래 작곡의 재료(Material)는 현대적 일지라도 어쩐지 낡은 서양의 전통적인 형식관에 따르고 있는 게 아닐까요. " (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "Perhaps Japanese composers follow the old Western traditional formalism even though the compositional materials [マテリアル] might be modern." (Park (2024) [2.3])

\ud718\ubaa8\ub9ac hwimori.text: Korean A: “자진모리伽倻琴散調는 대개 진양조, 중모리, 중중모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리 6樂章으로 되어 있고, 一般 的으로 羽調, 界面調, 平調를 使用하고 있다.” (Shin (2018) , 248) English A: “It presents four or more rhythmic patterns 장단 (jangdan) in “ascending orders of metrical speed” (Provine, Hwang, and Howard 2001)—from slow tempo (e.g., jinyang 진양) to fast rhythmic cycles (e.g., hwimori 휘모리)—demonstrating the performer’s technical proficiency and expressive abilities.” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) English B: a jangdan of fast tempo (Pyǒn (2012) 163)Korean B: 판소리나 산조, 민요 등에 사용되는 장단의 하나. 회오리 바람처 럼 휘몰아치는 빠른 속도라는 뜻을 가지고 있으며, 휘몰이라고 하기도 한다. 판소리, 농악에서는 단모리(2소박 4박 장단)를 가리키 는 말이나, 산조에서는 3소박 4박 정단을 휘몰아치는 장단을 의 미하기도 한다. (Pyǒn (2012) 163)
