ragtime.text: Source: “This rhythm has elsewhere been identified with ragtime music; the term “primary rag” has been used both for this specific pattern and for rhythmic displacements more generally, in contrast to “secondary rag,” a dissonance of triple groupings (Knowlton 1926, 581; discussed more fully in Berlin 1980, 128–134).” Biamonte commentary (2024) [5] Definition: “A style of popular music that flourished from the mid-1890s to 1918. Its main identifying trait is its ragged—i.e., syncopated—rhythm. While today it is most commonly thought of as a piano style, during the ragtime period the term also referred to other instrumental music, to vocal music, and to dance.” (Grove Music Online, “ragtime”)

\ud53c\uce58\uce74\ud1a0 pichikato.text: Korean A: “그에 대해서는 콘트라베이스의 네 개의 피치카토가 준비됩니 다. 그러므로 어디가 준비인가, 어디가 진짜 음인가 하는 것도 늘 상대적인 것입니다. 그리고 이 첫머리에서는 D음이 '하우프트톤' 인 것입이다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “About this tone [Bb], the four pizzicati by the contrabass prepares it. Therefore, it is all relative when it comes to determining what is a tone and what prepares the tone. And in this opening, the D tone is a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u0441\u0438\u0442\u043d\u043e \u0445\u0.text: Bulgarian A: “Най-малкият възможен такт от тези видове се образува от две обикновени тактови части  който, удвоен, дава обикновен ⅘ или ¾ правилен такт, основа на обикновено ситно хоро.” Hristov (1925) [p. 41] English A: “The smallest possible meter of these types [4/16 = 2/8] is formed by two ordinary metric parts, which, doubled, produces an ordinary 4/8 or 2/4 regular meter, the basis for the ordinary sitno horo.” Goldberg (2024) [5.1] See also: хоро/horo

Yun (1991) - Korean.text: Yun, Isang, and Akira Nishimura. 1991. “무한한 우주의 한 끝에서 [At One End of the Endless Universe].” Translated from Japanese to Korean by Jeongbok Seo. In 윤이상의 음악세계 [Musical World of Isang Yun], ed. Seongman Choe and Eunmi Hong. Hangil Sa. Originally published as “無限の宇宙の一端から.” 音楽芸術 [Musical Arts] 42 (1984): 50–61.

\u8840 chi.text: Japanese A: “機械を幾ら使っても、 機械から出る音楽は機械がつくるんです から、そこには血が流れないんです。こ れは大原則として、音楽には人間の血と 精神が通じてなければならない。究極は 人間の血と精神だと思います、純粋な考 え方をすれば。ぼくが亡びても、人間の血と精神はともに残るでしょう。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 61] English A: “No matter how much a machine can do, the music coming from the machine is made by the machine. No blood flows through the music. This is a fundamental principle. Music must channel human blood and spirit. Ultimately, I think music is human blood and spirit. To speak naively, a person’s blood and spirit will remain even after my death.” Park (2024) [7.2]

Octavos de tono.text: Spanish A: “He aquí esta obra escrita originalmente en cuartos, octavos y dieciséisavos de tono, para los solistas.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p.27] English A: “Here is that work, written originally in quarter tones, eighth tones, and sixteenth tones for the soloists.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p.27]

hemiola.text: English A: “The last B articulates a hemiola on the final syllable of “cres-cer” and “A ro-sa,” at first with simultaneous attacks and then almost like an echo of “rosa.” Finally, the drums play a fill, before gradually returning to the metrical regularity of the accompaniment.” (Stover (2024) [5.6]) Portuguese A: “ O último articula uma hemiola abaixo da sílaba final de "cres-cer" e "A ro-sa", a princípio com ataques simultâneos e depois quase como um eco de rosa. Finalmente, a bateria toca uma virada, antes de gradualmente retornar a uma certa regularidade métrica do acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc870 jo.text: English A: “Ujo and Pyeongjo are two jos 조 (modes) commonly used in pansori. The complexity of pansori modal theory is largely due to two features of the jo, particularly Ujo and Pyeongjo, in Korean folk music. First, a jo is not merely a collection of notes but involves a certain effect produced by each; for instance, Ujo is often described as “majestic” and “benevolent,” while Pyeongjo is less so. Second, certain notes of a given jo frequently incorporate ornamentations, such as vibrato, glissando, and slide, which play a crucial role in constructing the mood of the jo.” (Kim (2024) [0.2]) Korean B: 음악의 선법, 조명소, 가락, 풍씨, 속도 등을 나타내는 말. 첫 째, 선법을 나타내는 경우에는 평조와 계면조대해 2가지가 있다. 둘째, 조명을 나타내는 경우에는 조선전기에 사용된 일지-(협종, 고선), 이지-₩(중려, 유빈), 삼지=(임종), 황지#(이치, 남려), 우조7(무역, 웅종), 팔조기(청황종), 막조3호(청대려, 청태주) 등의 7개 조가 있고, 현재 사용되는 황종, 태주, 임종, 남려 등의 조가 있다. 셋째, 가락의 의미로 쓰이는 경우로는 김선조쇼, 풍입송조 소, 만전춘조봤해 등이 있다. 넷째, 풍으로 쓰이 는 경우로는 타령조, 염불조, 드렁조, 메나리조, 육자배기조 등이 있다. 다섯째, 속도로 쓰이는 경우로는 느린 속도의 만조해, 보 통 속도의 평조, 빠른 속도의 삭조해 등이 있다. (Pyǒn (2012) 78-79) English B: means following mode, key, melody, tempo, style, etc. of music (Pyǒn (2012) 78)

Kru\u0306stev (1967).text: Krŭstev, Venelin, and Institut za muzikoznanie. 1967. “Entsiklopedii︠a︡ Na bŭlgarskata Muzikalna Kultura.” Sofii︠a︡: Izd-vo na Bŭlgarskata akademii︠a︡ na naukite.

Proporciones.text: Spanish A: “Si dentro de la moderna mentalidad quisiéramos encontrar un sinónimo para estas “Leyes de metamorfosis”, paréceme que nada sería tan a propósito como llamarlas “Leyes de relaciones y proporciones,” pues efectivamente descansan sobre las relaciones y proporciones de los intervalos, tanto en su parte melódica como en la armónica.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22] English A: “If we wanted to find a synonym for these “Laws of Metamorphosis” from a modern point of view, I think nothing would be more appropriate than “Laws of Relations and Proportions.” Ultimately, these laws rest on intervallic relations and proportions in both their melodic and harmonic aspects.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22] Spanish B: “Las proporciones numéricas aplicadas a la música para explicar la relación de los sonidos y sus combinaciones en duración, estuvieron por mucho tiempo en uso entre los antiguos.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 379] Spanish C: “Las númericas aplicábanlas á la músicas los antiguos para explicar la relación de los sonidos y sus combinaciones de duración. Así, por medio de razones aritméticas, explicaban la calidad de un acorde y las distancias. La proporción dupla 2/1 y la subsesquialtera 2/3 indicaban la medida imperfecta; la 1ª. para la breve, y la 2ª. para la semibreve, y, al contrario, la tripla 3/1 y la sesquialtera 3/2 designaban la medida perfecta para la misma clase de notas. La proporción hemiolia tenía gran importancia.” Lacál (1900) [p. 423]

musical metamorphosis.text: Metamórfosis (Spanish) Source: “Although Carillo’s theory of musical metamorphosis shared elements with those of early twentieth-century theorists such as Arnold Schoenberg, it embraced far different goals and procedures, all of which make it a fascinating case study in global modernism.” Bauer commentary (2024) [1.1] Definition: “A complete change in the appearance, circumstances, condition, or character of a person, a state of affairs, etc.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “metamorphosis”)

Menezes (2024).text: Menezes, Enrique V. 2024. “The Origins of Syncopation in Brazilian Music: An Unpublished Manuscript by Mário de Andrade.” Music Theory Online, 30, no. 4.

\ucc44\ubcf4 chaebo.text: Korean A: “이들은 판소리를 가장 많이 채보 하고 분석한 대표적인 두 학자로, 이들이 설명하고 있는 판소리 자조와 평조에 대한 특징들의 연결점을 찾고, 차이점에서 발견되는 문제를 지적하는 데에서부터 의견의 합일점을 찾을 수 있 을 것이라 생각되기 때문이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 237] English A: “The text describing Baek’s pansori theory was published in 1982. Since then, extensive work has been done on transcription utilizing staff notation and analysis of pansori.” Kim (2024) [2.5]

\uace0\uc218 gosu.text: English A: “Pansori 판소리 and sanjo 산조 are small-ensemble genres of Korean folk music with many shared characteristics.(1) Pansori consists of a dramatic narrative performance by a sorikkun 소리꾼, a vocalist-narrator, and a gosu 고수, a drummer who provides rhythmic accompaniment on a barrel drum called a puk 북.” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) English B: a drummer for accompaning (Pyǒn (2012) 216)Korean B: 음악을 연주할 때 북이나 장구로 반주하는 사람. 산조에는 주 로 장구를 사용하고 판소리에는 소리북을 사용한다. 흔히 판소 리나 산조에서 장단을 치는 사람을 가리키나, 보통 고수라고 하면 판소리에서 소리북을 치는 사람을 의미한다. 북재비라고 도 한다. (Pyǒn (2012) 216–217)

accent displacement.text: Source: “The intuition present in this passage is impressive for exposing—perhaps for the first time by a Brazilian musicologist—the theoretical formalization, albeit incipient, of a displaced but consistent accent in relation to the main meter, functioning as a regular, tensioning, and complementary element to the meter. The formulation of a second rhythmic support point emerges, which is structured and constant, yet displaced in relation to the main beat. What Andrade seeks to describe—without a clear formulation—is a type of accent displacement that does not occur as a deviation or rupture of the musical discourse, but as a rule of the structure, which, appearing constantly in the performance of musicians from various American cultures, gains a different status from European syncopation.” Menezes (2024) [1.7]

identidade.text: English A: “The emphasis on the melody is so striking that all the notes that compose it are essential to the song’s identity, including those that would be considered surface-level ornaments in the European classical-romantic music that has so influenced popular Brazilian music. What could be considered superfluous for melodic evaluation, such as notes that are foreign to the basic harmonic structure of the song (grupetos, mordants, appoggiaturas) have a functional importance in popular Brazilian song.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “A ênfase na melodia é tão marcante que todas as notas que a compõem são essenciais para a identidade da canção, incluindo aquelas que seria consideradas ornamentos superficiais na música clássico-romântica européia que tanto influenciou a música brasileira popular. O que poderia ser considerado supérfluo para a avaliação melódica, como notas extranhas à estrutura harmônica básica na canção (grupetos, mordentes, appoggiaturas) têm uma importância funcional na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u97f3\u8272 y\u012bns\u00e8.text: Chinese A: “声音的属性之一，主要由其谐音的多寡及各谐音的相对强度所决定。也称音品、音质。每个人的声音以及各种乐器所发出的声音的区别，就是由音色不同造成的.” Hanyu dacidian (音色) Chinese B: “不論怎麼樣的一個樂音，誰也未曾在自然界裏面聽過。牠那種有一定的數目可查的顫動，以及牠的音色，都是由人們創造出來的，並不是從自然界照樣學來的。” Li (2024) [2.7] (See: 音 yīn, 声 shēng) English B: Timbre. “No musical tones can be heard in nature. They are scrutable vibrations; their timbre is manufactured by humans, not emulated from nature.” Li (2024) [2.7]

\u6a6b\u7b1b h\u00e9ngd\u00ed.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 今 度 は 器 楽 曲 に 移 り ま し て 、 す べ て の 器 楽 曲 は ま ず 声 楽 から 受 け 継 い で 、 そ れ を 発 展 さ せ た も の とい っ て も い い わ け で す 。 た と え ば 「 ⽝ 等 」と い い ま し て 、 横 笛 を ⾧ く し た 形 の 韓 国 の 民 族 楽 器 が あ り ま し て 、 そ れ で 奏 さ れ る 節 回 し は 歌 唱 を 受 け 継 い だ も の で す 。そ し て 、 そ こ に は 線 的 な ⾳ 楽 の 妙 味 が ある わ け で す.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5]) Japanese B: “にして吹く笛の総称。歌口は管の途中 にある. *神楽笛,*竜笛,*狛笛、*篠笛などの別がある、管を縦 (垂直)にして吹く縦笛(尺八、一節切など)に相対する語.” Tanabe (1975) [p. 187]

nguluin.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan nguluin artinya pemberian tanda kepada anak buahnya, pawisik (nabhe) namanya atau pangajen (guru). Pukulan mendahului memberikan tanda bahwa melodi akan berjalan ke arah tertentu.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Nguluin is an indication to one’s followers that one is leading (or teaching to go) somewhere. Striking the tone in advance signals that the melody will progress in a certain direction.” Tenzer (2024) [III.6] “Since the trompong plays a lead role, what is meant by “followers” is the rest of musicians in the gamelan…” Tenzer (2024) [3.7] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\uc131\uc545\uace1 seong-aggog.text: 악곡: composition; music; song  Korean A: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) Korean B: “목소리로 연주한 음악. 성악은 악기로 연주하는 기악(樂)과 대칭을 이룬다. 「문헌동고」(文獻通考)에 “주례』(周禮)에 '고인」(鼓人)은 여섯 가지 북과 네 가지 쇠[金]의 소리 를 맡고, 그것들로 성악을 절제한다. 네 가지 쇠란 순(算)·탁(鐸)·요(燒)·탁(鐲)이다. 금순(金 )은 북과 함께 연주한다"라고 하였다.” Song (2010) [p. 177]

autonomy.text: 独立 dú lì (Chinese) Source: “What exactly the concept of “autonomy” should mean, however, when transferred over into aesthetics is a little unclear. You might think that, by analogy, it should entail the claim that works of music are in some sense “self-governing,” or perhaps “self-generating.” That claim might in turn imply something like the high modernist injunction that each work creates its own (radically new and different) organizing principles; or at the other extreme, it might amount to Schenker’s view that each piece emanates outward from the Ursatz (or, somewhere in between, Réti’s that each grows outward like a crystal from its own unique motivic cell).” Martin commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “The condition or right of a state, institution, group, etc., to make its own laws or rules and administer its own affairs; self-government, independence.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “autonomy”)

pitch-centricity.text: Source: “Koizumi’s nuclear tones act in pairs, both exerting gravitational force on the music at the same time, allowing for multipolar senses of pitch-centricity. This idea is fundamental to the idea of the tetrachord, for which he is perhaps most famous, and which follows not long afterward in the book.” (Hynes-Tawa (2024) [0.1])

\uc601\uc6d0 yeongwon.text: Korean A: “'하우프트톤'의 경우, 음과 양의 상대시 변화는, 미세한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 시작하며 기대한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 이르기까지 여러 단계가 있습니 다. 거기에는 순간에 영원이 반영되고, 영원을 순간으로서 포착한 수가 있어요. 그것이 동양인의 '시'(時)에 대한 사고방식으로서, 서양인의 '시'의 사고방식과는 전혀 다른 점이지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

Cannon-Brown (2024).text: Cannon-Brown, Lee. 2024. “Julián Carrillo, Laws of Musical Metamorphosis, and the Landscape of Early Atonal Thought.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

\u7b2c\u4e00\u4e3b\u984c\u90e8 dai ichi.text:
第一 + 主題 + 部 第一: first, number one 主題: subject, theme, motif 部: part, portion 
 Japanese A: “「時」の考え方が形式観に反映した 例として西洋ではソナタ形式があります が、ソナタ形式ですと、第一主題部があ り、第二主題部がある。これらは対立し た区間であり、第二主題の部分は第一主 題と異なった時間を独自に形成するわけ ですから、瞬間に世界を持つ陰陽とは全 く異なるということですね。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “The Sonata form might be one example that reflects the Western formalistic view of time. In Sonata form, there are primary and secondary theme areas. They are contrasting sections that independently develop [the sense of] time. Therefore, it is completely different from yin and yang, which contain an eternity in a moment.” Park (2024) [4.2]

\u4e00\u4f53 Ittai.text: Japanese A: "ですから、先生の作品が終わりに近づくにつれ、それらが高い次死で融合して、一体のものであるということが非常に強く示されるという感動的なコーダをいつも聴くことができるんだと思うのですが、そういったものと感じてよろしいんでし." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) English A: "For this reason, toward the end of your works, they [the seemingly conflicting elements] are fused in a higher dimension and strongly express their bodily unity [一体]. That seems to be the reason why I always hear deeply moving codas." (Park (2024)  [2.2])

gana wedana.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat nem, gana wadana ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “if six, it is gana wedana [face of the wise elephant god Ganesha],” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug babarangan Anutasih ngaran. Yaning gage-Bus ges der pewayahau umbans taruns ngarang tan pa selat Anunggalpati ngaran. Yaning gebug selat siki Chandrapra-ba ngaran. Yaning gebug selat kalih Paduarsa ngaran. Yaning gebug selat telu Dahanamuka ngaran. Yaning gebug selat pat Anerang sasih ngaran. Yaning gebug selat lima Anerang Wisaya ngaran. Yaning gebug selat nem Gana wedana ngaran.” (Bandem (1986), 68)

maxixe.text: Portuguese A: “As síncopas europeias, desenvolvidas pelo afro-americano, nos deram o principal da prodigiosa riqueza rítmica que em nossa música se manifesta. Ao contato da polca europeia, que teve entre nós grande aceitação no Segundo Império, os negros brasileiros, da mesma forma com que os negros escravos da Colônia nos tinham dado o samba, nos deram o maxixe, nossa principal dansa de caráter urbano.” Andrade (2013)  English A: “The European syncopations, developed by African-Americans, gave us the main source of the prodigious rhythmic richness that manifests in our music. In contact with the European polka, which had great acceptance in the Second Empire, Brazilian blacks, in the same way that the enslaved blacks of the Colony had given us the samba, gave us the maxixe, our main urban dance.” Menezes (2024) [1.4] Portuguese B: “Dança e canto populares em voga no Brasil a partir do século passado. "Foi da fusão da habanera, pela rítmica, e da polca, pela an-dadura, com a adaptação da síncopa afro-lusitana que originou-se o Maxi-xc" (Andrade, Mário de. Ernesto Nazaré. Música, doce música, 1976, p.125).Nota da Pesquisa: Acolhemos para este termo documentação de Mário de Andrade aqui selecionada e organizada segundo: origens do termo, dança c canto; análise ritmico-melódica; influências estrangeiras; a evolução do gêncro.” (Andrade (1989), p. 317–325)

Zhongwai guangbo (1995).text: Zhongwai guangbuo dianshi baike quanshu 中外广播电视百科全书. Zhao Yuming 赵玉明, Wang Fushun 王福顺(eds.). Beijing: Zhongguo guangbo dianshi chuban she 北京:中国广播电视出版社, 1995.

Disminuci\u00f3n.text: Spanish A: “Existe en el clasicismo musical algo que pudiera creerse relacionado con estas “Leyes de Metamorfosis”: los procedimientos por “aumentación” y “disminución,” que se emplean en el canon y la fuga, pero debe desecharse tal idea; pues positivamente no tienen semejanza con lo que constituye la base misma de mis “Leyes de metamorfosis.””  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] English A: “In classical music, there exist procedures that could be thought of as related to these “Laws of Metamorphosis”: the procedures of “augmentation” and “diminution” that are employed in canon and fugue. But such a notion must be discarded, because augmentation and diminution bear absolutely no relationship to the very foundation of my “Laws of Metamorphosis.””  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “Artificio por el que, como sucede en el canon y la fuga, se reduce á la mitad el valor de las notas al repetir un pensamiento.” Lacál (1900) [p. 155] (See also: Canon, Fuga)

\u767db\u00e1i.text: Chinese: 特指戏曲中只说不唱的部分。其源甚早，唐变文《维摩诘经变文》已用白字，以别于唱. Hanyu dacidian  (白, 30) English: “Vocal sounds that differ from strict “singing” due to being recitative in style.” Qian (2024) (See also 乐说 yuèshuō)

\u697d\u53e5\u306e\u533a\u5206 gakuku no.text: 楽句 gakuku +区分 区分: division, section, demarcation Japanese A: “そしてdisとaisによる支配楽句の区分は比較的細かいけれども、上にのべたような意味で、終止音としての意味を持たないと考えられたばあいの出現を無視すると、第１行目は全体的にdisの支配下にあり、第２行目はaisの支配下にあると見ていい。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 2] English A: “Although I have narrowly divided the melody into phrases [phrasal divisions] controlled by D♯ and A♯ in a similar way to what I said above, if we ignore cases that I don’t think hold meaning as ending notes, we can see that the first line is entirely controlled by D♯, and the second line by A♯.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.3, brackets added separately]

Zhongguo wenxue (1997).text: Zhongguo wenxue da cidian 中国文学大辞典. Qian Zhonglian 钱仲联, Fu Xuancong 傅璇琮, Wangyunxi 王运熙 (eds.). Shanghai: Shanghai cishu chuban she 上海:上海辞书出版社, 1997.

\u6642 toki.text: Japanese A: “「ハウプト・トン」における陰と陽の相 対的な変化は、微細な時間によるとらえ 方から巨大な時間によるとらえ方までい ろいろな段階があります。そこでは瞬間 に永遠が反映され、永遠を瞬間としてつ かむことができるわけです。それが東洋人の「時」の考え方で、西 洋人の「時」の考え方と全く違うところ なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

Danielsen commentary (2024).text: Danielsen, Anne. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4 (2024).

Heterophony.text: Source: “As such, I read Yun’s critique not as a reiteration of problematic East/West binaries, but as a differential way of thinking about musical structure, process, interpretation, and experience that has affinities with how other experimental logics address matters of time, indeterminacy, mobile forms, heterophony and micropolyphony, and much more.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.4]) Definition: “Term coined by Plato, of uncertain meaning; now used to describe simultaneous variation of a single melody.” (”Heterophony,” Grove Music Online)

\u6f14\u594f\u5bb6 ens\u014dka.text:
演奏 + 家 演奏: musical performance 家: -ist, -er 
 Japanese A: “最後に、先生の作品は演奏家という媒体を通じて聴衆に伝えられるわけで すから、演奏家との深い信頼関係と、演 奏家の全人格に対しての信頼に基づいて つくられているものだと思います。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 61] English A: “In closing, your compositions reach the listening public through performers, which, I think, is grounded upon a deeply trusting relationship between you and the performers and faith in the performer’s whole personality.” Park (2024) [7.2]

\u97f3\u8907\u5408\u4f53 Oto fukug\u014d.text: English A: "The term Hauptklang is used by Yun in his 1985 lecture at Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen to denote “sonic complex” [음복합체, 音複合体], which describes an orchestral use of Hauptton." (Park (2024)  [Footnote 7])

\ud55c\uad6d\uc758 \uac00\ucc3d\u00a0han.text: 한국의: Korean 가창: singing Korean A: “그것이 선생님 작품의 선적 어법의 밑바탕 이 되어 있군요. 미분음적인 미세한 흔들림으로부터 3 도 이상의 전음(숍)에 이르는 독특한 선의 움직임은 한국의 가창.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

\u043d\u0430\u0440\u043e\u0434\u043d\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Ако хвърлим един бегъл поглед върху безбройните славянски песни, събрани от Кухач (Fr. S. Kuhac, Juno-slovenske narodne popjevke) иКуба (Ludvik Kuba, Slovanstvo ve svych zpěvech) и др., и ги сравним с нашите чисто народни песни, ще видим, че българската народна музика е несравнима с никоя друга по богатството си на ритъма и тоналността.” Hristov (1925) [p. 34] English A: “If we take a cursory glance at the unnumerable Slavic songs collected by Kuhač (Fr. S. Kuhač, Južno-slovjenske narodne popjevke), Kuba (Ludvík Kuba, Slovanstvo ve svých zpěvech), and others, and compare them with our pure folk songs, we will see that Bulgarian folk music is unmatched by any other in the richness of its rhythm and tonality.” Goldberg (2024) [2.5] Bulgarian B: “вокално, инструментално или вокално-инструментално музикално творчество на трудовия народ, създадено върху установени, постоянно развиващи се стилови художествени традиции, което се разпространява устно. Н. м. отразява художествено, пълно и всестранно живота, стремежите, борбите за свобода и човешки правдини на народа.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 207]

\u2fb3\u697d\u4e16\u754c\u00a0y\u012bn-R.text: 音楽 ongaku + 世 界: the world, society, universe Japanese A: “そ し て 韓 国 に は 厳 格 な⽴ 場 を と る 雅 楽 ⾳ 楽 と は 別 に 、 宮 廷 ⾳ 楽 で も 寺 院 ⾳ 楽 で も な い 、⼀ 般 ⼤ 衆 と 上 流 社 会 が 共 有 し て き た 、 西 洋 に ⾒ ら れ る よ う な 知 識 社 会 で 楽 し ん で き た ⾳ 楽 世 界 が ま だ あ り ま す 。 そ れ か ら ま た 芸 術 歌 曲 、芸 術 民 謡 と い い ま す か 、 そ う い う も の が あ り ま す " (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3]) Note: The Japanese translates literally to a “world of music” here.

\u4e2d\u5fc3\u97f3 ch\u016bshin-on.text: 中心: center/centered, core 音 oto: note Japanese A: “これはヨーロッパの調性音楽が、次第に従来の長・短調組織からぬけだして、自由な音語を使うようになってから、もっともひろい意味での調性の中心になる音という意味に使われていたものを、伝統音楽のばあいに適用したものと解することができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “It is understood that Mr. Itō applied the word “central tone” as something commonly used in Japanese traditional music, in the same way European music used it in a free pitch language after it gradually began to pull away from its original major- and minor-key organization of tonal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4]

Tomosha (2002).text: Tomosha, Ongaku no. 新編音楽中辞典 /Shinpen ongaku chūjiten. 2002.

\u541f y\u00edn.text: Chinese A: 吟咏；诵读. 叹息；呻吟。鸣；叫. Hanyu dacidian (吟, 1–3) Chinese B: “一种接近咏叹的歌唱方式。它主要用于五种场合:一、弦乐。代表旋律线起伏辐度较小的乐曲。例如“吟叹四曲”、《大雅吟》等。二、佛教呗赞音乐。代表同“转读”(一名美声朗诵法)音调相接近的歌唱。倒如敦煌讲唱术语中的“吟”、“平吟”、“侧吟”、“断吟”等等。三、民间谣歌。代表一种富于咏叹意味的歌唱。如李绅《过吴门诗》所云:“里吟传绮唱,乡语传认歈讴。”四、采用咏叹唱法的曲子歌唱。例如李白《秋浦清溪雪夜对酒客有唱〈鹧鸪〉者》所云:“客有桂阳至,能吟《山鹧鸪》。”又《教坊记》所载曲调名中有《浐水吟》、《碧霄吟》、《吴吟子》。五、文人吟诗调。如白居易《山中独吟》诗云:“狂吟惊林壑。”” Tangshi baike (1990) p. 1070-1071 English: “Vocal sounds that differ from strict “singing” due to being recitative in style.” Qian (2024) (See also 乐说 yuèshuō)

Apoteosis.text: Spanish A: “Muy conocido es, igualmente, el efecto formidable logrado por Ricardo Wagner en la obertura de Tannhauser, en la cual la aumentación rítmica y el cambio de matiz dan carácter de apoteosis al tema místico en el final de dicha Obra.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 18] English A: “Equally well-known is the formidable effect achieved by Richard Wagner in the overture to Tannhäuser, in which rhythmic augmentation and shifting nuances lend a character of apotheosis to the mystical theme at the end of the work.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 18]

buta kala.text: English: “An aling-aling is a wall at the gateway to almost all Balinese homes that forces someone coming in to turn immediately left or right. Its purpose is to prevent buta kala (malevolent powers believed to travel only in straight lines) from entering. This is one of two of Geria’s ubit-ubitan that does not feature interlocking rhythms. The three-note motive 123 in the polos (523 in the sangsih) repeats throughout, constantly backing up and trying again like a buta kala ramming into an aling-aling. At the end, at last, the 3 of the sangsih and polos aligns with the gending.” Tenzer (2024) [4.5] Balinese A: “makhluk-makhluk halus yg jahat dan bersifat merusak” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 83, Bidang Istilah Upakara]

\u9759 sei.text: Japanese A: “"動は静であり、静は動であるというのが私の音楽の総括的な見方だ." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) “「ハウプト・トン」は二つあるときも多いのです。二つあれば、それは陰陽関 係を持ちます。たとえば、動と静の関係 であったりします。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “Motion [動] is stillness [靜] and stillness [靜] is motion [動], it is my music’s overall perspective.” (Park (2024) [2]) “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1]

kabelit.text: English: “IV.2 through IV.5 can be discussed together since they are similar and all paired with the same oscillating two-note gending pattern. Gagelut and gagulet are assonant synonyms meaning hug, embrace, or even wrestle. The patterns are of a subtype called ubitan telu (telu = three) in which the two parts use a total of three tones, sharing an inner tone; hence embracing. These are indeed ubiquitous in the repertoire. Kabelit and kabelet, similarly related as words, mean stuck, stubborn, unmoving. They are of subtype called ubitan empat (empat = four) in which the two parts use two different but scale-adjacent tones each. When sounded the lower tone of the polos and the upper tone of the sangsih coincide, creating a dyad that protrudes from the texture to create a syncopated  3+2+3 cross-rhythm (the greyed notes). While the inner tones jostle, this prominent interval is “stuck” in its place.” Tenzer (2024) [4.6] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) See: kabelet

\u015b\u0323abda rasa.text: English: “Theories of poetic meter and rhyme scheme have been part of literary discourse for centuries (Hallisey 2003, 723–38); the value given to these ideas of sonic patterning is reflected in the fact that sung Sinhala poetry was prized as much for its sonic aesthetics (ṣ́abda rasa) as its semantic aesthetics (artha rasa).” Peiris (2024) [15]

\u043f\u0435\u0440\u0438\u043e\u0434\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Събраният по този начин материал да се систематизира: 1) по такт, 2) по сложение на периодите, 3) по тоналност, 4) по амбитус (тонов обем), 5) по общ характер на песента (любовна, елична, обредна и пр.). Всички тия особености да се пренесат в подходящи карти-диаграми.” Hristov (1925) [p. 36] English A: “The material collected in this way should be systematized: (1) by meter, (2) by composition of the periods, (3) by tonality, (4) by ambitus (tonal range), (5) by general character of the song (love, epic, ritual, etc.). All these features should be communicated in suitable diagrammatic charts.” Goldberg (2024) [2.10]

character.text: Source: Tenzer (2024) Ex. 2 Lexical fields Definition: “The sum of the moral and mental qualities which distinguish an individual or a people, viewed as a homogeneous whole; a person's or group's individuality deriving from environment, culture, experience, etc.; mental or moral constitution, personality..” (Oxford English Dictionary, II.9.a)

responsorial singing.text: Source: “In this note, Andrade is studying the article “African Negro Music” by Erich M. Hornbostel (1928). As the director of the Phonographic Archive in Berlin, Hornbostel was a pioneer in the academic study of African music. In this article, Hornbostel identifies some characteristics that he considers fundamental, which will be further developed by later authors: a highly developed rhythmic structure and, in vocal music, the predominance of responsorial singing and polyphony.” Menezes (2024) [1.14] Definition: “Relating to (liturgical) responses; sung alternately. In later use also: spec. (of a psalm in the liturgy) chosen for its thematic relation to the preceding reading and performed as a responsory.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “responsorial”)

deslocamento.text: English A: “For there to be syncopation, the presence of metric structure is necessary, with the beats hierarchically arranged so that the configuration of metric strength can be challenged by the displacement of the strong beats.” (Stover (2024) [1.3]) Portuguese A: “Para existir a síncopa é necessário, portanto, a presença de uma estrutura de compassos com os tempos hierarquicamente colocados para que esta configuração de poder da métrica possa ser desafiada pelo deslocamento dos tempos fortes.” (Ulhôa (1999))

auditory stream.text: Source: “In addition, while Keil wanted to direct attention to the vital effects produced by musicians co-articulating the same beat and thus contributing to the same auditory stream (Bregman 1994), métrica derramada asks musicians (and listeners) to refer to the same beat in two different streams.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [6])

\uac00\uc57c\uae08\uc0b0\uc870 gayageum.text: Korean A: “자진모리伽倻琴散調는 대개 진양조, 중모리, 중중모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리 6樂章으로 되어 있고, 一般 的으로 羽調, 界面調, 平調를 使用하고 있다.” (Shin (2018) , 248) English A: “Gayageum sanjo typically comprises six movements: jinyangjo, jungmori, jungjungmori, jajinmori, hwimori, and danmori; it commonly utilizes Ujo, Gyemyeonjo, and Pyeongjo.” (Kim (2024)  [3.2]) Korean B: “우조의 특징은 자진모리장단의 우조 대목에 나타나는 특징으로, 그 는 '자진모리-우조'라고 적음으로서 다른 장단의 우조 대목과 구별하였다. 또한, 가야금산조에 서 진양장단의 우조가 판소리에서 자진모리장단의 우조와 같이 La-re-mi 골격임을 지적함으로 서, 우조를 La-re-mi 골격으로 보았을 때 가야금산조와 판소리가 서로 통함을 드러내었다. 그 리고 La-re-mi 골격의 판소리 우조는 Sol-do-re 골격의 판소리 평조에 비하여 한 음씩 위인 점에서, 1970년대 김윤덕이 우조에 대해 "한 음 위의 조"라고 증언한 것과 연결 지었다.” Shin (2018) [p. 242] English B: “Lee’s description of Ujo’s traits recalls those of scenes in jajinmori jangdan. Lee specifies “jajinmori-Ujo” to distinguish it from Ujo scenes in other jangdan. Additionally, he notes that Ujo based on jajinmori jangdan in pansori has the same La-re-mi structure as Ujo in jinyang jangdan in gayageum sanjo; this indicates that gayageum sanjo and pansori strongly correspond with each other. The La-re-mi structure in pansori Ujo is also related to Kim Yundeok’s 1970s statement that Ujo is “a mode higher than a whole step,” since it is a step higher than the Sol-do-re structure in pansori Pyeongjo (Lee 2002, 218).” Kim (2024) [3.15] English C: a Sanjo for gayageum (Pyǒn (2012) 104) Korean C: 가야금으로 연주하는 산조. 진양조•중모리 •중중모리 •엇모 리 • 굿거리 • 늦은자진모리 • 자진모리 • 휘모리 • 단모리(세산조 시) 등의 장단에 의한 악장으로 구분되며, 장구반주가 따른다. 우조, 평조, 계면조, 경드름, 강산제로 이루어진다. 김창조가 틀 을 짜서 오늘날과 같은 산조의 체계를 세웠다는 설이 지배적이 며, 현재 전승되는 유파는 성금류, 김파류, 최옥삼류, 김윤 덕류, 강태홍류, 정남희류, 김병호류, 심상건류, 박상근류 등이 있다. (Pyǒn (2012) 104)

ubit-ubitan.text: English: “Balinese interlocking patterns are played by pairs of musicians and on some instruments may involve improvisation, though in a different way than the patterns in Part III (see Tilley 2019). But Geria only addresses a type called ubit-ubitan, played on the upper-register gangsa (metallophone family). Most gamelan have eight gangsa. In ubit-ubitan rhythm and contour are fully specified, though patterns may perch on any set of scale degrees depending on the surrounding musical context.” Tenzer (2024) [4.1] English B: “To introduce some cross-cultural perspective, Example 3 reproduces my typology of ubit-ubitan patterns, based also on sensitivity to contour but differently than Geria (Tenzer 2000a, 225; Tenzer 2000b). I separate ubit-ubitan into two collections, ubit telu (ubit “three”, shown at left) and ubit empat (ubit “four”, shown at right). This is such a quotidian distinction for Balinese that Geria did perhaps not even consider invoking it. In ubit telu patterns, three contiguous scale-tone pitches are used, and the polos and sangsih parts always share the middle pitch. In ubit empat a fourth pitch is added such that each part has its own two pitches, and when the low part sounds its lower pitch, the high part always sounds its higher one. This generates dyads that protrude from the texture as cross-rhythms when patterns repeat. Aside from this, though, the collections of ubit telu and ubit empat patterns are identical from the standpoint of the contours of the lower three pitches in each.” (Tenzer (2024) [5.3])

\uc6b0\ub9ac \uc545\uae30 uli aggi\u00a0.text: 악기: musical instrument Korean A: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) Note: In this translation, “Japanese traditional instruments” is translated to “our instruments.”

accentuar.text: English A: “In Brazil, a musical performance is influenced primarily by one’s manner of accentuating words in speech, whose “prosodic values transfigure the melody” (Andrade 1972, 23).” (Stover (2024) [1.1]) Portuguese A: “No Brasil, a performance musical seria influenciada principalmente pela maneira de acentuar as palavras na fala, cujos "valores prosódicos … transfiguram a melodia" (p. 23).” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “Song melodies would not be syncopated, the ambivalence emerging from their counterposition with the accompaniment, which would accentuate the beat. Instead, the melodic flow would be non-metrical, its accentuation driven by a “musical fantasy, pure virtuosity, or prosodic precision … a subtle compromise between recitative and strophic singing” (36).” (Stover (2024) [1.6]) Portuguese B: “As melodias das canções não seriam sincopadas, a ambivalência emergindo da contraposição com o acompanhamento, que acentuaria o tempo. O fluir da melodia seria não-métrico, a acentuação sendo dirigida por uma "fantasia musical, puro virtuosismo, ou precisão prosódica ... um compromisso sutil entre o canto recitativo e estrófico" (p. 36).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u30e1\u30bf\u30d5\u30a3\u30b8\u30ab\u30.text: Japanese A: “メタフィジカルじゃないけれども、たとえば《レアク》は雅楽の要素を持っています。韓国でもそう、日本でもそうですけれども、雅楽はほとんど人間世界。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “It is not metaphysical, per se. For example, Reak contains elements from A-ak. It is the case in both Korea and Japan that A-ak largely expresses the world mostly beyond the human realm for me.” Park (2024) [5.2]

\u043f\u0438\u0440\u0438\u043a\u0438\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6] Bulgarian B: “Пирихий или пирихийска стъпка (гр. pyrrichos, от името на старогръцкия поет Пирих, предполагаемият изобретател на П.) двусложна стихотворна стъпка в двувременен такт, образувана от две крат- ки срички.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 255, “Пирихий или пирихийска стъпка”]

subdivis\u00e3o.text: Portuguese A: “A síncopa europeia me parece um produto exclusivamente musical, e ainda mais, uma verdadeira especulação teórica proveniente da subdivisão da unidade de tempo em quantidades irregulares em que as batidas fortes subsistem em seus lugares teóricos e se tornam pois musicalmente elípticas.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota. no. 9] English A: “European syncopation seems to me an exclusively musical product, and furthermore, a true theoretical speculation stemming from the subdivision of the time unit into irregular quantities where strong beats persist in their theoretical places and thus become musically elliptical.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

Shijie shixue (1999).text: “World Encyclopedia of Poetics 世界诗学百科全书.” Zhou Shizhong 周式中,Sun Hong 孙宏,Tan Tianjian 谭天健等主编. Xi’an: Shaanxi People’s Publishing House 西安:陕西人民出版社. 1999

cadential function.text: Source: “Another significant feature of the pansori modes discussed in the translated text is that each constituent note assumes individual attributes. This is most evident in Baek’s explanation of Ujo and Pyeongjo in Tables 2 and 3, where constituent notes are defined not only by particular intervals, but also by specific singing methods and techniques, frequency of occurrence, cadential function, melodic direction, and so on.” Lee commentary (2024) [6]

masculinity.text: Source: “Additionally, the ubọ-aka is a symbol of masculinity and manhood, reflecting the patrilineal nature of social organization among the Nri people. It also plays a role in socialization, as it is used for leisure and relaxation, and is associated with courtship and marriage, conveying love and expectations in married lives.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.3] Definition: “The state or fact of being masculine; the assemblage of qualities regarded as characteristic of men; maleness, manliness.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “masculinity”)

\ubb34\ub300\uc131 mudaeseong.text: Korean A: “그러므로 내 자신은 그렇게 생각하고 곡을 썼지만 그것을 배제해버리고 들어 줬으면 합니다. 음악에는 묘사적인 요소는 전혀 없습니다. 또한 무대성(舞臺性)도 없습니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 159] English A: “Therefore, even though I composed these pieces with narratives in mind, I wish the pieces to be listened to without consideration for them. There are no depictive elements in music, and also no theatrical [舞台性] elements.” Park (2024) [5.2]

\uc18c\ub9ac\uafbc sorikkun.text: English A: “Pansori 판소리 and sanjo 산조 are small-ensemble genres of Korean folk music with many shared characteristics.(1) Pansori consists of a dramatic narrative performance by a sorikkun 소리꾼, a vocalist-narrator, and a gosu 고수, a drummer who provides rhythmic accompaniment on a barrel drum called a puk 북.” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) English B: a singer (Pyǒn (2012) 225)Korean B:  판소리나 민요 등의 소리를 하는 사람 (Pyǒn (2012) 225)

Beijing daxue faxue (1999).text: Beijing daxue faxue baikequanshu xianfaxue || xingzhengfaxue 北京大学法学百科全书 宪法学||行政法学. Xiao Weiyun 肖蔚云, Jiang Mingan 姜明安主编 (eds.). Beijing: Beijingdaxue chubanshe 北京:北京大学出版社, 1999.

antecipa\u00e7\u00e3o.text: Portuguese A: “No nº 26, p. 343 vem um Danzon cubano com antecipações. Notar na mesma peça (3ª parte) o grande caráter de peça afroianque mostrando influência de Cuba no jazz.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 28] English A: “In number 26, p. 343, there is a Cuban Danzón with anticipations. Note in the same piece (3rd part) the strong Afro-Cuban character showing influence from Cuba on jazz.” Menezes (2024) [1.11] Portuguese B: “(1) Processo que consiste em executar uma ou mais notas dum acorde, antes da realização dêsse mesmo acorde. (2) F. Prélèvement.[Música Concreta]. Todo o movimento que produz um som cujo efeito é registrado numa placa de disco ou sôbre uma fita de magnetofone. As antecipações podem, pois, ser registros de som "di-reto", ou registros de sons obtidos com o auxílio de registros prévios. Ver também Música Concreta.” (Cosme (1957) 9)

\uc120 seon.text: Korean A: “'또한 '하우프트톤'은 단속적으로 토막토막난 형태로 나타나기도 합니다. 어쨌든 여러 가지 선이 되어 나타나는데…” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “Also, a Hauptton sometimes intermittently appears in the shape of little pieces. In any case, it appears as various lines.” Park (2024) [4.1]

akpo\u0323.text: English A: “Ubo is something that is plucked/If it did not originate from the Igbo people, it would not have that name.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Ụbọ bụ ihe a na-akpọ akpọ/Ọ bụrụ na ọ bụghị ndị Igbo nwe ya ọ gaghị aza afa ahu na mbụ.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

\u0442\u044c\u043f\u0430\u043d/t\u2019pa.text: Bulgarian A: “нцови песни (коледарски, седенкови и др .). Обикновената или женската ръченица е танц с три стъпки и се играе обикновено от един, двама един срещу други или от няколко двойки.Темпото на целия такте между 60—66 по М . М . И трите времена от такта имаг еднакво силни ударения. Акомпаниментът с тьпан или дайрепесни в този такт става по следния начин:” Hristov (1925) (p. 48) English A: “The ordinary or zhenska rŭchenitsa is a dance with three steps, and it is ordinarily danced individually, between two people with one facing the other, or in several pairs. The tempo of the entire measure is between 60–66 M. M. The three beats in the meter also have equally strong accents. The accompaniment of songs in this meter with tŭpan or daire occurs in the following way:” Goldberg (2024) [5.16] English: “The tŭpan is a large double-sided drum, played with a beater on one side and a thin, flexible switch on the other side.” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 24] Bulgarian B: “ударен народенинструмент с две кожени мембрани. Среща се почти на-всякьде в страната. Най-разпространей е в Пиринския край и в Странджа.” (Krŭstev (1967) p. 426–27)

\u4e0d\u6b63\u78ba fuseikaku.text: 不: un-, non- + 正確: accurate, correct, precise, exact Japanese A: “しかし鎌倉・室町時代に興った能楽の譜では、この点がはなはだ不正確で、絶対音高を表示する譜面によってはとらえることが困難である。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “However, in the sheet music of nō, which became prosperous in the Kamakura [1185 – 1333 CE] and Muromachi [1336 – 1573 CE] periods, the notes are extremely imprecise, and it is difficult to capture absolute pitch from what is displayed in the sheet music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.1]

finais.text: English A: “These rhetorical gestures, as well as the spaces between musicians’ attacks or note endings in a musical performance, contribute greatly to making people move their bodies in specific ways and to hearing the “grain” of the song.” (Stover (2024) [5.8]) Portuguese A: “Estes gestos retóricos, bem como os espaços entre os ataques ou finais de nota dos músicos numa performance musical contribuem enormemente para fazer as pessoas moverem seus corpos de maneira específica, e para escutar o "grão" da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u672c\u8abf\u5b50 hon ch\u014dshi.text: Japanese A: “たとえば長唄の「老松」では、かりに本調子を３本にとると（三味線の第１弦をＨに合わせる）、譜２６のようになる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “For example, in the nagauta “Oimatsu (Old Pine),” if we take honchōshi on the third string (in which it matches the first string of the shamisen, which is tuned to B), it will be transcribed as in example 26 (Example 3).” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1] “Honchōshi 本調子 is the most basic shamisen tuning, which puts the strings at roughly B-E-B.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 6] Japanese B: “三味線の基本の調絃法・第1絃と第2紘の間が 完全4度音程,第2絃と第3絃の間が完全5度音程(したがって第1 絃と第3絃とは八度)、普通第2紘の開放音を音階の主音としている。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 168]

dung.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Dari 10 (sepuluh) nada yang dijiwai oleh Smara dan Ratih sebagai Dewa Percintaan bersumber pada 7 (tujuh) buah nada yang urutan nadanya sebagai berikut: ding, dong, deng, ndung, dung, dang, nding. Ketujuh nada di atas merupakan sumber bunyi dalam gambelan Bali dan menurut Prakempa bunyi (suara) itu disebut Genta Pinara Pitu (bunyi berjarak tujuh) (alinea : 7 - 10).” Bandem (1986) [p. 13] Balinese D: “nada keempat dr gamelan gong pancanada” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 159, Bidang Istilah Musik, “ndung”]

\u0438\u0433\u0440\u0430/igra.text: Bulgarian A: “Напротив, мярката на пайдушката 5/16, двойната мярка 7/16 (ръченица и македонско хоро), 9/16 (тропливата игра или радомирското хоро), 11/16 (хайдушка игра) и др. там никак не се срещат.” Hristov (1925) [p. 35] English A: “To the contrary, the time signature of 5/16 (paidushkata), both 7/16 time signatures (rŭchenitsa and makedonsko horo), 9/16 (troplivata igra or radomirskoto horo), 11/16 (haidushka igra), etc., are in no way found there.” Goldberg (2024) [2.7] “Horo and igra are names for types of Bulgarian dances. Both typically involve dancing in one or more lines or open circles, which dancers form by holding hands, belts, or shoulders.” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 8]

\u30c6\u30c8\u30e9\u30b3\u30eb\u30c9 tet.text: Japanese A: “しかし、私の取扱おうとする素材は、単にそのように出来上った芸術音楽ばかりでなく、もっとトニカの不明瞭な民俗的素材をもふくむわけだし、またその点でさらに困難な琉球・朝鮮・中国をはじめ、アジア一般の音組織にもこの概念を適用させようとする上、後に詳しく説明するような、４度構造のテトラコルドを単位として旋律を分析するばあいの、「枠になる重要な音」として、この核音がオクターヴの中に２～３個現われることもありうるので、中心音という、何か一元的な響きの言葉では、狭くなりすぎるようにも思える。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “However, the materials that I intend to handle are not simply art musics that are already established, but also include folk musics in which the tonic pitch is less clear. Also, to take that point further, starting with the Ryukyus, Korea, and China (which pose some difficulty), I want to apply this concept to a generalized organization of notes in Asian music, and explain them afterward in detail, analyzing their melodies using the unit of the tetrachord, which spans the interval of a fourth. In such cases, two or three of these nuclear tones can appear within an octave as “important notes that make a melodic frame.” For that reason, the word “central tone” has a somewhat one-dimensional ring to it, and I think its meaning is too narrow.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4] Japanese B: “ の 意 。 古 代 ギ リ シ ア の ⾳ 楽 理 論 ⽤ 話 で 、 完 全 4 度 の 枠 を も ち 、 両 端 が 固 定 し 中 間 ⾳ が 変 化 す る 4 つ の ⾳ か ら な る ⾳ 列 を い う 。 古 代 ギ リ シ ア で は ⾳ 組 織 の 基 本 単 位 と し て ⽤ い ら れ 、 そ れ を 積 み 重 ね る こ と に よ っ て ⾳ 列 を 拡 ⼤ す る 。 テ ト ラ コ ー ド は ⾃ 然 民 族 や ⾼ ⽂ 化 を も つ ⾮ 欧 ⽶ 諸 民 族 の ⾸ 組 織 分 析 に も 援 ⽤ さ れ る が 、 そ の さ い に は 中 間 ⾳ は 2 つ と は 限 ら ず 、 1 つ と な る こ とあ る.” (Tomosha (2002), 432)

\uc5b4\ub450\uc6b4 eoduun.text: Korean A: “우선 낮은 음에서 시작합니다. B음으로서, 이것은 어두운 음이지 요. 무에서 생겨납니다. 실은 이건 피아니시모이지만, 이건 암시이지 요. 아직 음이 아닌 거지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “First of all, it begins with a low pitch [Example 1]. With the Bb, it is a dark tone. It emerges from nothing. Although it is in pianissimo, it is an implication [暗示]. It is not yet a tone.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\uc9c4\uc6b0\uc870 jin-ujo.text: Korean A: “또한, 백대웅은 우조의 종류를 진우조, 평우조, 가곡성우조의 셋으로 정리하였다. 그 중 진우 조는 우조의 성격을 가장 분명하게 드러낸 것으로, 진우조에서는 특히 하본청과 상본청의 4도 골격(라-레)이 드러나며 분위기를 고조시키는데, 이는 청을 한 음 높이는 효과를 낸다고 하였 다.” Shin (2018) [p. 239] English A: “Furthermore, Baek assigns three subcategories to Ujo: Jin-ujo, Pyeong-ujo, and Gagokseong-ujo. Jin-ujo best expresses the nature of the Ujo; in particular, the fourth interval (la-re) between haboncheong and sangboncheong heightens the atmosphere with the impact of raising one step the tonic [cheong].” Kim (2024) [3.7]

Octavas.text: Spanish A: “Como las ocho octavas al metamorfosearse al duplo necesitarían dieciséis octavas de extensión, se tendrá cuidado en composiciones metamorfoseadas al duplo y que en el original excedan de cuatro octavas, por la parte grave y la aguda, de invertir las notas que excedan de la extensión del piano, ya sea bajándolas o subiéndolas según el cas…” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 26] English A: “When metamorphosed to the double, eight octaves necessitate a range of sixteen octaves. When original compositions exceed four octaves, then, care must be taken to invert the notes that lie outside the range of the piano, either by lowering them or raising them, depending on the case.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 26] Spanish B: “La voz que completa el diapason. Este intervalo no se altera, pues es especei consonante y perfecta, y consta de cinco tonos y dos semitonos mayores, como de Ut grave, á el Ut agudo, y en este sentido decimos que salta á la Octava, que entra en la Octava del tono.” Palatín (1990) [p. 79] Spanish C: “Fórmula armónica que determina los acrodes que pueden acompañar los sonidos de l a escala diatónica mayor ó menor.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 322]

Hristov (1925).text: Hristov, Dobri. “Metrichnite i ritmichnite osnovi na b ˘ ulgarskata narodna muzika,” in Muzikalno-teoretichesko i publitsistichesko nasledstvo, vol. 1, ed. Venelin Kr ˘ ustev, Sofia 1967, pp. 33–98.

dong.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Dari 10 (sepuluh) nada yang dijiwai oleh Smara dan Ratih sebagai Dewa Percintaan bersumber pada 7 (tujuh) buah nada yang urutan nadanya sebagai berikut: ding, dong, deng, ndung, dung, dang, nding. Ketujuh nada di atas merupakan sumber bunyi dalam gambelan Bali dan menurut Prakempa bunyi (suara) itu disebut Genta Pinara Pitu (bunyi berjarak tujuh) (alinea : 7 - 10).” Bandem (1986) [p. 13] Balinese D: “1) salah satu nada pd laras ding-dong; 2) nada kedua dr gamelan gong pancanada; 3) salah satu saih yg terdapat pd perangkat gambelan Slonding dr Desa Asak, Kabupaten ten Amlapura, dg urutan nada 23 4 6 7; 4) nada yg timbul jika semua lubang pd tutupan suling ditutup, satu jari paling bawah dibuka akan menimbulkan nada déng, dua jari berikutnya dibuka akan menimbulkan nada dung, satu jari berikutnya dibuka akan menimbulkan nada dang, dan satu jari paling atas dibuka akan menimbulkan nada ding.” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 159, Bidang Istilah Musik, “ndong”]

\u0441\u0442\u0440\u0443\u043a\u0442\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “В истинския " си такт ( ¼ 6) горната песен е с тритактови фрази и шесттактово предложение, а не с класическата структура 2+2 такта в едно предложение.” Hristov (1925) (p. 50) English A: “In its true meter (7/16), the above song has three-measure phrases and six-measure sentences, and not the classical structure of 2+2 measures in one sentence.” Goldberg (2024) [5.22]

modinha.text: English A: “This autonomy of melody appears very frequently in the romantic song tradition that I call modinha-type songs. In the performance of modinhas, the vocal solo stands out in front of the arrangement, with the instrumental harmonic accompaniment laying out a known and predictable structure, a bed for the unveiling of lyrical and undulating melodies.” (Stover (2024) [2.8]) Portuguese A: “Esta autonomia da melodia aparece com grande frequência na tradição de canção romântica no que chamo de canções tipo modinha. Na performance de modinhas o solo vocal se sobressae à frente do arranjo, com o acompanhamento harmônico instrumental espalhando uma estrutura conhecida e previsível, um leito para o desvelamento de melodias líricas e onduladas.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Canto de salão, urbano, conhecido no Brasil c cm Por-tugal, com versos "a maioria das vezes anônimos. (...) Mas às vezes os poctas bons também eram musicados. Sem insistir sobre o caso famoso do mulato Caldas Barbosa cuja modinhação contumaz se tornou de citação obrigada pelo muito que fez babar de gozo os reinóis, pode-se dizer que desde os mestres da Escola Mineira até lins do Romantismo, todos os nossos poctas ilustres loram melodizados em modinhas. Dos grandes nomes românticos os mais aproveitados foram Gonçalves Dias, Álvares de Azevedo c Casimiro de Abreu. (...) Quanto à música importa desde logo salientar um problema curioso e ainda não tratado.” (Andrade (1989), 344–48) Portuguese C: “- (Bras.) (Música popular urbana). Gênero de canção amorosa e sentimental, nascida na segunda metade do séc. XVIII. Até a segunda metade do séc. XIX, foi exclusivamente música de salão, cultivada intensamente, tanto no Brasil, como em Portugal. A modinha teve uso intenso e corrente em todo o Brasil e, na sua fase popular, foi desenvolvida especialmente no Rio de Janeiro e na Bahia. A importância da modinha em nossa vida musical urbana durou até os últimos anos do séc. XIX.” (Cosme (1957) 74)

\u4e61\u97f5 xi\u0101ngy\u00f9n.text: English: “Taking again the perspective of regional vocal music research, I have proposed that there are at least five aspects to this research. […] (1) Tracing the source of “xiangyun鄉韻” (regional musical charm)…” Qian (2024)

Base de semitonos (?).text: Spanish A: “…acompañara a base de semitonos en el cual los intervalos de 4os. de tono se ampliaron a semitonos.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 27] English A: “…accompanied [my soloists] in twelve-tone equal temperament, in such a way that quarter-tone intervals were expanded to become semitones.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 27]

\u0445\u0430\u0440\u0430\u043a\u0442\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Събраният по този начин материал да се систематизира: 1) по такт, 2) по сложение на периодите, 3) по тоналност, 4) по амбитус (тонов обем), 5) по общ характер на песента (любовна, елична, обредна и пр.). Всички тия особености да се пренесат в подходящи карти-диаграми.” Hristov (1925) [p. 36] English A: “The material collected in this way should be systematized: (1) by meter, (2) by composition of the periods, (3) by tonality, (4) by ambitus (tonal range), (5) by general character of the song (love, epic, ritual, etc.). All these features should be communicated in suitable diagrammatic charts.” Goldberg (2024) [2.10]

ub\u1ecd-aka.text: English A: "What I’m holding is called ubọ-aka/It’s an Igbo musical instrument/It’s what the Igbo used to entertain themselves and be joyful in the past.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Ihe a m ji n'aka bu ubọ-aka, ubọ-aka/ọ bụ ngwa ndị Igbo/Oo ihe ndi igbo ji eme onwe ha obi añụri- ọ bụ ihe …”(Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

\u043f\u0440\u0430\u0432\u0438\u043b\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Различни комбинации от кратки и протегнати части образуват редица неправилни и правилни тактове, всеки от които служи за основа на особен танц.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “Different combinations of short and elongated parts form a series of irregular and regular meters, each of which serves as the basis for a particular dance.” Goldberg (2024) [3.2]

acento sil\u00e1bico.text: acento + silábico silábico: syllabic English A: “Brazilian Portuguese, like many other languages, uses syllabic stress as a means of phonological identification. One of the main characteristics of its accentuation patterning is the presence of a large number of paroxytonic words. This gives the language, and consequently the metric/prosodic structuring of its musical paradigm, an anacrustic tendency or feel.” (Stover (2024) [3.1]) Portuguese A: “O português brasileiro, como muitas outras línguas, usa o acento silábico como um meio de identificação fonológica. Uma das características principais de seu padrão de acentuação é a presença de um número grande de palavras paroxítonas. Isto dá à língua, e consequentemente ao paradigma musical para estruturação métrica/prosódica uma tendência ou sensação anacrústica.” (Ulhôa (1999))  Portuguese B: “Destque de sílabas.” (Cosme (1957), 4)

\uc8fc\uc74c jueum.text:
주 + 음 eum  주: main 
 Korean A: “판소리 우조와 평조의 구체적인 구성음과 주음을 제시하고 있는 개론서는 김해숙·백대웅· 최태현 공저의 전통음악개론』과 김영운의 『국악개론』이 유일하다. 전통음악개론』은 백대웅 이 필자로 참여하고 있는 바, 백대웅의 판소리 악조 이론이 그대로 제시되었다.” Shin (2018) [p. 236] English A: “Only two publications—Kim, Baek, and Choe 1999 and Kim 2015—provide scale degrees and tonics of Ujo and Pyeongjo in pansori. Baek’s pansori modal theory is presented in Kim, Baek, and Choe 1999, which he co-authored.” Kim (2024) [2.3]

\u043d\u0435\u043f\u0440\u0430\u0432\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Различни комбинации от кратки и протегнати части образуват редица неправилни и правилни тактове, всеки от които служи за основа на особен танц.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “Different combinations of short and elongated parts form a series of irregular and regular meters, each of which serves as the basis for a particular dance.” Goldberg (2024) [3.2]

\u7b5d\u66f2 s\u014dkyoku.text: Japanese A: “ただ筝曲や尺八のような器楽には、非常に自由な旋律の跳躍が見られ、核音の支配から脱しているかのように思える.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 9] English A: “In instrumental music such as pieces for the koto or shakuhachi, we can see extraordinary freedom of melodic leaps, and so one may think that they have broken away from the control of their nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [6.1] Japanese B: “雅楽において特に筝曲としての独立曲はない、平安 時代に藤原貞敏が唐から筝曲を伝えたとか石川色子が九州で唐人から 筝曲を学んだとかいう話はあるが、それは一つも残っていない。“平 家物語”には小督局が“想夫恋”という箏曲を弾いたとあるが、それ は伝説にすぎない。しかし当時*催馬楽や今様歌(越天楽今様)など に挙を合せて弾いたことは考えられる。[…] 即ち当時箏曲としては、1) 佐賀を中心と した筑紫流、2) 京阪地方を中心とした俗曲の箏曲、3) 八橋検校を祖と する箏の組歌及び段物、元禄の頃八橋検校の孫弟子に当たる生田検校 は三味線曲である地唄を箏にとり入れて世に弘めた、生田流の曲の大 部分は三味線曲の地唄との連合曲である。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 103]

Kalimba.text: English A: “Some people call it Kalimba, people of Cameroon/Some people call it Ilimba (Tanzanians)/Some others call it, I think that there are some people who call it Marimbạ.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “O nwekwa ndị na-akpọ ya Kalimba, ndị Cameroon/O nwekwa ndị na-akpọ ya Ilimba (ndi Tanzania)/Nwekwa ndị na-akpọ ya, I think o na-adi m ka o nwekwaa ndị na-akpọ ya Marimba.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

\u8907\u97f3\u97f3\u6a02 f\u00f9y\u012bn.text: Chinese A: “自複音音樂得到最美滿的發達以來，無論那一度音程，亦無論那一種聲調，都可以憑著和音的使用，得到各種性質的變換，希臘人所謂各個音類都有牠一定的特性的學說。” Li (2024)  Chinese B: “由几个频率合成的声音,波形较复杂。日常听到的声音都是复音。大多数的乐器声和人声都是复音.” Zhongwai guangbo (1995) (p. 695) English: Polyphony or polyphonic music. “Since the consummate development of polyphonic music, the use of harmony has had the capability to alter the nature of any interval or mode.” Li (2024) [1.12–1.13]

tremolo.text: English A: “In “Canção da América,” the words expand by leaps with or without portamento, melisma, tremolo, the most diverse appoggiaturas, mordents and grupetos, highlighting the emotional content of the song: the heart cries for escape—the feeling trapped in the chest—and to reestablish the bonds of friendship you have to listen to your heart, no matter what happens. (Carvalho 1990, 325–30).” (Stover (2024) [5.7]) Portuguese A: “Em "Canção da América" as palavras expandidas por saltos com ou sem portamento, melisma, tremolo, appoggiaturas as mais diversas, mordentes e grupetos, realçam o conteúdo emocional da canção: o coração chora pela partida - o sentimento preso no peito - e para reestabelecer os laços de amizade tem-se que ouvir o coração, não importa o que aconteça. (p. 325-10).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Desdobramento de uma figura em valores menores obtido pela repetição rápida de uma nota, ou pela rápida alternância entre duas notas ou acordes. Este recurso tem seu melhor efeito quando e-xecutado por instrumentos de cordas. É menos usado ao piano e é impraticável à maior parte dos instrumentos de sopro e ao órgão. O trêmolo é grafado através de curtas barras que indicam também o valor a ser utilizado na execução. V. fioritura. (DM-MA)” (Andrade (1989), 528)

samas nyata.text: English A: “The technique of plucking the genggong is called amebet lati; its sound is samas nyata.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.15]) See genggong  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang anyetat genggong disebut amebet lati, samas nyata nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The genggong is a jew’s harp made with a wooden tongue set in a small frame held in the mouth. One vibrates the tongue by jerking a stick tied to a cord attached to the tongue; the sound is resonated by the oral cavity. Amebet means tide or wave, and lati is lips, thus, a wave of sound coming from the lips. Samas means four hundred and nyata means to drain or to dry—is Geria saying that after so many yanks one’s mouth is dry? None of my Balinese interlocutors know.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.14]) *Lexical field: Natural world (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\ubcc0\uc870 byeonjo.text: Korean A: “우조의 경우, 하청은 떠는 기능을 갖고 있지 않고, 반종지하는 음이다. 하본청은 전조와 변조 에 기능하는 음으로서 그 역할이 작지 않고, 옥타브 위에서는 우조 특유의 씩씩한 느낌을 주는 핵심적인 음이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238-239] English A: “In Ujo, hacheong is the note of a half cadence, without the capacity for vibration. It plays a significant role in transposition and modulation and, when used above the octave, contributes to the distinctive and energizing quality of Ujo.” Kim (2024) [3.6]

\u7ba1\u5f26 kangen.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) Japanese B: “①広い意味で管楽器と絃楽器を合奏する形式、②雅楽 において楽器だけの合奏、舞楽に対して用いる。左方では管(竜笛, 篳篥,笙)絃(琵琶,箏)鼓(太鼓、鉦鼓、鞨鼓)の合奏、右方では 管(狛笛,篳篥)紘(琵琶,箏)鼓(太鼓,鉦鼓,三ノ鼓)の合奏、 しかし近代右方の楽は舞楽だけに用いるので紋は用いない。したがっ て唯管と鼓の合奏だけでも舞が伴わなければ管絃の部に入る。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 40]

Goldberg (2024).text: Goldberg, Daniel. 2024. “Translation of Dobri Hristov’s “Metric and Rhythmic Fundamentals of Bulgarian Folk Music.”” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

\uc74c\uc758\ub192\uc774 eumui nopi.text: Korean A: “중요한 것은, 본청과 상청의 음정 간격, 즉 상청의 음높이가 우조길과 평조길을 구분 하는 핵심이 된다고 설명하여, 상청 음의 높이로 우조와 평조를 분별한다.” Shin (2018) [p. 239] English A: “The five notes comprising Baek’s Ujo-gil in pansori are sol, la, do, re, and mi, with do serving as the mode’s tonic [boncheong]. The interval between boncheong and sangcheong, that is, the relative pitch of sangcheong, is the determining factor in distinguishing Ujo-gil from Pyeongjo-gil.” Kim (2024) [3.8]

\u4e3b\u8981\u97f3\u97ff shuy\u014d onky.text: Japanese A: “も ち ろ ん こ れ は 線 的 な も の な ん で す 。 単 ⾳ 的 な 意 味 で す 。 単 旋 律 的 な 意 味 で す 。 し か し 、 今 度 は 単 旋 律 と い う 要 素 が 重 な る と 、 主 要 ⾳ 響 に な る わ け で す 。 線 が 束 に な っ て 流 れ て い る こ と に な り ま す 。 だ か ら 、⼀ つ ⼀ つ か ら す れ ば 主 要 ⾳ で あ り 、 束 に な っ て 流 れ れ ば 主 要 ⾳ 響 で あ り ま す 。 そ し て そ れ ら の ⼀ つ ⼀ つが 似 て い る わ け で す 。 似 て い て 、 し か も 全 体 が 同 ⼀ 性 を 持 っ て い る と い う こ と で す.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 52) English A: "It refers to a singular note and a singular melodic line. But when linear elements are stacked, they become Hauptklang [主要音響].(7) Lines become a bundle and begin to flow. In short, each line is Hauptton, and when it is bundled and flows it is Hauptklang. In other words, each of the lines is analogous while the whole is uniform." (Park (2024)  [1.7])

ngoktap.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  “This alternative term for ngembat, from the English “octave” is a loan word Geria probably learned when teaching in Java.” Tenzer (2024) [Footnote 7] See: ngembat

nam/na\u1e43.text: Sinhalese A: “tat-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? jit-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? ton-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? nam-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki?” Peiris (2024) [9] English A: “Unto whom is the syllable tat a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable jit a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable ton a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable nam a salutation?” Peiris (2024) [9] English A: “These four strokes (and associated timbres) are termed “seed syllables” (bīja akṣara) and they are named as follows: tat—a damped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 8; see also Video 4), dit (or dik or jit)—a damped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 9; see also Video 5), ton (or tom or toṃ)—an undamped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 10; see also Video 6), and nam (or naṃ)—an undamped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 11; see also Video 7).” (Peiris (2024) [4.1]) English B: mnemonic syllable for a drum stroke (Peiris (2025))

Songci da (2003).text: Songci da cidian 宋词大辞典. Wang Zhoapeng 王兆鹏, Liu Zunming 刘尊明 (eds.). Nanjing: Fenghuang chuban she 南京:凤凰出版社, 2003.

\u8df3\u8e8d\u7684\u306a\u529b ch\u014dy.text: 跳躍: jump, leap, skip, bound 力: force, strength, power Japanese A: “また１つの核音の支配圏から脱して他の核音の圏に移るには、それだけの旋律構成上の力がなければならない。したがって核音による区分の縦線は、その次に来る旋律の跳躍的な力を意味する重要な句節法となる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 6] English A: “Also, in order to escape one nuclear tone’s sphere of control and move to another nuclear tone’s sphere, the melody must be strongly constructed. Therefore, the vertical lines that I have drawn to divide these melodies by their governing nuclear tones can be seen as illustrating an important phrasal principle, which indicates how the upcoming melody will be able to leap [leaping power].” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3, brackets added separately] See also 旋律の跳躍 senritsu no chōyaku

\u610f\u8b58 ishiki.text: Japanese A: “先生が獄中で書かれたオペラのことですが、先生は健康も害されて、その オペラ自体は演奏される見通しすらない し、その作品自体が獄中から出れるかど うかもわからない、そういった中で、意 識を超越して一気にお書きになったとう かがったのですが。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 59] English A: “Regarding the opera you had composed while in prison [Die Witwe des Schmetterlings (Butterfly Widow)], at the time, you were in poor health, there was no perspective for its performance, and you weren’t even sure whether you could transport the score outside of the prison cell. How were you able to overcome senses [意識] and compose in these circumstances with one stroke?” Park (2024) [6.1]

\u30d8\u30c6\u30ed\u30d5\u30a9\u30cb\u30.text: Japanese A: "西村それで私が少し感じるのは、これは全く当たっていないかもしれませんが、ヘテロフォニーという考え方がございま すね。あれは非常に単純に割り切った言い方をしてしまえば、主になる旋律と、同時に装飾的なものが存在する。一つの本質のものが、同時に多像をとりながら共存していくのが、ヘテロフォニーの形だと思うんですが、先生がいまおっしゃったことからすると、その「ハウプト・トン」とヘテロフォニーとは関係があるのではないでしょうか。" (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) English A: "I have sensed from your description, maybe I am off-topic here, but do you know the term “heterophony”? To put it concisely, it means the coexistence of the main melody and an embellishing melody. I think, in heterophony, an essential idea simultaneously takes various appearances [상, 像] and they coexist. Based on what you have described, wouldn’t there be a correlation between the Hauptton concept and heterophony?" (Park (2024) [2.1]) Japanese B: “同一旋律を複数の奏者が演奏するとき、即興的な装飾や変形などのため、音程やリズムにずれを生じた状態。民族音楽では、伴奏楽器が歌と同旋律を装飾的に演奏することで、この状態を生じることが多い。” (Tomosha (2002), 620)

\u0442\u0430\u043a\u0442\u043e\u0432\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Различни комбинации от кратки и протегнати части образуват редица неправилни и правилни тактове, всеки от които служи за основа на особен танц. Така образуваните тактове ще нарека тактове от първа група.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “Different combinations of short and elongated parts form a series of irregular and regular meters, each of which serves as the basis for a particular dance. The meters formed in this way will be called the first group of meters:” Goldberg (2024) [3.2]

\u6b4c\u5531 kash\u014d.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 、 先 ⽣ の 作 品 の 線 的 な 語 法 の も と に な っ て い る わ け で す ね 。 微 分 ⾳ 的 な 細 か い 揺 れ か ら 3 度 以 上 の シ ェ イ ク に ⾄ る よ う な 、 独 特 な 線 の 動 き は 、 韓 国 の 歌 唱 の ⽅ 法 か ら ⽣ み 出 さ れ た も の と 考 え て い い わ け で す ね .” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4]) Japanese B: “人間の基本的表現手段である声を用いた音楽的行為は、文明の最初期からみられる。ここで、鳥のさえずりと人間の歌を区別する目安は、言葉を伝えるものか否かという点にあり、15世紀の音楽理論家*ティンクトーリスもリズム・音程・発声とならんで発音の重要性を指摘している。言葉をいかに明確に歌うかということ（*デクラメーション）は、歌唱芸術（創作・演奏）の課題であった。したがって、ハミングやヴォカリーズなどは歌唱の特殊形態と考えるべきであるう。” (Tomosha (2002), 137–138)

intergenerational transmission.text: Source: “Igbo ubọ-aka music is an oral tradition maintained through intergenerational transmission and rote learning. However, Eze is among a small group of ubọ-aka players in Anambra state who use standard music notation to record and transmit ubọ-aka pieces, particularly the purpose of teaching the instrument.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [4.1]

International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA).text: Source: “Qian’s attention to Sinitic traditional music and its regional varieties diverges from scholarship on Mandarin opera and popular music, which has been the focus of English-language scholarship on Mandarin vocal music. But the challenge is how to analyze this music. She advocates for the use of IPA. For example, her Shuang Yin Vocal Notation includes an IPA text with tone notation under (Western) staff notation.” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [9]

interpretativas.text: English A: “A complete study of musical prosody—including intonation, accent, melody, rhythm, and specific interpretative practices—is beyond the limits of this article, which is limited to discussing melody, melody and spoken language, and the relationship between melody and accompaniment in Brazilian popular song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Um estudo completo da prosodia musical - incluindo entonação, acento, melodia, ritmo e práticas interpretativas específicas - foge aos limites deste estudo, que se limita a discutir melodia, melodia e língua falada e a relação melodia e acompanhamento na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “However, much of the musical meaning only emerges during the moment of performance. In performance, and especially in the case of popular song, singers use their interpretive skills to articulate and highlight the emotional content of each song.” (Stover (2024) [5.11]) Portuguese B: “Entretanto, muito do significado musical só emerge durante o momento da performance. Na performance, e, principalmente no caso da canção popular, cantores usam sua habilidade interpretativa para articular e salientar o conteúdo emocional de cada canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

singer.text: 소리꾼 sorikkun (Korean) Source: “The translator’s choice of Shin Eun-Joo’s article on pansori is perfectly suited to presenting such an introduction. Pansori is one of the most important genres in Korean traditional music. Although frequently compared to Western classical opera due to their shared vocal and theatrical attributes, pansori is essentially an epic, narrative storytelling vocal performance executed by a singer and a drum accompanist without stage design or theatrical costumes. Unlike court or ritual music, pansori was first circulated among commoners and the lower class, and later enjoyed by all classes as a principal form of entertainment.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “One who sings; a trained vocalist” (Oxford English Dictionary, “singer”)

\ud3c9\uc6b0\uc870 pyeong-ujo.text: Korean A: “또한, 백대웅은 우조의 종류를 진우조, 평우조, 가곡성우조의 셋으로 정리하였다. 그 중 진우 조는 우조의 성격을 가장 분명하게 드러낸 것으로, 진우조에서는 특히 하본청과 상본청의 4도 골격(라-레)이 드러나며 분위기를 고조시키는데, 이는 청을 한 음 높이는 효과를 낸다고 하였 다.” Shin (2018) [p. 239] English A: “Furthermore, Baek assigns three subcategories to Ujo: Jin-ujo, Pyeong-ujo, and Gagokseong-ujo. Jin-ujo best expresses the nature of the Ujo; in particular, the fourth interval (la-re) between haboncheong and sangboncheong heightens the atmosphere with the impact of raising one step the tonic [cheong].” Kim (2024) [3.7]

\u65cb\u5bab xu\u00e1n g\u014dng.text: Definitions: Chinese A: “旋宫”指的是：宫音在十二律上的位置有所移动，这时，商、角、徵、羽各阶在十二律上的位置当然也随之相应移动。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) （旋宫) Chinese B: “古代以五声、七声配十二律,使十二律轮流作为宫音,以构成不同调高的五声、七声等音阶,称“旋相为宫”,简称“旋宫”。《礼记·礼运》:“五声六律十二管旋相为宫。”新构成的音阶依据宫音所在的黄钟、大吕……等律,称为黄钟均、大吕均……等.” Zhongguo gudian (1991) (p. 290) For further discussion, see also:  Zhongguo qu xue (1997) (p. 675), Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (”旋宫”, p. 442) English: “…the transformations from one pentatonic scale to another (Du 2019; Du and Qin 2007, 200–233). These transformations are known variously as xuangong 旋宮, modulation (zhuandiao/fandiao 轉調/犯調), or the theory of 60 modes (liushidiao 六十調). The terms collectively describe modal relations involving the cycles of five pentatonic positions, of twelve chromatic pitch classes, and of their product (12 × 5 = 60).” Lam (2024)  “Xuangong means “to rotate gong,” or for a lülü “to rotate as gong.” Lam (2024)

\u0440\u0443\u0441\u043a\u0438\u044f \u0.text: Bulgarian A: “По стъпките (две кратки и една протегната) ръченицата прилича на чешкия народен танц полка. А по чупене на тялото (особени движения на ръцете, краката и приклякане) ръченицата прилича твърде много на руския казачок, на словенския танц хошие на маджарския чардаш.” Hristov (1925) (p. 48) English A: “In its steps (two short and one elongated), the rŭchenitsa resembles the Czech national dance, polka. But in twisting the body (especially the movements of the hands and feet and squatting) the rŭchenitsa very much resembles the Russian kazachok (fast 2/4 meter), the Slovenian dance hoshie (2/4) [Example 12], and the Hungarian csárdás.” Goldberg (2024) [5.18] Bulgarian B: “Казачок (рус.) украински и руски народен танц в 2/4 такт, в началото в сдържано темпо, което постепенно се ускорява; изпълнява се по двойки, при ръководна роля на девойката, която с пляскане на ръце, предупреждава за смяната на фигурите. Има импровизационен характер. Във втората половина на 18 в. се появява на балетната сцена във Франция. К. влиза в творчеството на руските композитори, напр. К. от Даргомижски за симф. оркестър.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 128, “Казачок”]

\u30d4\u30a2\u30ce piano.text: Japanese A: “ピアノもないし、机もないし、 鉛筆と紙だけだったんです。それからテ キスト。私がそういう状態でも音符を書 かなければならなかったのは、自分が死 んでしまえば、自分の中に残っているた くさんの音楽は自分とともに死んでしま う。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 60] English A: “No piano, no desk, only pencil and paper. And the text. The reason why I could not stop writing the notes even in that situation was that if I die then and there, the music in me also dies.” Park (2024) [6.3] Japanese B: “ピアノフォルテの略称。楽器分類上は箱形ツイターに属する有鍵打弦楽器で，グランド型とアップライト型の2種類に分けられる。グランド型が本来で、チェンバロから形状を受けついでいる。大きさは、家庭用の長さが1.5mに満たないものから、3m近いフル・コンサート型まで各種あり、音域は7オクターヴと3音である。” (Tomosha (2002), 544)

\u6d41\u308c\u308b\u7dda Nagareru sen.text: Japanese A: “流 れ る 線 の 中 に 重 要 な ⾳ が あ り 、 そ れを 囲 む ⾳ す べ て が 「 主 要 ⾳ 」 だ” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: “Within a flowing line [流れる線], there is one important tone [音].
