With this tone in the center, I call all sounds that surround it Hauptton [主要音].” (Park (2024) [1])

concep\u00e7\u00e3o r\u00edtmica europei.text: English A: “One of the basic principles of European rhythmic construction, which was in the process of being developed at the time of the discovery of Brazil, as Manuel Veiga would say, is the concept of meter (compasso), or the metric verticalization of musical structure.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “Um dos princípios básicos da concepção rítmica europeia, em processo de estruturação na época do achamento do Brasil, como diria Manuel Veiga, é a concepção de compasso, ou verticalização métrica da estrutura musical.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u0430\u043c\u0431\u0438\u0442\u0443\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Събраният по този начин материал да се систематизира: 1) по такт, 2) по сложение на периодите, 3) по тоналност, 4) по амбитус (тонов обем), 5) по общ характер на песента (любовна, елична, обредна и пр.). Всички тия особености да се пренесат в подходящи карти-диаграми.” Hristov (1925) [p. 36] English A: “The material collected in this way should be systematized: (1) by meter, (2) by composition of the periods, (3) by tonality, (4) by ambitus (tonal range), (5) by general character of the song (love, epic, ritual, etc.). All these features should be communicated in suitable diagrammatic charts.” Goldberg (2024) [2.10] Bulgarian B: “Амбитус (лат. ambitus обхождане, обиколка) интервалът, образуван между найниския и най-високия тон в една мелодия, независимо от тоновото и съдържание. А. се измерва в тонове, полутонове, и коми*. Мелодии с еднакъв А. могат да имат различно тоново съдържание. Обикновено по-простите, по-първобитните народни мелодии имат и по-тесен А., а мелодии с широк А., съчетани и с богато тоново съдържание, са указание и за по-сложно музикално мислене.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 20-21]

\u97f3\u968e onkai.text: 音+階 音 oto : sound 階: stairs Japanese A: “このどちらもが、日本の音階と旋律法のヨーロッパとの違いはもちろん、アジア音楽の中での、特異性をきわめて明確に規定する要素なのであるが、ここではまず前者について考えて見よう。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] English A: “For both of these, the differences between Japanese musical [scalar] rules and those of Europe are of course the elements make Asian music seem so extremely peculiar.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1, brackets added separately] Japanese B: “⽤ い ら れ る ⾳ を ⾼ さ の 順 に 配 列 し た も の は 、⼀定 の ⾳ 程 関 係 を く り 返 す 形 で な ら ぶ が 、 そ の くり 返 し の 最 ⼩ の 単 位 を ⾳ 階 と い う 。” (Tomosha (2002), 119–120) See more in attached pdf.

danzones.text: Portuguese A: “É uma realização imediata e espontânea das nossas maneiras de dançar, mais sensuais, provindas do clima talvez, e do amolecimento fisiológico das raças que se caldearam pra nos formar e formaram também o remeleixo, o requebro, o dengue. É o movimento dengoso do corpo na dança que deformou a rítmica da polca primeiramente na rítmica da habanera em seguida no do maxixe. Acresce ainda que em habaneras e danzones é comum o elemento da tercina (ver se a tercina ocorre no primeiro tempo).” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Here, syncopation is of immediate, constant, and directly choreographic application. In America, syncopation does not come from European syncopation. It is an immediate and spontaneous realization of our ways of dancing, more sensual, perhaps stemming from the climate, and the physiological softening of the races that melded to form us and also formed the remeleixo, the requebro, the dengue. It is the languid body movement in dance that deformed the rhythm of the polka first into the rhythm of the habanera and then into that of the maxixe. Furthermore, in habaneras and danzones, the element of triplet (check if the triplet occurs on the first beat) is common.” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “Dança popular em compasso 2/4, muito dilundida cmCuba, originada nas danzas cubanas importadas de França em fins de 1800;"começa com uma introdução ou cedazo pelos bailarinos, que consta geralmente de uma frase melódica de oito compassos que se repctem, seguida pela 'parte dos clarinetes', assim chamada por ser quase um'obligato' para estes instrumentos e que consta, normalmente, de dezesseis compassos.Depois se repete a introdução. Cada uma destas segundas partes apresenta temas melódicos diferentes, chegando algumas vezes a trinta e dois compassos de extensão, sem que haja, porém, uma regra fixa a respeito do número de compassos que deva ter cada segunda parte." Sua estrutura pode assim variar de AB - AC a ABACADAE. (Sanchez de Fuentes y Pelaéz, E. El folk-lor en la musica cubana, 1923, p. 28).” (Andrade (1989) 183–84)

\u7d14\u7c8b\u306a\u97f3 junsuina oto.text:
純粋 + 音 oto  純粋: pure, true, genuine (see also: 純粋性 junsuisei) 
 Japanese A: “だから、そういうイマジ ネーションが、ところどころにつかめる だけなんです。しかし、私にとっては作 曲家としてそういうようなファンタジー を持つことが、創作の大きな力となって います。純粋な音だけによって、一九六 ○年代から七〇年の初期まで作曲をしま した。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 59] English A: “In other words, those imaginations are only captured here and there. As a composer, however, those fantastical stories greatly aid my creative process. I had been composing with pure sounds [absolute music?] from the 1960s until the early 1970s.” Park (2024) [5.2]

\u7bc0\u56de bushi kai.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 今 度 は 器 楽 曲 に 移 り ま し て 、 す べ て の 器 楽 曲 は ま ず 声 楽 から 受 け 継 い で 、 そ れ を 発 展 さ せ た も の とい っ て も い い わ け で す 。 た と え ば 「 ⽝ 等 」と い い ま し て 、 横 笛 を ⾧ く し た 形 の 韓 国 の 民 族 楽 器 が あ り ま し て 、 そ れ で 奏 さ れ る 節 回 し は 歌 唱 を 受 け 継 い だ も の で す 。そ し て 、 そ こ に は 線 的 な ⾳ 楽 の 妙 味 が ある わ け で す.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5])

\ubc18\uc885\uc9c0 ban-jongji.text: English A: “This translation presented unique challenges, particularly regarding the original author’s use of Western musical concepts such as letter names, solfège, staff notation, and the concepts of key (joseong 조성), half cadence (ban-jongji 반종지), and cadence (jongji 종지).” (Kim (2024) [0.4]) Korean B: “우조의 경우, 하청은 떠는 기능을 갖고 있지 않고, 반종지하는 음이다. 하본청은 전조와 변조 에 기능하는 음으로서 그 역할이 작지 않고, 옥타브 위에서는 우조 특유의 씩씩한 느낌을 주는 핵심적인 음이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238-239] English B: “In Ujo, hacheong is the note of a half cadence, without the capacity for vibration. It plays a significant role in transposition and modulation and, when used above the octave, contributes to the distinctive and energizing quality of Ujo.” Kim (2024) [3.6]

thumb piano.text: Source: “Over time, the Zimbabwean term mbira has been generalized to represent all thumb pianos, including those found in Africa and South America (Kubik and Cooke 2001). The generalization of the indigenous name suggests that the Zimbabwean instruments, probably owing to Tracey’s promotion, have served in the Anglophone world as important representatives of this family of lamellophones.” Chow commentary (2024) [1]

nyillasih.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan nyiliasih artinya pukulan kembali dari tepi mengarah ke tengah sama bekerja. Pukulan ini adalah pukulan silih berganti dari tepi ke tengah.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Nyiliasih is a motion from one end of the instrument toward its middle with [the two hands] playing in alternation.” Tenzer (2024) [III.2] “Nyiliasih means to love one another, here in reference to the graceful motion of the two hands crossing over one another.” Tenzer (2024) [3.3] *Lexical field: Emotions or character (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u5bfa\u9662\u2fb3\u697d\u00a0Tera in y\.text: Japanese A: “そ し て 韓 国 に は 厳 格 な⽴ 場 を と る 雅 楽 ⾳ 楽 と は 別 に 、 宮 廷 ⾳ 楽 で も 寺 院 ⾳ 楽 で も な い 、⼀ 般 ⼤ 衆 と 上 流 社 会 が 共 有 し て き た 、 西 洋 に ⾒ ら れ る よ う な 知 識 社 会 で 楽 し ん で き た ⾳ 楽 世 界 が ま だ あ り ま す 。 そ れ か ら ま た 芸 術 歌 曲 、芸 術 民 謡 と い い ま す か 、 そ う い う も の が あ り ま す " (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3])

pasu.text: English A: “Thus there is pasu [materials made from domesticated animals], pasu connotes the beginning, the origin of sound and energy. This is why there is sound and thought; because it can know the mind, the mind creates, the mind makes sound. Sound makes energy, there is thought, sound, energy, this is the significance of the origin in pasu.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.2]) Balinese A: “Hana saking pasu, pitegesing pasu, ngaran babad; pitegesing babad, ngaran wiwit, wiwiting sabda bayu. Ika marmanya hana sabda idep; apan kawruhaning idep, idep anyipta, idep angawe sabda. Sabda angawe bayu, hana idep, sabda, bayu, mangkana pitegesing babad.” (Geria (n.d.))

eli-v\u00e4\u1e6da.text: English A: “The Sinhala verses in both the däkum ata (Paragraph 9) and the upat kavi (Paragraphs 30–37) follow the cyclic format known as sivpada (Sin. quatrain), in which each line of poetry contains an approximately equal number of morae and ends with eli-väṭa (Sin. rhyming/assonant phonemes). As mentioned, the Sinhala däkum ata verses (Paragraph 9) contain eighteen morae per line.” Peiris (2024) [17] English B: “rhyme” (Peiris (2025)

sensation.text: Source A: “But Geria gradually passes from Prakempa’s metaphysical style to a discourse on the play of tones and the concrete sensations they produce. Having sculpted these worlds as continuous, even a non-Balinese reader can connect the umwelt of precolonial Bali to an international emergent music theory based on earthly perception and cognition.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.6]) Source B: “Which is to say that the entry of “tickling” here both closes and opens the gap to the direct confrontation of touch. The sound both raises the sensation associated with a kind of touch-play while also safeguarding it away from immediate touch, where tickling is more likely to be a source, say, of a sustained and mild pleasure than a body-contorting pleasure/panic.” (Wang commentary (2024) [2.6]) Definition: “A physical feeling; spec. a mental state resulting from a stimulus operating on any of the senses or from a condition of part of the body.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “sensation” 1a)

\u044e\u0447\u0430\u0442\u0430/yuchata.text: Bulgarian A: “ В Сливенско, Ямболско, също в Болград играят особена пайдушка наречена ючата, ескийската, в Берковско като обикновено хоро, а в Брезнишко и Трънско — „Четворка"” Hristov (1925) [p. 44] English A: “In the Sliven and Yambol regions, as well as in Bolgrad, they dance a specific paidushka, called yuchata or eskiiskata; in the Berkovitsa region paidushka is danced as a normal horo, and in the Breznik and Trŭn regions, as a “chetvorka.”” Goldberg (2024) [5.6]

\u7dca\u5f35\u529b kinch\u014dryoku.text: Japanese A: “走り ながら、今度は生命力を、緊張力を高め るためにヴィヴラートを生じさせるわけで す。ヴィヴラートによって、集中力と緊張 感を増します。そしてメリスマ的な要素 が加わります。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “As it runs, it creates vibratos in order to heighten its lifeforce and tension. Through vibrato, the concentration and tension are increased. And melismatic elements are added.” Park (2024) [4.1]

Py\u01d2n (2012).text: Pyŏn, Mi-hye. Kugak yongŏ sajŏn = Korean music terms dictionary. Ch’op’an. Sŏul: Minsogwŏn, 2012. Print.

akpo\u0323kwa.text: Igbo A: “Na emekwa ya n'egwu m/Na-akpọkwa ya n'egwu” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) English A: “I use it in my musical ensemble/I perform it in songs.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

sincroniza\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “In this text I expand on some aspects raised by Andrade, putting up for discussion a hypothesis about musical prosody in Brazilian popular song, the concept of fluid meter [métrica derramada], which refers both to aspects of synchronization between singing and accompaniment and to issues of accentuation in the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.7]) Portuguese A: “Neste texto amplio alguns aspectos levantados por Mário de Andrade, colocando para discussão uma hipótese sobre a prosódia musical da canção brasileira popular, o conceito de métrica derramada, que se refere tanto a aspectos de sincronização entre canto e acompanhamento como a questões de acentuação na canção.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “In metric music of the European tradition, all parts tend to synchronize precisely; time is counted in regular pulsations, generally contained within binary or ternary measures, whose limits are represented by barlines, with an accent at the beginning of each measure.” (Stover (2024) [5.12]) Portuguese B: “Na música medida de tradição européia todas as partes tendem a se sincronizar precisamente; o tempo é contado em pulsações regulares, geralmente contidos em compassos binários ou ternários, cujos limites são representados por barras de compasso, com uma acentuação no começo de cada compasso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

t\u00f4nicas.text: English A: “Although each word may have its stressed and unstressed syllables, it is the logic of the sentence that prevails. Depending on its location in a verse or phrase, an accented word or syllable may have its accent nullified, or the phrase may vary in terms of syllable limits, and its syllables may even be prosodic or metric, as in the word luar, which can be counted as a monosyllabic word, like “luar,” or two-syllable, like “lu-ar” (Carvalho 1970).” (Stover (2024) [3.3]) Portuguese A: “Embora cada palavra possa ter suas sílabas tônicas e átonas, é a lógica da sentença que prevalece. Dependendo da sua localização num verso ou frase, uma palavra ou sílaba acentuada pode ter seu acento negligenciado, ou variar em termos de limites silábicos, podendo inclusive as sílabas serem prosódicas ou métricas, como na palavra luar, que pode ser contada como palavra monossilábica, como luar, ou dissílaba, como lu-ar (Carvalho 1970).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “A primeira nota duma escala tonal.” (Cosme (1957) 121)

\uc74c\uc758\ube44\uc911 eumui bijung.text: Korean A: “이는, 민요에서 토리를 이야기할 때 단순히 출현음만을 제시하지 않고 떨고, 꺾고, 흘리는 등의 시김새와 음의 비중, 종지 등을 언급해야 하는 것과 마찬가지이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 248] English A: “When discussing tori in a folk song, it is important to not only list the individual notes but also include details like shaking, bending, falling, the value [sonic gravity] of each pitch, and the cadence.” Kim (2024) [3.32, brackets added separately]

\u5185\u754c n\u00e8i j\u00ece.text: Chinese A: “我們這裏姑就人類來說，凡屬人類，不問他是到了怎麼樣的文化程度，遇着說出來的話不能夠滿足他的內界要求的時候，他總會由自己的內界發出一些聲響來，或歡笑，或愁歎，這些由人們的內界發出來的自然的聲響，就是音樂的原素。音樂是用來補救說話的缺乏的一種語言，這就是希臘人對於音樂的根本理解.” Li (2024) [1.16] English A: “However civilized a human being is, when confronted with speech that fails to satisfy the demands of their inner realm (neijie), it will inevitably produce sounds—be they joyful or sorrowful—that arise from within. These natural sounds from the inner realm are the sources of Music. Music is a language that compensates for the limitations of speech. This fundamental understanding of Music constituted the core belief held by the Greeks.” Li (2024) [1.16] For more commentary on the inner realm, see Li (2024) [2.1, 2.6, 2.10, 2.12, 2.15] and Footnote 23 Chinese B: “眾生之身心，分內外二界，身體為外界，心意為內界。又，六界中地水火風空之五界為外界，第六之識界為內界。” Ding (1969) (四画) Chinese C: “眾生之身心，分內外二界，身體為外界，心意為內界。又，六界中地水火風空之五界為外界，第六之識界為內界.” Hanyu dacidian (内界)

\u5c3a\u516b shakuhachi.text: 尺+八 尺: Japanese foot, measure, scale, rule 八: eight Japanese A: “ただ筝曲や尺八のような器楽には、非常に自由な旋律の跳躍が見られ、核音の支配から脱しているかのように思える.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 9] English A: “In instrumental music such as pieces for the koto or shakuhachi, we can see extraordinary freedom of melodic leaps, and so one may think that they have broken away from the control of their nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [6.1] Japanese B: “東洋における縦笛、中国で管長1尺8寸と定めたのでこれを“尺八”と称したというのが通説で あるが、事実は長短各種あり、おそらくチュパと いう楽器名に尺八の字を当てたものらしい、歴史 では唐初呂才が創作したと称されている。おそら く古来の洞簫を改革したものであろう、特徴 は歌口が斜めに削り取ってあることである。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 84]

bossa nova.text: English A: “However, with bossa nova, there was an aesthetic shift in the relationship between melody and harmony. Before the bossa nova “revolution,” harmony functioned mainly as support for a relatively autonomous melody. The emergence of bossa nova, with its emphasis on a “parlando” style and colloquial singing, as well as its use of complex harmonic progressions, represented a break with the romantic style of the time, which had become cliché. Bossa nova favored a cool and more restrained diction, with artistic and literary intentions.” (Stover (2024) [2.9]) Portuguese A: “Entretanto, com a bossa nova houve um deslocamento estético nesta relação entre melodia e harmonia na canção. Antes da "revolução" bossanovista a harmonia funcionava principalmente como suporte para uma melodia relativamente autônoma. O aparecimento da bossa nova, com sua ênfase num estilo "parlando" e canto coloquial, bem como seu uso de progressões harmônicas complexas, representou uma ruptura com o estilo romântico mais antigo. Nos anos sessenta, a expressão melodramática tornara-se cliché. Bossa nova privilegiava uma dicção mais "cool" e contida com intenções artísticas e literárias.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Bossa–Letra pra dança popular (Rio de Janeiro).” (Andrade (1989), 69)

\u0431\u0435\u0437\u043c\u0435\u043d\u04.text: безмензурн + песни/pesni  безмензурн: without measures Bulgarian A: “Освен песни с точно определен такт в народната ни музика има твърде много песни, лишени от всякаква следа на каквто и да е такт.Тези песни могат да се нарекат безмензурни (безтактови) и се отличават със съвършено волно движение (ad libitum) без определен ритъм.В безмензурните ни песни някои слогове са твъорде много протегнати и правят декламацията неестествена. Друг съществен белег на тия песни са непрекъснатите сложни фиоритури (рулади).” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “In addition to songs with precisely defined meter, in our folk music there are rather many songs that are devoid of all traces of any kind of meter. These songs can be called unmeasured (unmetered), and they are distinguished by a completely free pulse (ad libitum) without a determinate rhythm. In our unmeasured songs some syllables are quite elongated, making the declamation unnatural. Another essential characteristic of these songs is the continuous use of complex fiorituri (roulades).” Goldberg (2024) [4.1] Bulgarian B: “български народни песни, които се пеят с голяма свобода, чести фермати* и богата орнаментика и не са подчинени на определен метрум. Народът ги нарича „проточени", „провлечени", „на трапеза". Срещат се и инструментални безмензурни мелодии, които народните музиканти изпълняват с голямо майсторство на кавал, гайда* или гъдулка*.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 43]

motivos.text: English A: “The melody of a popular song is generally composed of the repetition or grouping of short melodic motifs: melodic-rhythmic formulas that function as “blocks of meaning,” as Gino Stefani (1987) puts it, ready to be incorporated, repeated, combined, or associated in creating the song.” (Stover (2024) [2.1]) Portuguese A: “A melodia da canção popular é geralmente composta a partir da repetição ou agrupamento de motivos melódicos curtos, espécie de fórmulas melódico-rítmicas que funcionam como "blocos de significação", como coloca Gino Stefani, prontos para serem incorporados, repetidos, combinados ou associados na feitura da canção. “ (Ulhôa (1999))

heterarchical.text: Source: “Prakempa’s pivotal mandala-like illustration, the pangider bhuwana (dispersion around the cosmos; see Example 1) comprises heterarchical groupings of tones, letters, colors, gods, and parts of the body, each “installed” at one of ten cardinal direction points (North, Northeast, East, Southeast, South, Southwest, West, Northwest, and above and below the Center).” (Tenzer (2024) [0.5]) Definition: “heterarchy, form of management or rule in which any unit can govern or be governed by others, depending on circumstances, and, hence, no one unit dominates the rest. Authority within a heterarchy is distributed. A heterarchy possesses a flexible structure made up of interdependent units, and the relationships between those units are characterized by multiple intricate linkages that create circular paths rather than hierarchical ones. Heterarchies are best described as networks of actors—each of which may be made up of one or more hierarchies—that are variously ranked according to different metrics. Etymologically speaking, the term is made up of the Greek words heteros, meaning “the other,” and archein, meaning “to rule.”” (Britannica, “heterarchy”)

lied.text: Portuguese A: “Na infinita maioria dos casos ocorre dentro do conceito de lied. É na canção, e principalmente na canção exclusivamente instrumental (o que é importante para esta observação) que ocorre síncopas. (dar exemplos). [Estudar os flamengos e os ante-monteverdianos pra ver a síncopa neles].” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “In the vast majority of cases, it occurs within the concept of lied. It is in the song, and mainly in the exclusively instrumental song (which is important for this observation), that syncopations occur. (Studying the Flemish and pre-Monteverdian to see the syncopation in them).” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “Gêncro poético musical em voga durante o século XIX, composição para voz c piano. Mário de Andrade estende a denominação de Lied às canções populares alemas do séc. XVI, volkslied, escritas "em língua vulgar, muitas vezes discrepando ingenuamente do espírito católico Iegítimo." (Pequena história da música, 6a. cd., p. 90). Nas composições do Romantismo alemão, o acompanhamento tem papel preponderante: "Agora o piano não se limita mais a acompanhar o canto, porém é o comentador psicológico, e ambientador, às vezes até descritivo, do texto.” (Andrade (1989) 284) Portuguese C: “Canção, romança, balada.Plural: lieder. A história do lied pode ser dividida nos seguintes períodos: a) Minnesinger e Meistersinger (c. 1250-1550); b) o Lied polifônico (séculos XV e XVI); o lied acompanhado da era Barroca (1600-1750); c) o lied popular (1775-1825); o lied alemão do século XIX). - "O Lied oitocentista não vem a ser mais do que a antiga monodia acom-panhada, mas em que o poema, na generalidade de uma factura literária supe-rior, tende, se não a sobrepôr-se à mú-sica, pelo menos a informar inteiramente a sua expressão e a sua estrutura.” (Cosme (1957) 65)

\ucc9c\uc0c1\uc138\uacc4 cheonsangsegye.text:
천상 + 세계 천상: celestial, heaven 세계: world 
 Korean A: “순수한 유 사체 로서 인간의 현세를 초월한, 그런 인간세계와 천상세계의 중간, 인간세계와 천상세계의 접촉이라고나 할까 또는 지옥이라고 하는 전혀 인간의 현실세계와는 유리되어 초월한 우주의 문제를 취급한 작품은 그밖에도 많습니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 159] English A: “The realm that is in between the mortal world and the celestial world, or perhaps a contact between the two worlds. There are many other compositions that deal with a topic that is separate from the real world, such as purgatory and a transcendent universe.” Park (2024) [5.3]

control.text: Source: “This weakness, again, may seem a non-problem to those immersed in the cultural milieu of Euro-American music theory, where such concepts abound, or dare I say control thought. In my view it is one of the fundamental weaknesses of Western music theory—a note-centric, rather than melody-centric approach. The desire to find the rules, the laws of music, what it is that governs musical construction. These are chimeras rooted in the fundamental Platonic fallacy underlying music theory, which—as I alluded to above—disappeared in the field of Linguistics with the comparative revolution and the understanding of the fundamentally arbitrary nature of communication. Back to Koizumi’s text, there is a big leap between observing that certain notes are poles of melodic attraction and asserting that they control melodies. The first is evident aurally. The second is a philosophical assertion ungrounded in any evidence and untested (and perhaps untestable) scientifically. What does this concept of “control” even mean in the musical context? Perhaps the ghost of the racist Heinrich Schenker can explain it to me..” (Shumays commentary (2024)[3.6]) Definition: “The fact or power of directing and regulating the actions of people or things; direction, management; command. Also occasionally: an instance of this.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “control” 2a)

\u80fd\u697d n\u014dgaku.text: Japanese A: “この核音は、民謡よりもむしろ芸術音楽ことに能楽の謡や三味線声楽の長唄などでは非常にはっきりとした形で現われており、そのばあいの旋律は、ただある１つの核音をめぐって上下浮動するという状態である。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “These nuclear tones appear extremely clearly in Japanese art music, especially in the utai of nō music and shamisen vocal music like nagauta, even more than in folk songs. The melodies in those (art music) cases have the characteristic of revolving around only one nuclear tone, and bobbing up and down around it.” Hynes-Tawa (2024)  [2.1] “Utai 謡, while etymologically meaning simply “song,” has come to refer specifically to the vocal music of the nō 能 theater tradition. It is accompanied by a hayashi 囃子 ensemble, which consists of a few drums and a flute.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 4] Japanese B: “明治20年代以後,“能”を特に“能楽”と呼ぶ習慣を 生じた、久米邦武博士等の命名と称される。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 141]

gamelan gender wayang.text: English A: “He begins with gamelan gender wayang, the quartet of ten-keyed metallophones that accompany Balinese shadow plays and other rituals.” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese C: “Iti Swara patutan Catur, ingambil ring Sapta swara Genta Pi-nara Pitu ngaran, iki kang rumanjing ring Angklung, apan sapta swara iki kewaseaken angwetuaken salwiring swara papatutan sami, marmanya hana papatutan tiga, Iwirnya; yan ring patut Pelog, Demung, Salisir mwang Sundari. Yan ring Patut Slendro yaika, Pudak Sategal, Sekar Kemoning mwang Asep Cina.Patutan iki kang umanjing ring Gender Pawayangan, RingPajogedan mwang ring sarwa Pupuh-pupuh sami.” (Bandem (1986), 58) English C (Chat GPT Translation): “These are the four classifications of sound (Swara Patutan Catur), derived from the Seven Tones of the Sacred Bell (Sapta Swara Genta Pinara Pitu). These sounds are present in the Angklung (a traditional bamboo instrument), as the seven tones have the power to produce all forms of classified sounds. Because of this, there are three main groupings, as follows: These classifications of sound are used in Gender Wayang (the metallophone used in shadow puppetry), in dance performances (Pajogedan), and in all forms of Pupuh (traditional sung poetry).”

garbha ak\u1e63ara.text: English A: “ This extended vocabulary of spoken syllables is known as garbha akṣara (Sin. womb syllables).(29) Like the names of the seed syllables, the spoken sounds of many womb syllables loosely resemble the timbres of the corresponding gäṭa beraya drum strokes, however, the resemblances are far from systematic.” (Peiris (2024) [4.3])

\u58f0\u697d\u66f2 Seigaku.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) Japanese B: “人間の声によって歌われる音楽。または人間の声を中心とした音楽。「器楽」の対語。” (Tomosha (2002), 356)

Lac\u00e1l (1900).text: Lacál, Luisa. Diccionario De La Música Técnico, Histórico, Bio-Bibliográfico. 3. ed. Madrid: San Francisco de Sales, 1900.

\ub0a8\ubd80\uacbd\ud1a0\ub9ac(\uc131\uc.text: Korean A: “또한, 판소리의 평조는 민요의 남부경토리(성주풀이토리)와 동일하고, 가야금산조의 평조와 연결되되, 함동정월류 가야금산조의 석화제 대목이 평조에 해당하며, 현행 가곡과 비교하면 가곡의 계면조가 평조와 통한다고 하였다.” Shin (2018) [p. 243] English A: “Further, Pyeongjo in pansori is equivalent to Nambugyeong-tori (Seongjupuri-tori) in folk songs, connected to Pyeongjo in gayageum sanjo such as Seokhwajje 석화제 scenes of Ham-Dongjeongweol ryu 류 [school] gayageum sanjo, and corresponds to Gyemyeonjo in contemporary gagok.” Kim (2024) [3.8]

diminution.text: Disminución (Spanish) Source: “By referencing canonical composers such as Bach, Beethoven, and Wagner, Carrillo framed his musical laws as a continuation, and a radicalization, of techniques such as contrapuntal augmentation and diminution, which had suffused the musical works and theoretical treatises he most admired.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [3.7] Definition: “A term used in the context of improvised embellishment during the Renaissance and Baroque periods to describe a melodic figure that replaces a long note with notes of shorter value. Diminution is close in meaning to the English ‘division’, the Italian passaggio, the Spanish glosa, and the French double. Whereas specific graces such as trills or appoggiaturas were applied to single notes, diminutions served to decorate the transition from one note of a melody to the next with passage-work, giving scope for virtuoso display. 16th- and 17th-century instruction books provide tables of diminution formulae for the most used musical intervals, in various note values, which performers could learn by rote and apply to any piece of music.” (Grove Music Online, “diminution”)

dawula.text: English A: “The first set of sung verses presented here—in Paragraphs 9 and 12—belongs to the genre known as däkum ata, which is performed as an “offering of sound” (śabda pūjāva) during a Bera Pōya Hēvisi ritual. Each line in these verses contains eighteen poetic morae. Although this repertoire is more closely associated with dawula drums (Example 3), in the recording featured here—Videos 1 and 2—they are performed with gäṭa beraya drums (Example 4).” Peiris (2024) [8] English B: “Taking the five instruments– dawula drum (double headed cylindrical drum), other drums, horanǟwa (small quadruple-reed shawm), nāgasinnam (larger shawm),and däkkiya drum (hour-glass shaped variable tension drum)” (Peiris (2024) [6.6])  Sinhalese B: “dawul bhēri horanǟ nāsinnam däkki mepasa gattayi – räňgu” (Peiris (2024) [6.6]) English C: “type of drum” (Peiris (2025))

\u6587\u4eba w\u00e9n r\u00e9n.text: Chinese A: “中國舊日的文人是包辦一切的，祇有文人才配稱儒者。他們當日竟提出那個「一事不知，儒者之恥」的口號，儒冠的文人要把音樂圈入他的勢力範圍裏面，這自然是很難怪了” Li (2024)  “。。。因為在文人看來，道是造分天地，化成萬物的一樣東西，凡屬可以行道的詩書易禮，都是道的工具，固不僅音樂是如是。” Li (2024)  English A: “The literati in ancient China monopolized everything; only they were considered worthy of being called Confucians. They proposed that “ignorance of any matter brings shame upon a Confucian,” in order to expand their sphere of influence to the realm of Music.” Li (2024)  “For the literati, the Way generated Heaven, the Earth, and ten thousand things (wanwu). Like Music—Poetry, Literature, and Ritual were means for the literati to unite with the Way.” Li (2024)  Chinese B: “古称先祖之有文德者.” Hanyu dacidian (文人, 1)

horan\u01dfwa.text: English A: “Taking the five instruments– dawula drum (double headed cylindrical drum), other drums, horanǟwa (small quadruple-reed shawm), nāgasinnam (larger shawm),and däkkiya drum (hour-glass shaped variable tension drum)” (Peiris (2024) [6.6])  Sinhalese A: “dawul bhēri horanǟ nāsinnam däkki mepasa gattayi – räňgu” (Peiris (2024) [6.6]) English B: “type of wind instrument” (Peiris (2025))

\u97f3 y\u012bn.text: Chinese A: “指有确定高度的声音，亦称乐音。它是物体有规则的振动所产生的，为构成音乐作品的基本素材。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) (”音,” p. 464) Chinese B: “(1) 乐音。相对于噪音而言,有一定音高、和谐悦耳的声音。(2) 音乐。《乐记》:“声 成文,谓之音。”古代音乐理论中单用“音”字时,一般不指乐音,而指音乐。” Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (音) English: “The use of a single term, yin, for both the scalular and orchestrational aspects of a single tone, indicates that at the deepest level the term was thought to cover the whole range of sounds which stand in relation to each other.” Cook (1995)  “In all cases, the arising of music (yin) is born in the hearts of men. The movement of men's hearts is made so by (external] things. They are touched off by things and move, thus they take shape in [human] sound (sheng). Sounds respond to each other, and thus give birth to change. Change forms a pattern, and this is called music (yin). The music is brought close and found enjoyable, and reaches the point of shields and axes, feathers and pennants, and this is called Music (yue).” Cook (1995) (1.1) (See: 声 shēng, 乐 yuè) For further discussion, see Li (2024) [2.7]

Shumays commentary (2024).text: Shumays, Sami A. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4 (2024).

gineman trompong.text: English: “This [nerumpuk] is often heard in unmeasured passages called gineman trompong.” Tenzer (2024) [3.6] See: nerumpuk, trompong

hand-plucked.text: Source: “The Igbo people have a different method of categorization. According to Lo Bamijoko (1987), “ubọ” describes an instrument that is plucked, and “aka” means hand. The name therefore means “hand-plucked” and could be confused with other instruments, such as string instruments, which are also hand-plucked. The instrument’s name not only describes how it is played but also indicates how it is used.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.2]

suling.text: English A: “The bowed spike lute rebab and the bamboo end-blown flutes suling play the melody in the Gamelan Gambuh, an ensemble dating perhaps to as early as the fifteenth century, and commonly understood to be the crucial precursor of later gamelan composed of bronze keyed instruments and gongs.” (Tenzer (2024) [1.1]) Balinese B: “Hana mwah swara wetu saking pring, ngaran suling, suling ngaran bumi laras, apan salwring laras patutan juga mungguh ring suling, suling paraganing laki, rebab paraganing wadu, apan swaraning suling reng pangucapira sang hyang smara, swaraning rebab pangucapira sang hyang ratih, hana swara manis ngarerengih, mwah swarangalup manis, apan matunggalan pangucapira sang hyang smara ratih. Mangkana kalingganya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “There is another sound that emerges from bamboo, namely the suling [bamboo flute]. Suling signifies the earth as if tuned, because all the tunings and modes are contained in the flute. The flute is the embodiment of maleness, and the rebab of the female, because the sound of the flute is the source of the sound from Sang Hyang Semara, the sound of the rebab comes from Sang Hyang Ratih. A very melodious, sweet high voice comes from the singular voice of Sang Hyang Semara and Ratih combined.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.7]) Balinese C: “Mwah yan Smar Patangian, ndyata : kempul satunggal sawur-nya manyomanan ndung, kemong gantung sanunggal swaranya ndung, kajar sanunggal sawurnya ndung, gupek roro lanang wadon, rebab sanunggal, suling ageng roro, suling babarangan roro sama ngumbang ngisep, gender ageng sapasang, jegogan sapasang, jublag sapasang, panyacah sapasang, kantil sapasang, gangsa manengah sapasang, gangsa alit apasang, nging sama ngumbang gisep, gumanak tatiga, genta orag apancer alit, kecek tigang wungkul alit, kecek manengah kalih wungkul, kecek ageng sawungkul, jangkep kayeki.”  English C (Chat-GPT): “Smara Patangian Ensemble The Smara Patangian gamelan is more rhythmic and ceremonial, used in rituals and processions. It consists of: Thus, this ensemble is also considered complete (jangkep). This classification reflects the structural and tonal balance within different Balinese gamelan styles, each serving specific cultural and artistic purposes.” Balinese D: “seruling bambu dg enam buah lubang nada, satu lubang untuk menimbulkan bunyi dan ber-siwer” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 171, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\u97f3\u8c03 y\u012bndi\u00e0o.text: Chinese A: “我這裏祇說各個音類，（即世人所謂音調，如C調，G調之類，）希臘人對於各個音類，認為是各有各的特性，決不可以把牠混淆.” Li (2024) [1.12] English A: Modes; “Here I shall only discuss the different categories of tunes (referred to by earthly beings as “modes,” such as C major, G major, etc.). The Ancient Greeks believed that each mode has its own character, and should not be mixed up. Some music theory books nowadays still attempt to preserve this understanding of mode characters and apply it to contemporary music.” Li (2024) [1.12] Chinese B: “发声说话、吟诵诗文时的腔调.” Hanyu dacidian (音调, 1)

\u0447\u0435\u043f\u043d\u0438\u043a/che.text: Bulgarian A: “Думата ръченица произхожда от ръченик (кърпа), койго обикновено се развява ту в дясна, ту в лява ръка при играта. По някои места наричат тази игра чупница (кършница), което произхожда от чупене, кършене тялото и от чепник (чрез палеца и средния пръст из-даване на особени звуци по време на танца); а така също пешачка (в Софийско).” Hristov (1925) [p. 48] English A: “The word rŭchenitsa derives from rŭchenik (handkerchief), which is usually waved now in the right, now in the left hand during the dance. In some places they call this dance chupnitsa (kŭrshnitsa), which derives from twisting, turning the body and from chepnik (particular sounds generated with the thumb and middle finger during the dance); and likewise peshachka (in the Sofia region).” Goldberg (2024) [5.17]

\u967d hi.text: Japanese A: “「ハウプト・トン」は二つあるときも多いのです。二つあれば、それは陰陽関 係を持ちます。たとえば、動と静の関係 であったりします。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u96c5\u697d gagaku.text: 雅+楽 gaku  雅: elegance, grace Japanese A: “さて、核音の旋律中におけるこのような支配は、伝統音楽のそれぞれのジャンルにどのように現われているだろうか、雅楽輸入以前の音楽をわれわれは正確に知ることができないし、現在残っているものでも、起原の古いものは、時代が経過するにつれて、多少改変させられたかも知れない。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 8] English A: “Now then, how does the control over melodies that nuclear tones have manifest in various different genres of traditional music? We cannot know anything for certain about music before the importation of gagaku, and even that old original music that does remain in the present has probably undergone some change as eras have passed.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [5.1] Japanese B: “1) 本来は中国古代において礼楽思想に基づく雅正の楽の 意であったが、中世には主として宮廷における祭祀の音楽を指し、饗 宴の楽である*宴楽 (燕楽)に対する呼称となった。2) 日本の雅楽は 大宝二年(702)に制定された大宝令によって創設された雅楽寮におい て扱われている楽舞をいう。今日では宮内庁の楽部において行われて いる日本の楽舞を中心とし、それと同系に属する各神社や寺院の祭儀 に行われる楽舞をいう。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 30] See also: Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58]

Zhongguo yinyue (1984).text: Zhongguo Yin Yue Ci Dian. Beijing di 1 ban. Beijing: Ren min yin yue chu ban she, 1984.

\u30f4\u30a3\u30d6\u30e9\u30fc\u30c8 vu~.text: Japanese A: “まず、装飾音です。装飾音から始めて、 だんだん揺れが大きくなって、場合によ ってはヴィヴラートが4度までいきます。 スタートする音に力を集めるために、装 飾音があるわけで、それ自体に意味はな いわけです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “Now, it is a decorative tone. Beginning from the decorative tone, the trembling grows larger and, at times, the vibrato gets as wide as a fourth. The decorative tone exists to concentrate on the tone’s beginning, and it is meaningless by itself.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “音の高さをわずかに揺らしながら演奏すること。声楽や多くの楽器の演奏で広くおこなわれる技巧で、声や音を豊かに美しく響かせる目的で用いられる。弦楽器の場合は弦を押さえる指の振動によって，管楽器の場合は一種のブレス・コントロールによっておこなわれる。” (Tomosha (2002), 65)

Boyd commentary (2024).text: Boyd, Clifton. “Commentary: Music Theory, Nationalism, and the “Invention” of Bulgarian Rhythm.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

Ulh\u00f4a (1999).text: Ulhôa, Martha Tupinambá de. “Métrica derramada: prosódia musical na Canção Brasileira Popular.” 1999. https://archive.hemispheric.org/course-rio/imperio/materials/text/metrica.htm

\u043e\u0441\u043d\u043e\u0432\u0430 \u0.text: Bulgarian A: “Неправилните тактове, които покрай обикновените правилни тактове са главна основа на нашата музика, значително се отличават от известните в художествената европейска музика неправилни тактове.” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “The irregular meters that, alongside the usual regular meters, are one of the main foundations of our music, differ significantly from the irregular meters that are known in European art music.” Goldberg (2024) [4.3]

upat kavi.text: English A: “The second set of sung verses (transliterated and translated at the end of this article in paragraphs 30–37, and performed by Muddanave Sunil in Audio 1–8) consists of eight verses that belong to the category of upat kavi (origin verses). Upat kavi—which detail the (often supernatural) origins of things of spiritual significance, such as deities (Kulatillake 1976b, 3–4), types of repertoires (Karunaratne 2008, 23; Sykes 2018, 58–59), and drums (Sedaraman 2008 [1964], 37–42)—are rarely performed today; however, in the past they were often sung or chanted as introductory prefaces during rituals (Muddanave Sunil, pers. comm).” Peiris (2024) [13] English B: “origin story” (Peiris (2025)

Kamus Budaya Bali (2016).text: Kamus Budaya Bali. Bali: Balai Bahasa Bali, 2016.

\u4eba\u9593\u4e16\u754c ningen sekai.text:
人間 + 世界 人間: humankind 世界: world 
 Japanese A: “純粋な音自体を持って、人間の現世を超越した、そういう人間世界と天空の世界の中間、人間世界と天空の世界の接触といいますか、あるいは地 獄のというように、全く人間の現世の世 界とは離れて、超越した宇宙の問題を取 り扱った、そういう作品は他にもたくさ んあります。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 59] English A: “The realm that is in between the mortal world and the celestial world, or perhaps a contact between the two worlds. There are many other compositions that deal with a topic that is separate from the real world, such as purgatory and a transcendent universe.” Park (2024) [5.3]

\u8282\u62cd ji\u00e9p\u0101i.text: Chinese A: “乐曲中周期性出现的有一定强弱分别的一系列拍子，是衡量节奏的单位.” Hanyu dacidian  (节拍, 1) Chinese B: “原为音乐术语;在诗歌里,格律学家借用它来代替“重音”。学者们把诗行中以重音为基础的音步比作音乐中的小节。只要重音结构符合规范,音步中的音节数便可以变化,就像音乐中一个小节可以有不同数量的音符。” Shijie shixue (1999) (p. 262) English: Takt, beat, or meter. ”In Chapter 3 of A General Treatise on Music, Li (1930/1933, 24–37) discussed four foundational elements of Music: Rhythmus (shengdiao 聲調), Takt (jiepai節拍), Harmonie (heyin和音), and Melodie (qudiao曲調 or yuediao樂調). Li’s understanding of these elements echoed his thoughts on Music as a language of the upper realm.” Li (2024) [Footnote 28]

Yun (1984) - Japanese.text: Yun, Isang, and Akira Nishimura. 1984. “無限の宇宙の一端から [At One End of the Endless Universe].”  音楽芸術 [Musical Arts] 42 (1984): 50–61.

\u591a\u58f0\u6027 \u014dzei-sei.text: 多: multi- + 声: voice, sound + 性: nature, custom, convention Japanese A: “リズム・旋律法・多声性・楽器編成などあらゆる点でその他のジャンルと異なる” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 14] English A: “All aspects such as rhythm, melodic system, polyphony, and instrumental organization differ from other genres.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [8.2] Japanese B: “複 数 の 声 部 が そ れ ぞ れ の 旋 律 的 独 ⾃ 性 を 保 持 し つ つ 動 く ⾳ 楽 形 態 。 多 声 ⾳ 楽 。 「 多 く の 声 （ 部 ） 」 を 意 味 す る ギ リ シ ア 語 に 由 来 す る 名 称 。 同 じ く 複 数 の 声 部 か ら な る が 、 旋 律 の 独 ⾃ 性 が 特 定 の 1 声 部 の み に し か 与 え ら れ な い * ホ モ フ ォ ニ ー と は 区 別 さ 秋 岡 陽 れ る 。” (Tomosha (2002), 648)

Zhongguo qu xue (1997).text: Zhongguo qu xue da cidian 中国曲学大辞典. Qi Senhua 齐森华, Chen Duo 陈多, Ye Changhai 叶长海 (eds.). Hangzhou: Zhejiang jiaoyu chuban she 杭州:浙江教育出版社, 1997.

Klangfarbenmelodie.text: Source: “Alongside this unfolding, we hear a timbrally heterogeneous texture involving six wind or brass instruments playing what could be construed as a single Klangfarbenmelodie line or, perhaps, as a pair of shorter composite gestures in a kind of antecedent-consequent relation.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.9] This is technically a German term…? Definition: “A term coined by Schoenberg in his Harmonielehre (1911) to refer to the possibility of a succession of tone-colours related to one another in a way analogous to a relationship between the pitches in a melody.” (”Klangfarbenmelodie,” Grove Music Online)

Palat\u00edn (1990).text: Palatín, Fernando. Diccionario de Música (Sevilla, 1818). Edited by Angel Medina. Universidad de Oviedo Servicio de Publicaciones, 1990.

ngibing.text: English A: “Gerantang joged bumbung refers to an ensemble of gerantang accompanying ngibing, a flirtation dance. Bramana ngisep sari means “beetle sips flower essence”; pangirik is a tickling sensation. The juxtaposed and somewhat incongruous imagery of beetle, flower, and tickling cunningly reveals the potential of ngibing, which in yesteryear led to more than flirtation.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.13])

frequency.text: Source: “Another significant feature of the pansori modes discussed in the translated text is that each constituent note assumes individual attributes. This is most evident in Baek’s explanation of Ujo and Pyeongjo in Tables 2 and 3, where constituent notes are defined not only by particular intervals, but also by specific singing methods and techniques, frequency of occurrence, cadential function, melodic direction, and so on.” Lee commentary (2024) [6] Definition: “The number of times per second (or other unit of time) that a cycle of disturbances is exactly repeated. For example, if a string is vibrating in its fundamental mode, one cycle could be thought of as starting from the mid-position, moving to a maximum displacement in one direction, moving back to zero, moving to a maximum displacement in the other direction and finally back to zero.” (Greated, Clive. "Frequency." Grove Music Online. 2001)

\u0432\u043e\u043b\u043d\u043e \u0434\u0.text: волно + движение/dvizhenie  волно: free, voluntary Bulgarian A: “Освен песни с точно определен такт в народната ни музика има твърде много песни, лишени от всякаква следа на какъвто и да е такт.Тези песни могат да се нарекат безмензурни (безтактови) и се отличават със съвършено волно движение (ad libitum) без определен ритъм.В безмензурните ни песни някои слогове са твърде много протегнати и правят декламацията неестествена. Друг съществен белег на тия песни са непрекъснатите сложни фиоритури (рулади).” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “In addition to songs with precisely defined meter, in our folk music there are rather many songs that are devoid of all traces of any kind of meter. These songs can be called unmeasured (unmetered), and they are distinguished by a completely free pulse (ad libitum) without a determinate rhythm. In our unmeasured songs some syllables are quite elongated, making the declamation unnatural. Another essential characteristic of these songs is the continuous use of complex fiorituri (roulades).” Goldberg (2024) [4.1]

Stover (2024).text: Stover, Chris. 2024. “Translation of Martha Ulhôa de Tupinamba’s “Métrica derramada: Musical Prosody in Brazilian Popular Song”.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

\u0445\u0430\u0439\u0434\u0443\u0448\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “И в сборниците на Куба и Кухач има български, македонски и др. песни, но и в тяхната автентичност може да се има толкова вяра, колкото в материалите от министерските сборници. Както в едните, той и в другите се срещат, макар рядко, песни с мерки 5/4 и 7/4, обаче само в бавно движение. Това са мерки, конто, може да се каже, се създават по изкуствен начин от записвачите, защото те не са основа на някакви известни народни танци. Напротив, мярката на пайдушката 5/16, двойната мярка 7/16 (ръченица и македонско хоро), 9/16 (тропливата игра или радомирското хоро), 11/16 (хайдушка игра) и др. там никак не се срещат.” Hristov (1925) [p. 35] English A: “There are also Bulgarian, Macedonian, and other songs in the collections by Kuba and Kuhač, but there can be as much faith in the reliability of this work as in the materials from the Ministry collections. In both sets of collections are found, though rarely, songs with the time signatures 5/4 and 7/4, but only at a slow tempo. These are time signatures that are created artificially, so to speak, by the transcribers, because they are not the basis for any known folk dances. To the contrary, the time signature of 5/16 (paidushkata), both 7/16 time signatures (rŭchenitsa and makedonsko horo), 9/16 (troplivata igra or radomirskoto horo), 11/16 (haidushka igra), etc., are in no way found there.” Goldberg (2024) [2.7] See also: игра/igra

\ubcf8\uc131 bonseong.text: Korean A: "그러나 나의 음악이 장시 긴장감을 유지하고 있다는 것은 사실입니다. 내 음악의 근본을 이부 고 있는 선적인 요소가 교묘히 지속성을 갖고 있는데, 그 본성 자체 가 지속의 무한한 가능성을 갖고 있어요. 예컨대 노나 가부키처럼 몇 시간씩 같은 선을 들어도 절대 물리지 않는 비밀이 이거지요." (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

\u043c\u0430\u0434\u0436\u0430\u0440\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “По стъпките (две кратки и една протегната) ръченицата прилича на чешкия народен танц полка. А по чупене на тялото (особени движения на ръцете, краката и приклякане) ръченицата прилича твърде много на руския казачок, на словенския танц хошие на маджарския чардаш.” Hristov (1925) (p. 48) English A: “In its steps (two short and one elongated), the rŭchenitsa resembles the Czech national dance, polka. But in twisting the body (especially the movements of the hands and feet and squatting) the rŭchenitsa very much resembles the Russian kazachok (fast 2/4 meter), the Slovenian dance hoshie (2/4) [Example 12], and the Hungarian csárdás.” Goldberg (2024) [5.18] Bulgarian B: “(унг. csardas or csarda кръчма) характерен унгарски народен танц. Състои се от две части: първата е въведение в твърде бавно темпо, в 4/4 такт, понякога с патетичен или тъжен характер. Нарича се лашан". След нея следва стремително жива част, наречена фришка", в 2/4 такт, със силно синкопиран ритъм. В Ч. са да ли отпечатък музикалните традиции на два народа от една страна, ритмиката на унгарската народна музика и, от друга, виртуозното изкуство (главно на цигулка и цимбал*) на унгарските цигани, на тяхната изразност, страст, наклонност към орнаментиране и мелодика.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 384-385]

\uc120\uc728 seonyul.text: Korean A: “흔히 판소리 우조를 설명할 때 씩씩하 며 위엄있다 하고, 계면조를 슬픈 느낌의 애원성이라고 하는 것은 사설의 분위기를 선율에서 그대로 표출하기 때문이다. 이러한 감정의 표출은 시김새를 통해 가장 잘 드러나며, 시김새가격해질수록 2도 및 3도의 순차 진행 보다는 4~5도 진행이 많이 이루어지면서 자연히 각 음의 비중이 차이를 보이게 된다.” Shin (2018) [p. 248] English A: “These descriptions reflect the mood of sasul 사설 [comparable to recitativo in opera], being the directly expressed in the melody. The intensity of emotions is most effectively conveyed through sigimsae, with the fourth and fifth degrees occurring more frequently than the second and third degrees; there is a distinct variation in the relative occurrences of each note.” Kim (2024) [3.32]

Ilimba.text: English A: “Some people call it Kalimba, people of Cameroon/Some people call it Ilimba (Tanzanians)/Some others call it, I think that there are some people who call it Marimbạ.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “O nwekwa ndị na-akpọ ya Kalimba, ndị Cameroon/O nwekwa ndị na-akpọ ya Ilimba (ndi Tanzania)/Nwekwa ndị na-akpọ ya, I think o na-adi m ka o nwekwaa ndị na-akpọ ya Marimba.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

batidas fortes.text: Portuguese A: “A síncopa europeia me parece um produto exclusivamente musical, e ainda mais, uma verdadeira especulação teórica proveniente da subdivisão da unidade de tempo em quantidades irregulares em que as batidas fortes subsistem em seus lugares teóricos e se tornam pois musicalmente elípticas.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota. no. 9] English A: “European syncopation seems to me an exclusively musical product, and furthermore, a true theoretical speculation stemming from the subdivision of the time unit into irregular quantities where strong beats persist in their theoretical places and thus become musically elliptical.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

escan\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “The scansion, or separation and counting of syllables, will depend on the total number of syllables in the verse.” (Stover (2024) [3.3]) Portuguese A: “ A escanção, ou separação e contagem de sílabas vai depender do número total de sílabas do verso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

canto acompanhado.text: English A: “A popular song is accompanied singing. The interference in the rhythm of the spoken word’s temporal organization does not pose any problem for monodic singing, but it becomes a complicating element for the performance of a song, precisely because it makes synchronization between the melody and the accompaniment difficult.” (Stover (2024) [4.1]) Portuguese A: “A canção popular é um canto acompanhado. A interferência do ritmo da palavra falada na organização temporal, não traz nenhum problema para o canto religioso monódico, mas se torna um elemento complicador para a performance da canção, exatamente por dificultar a sincronização entre a melodia e o acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

Carter-\u00c9ny\u00ec commentary (2024).text: Carter-Ényì, Aaron. 2024. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4. (CHECK CITATION)

opera.text: 오페라 opera (Korean) オペラ opera (Japanese) Source: “As such, assertions of music’s autonomy tend to shade over into a commitment to “art for art’s sake,” and perhaps to lead one to (or justify after the fact—which is the cart? which the horse?) a distaste for opera or program music and a comparative valorization, say, of string quartets by Brahms.” Martin commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “Most narrowly conceived, the word ‘opera’ signifies a drama in which the actors sing throughout. There are, however, so many exceptions among the operatic works of the West – so many works popularly called operas in which some parts are spoken or mimed – that the word should be more generically defined as a drama in which the actors sing some or all of their parts.” (Grove Music Online, “Opera (i)”)

\u5fae\u7d30\u306a\u6642\u9593 bisaina j.text:
微細 + 時間 微細: minute, fine 時間: time 
 Japanese A: “「ハウプト・トン」における陰と陽の相 対的な変化は、微細な時間によるとらえ 方から巨大な時間によるとらえ方までい ろいろな段階があります。そこでは瞬間 に永遠が反映され、永遠を瞬間としてつ かむことができるわけです。それが東洋人の「時」の考え方で、西 洋人の「時」の考え方と全く違うところ なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u7cbe\u795e seishin.text: Japanese A: “機械を幾ら使っても、 機械から出る音楽は機械がつくるんです から、そこには血が流れないんです。こ れは大原則として、音楽には人間の血と 精神が通じてなければならない。究極は 人間の血と精神だと思います、純粋な考 え方をすれば。ぼくが亡びても、人間の血と精神はともに残るでしょう。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 61] English A: “No matter how much a machine can do, the music coming from the machine is made by the machine. No blood flows through the music. This is a fundamental principle. Music must channel human blood and spirit. Ultimately, I think music is human blood and spirit. To speak naively, a person’s blood and spirit will remain even after my death.” Park (2024) [7.2]

\u6697\u3044 kurai.text: 暗い: dark, gloomy, murky, dull https://www.japandict.com/暗い#entry-1154330 Japanese A: “まず低い音から始まります。Bbの音で、 これは暗い音なんです。無から生まれる。 実はこれはピアニッシモなんですけれど も。これは暗示です。まだ音じゃないわ けなんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “First of all, it begins with a low pitch [Example 1]. With the Bb, it is a dark tone. It emerges from nothing. Although it is in pianissimo, it is an implication [暗示]. It is not yet a tone.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\uc74c\uc545\uc138\uacc4 eum-agsegye.text: Korean A: “ 그리고 한국에는 엄격한 입장을 취하는 아악과는 변도 로, 송정음악도 사원음악도 아니면서 일반대중과 상류사회가 공유해 온, 서양에서 볼 수 있듯이 지식사회에서 즐겨온 음악세계가 있어 요. 그리고 또 예술가곡• 예술민요라고 합니다만 그런 것이 또 있어 요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean,147) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3]) Note: Here, eum-agsegye translated directly to a “world of music.”

Ding (1969).text: Ding, Fubao, Fo Xue Da Ci Dian. Taibei Shi: Hua yan lian she, n581.

\u0442\u0440\u043e\u0439\u043d\u0438/tro.text: Bulgarian A: “Разликата между първата и втората група тактове е доста съществена. Докато акцентите в първата група се падат на двойни и тройни елементи, т. е. на т. нар. кратки и протегнати части, във втората група всеки елемент се явява като отделно тактово време със самостоятелен акцент.” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “The difference between the first and second group of meters is quite substantial. Whereas the accents in the first group fall on duple and triple elements, i.e., on so-called short and elongated parts, in the second group each element manifests as a separate metric beat with independent accent.” Goldberg (2024) [3.6]

\u77ac\u9593 shunkan.text: Japanese A: “瞬間に永遠が反映され、永遠を瞬間と してつかむ―東洋人の考え方です。”  Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 56] English A: “A moment reflects eternity, and the eternity can be captured as a moment.” Park (2024)  [4]

\u0441\u043c\u0435\u0441\u0435\u043d \u0.text: Bulgarian A: “…напр, началото на периода с 3/4 такт, по средата вмъкнат един 3/4 или 5/4 такт. Такива са песните със смесен такт. [...] Докато в песни със смесен такт има случайни промени на един установен такт, в песни с неправилен такт редовно се повтаря из вестна комбинация с дву- и триделни части.” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “…for example, notating the beginning of the period in 2/4 meter and inserting a measure of 3/4 or 5/4 in the middle. These are songs with mixed meter. […] Whereas in songs with mixed meter there are occasional changes to an established meter, in songs with irregular meter a certain combination of two- and three-element parts repeats regularly.” Goldberg (2024) [4.2]

reyong.text: English A: “ reyong (row of tuned gongs usually played by four musicians)” (Tenzer (2024) [2.1]) Balinese B: “deretan gong kecil di atas pelawah berjumlah dua belas buah dan dimainkan oleh empat orang” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 167, Bidang Istilah Musik]

speech.text: fala (Portuguese Source: “A vocalist sings to a drum player’s accompaniment. The vocalist performs three artistic acts: singing, speech, and body gestures. The drummer controls the flow of the music through rhythmic patterns.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “The act of speaking; the natural exercise of the vocal organs; the utterance of words or sentences; oral expression of thought or feeling.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “speech”)

cakewalk.text: Source: “The pattern also appears in Example 5 ([1.19]), a transcription of Amerindian music transcribed by the French musicologist Marguerite Béclard d’Harcourt, who identifies the pattern with Indigenous and Black musics, as well as cakewalks, two-steps, and tangos.” Biamonte commentary (2024) [5] Definition: “A social and theatrical dance of African American origin, developed from a competitive “prize walk” done by slaves on antebellum plantations in southern states. The original form, called a “chalkline walk,” known from about 1850 in Florida, was a contest for performers walking solemnly while balancing buckets of water on their heads.” (Grove Music Online, “cakewalk”)

\u6c11\u4fd7\u7684\u7d20\u6750 minzoku t.text: 民俗: folk customs, ethnic customs 素材: material Japanese A: “しかし、私の取扱おうとする素材は、単にそのように出来上った芸術音楽ばかりでなく、もっとトニカの不明瞭な民俗的素材をもふくむわけだし、またその点でさらに困難な琉球・朝鮮・中国をはじめ、アジア一般の音組織にもこの概念を適用させようとする上、後に詳しく説明するような、４度構造のテトラコルドを単位として旋律を分析するばあいの、「枠になる重要な音」として、この核音がオクターヴの中に２～３個現われることもありうるので、中心音という、何か一元的な響きの言葉では、狭くなりすぎるようにも思える。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “However, the materials that I intend to handle are not simply art musics that are already established, but also include folk musics in which the tonic pitch is less clear. Also, to take that point further, starting with the Ryukyus, Korea, and China (which pose some difficulty), I want to apply this concept to a generalized organization of notes in Asian music, and explain them afterward in detail, analyzing their melodies using the unit of the tetrachord, which spans the interval of a fourth. In such cases, two or three of these nuclear tones can appear within an octave as “important notes that make a melodic frame.” For that reason, the word “central tone” has a somewhat one-dimensional ring to it, and I think its meaning is too narrow.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4] Japanese B: “1. ⾳ 楽 の 創 作 、 演 奏 、 聴 取 が あ る 程 度 分 化 さ れ ， 職 業 ⾳ 楽 家 が 存 在 す る 階 層 化 社 会 に お い て 、 民 衆 の あ い だ で ⼜ 頭 伝 承 さ れ て き た ⾳ 楽 。地 域 ⾊ と ヴ ァ リ エ ー シ ョ ン が 豊 か で 、 共 同 体 内 で 相 当 の 年 ⽉ に わ た っ て 共 有 さ れ て き た も の で 、 作 曲 者 や 創 始 者 個 ⼈ へ の 関 ⼼ は 薄 い 。 ⽀ 配 階 級 や エ リ ー ト 層 、 都 市 民 の 娯 楽 の た め に 発 展 し て き た 職 業 ⾳ 楽 家 に よ る 芸 術 ⾳ 楽 や ⼤ 衆 ⾳ 楽 と 区 別 す る た め に ⽤ い ら れ る 。 し か し 、 ⽂ 化 的 社 会 的 環 境 の 違 い や 、 近 年 の メ デ ィ ア の 発 達 、 共 同 体 の 崩 壊 な ど に よ り 、 従 来 の 伝 承 形 態 や 伝 播 の 仕 ⽅ ， 担 い ⼿ の 意 識 な ど が い ち じ る し く 変 化 し て お り 、 厳 密 な 定 義 づ け は 困 難 で 2. ⽇ 本 の ⾳ 楽 は 、 雅 楽 、 能 楽 、 近 世 邦 楽 な どの 芸 術 的 ⾳ 楽 、 演 歌 や コ ー ポ ッ プ な ど の ポ ピ ュ ラ ー ⾳ 楽 、 ⽣ 活 に 結 び つ く 民 俗 レ ベ ル の 民 俗 ⾳ 楽 に 類 別 。 民 俗 ⾳ 楽 は 、 祭 礼 な ど の 宗 教 的 ⾏ 事 ， 労 働 、 ⼈ ⽣ の 節 ⽬ や 四 季 の 巡 り を 祝 う 祝 祭 、 娯 楽 、 ⼦ 供 の 遊 び の 場 な ど で お こ な わ れ る ⾳ 楽 で あ る 。 ⼦ 供 が 遊 び な が ら 歌 う わ ら ぺ う た ， 労 働 、 祝 祭 、 娯 楽 の 場 で 歌 わ れ る 民 謡 、 祭 礼 に さ い し て 神 の た め に 演 ず る 民 俗 芸 能 の ⾳ 楽 が こ の 範 職 で あ る 。 現 代 の ⽇ 本 に お い て 、 民 俗 レ ベ ル の ⾳ 楽 は 、 消 滅 、 衰 退 ， 変 質 さ れ つ つ あ り 、 豊 か な 民 俗 ⾳ 楽 の 伝 承 は 、 終 わ ろ う と し て.” (Tomosha (2002), 684)

consoantes.text: English A: “Melody is generally associated with the human voice; we think of it in terms of the continuous sound of singing. Singing, in turn, uses verbal language, whose minimum components are vowels and consonants. A song made only with vowels intoned in a continuous melodic line produces a melody in its closest state to human expression.” (Stover (2024) [2.3]) Portuguese A: “A melodia está geralmente associada à voz humana, pensamos nela em termos do som contínuo do canto. O canto por sua vez utiliza a linguagem verbal, cujos componentes mínimos são as vogais e consoantes. Um canto feito somente com vogais, entoadas numa linha melódica contínua produz uma melodia no seu estado mais próximo da sensibilidade humana.” (Ulhôa (1999))

kumbang atarung.text: English A: “As for the technique of playing gender wayang, it is called kumbang atarung [quarreling bees] if all the keys are struck one by one. ” (Tenzer (2024) [1.8]) See gamelan gender wayang  Balinese A: “Niyan gagebug gender wawayangan, kumbang atarung ngaran, yaning gebug siki-sikinya,” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “I. 7. The technique of playing gendér in the gamelan gender wayang is called kumbang atarung.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.7]) See gendér  Balinese/Indonesian B: “Pukulan gendér pawayangan, kupu-kupu atarung namanya.” (Geria (n.d.))  English C: “Quarreling bees; cf. I.5 above. This kind of gamelan features “quarrelling” contrapuntal and interlocking textures in a narrow ambitus, perhaps not unlike the inside of a hive. The bee metaphor gains richness with the common terms pengumbang and pengisep (the first from the word for bee, kumbang, and the second from isep, to sip, i.e., nectar) that name the lower and higher tones in Balinese paired tunings that create intense acoustical beats between “unisons” on pairs of otherwise identical instruments.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.6]) *Lexical field: Natural world (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) Balinese D: “Iti gagebug Angklung.Gagebug Angklung Kumbang atarun Gambans Faclah asih aran, ing sata. Mwah tingkahing sagebug arambavan, Angen trag tunu ngaran, Geleng pengasuh araning swara Mwang tandang Rere-baban, Bhuta ngawa sari ngaran, Madukaralalita araning swara.Mwang tandang Sasulingan Tunjung arip ngaran, Karna manu-hara araning swara. Mwang tandang Angenggong, Hametbet lati ngaran, Madukara santun araning swara, denya samar nyata ngaran. Mwah tandang angebug Cengceng, Edan ulangun ngaran, banyu runtuh araning swara. Mwah tandang angebug Kaklentangan Kaget asih ngaran. Nyan wustuning gagebug.” (Bandem (1986), 70) English D (Chat-GPT Translation): “The Striking Techniques of the Angklung (Iti Gagebug Angklung) The striking techniques of the Angklung include various rhythmic patterns and symbolic names.

untal-antil.text: English A: “II.6. The technique of playing gendér in the gamelan bebarongan [much like the pelegongan, and used to accompany the dance of the lion-dragon barong] is called untal-antil [to wave back-and-forth like the barong’s tail].” (Tenzer (2024) [II.6]) See gendér and gamelan bebarongan  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Pukulan gendér babarongan, untal antil namanya.” (Geria (n.d.)) *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions and cultural practice or unseen phenomenon (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

giying.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug giying ngaran panuntun, ngaran lagu.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “What the giying plays is called the guide panuntun, it provides the most songlike version of the melody [that is, in the manner of sung poetry].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.9]) Balinese C: “Iti haraning Gagebug.Yaning gagebug gong, Kaget atangi ngaran Bhuhloka nada ngaran. Yaning gagebug trompong Sekar Tanjungsusun nga-ran, denya angembat silih asih. Ikang gagebug babarangan Sad-pada angaras santun ngaran, mwang babancangan, Tadah rasmi araning swara. Ikang gagebug rariyongan I Gajahmina ngaran.Ikang gagebug giying, Tuntun Rasmi ngaran. Ikang gagebug pemade mwang kantil, I Talutur mwang sadulur ngaran. Ikang gagebug gender rambat Ekatanu mwang aninglas ngaran.” (Bandem (1986), 68) Balinese D: “gangsa berbilah sepuluh yg berfungsi sbg pembawa lagu pd gong kebyar” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 145, Bidang Istilah Musik]

cosmology.text: Source A: “The mythological stories featured in these verses are also consistent with long-established Sinhalese Buddhist cosmological worldviews, and arguably served to give value and meaning to the dancing, singing, and drumming associated with religious rituals.” (Peiris (2024) [1.4]) Source B: “Prakempa (and the related Aji Gurnita lontar)(2) are gnomic and cosmological, and unlikely to have been intended for any public.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “The science or theory of the universe as an ordered whole, and of the general laws which govern it. Also, a particular account or system of the universe and its laws.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “cosmology”)

\u6b4c\u66f2 uta kyoku.text: Japanese A: “う で す 。 厳 格 な 雅 楽 の ⾳ 楽 の 組 み ⽅ と 、 哲 学 的 な 内 容 と 、 そ れ か ら 流 暢 に 流 れ る 線 的 な 美 し さ を 、 た と え ば 南 道 唱 と か 歌 曲 と い っ た 形 式 の ⼀ 連 の 声 楽 が あ り ま す が 、 そ う い う と こ ろ か ら た く さ ん 学 び ま し た 。 そ こ に 、 今 度 は 線 的 な 動 き ⽅ の ⾳ 楽 的 な 理 論 を ⼤ 系 づ け ま し た.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: “Yes. I learned a lot from A-ak’s strict organization and philosophical content, and vocal music’s smoothly flowing linear beauty, such as Namdo Chang and Gagok [가곡], or other vocal genres.(4) Based on these, I organized my own musical theory of linear motion." (Park (2024) [1.4])

Escala crom\u00e1tica.text: Spanish A: “La llamada escala cromática, y que en su forma clásica procede por semitonos, en su metamorfosis al duplo quedará por tonos enteros.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 23] English A: “The so-called chromatic scale, which in its classical form proceeds by semitones, proceeds by whole tones under its metamorphosis to the double.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 23] See also Cromatico/ca  Spanish B: “En la música moderna es una serie consecutiva de sonidos conjuntos que se diferencia de la diatónica en que ésta procede por tonos y semitonos.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 122] See also: Cromatico/ca

tom.text: English A: “This may even be the reason why so many popular Brazilian songs have an instrumental introduction: to give the singer the tonality of the song and allow them to start with an anacrusis.” (Stover (2024) [5.3]) Portuguese A: “Esta pode ser inclusive a razão por que tantas canções brasileiras populares têm uma introdução instrumental: para dar ao cantor ou cantora o tom da música e permitír-lhe começar em anacruse.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “

Diecis\u00e9isavos de tono.text: Spanish A: “He aquí esta obra escrita originalmente en cuartos, octavos y dieciséisavos de tono, para los solistas.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p.27] English A: “Here is that work, written originally in quarter tones, eighth tones, and sixteenth tones for the soloists.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p.27]

improvisation.text: Source: “The artistic act of a singer interpreting and directing a story through sound is not an undirected improvisation, but—as in music composition—is carried out within a framework of three musical elements: tone color, mode, and rhythmic pattern.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “The creation of a musical work, or the final form of a musical work, as it is being performed. It may involve the work’s immediate composition by its performers, or the elaboration or adjustment of an existing framework, or anything in between. To some extent every performance involves elements of improvisation, although its degree varies according to period and place, and to some extent every improvisation rests on a series of conventions or implicit rules.” (Nettl, Bruno, Rob C. Wegman, Imogene Horsley, Michael Collins, Stewart A. Carter, Greer Garden, Robert E. Seletsky, Robert D. Levin, Will Crutchfield, John Rink, Paul Griffiths, and Barry Kernfeld. "Improvisation." Grove Music Online. 2001)

musical universalism.text: Source: “This annotated translation aspires to draw readers into a mode of music-theorizing that espouses a musical universalism rooted in a specific culture, in response to a particular cultural crisis, and expressed through a distinct sphere of morphology and rhetoric.” Li (2024) [0.5]

freq\u00fc\u00eancia.text: English A: “In measured tonal music, although dynamics play a central role, duration and frequency (both in pitch class and harmony) also contribute to musical accentuation.” (Stover (2024) [5.10]) Portuguese A: “Na música medida tonal, embora a dinâmica tenha um papel central, duração e freqüência (tanto em classe de altura quanto harmonia) também contribuem para a acentuação musical.” (Ulhôa (1999))

Cromatico/ca.text: Spanish A: “Mús. que se aplica á uno de los tres generos del sistema músico, y es el que procede por dos semitonos y una tercera menor ó semiditono.” Palatín (1990) [p. 54] Spanish B: “Del griego chroma color.  — Escala de los doce semitonos del sistema temperado. Puede ser ASCENDENTE Ó DESCENDENTE por distancias de medio tono, á diferencia de la diatónica que procede por tonos. Se atribuyen á Agathon las primeras composiciones CROMÁTICAS. Aris - tógenes divide este género en tres especies: molle, hemolion y tonicum. Tolomeo sólo en dos: intensum y molle ó anticum.” Lacál (1900) [p. 142] See also Escala cromática

\u0434\u0432\u0438\u0436\u0435\u043d\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “По отношение на такта българската музика съдържа една особеност, която е чужда не само на западната музика, но и на музиката на съседните нам страни, както и на източната (персо-арабска) музика. Тая особеност се крие в образуването на редица тактове, служещи за основа на разнообразните наши танци. За основен (първичен) елемент (хронос протос) в тия тактове служи движение (време) с бързина около 400—432 на минута, т.е. движение, пет пъти по-бързо от пулса на възрастен човек.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “With regard to meter, Bulgarian music contains a feature that is foreign not only to Western music, but also to the music of our neighboring countries, as well as to Eastern (Persian-Arabic) music. This feature is hidden in the formation of a series of meters that serve as a basis for our diverse dances. Serving as a fundamental (primary) element (chronos protos) in these meters is a pulse (beat) with a tempo of around 400–432 per minute, i.e., five times faster than the heartrate of an adult person.” Goldberg (2024) [3.1]

metaphor.text: Source: “On one side of the tension, we find language that seems to invoke the function of metaphor or simile, “beetle sips flower essence”; on the other side is a description of a sensation from the perspective of the recipient of a sensory act. After the presentation of this sustained tension between metaphor and sensation comes Tenzer’s clarifying gloss that “reveals” the hidden subtext of sexuality, a revelation that nevertheless takes the form of a euphemistic concealment (“which in yesteryear led to more than flirtation”).” (Wang commentary (2024) [2.3]) Definition: “Something regarded as representative or suggestive of something else, esp. as a material emblem of an abstract quality, condition, notion, etc.; a symbol, a token. Frequently with for, of.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “metaphor” 2)

Cosme (1957).text: Cosme, Luiz. Dicionário Musical. Instituto Nacional do Livro, 1957.

canto mon\u00f3dico.text: English A: “A popular song is accompanied singing. The interference in the rhythm of the spoken word’s temporal organization does not pose any problem for monodic singing, but it becomes a complicating element for the performance of a song, precisely because it makes synchronization between the melody and the accompaniment difficult.” (Stover (2024) [4.1]) Portuguese A: “A canção popular é um canto acompanhado. A interferência do ritmo da palavra falada na organização temporal, não traz nenhum problema para o canto religioso monódico, mas se torna um elemento complicador para a performance da canção, exatamente por dificultar a sincronização entre a melodia e o acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\ub5a0\ub294 tteoneun.text: Korean A: “우조의 경우, 하청은 떠는 기능을 갖고 있지 않고, 반종지하는 음이다. 하본청은 전조와 변조 에 기능하는 음으로서 그 역할이 작지 않고, 옥타브 위에서는 우조 특유의 씩씩한 느낌을 주는 핵심적인 음이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238-239] English A: “In Ujo, hacheong is the note of a half cadence, without the capacity for vibration. It plays a significant role in transposition and modulation and, when used above the octave, contributes to the distinctive and energizing quality of Ujo.” Kim (2024) [3.6]

\ud754\ub4e4\ub9bc heundeullim.text: Korean A: “그것이 선생님 작품의 선적 어법의 밑바탕 이 되어 있군요. 미분음적인 미세한 흔들림으로부터 3 도 이상의 전음(숍)에 이르는 독특한 선의 움직임은 한국의 가창.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

\uac00\ub77d\uc740 galag-eun.text: Korean A: “그게 이번에는 기악곡으로 옮겨가는데, 모든 기억 곡은 먼저 성악곡으로부터 이어받아 그것을 발전시킨 것이라고 해도 좋겠지요. 예를 들면 '대금'이라는 횡적을 길게 한 형태 의 한국 민족악기가 있는데, 그걸로 연주하는 가락은 가창을 이어받 은 것이지요. 그런데 거기에는 선적인 음악의 묘미가 있어요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: “And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5])

discrep\u00e2ncia participativa.text: English A: “The intensity, which Tatit would call passionate tenseness, is intensified by the “participatory discrepancy” between solo and accompaniment.” (Stover (2024) [5.6]) Portuguese A: “A tensão, que Tatit chamaria de tensividade passional, é intensificada pela "discrepância participativa" entre solo e acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\ubcf8\uccad boncheong.text: Kim (2024) Ex. 2–1 Korean A: “백대웅이 설명하고 있는 우조길 각 음의 특징 중 가장 주목해야 할 음은 상청이다. 그는 상청에 대해 '우조길의 특징을 평조길과 구별하게 하는 음'이라고 제시하고 있으며, '본청과 장3 도의 음정관계라는 점이 큰 의미를 갖는다(평조길은 완전4도)'라고 설명한다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238] English A: “When examining the qualities of each note in Ujo-gil as Baek describes them, it is crucial to focus on the characteristics of sangcheong. Baek claims that the sangcheong “distinguishes Pyeongjo-gil from Ujo-gil” and that “it is crucial that the interval between boncheong and sangcheong is a major 3rd (a perfect 4th in the case of Pyeongjo-gil)” (Baek 1982, 1995, 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.4] English B: “a fundamental key” (Pyǒn (2012) 44)Korean B: “시나위, 산조, 민요 등의 악곡에서 중심이 되는 청을 말함.” (Pyǒn (2012) 44)

\uc644\uc8044\ub3c4 wanjeo 4 do.text:
완전 + 4 + 도 do  완전: perfect 
 Korean A: “백대웅이 설명하고 있는 우조길 각 음의 특징 중 가장 주목해야 할 음은 상청이다. 그는 상청에 대해 '우조길의 특징을 평조길과 구별하게 하는 음'이라고 제시하고 있으며, '본청과 장3 도의 음정관계라는 점이 큰 의미를 갖는다(평조길은 완전4도)'라고 설명한다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238] English A: “When examining the qualities of each note in Ujo-gil as Baek describes them, it is crucial to focus on the characteristics of sangcheong. Baek claims that the sangcheong “distinguishes Pyeongjo-gil from Ujo-gil” and that “it is crucial that the interval between boncheong and sangcheong is a major 3rd (a perfect 4th in the case of Pyeongjo-gil)” (Baek 1982, 1995, 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.4]

melodic direction.text: Source: “Another significant feature of the pansori modes discussed in the translated text is that each constituent note assumes individual attributes. This is most evident in Baek’s explanation of Ujo and Pyeongjo in Tables 2 and 3, where constituent notes are defined not only by particular intervals, but also by specific singing methods and techniques, frequency of occurrence, cadential function, melodic direction, and so on.” Lee commentary (2024) [6]

accent.text: акцент/aktsent (Bulgarian) acento (Portuguese) Source: “The intuition present in this passage is impressive for exposing—perhaps for the first time by a Brazilian musicologist—the theoretical formalization, albeit incipient, of a displaced but consistent accent in relation to the main meter, functioning as a regular, tensioning, and complementary element to the meter. The formulation of a second rhythmic support point emerges, which is structured and constant, yet displaced in relation to the main beat. What Andrade seeks to describe—without a clear formulation—is a type of accent displacement that does not occur as a deviation or rupture of the musical discourse, but as a rule of the structure, which, appearing constantly in the performance of musicians from various American cultures, gains a different status from European syncopation.” Menezes (2024) [1.7] Definition: “The prominence given to a note or notes in performance by a perceptible alteration (usually increase) in volume (‘dynamic accent’); a lengthening of duration or a brief preceding silence of articulation (‘agogic accent’); an added ornament or pitch inflection of a melodic note (‘pitch accent’); or by any combination of these. The term is also used for any of the notational signs used to indicate that such prominence is required.” (Grove Music Online, “accent”)

Dissanayake (1985).text: Dissanayake, Mudiyanse. Kohomba Yak Kankariya and Its Social Relevance (Ritual of the Demon/Deity of Kohomba). 1985.

Tenzer (2024).text: Tenzer, Michael. “Gusti Putu Madé Geria’s Theory for Balinese Gamela.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4 (2024).

\u4e2d\u6838\u97f3/\u6838\u97f3 chukaku-.text: 中/核+音 oto  中: middle, center 核: core, nucleus, heart Japanese A: “このようなばあい、終止音は一方からは単に楽曲の終止音としての意味ばかりでなく、旋律線の上下動における中核的な意味を持つという理由で、他方では、連続的にくり返されるべき性質の「数え唄」や「網引唄」の中には、かならずしも終止音に終らない旋律も多いという理由で（そのばあいですら旋律線の中核的意味を失わない）、終止音とよぶより中核音または単に核音とよぶ方が適当ではないだろうか。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] Japanese B: “民 族 ⾳ 楽 学 上 の ⾳ 階 や ⾳ 組 織 に 関 す る もっ と も 基 礎 的 な 概 念 の ひ と つ 。 ⽇ 本 を 含 む 世 界 の 諸 民 族 の ⾳ 楽 に お い て 、 旋 律 の な か で ⾳ 程 が 安 定 し 、 主 ⾳ や 終 ⽌ ⾳ と し て の 機 能 を も つ も の.” Tomosha (2002) [p. 134] English A: “In cases like these, the ending note on the one hand holds meaning not only as a simple ending note to the piece, but also holds meaning as a central nucleus of upward and downward movement in the melodic line.
