On the other hand, among songs like “Counting Song” and “Net-Pulling Song” whose melodies tend to be repeated continuously, there are many songs with melodies that certainly do not end on the ending note (even in those cases, the ending notes do not lose the meaning of a central nucleus of the melodic line). For that reason, rather than calling them ending notes, it may be more appropriate to call them central nuclear tones or simply nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1]

\u52d5 d\u014d.text: Japanese A: “"動は静であり、静は動であるというのが私の音楽の総括的な見方だ." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) “「ハウプト・トン」は二つあるときも多いのです。二つあれば、それは陰陽関 係を持ちます。たとえば、動と静の関係 であったりします。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “Motion [動] is stillness [靜] and stillness [靜] is motion [動], it is my music’s overall perspective.” (Park (2024) [2]) “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1]

kama nada.text: Balinese A: “smara ngaran laki, ratih ngaran wadu, swaraning smara ngaran kama nada, swaraning ratih ngaran kama sraga. Rikalanya anunggal swara ika, hana swara karenga ngararengih ngalup manis, kadi reng pangucapira sanghyang smara ratih, patemuan nira murda, ring murda panunggara nira sanghyang ardanareswari, apan sira wenang surup sinurup, ganti gumanti, matemahan ring windu nada candra.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: ““Semara” indicates male, “Ratih” indicates female, the voice of Semara is called kama nada, [kama = desire; nada = tone] the voice of Ratih is called kama sraga [sraga = form]. When these voices become one, there is a tinkling, sweet sound, like the vibrations of Sang Hyang Semara and Ratih’s words at their summit, at the highest realm of Sang Hyang Ardanareswari [a manifestation of Siva and his consort Parvati unifying male and female] because he can go in and out, again and again, on the tones of Windu Chandra [windu is a point, an essence; chandra can suggest brightness or the moon].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.6])

pros\u00f3dia.text: English A: “In this text I expand on some aspects raised by Andrade, putting up for discussion a hypothesis about musical prosody in Brazilian popular song, the concept of fluid meter [métrica derramada], which refers both to aspects of synchronization between singing and accompaniment and to issues of accentuation in the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.7]) Portuguese A: “Neste texto amplio alguns aspectos levantados por Mário de Andrade, colocando para discussão uma hipótese sobre a prosódia musical da canção brasileira popular, o conceito de métrica derramada, que se refere tanto a aspectos de sincronização entre canto e acompanhamento como a questões de acentuação na canção.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Prosódia musical: Ajuste des palavras à música e vice-versa. a) Aos tempos fortes, partes fortes de tempo ou relativamente fortes, correspondem as silabas tônicas; b) Excepcionalmente pode uma sílaba fraca final recair sôbre um tempo forte ou parte forte de tempo, quando a tônica houver recaído sôbre o tempo forte anterior; c) Sempre que possível deve evitar-se que palavar átona recaia sôbre o 1˚ tempo dos compassos.” (Cosme (1957) 93)

Lunli xue (1989).text: “Dictionary of Ethics 伦理学大辞典.” Song Xiren 宋希仁, Chen Laozhi 陈劳志, Zhao Renguang 赵仁光 (eds.)  Changchun: Jilin People’s Publishing House 长春:吉林人民出版社, 1989.

\ud76c\uadf9 higeuk.text: Korean A: “감옥 속에서 쓴 작품은 희극적 내용이었다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 160] English A: ”The circumstances were the worst, however, the opera I completed in the prison was a comedy.” Park (2024) [6]

Martin commentary (2024).text: Martin, Nathan John. 2024. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

\u751f\u547d\u529b seimeiryoku.text: Japanese A: “走り ながら、今度は生命力を、緊張力を高め るためにヴィヴラートを生じさせるわけで す。ヴィヴラートによって、集中力と緊張 感を増します。そしてメリスマ的な要素 が加わります。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “As it runs, it creates vibratos in order to heighten its lifeforce and tension. Through vibrato, the concentration and tension are increased. And melismatic elements are added.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\uc815\uc545 jeongak.text: Korean A: “1975년 장사훈과 한만영이 발간한 『국악개론』에서 판소리 우조에 대해 가곡의 우조나 3음 음계 계면조와 같이 정악 스타일을 판소리에 도입한 것이라 하며, 평조에 대해서는 우조와 조성 의 차이가 아니라 창법과 선을 형태의 차이로 설명하고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 236] English A: “Chang and Han 1975 claim that pansori’s Ujo incorporates jeongak styles, similar to gagok’s Ujo or the three-note scale, Gyemyeonjo. They specify that pansori’s Pyeongjo is distinguished from Ujo by its vocal style and melodic structure, rather than tonality.” Kim (2024) [2.2] English B: 1. classical music 2. pungnyueumak (Pyǒn (2012) 121) Korean B:

\uc74c\uc815 eumjeong.text: 음 eum + 정 정: unit of distance Korean A: “Bb은 단지 준비의 음입니다. 그러나 D를 만들어내기 위해서는 장3도가 생겨납니다. 장3도는 밝은 음정이지요. 그래서 어두운 음으 로부터 밝은 음이 됩니다. 그건 조금씩 빛이 비쳐드는 것이지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “The Bb is just a tone for preparation. But, in order to create D, a major third is created. A major third is a bright interval. So, a dark tone becomes a bright tone. It is like light is peeking through little by little.” Park (2024) [4.1] See also: Shin (2018) [p. 238], Kim (2024)

\u0441\u043b\u043e\u0436\u043d\u043e\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Записвачът да не е лишен от един по-възможност най-усъвършенствуван фонограф за схващането на ония песни, които по своята метроритмична и мелодична сложност биха го затруднили на прво време.” Hristov (1925) (p. 35) English A: “The transcriber should not be deprived of the most sophisticated possible phonograph for understanding those songs that by their rhythmic and melodic complexity would make comprehension difficult at first.” Goldberg (2024) [2.10]

can\u00e7\u00e3o brasileira popular.text: English A: “In this text I expand on some aspects raised by Andrade, putting up for discussion a hypothesis about musical prosody in Brazilian popular song, the concept of fluid meter [métrica derramada], which refers both to aspects of synchronization between singing and accompaniment and to issues of accentuation in the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.7]) Portuguese A: “Neste texto amplio alguns aspectos levantados por Mário de Andrade, colocando para discussão uma hipótese sobre a prosódia musical da canção brasileira popular, o conceito de métrica derramada, que se refere tanto a aspectos de sincronização entre canto e acompanhamento como a questões de acentuação na canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

music aesthetics.text: Source: “Li’s most significant contributions were in the field of music aesthetics. As Cai Zhongde (1995, 95) comments on the historical value of Li’s works: Li “is not only a representative of modern Chinese Enlightenment in the field of music aesthetics but also the only music aesthetician in modern China.” Li’s most influential works are two music-theoretical texts published in the 1930s: Yuehua樂話Chitchat about Music (1930) and Yinyuetonglun 音樂通論A General Treatise on Music (1930/1933).” Li (2024) [0.1] Definition: “The theoretical reflections on the status of music as an art and as a form of meaningful articulation, which constitute what is now termed the ‘aesthetics of music’, are often seen as merely a continuation of philosophical reflection upon music of the kind that began with the Greeks.” (Grove Music Online, “Philosophy of music”)

\uc790\uc9c4\ubaa8\ub9ac jajinmori.text: Korean A: “자진모리伽倻琴散調는 대개 진양조, 중모리, 중중모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리 6樂章으로 되어 있고, 一般 的으로 羽調, 界面調, 平調를 使用하고 있다.” (Shin (2018) , 248) English A: “Gayageum sanjo typically comprises six movements: jinyangjo, jungmori, jungjungmori, jajinmori, hwimori, and danmori; it commonly utilizes Ujo, Gyemyeonjo, and Pyeongjo.” (Kim (2024)  [3.2]) English B: “Jajinmori jangdan “comprises four fast beats with three subdivisions in each beat (12/8) and is used to accompany songs which describe urgent or agitated scenes or moods” (Lee and Lee 2007, 113).” (Kim (2024), Footnote 18) Korean C: “이보형은 판소리 창자들이 흔히 우조라고 이르는 <춘향가>의 '궁자노래', '신연맞이'와 같은 자진모리장단 대목에서 우조의 특징을 다음과 같이 정리하였다.” Shin (2018) [p. 242] English C: “According to Lee, scenes based on the jajinmori jangdan [rhythmic pattern, literally means “long and short”], such as “Gungja norae” “궁자노래” [The Song of Gungja] and “Sinyeon maji” “신연맞이” [New Leader Inauguration] in Chunhyang-ga, are frequently referred to as Ujo by pansori singers. Through these, Lee encapsulates Ujo’s distinctive qualities.” Kim (2024) [3.4] English D: 1. a jangdan indicating fast tempo 2. musical piece (Pyǒn (2012) 152)Korean D: 판소리나 민요, 산조 등에 사용되는 장단의 하나. 조금 빠른 3소박 4박 장단으로 되어 있다. 자진모리의 '자진'은 빠른 속도라는 뜻이 고 모리'는 몬다는 뜻이므로 자진모리는 보통보다 빠르게 모는 장단의 의미를 지니고 있다. 민속악에서는 곡의 속도를 나타내는 용어로도 사용하며, 산조에서는 곡명으로 가리키기도 한다. 새복 자진모리장단 (Pyǒn (2012) 152)

\u897f\u6d0b\u97f3\u697d seiy\u014d onga.text: 西洋: the West/Western 音楽 ongaku  Japanese A: “核音の比較音楽学的意味については第４節でのべるが、西洋音楽一般についてはこれにあたるものを見ない。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 5] English A: “I will discuss the meanings of nuclear tones in comparative musicology in section 4, but in Western music, we do not generally see things like this.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3]

som\u00e1tica/tem\u00e1tica.text: English A: “Luiz Tatit, in his work on song, discusses in detail the role vowels and consonants play in the song. According to Tatit (1996), vowels are responsible for what he calls “passionate tensivity” [tensividade passional], produced both by the stabilization of the melodic curve and by the discursive intonation of speech. In another process of tensividade, which he describes as “somatic” or “thematic,” consonants generate movements, outline rhythms, build characters, establish genres.” (Stover (2024) [2.6]) Portuguese A: “Luiz Tatit no seu trabalho sobre a canção discute bem o papel das vogais e consoantes na canção. Segundo Tatit (1986, 1996), as vogais são responsáveis pelo que chama de "tensividade passional", produzida tanto pela estabilização da curva melódica quanto pela entoação discursiva da fala. Num outro processo de tensividade, agora "somática" ou "temática", as consoantes geram movimentos, delineiam rítmos, constroem personagens, estabelecem gêneros.” (Ulhôa (1999))

samba.text: English A: “The most obvious example of this “overflow” [derramamento] is samba, where there is a binary measure, but with the accent transferred from the beginning of the measure to its second half.” (Stover (2024) [4.5]) Portuguese A: “O exemplo mais evidente deste "derramamento" é o samba onde se tem um compasso binário, mas com a acentuação transferida do início do compasso para a sua segunda metade.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “1. Qualquer bailarico popular. "Está aí um preso. Furou, inda agorinha, um homem, num samba prás bandas da Estação." (Queiroz, R.João Miguel, 1932, p. 10). (MA)2. Dança de salão, aos pares, com acompanhamento de canto, em compasso2/4 e ritmo sincopado. Admite três construções: a) introdução instrumental, solista (estrofe) e coral (refrão); b) em três partes, mas sem estrofe e refrão;c) introdução e estrofe. A este samba Renato Almeida haura de sarada carioca ou de salão. (História da música brasileira, 1942, p. 191).” (Andrade (1989) 453–56) Portuguese C: “(Bras.) (1) Durante a segunda época ou período de caracterização da música nacional brasileira (séc.XVI), o samba se denominava no Rio de Janeiro chiba; no Estado de Minas cateretê e nos estados do sul jandango. Era uma dança de roda, ao ar livre, em que por instrumentos entravam o vio-lão, a viola de arame, o cavaquinho, sob a toada da qual se cantava e sapateava ao ritmar das palmas, dos pratos e dos pandeiros.(2) Dança de con-junto formada de grandes rodas de homens e mulheres, que cantam no côro, batem as mãos em tempo, e dançam com o corpo sem sair do lugar…” (Cosme (1957) 104–105) (See also: Andrade (2013))

ngantu.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngantu, artinya ngungkurin, lambat datang, pangemban namanya. Oleh karena dia berfungsi sebagai pengembala anak buahnya (pangkuan atau pangasuh). Pukulan yang jatuh satu ketukan setelah paniti calung atau jublag, memberi kesan lambat dan menunjukkan kematangan seorang pemain trompong.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngantu means hanging, waiting. The leader arrives late because it is the caretaker of its followers. Coming afterwards suggests the trompong player’s maturity and responsibility, as when the trompong attains the goal tone [6 in the example] a full beat after the other instruments do.” Tenzer (2024) [III.7] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u7dca\u5f35 kinch\u014d.text: Japanese A: “"しかし、私の音楽が長時間緊張感を保っているということは、全くそのとおりなんです。私の音楽の根本をなしている線的な要素が、巧妙に持続性を持っており、そのナチュール自体が、持続の無限な可能性を持っているのです。たとえば能の音楽とか歌舞伎のように、何時間同じ線を聴いても絶対飽きない秘密がこれなんです." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

drum stroke.text: Source: “This article aims to broaden common understandings of music theory through the lens of orally transmitted ritualistic verses from Sri Lanka, which are sung or recited along with drumming. I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2])

ambival\u00eancia.text: English A: “The Brazilian musician makes this ambivalence “an element of musical expression” (32), and much of what is called syncopation in reality would not be syncopation in the traditional usage of the term, but rather “rhythms that accept the physiological determinations of arsis and thesis, but ignore (or purposefully infringe on) the false dynamic doctrine of [Western European] meter” (33–34).” (Stover (2024) [1.6]) Portuguese A: “O brasileiro fez desta ambivalência "um elemento de expressão musical" (p. 32), sendo que muito do que é chamado de sincopado na realidade não seria síncopa na concepção tradicional do termo, mas sim "rítmos de quem aceita as determinações fisiológicas de arsis e tesis, porem ignora (ou infringe propositalmente) a doutrina dinâmica falsa do compasso" (pp. 33-34).” (Ulhôa (1999))

syncopation.text: síncopa (Portuguese) Source: “Mário de Andrade (1893–1945), a key figure in Brazilian modernism, intended, alongside his many activities, to write a book about the origins of syncopation in Brazil. This project was announced in his 1928 Ensaio sobre a música brasileira in a brief suggestion that “syncopation [is] more likely imported from Portugal than from Africa (as I will certainly show in a future book) [...]” (Andrade 2020 [1928]). It is known that this book was never written; the writer died relatively young, at 51, before working on it.” Menezes (2024) [1.1] Definition: “The regular shifting of each beat in a measured pattern by the same amount ahead of or behind its normal position in that pattern; in polyphonic textures this may occur in some or all of the parts. Syncopation usually occurs in lines in which the strong beats receive no articulation.” (Grove Music Online, “syncopation”)

\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0438\u043d\u0441\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Сръбски музиколози (например Т . Маринкович) отбелязват песни с такта на ръченицата по един несвойствен на истинския ритъм начин, който съвсем изменя акцентовката и образа на песента.” Hristov (1925) (p. 50) English A: “Serbian musicologists (for example T. Marinković) notate songs with the meter of the rŭchenitsa in a way that is alien to the true rhythm, completely changing the accentuation and form of the song.” Goldberg (2024) [5.22]

\ub0a8\ub3c4\ucc3d Namdo Chang\u00a0.text: Korean A: “그중 하나로 남도창(m)이라고 해서 남한 일대를 중심으로 발전해온 맑고 큰소리로 노래 부르는 민속음악이 있어요. 나는 그 음악에서 큰 영향을 받았지요. (Yun (1991) - Korean,148) English A: "One of them is called Namdo Chang [남도창, 南道唱], which is folk music that features a clear and loud voice and has been passed down in the southern Korean region. I have been greatly influenced by that genre." (Park (2024) [1.3])

\uc7a5\ub2e8 jangdan.text: English A: “It presents four or more rhythmic patterns 장단 (jangdan) in “ascending orders of metrical speed” (Provine, Hwang, and Howard 2001)—from slow tempo (e.g., jinyang 진양) to fast rhythmic cycles (e.g., hwimori 휘모리)—demonstrating the performer’s technical proficiency and expressive abilities.” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) Korean B: “우조의 특징은 자진모리장단의 우조 대목에 나타나는 특징으로, 그 는 '자진모리-우조'라고 적음으로서 다른 장단의 우조 대목과 구별하였다. 또한, 가야금산조에 서 진양장단의 우조가 판소리에서 자진모리장단의 우조와 같이 La-re-mi 골격임을 지적함으로 서, 우조를 La-re-mi 골격으로 보았을 때 가야금산조와 판소리가 서로 통함을 드러내었다. 그 리고 La-re-mi 골격의 판소리 우조는 Sol-do-re 골격의 판소리 평조에 비하여 한 음씩 위인 점에서, 1970년대 김윤덕이 우조에 대해 "한 음 위의 조"라고 증언한 것과 연결 지었다.” Shin (2018) [p. 242] English B: “Lee’s description of Ujo’s traits recalls those of scenes in jajinmori jangdan. Lee specifies “jajinmori-Ujo” to distinguish it from Ujo scenes in other jangdan. Additionally, he notes that Ujo based on jajinmori jangdan in pansori has the same La-re-mi structure as Ujo in jinyang jangdan in gayageum sanjo; this indicates that gayageum sanjo and pansori strongly correspond with each other. The La-re-mi structure in pansori Ujo is also related to Kim Yundeok’s 1970s statement that Ujo is “a mode higher than a whole step,” since it is a step higher than the Sol-do-re structure in pansori Pyeongjo (Lee 2002, 218).” Kim (2024) [3.15] Korean C: '길고 짧음'을 의미하는 말로써 '길이'라는 보편적인 개념으로 사 용되었으며 음악에서는 '소리의 길이의 길고 짧음'을 뜻한다. 일 반적으로 장단은 주기를 단위로 한 소리의 길고 짧은 꼴로, 박, 빠르기, 장단형 등의 개념을 함축하고 있다. 또한 악곡과 반주의 일정한 장단꼴이나 가락을 총칭하기도 하고, 일정한 길이의 단 위, 악장 등의 의미로도 사용되는 다의적인 개념이다. 평택 농악 장단을 평택가락'이라고 하듯이 가락을 의미하고, 일정한 길이 의 단위인 각체과 같은 의미로도 쓰이며, 산조에서 '진양조' 부분처럼 악장을 의미하기도 한다. 연물, 장기 (Pyǒn (2012) 73-74) English C: one of musical elements. collective meaning includes beat, tempo, pattern, etc. (Pyǒn (2012) 73) Korean D: “음악의 박자와 선율(旋律), 처음에 박(拍)을 쳐서 기악(起樂: 음악을 시 작함)하고, 악절(樂節)에 따라 박을 치고, 또 급히 쳐서 음악을 그치게 한다. 모든 음악의 장단 곡절 및 악작(樂作: 음악의 시작)과 악지(樂止: 음악의 종지)는 모두 박의 소리에 따른다.” Song (2010) [p. 284, “장단곡절(長短曲節)”]

\uc911\ubaa8\ub9ac jungmori.text: Korean A: “자진모리伽倻琴散調는 대개 진양조, 중모리, 중중모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리 6樂章으로 되어 있고, 一般 的으로 羽調, 界面調, 平調를 使用하고 있다.” (Shin (2018) , 248) English A: “Gayageum sanjo typically comprises six movements: jinyangjo, jungmori, jungjungmori, jajinmori, hwimori, and danmori; it commonly utilizes Ujo, Gyemyeonjo, and Pyeongjo.” (Kim (2024)  [3.2]) English B: “Jungmori jangdan “has a faster tempo than jinyang. Its basic pattern consists of twelve beats (12/4) with the accent on the ninth beat and each beat is divided into two subdivisions. It used to accompany songs in a peaceful to sorrowful mood as well as in the dan-ga (introductory song) and gayageum byeongchang (voice with a gayageum accompaniment)” (Lee and Lee 2007, 113).]” (Kim (2024) Footnote 23) English C: 1. a jangdan indicating normal tempo 2. musical piece (Pyǒn (2012) 155)Korean C: 판소리, 민요, 산조 등에 쓰이는 중간 속도 즉, 보통 빠르기로 된 장단으로 12박으로 되어 있다. 중모리의 '중'은 중간 속도라 는 뜻이고 '모리'는 몬다는 뜻을 갖고 있다. 민속악에서는 곡의 속도를 나타내는 용어로도 사용하며, 산조에서는 곡명을 가리키 기도 한다. 중모리장단 (Pyǒn (2012) 155)

r\u00edtmica orat\u00f3ria.text: English A: “This “rhythmic oratory,” free from the notion of the predictable succession of measures, conflicts with traditional European rhythmic processes, which operate within a metric structure conceived as having an autonomous musical sense.” (Stover (2024) [1.5]) Portuguese A: “Essa "rítmica oratória", livre da noção de sucessão previsível de compassos entraria em conflito com os processos rítmicos tradicionais europeus, que funcionam numa estrutura métrica concebida como possuíndo um sentido musical autônomo.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u6c11\u8b21 min\u2019y\u014d.text: 民+謡 民: people, citizens, subjects 謡: song, sing, ballad, noh chanting Japanese A: “譜２５のＡは、任意に拾いあげた民謡の一例を、楽譜の上段には終止音gとdにより、それぞれ支配的な楽句を区分し、下段には終止音間の４度音程と５度音程によって、それぞれの占める楽句を区分したものである。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] English A: “Example 25A (Example 1) takes an arbitrarily-chosen example of a folk song, and above the notation divides the various musical phrases into those controlled by the ending note G and those controlled by D. Below it, it divides the phrases bounded by the interval of a fourth from those bounded by a fifth.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1] Japanese B: “民 来 の ⽇ 常 ⽣ 活 の な か か ら ⾃ 然 に ⽣ま れ 、 民 衆 の あ い だ で ⾧ く 歌 い つ が れ 、 そ の ⼟ 地 の ⼈ 々 の ⽣ 活 感 情 を 反 映 し た 歌 謡.” Tomosha (2002) [p. 686] Japanese C: “一般に郷土音楽に属する歌曲を総称しているが、本来 俚謡(Country song) と民謡 (folks song) とは区別さるべきもので ある、そこで農山漁村の限られた地域で行われている郷土音楽を俚謡 と言い、その中で特に面白く、全国各地(都会も含めて)で愛唱され るものを民謡というように区別するのが適当かと思われる。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 176]

microtiming.text: Source: “Among many important theoretical contributions is this 1999 article on “métrica derramada,” which approaches the issue of musical microtiming from the perspective of the speech prosody of Brazilian Portuguese.” (Stover (2024) [0.1])

\u043f\u0435\u0441\u043d\u0438/pesni.text: Bulgarian A: “Събраният по този начин материал да се систематизира: 1) по такт, 2) по сложение на периодите, 3) по тоналност, 4) по амбитус (тонов обем), 5) по общ характер на песента (любовна, елична, обредна и пр.). Всички тия особености да се пренесат в подходящи карти-диаграми.” Hristov (1925) [p. 36] “Една от най-характерните прояви на българското народно творчество е неговата музика. Грозното петвековно робство е заличило почти всички паметници, напомнящи някогашното величие и култура на отечеството ни; но песента — най-интимният израз на най-скрити душевни преживявания, която устно се е предавала от поколение на поколение — не е могла от нищо да бъде заличена.” Hristov (1925) [p. 34] English A: “The material collected in this way should be systematized: (1) by meter, (2) by composition of the periods, (3) by tonality, (4) by ambitus (tonal range), (5) by general character of the song (love, epic, ritual, etc.). All these features should be communicated in suitable diagrammatic charts.” Goldberg (2024) [2.10] “One of the most characteristic manifestations of Bulgarian folk creation is music. The unsightly five centuries of slavery have erased almost all monuments commemorating the onetime greatness and culture of our homeland, but song—the most intimate expression of the most hidden soulful experiences, passed down orally from generation to generation—nothing has been able to erase.” Goldberg (2024) [2.7] (See also песента/pesenta)

\u0447\u0435\u0448\u043a\u0438\u044f \u0.text: Bulgarian A: “По стъпките (две кратки и една протегната) ръченицата прилича на чешкия народен танц полка. А по чупене на тялото (особени движения на ръцете, краката и приклякане) ръченицата прилича твърде много на руския казачок, на словенския танц хошие на маджарския чардаш.” Hristov (1925) (p. 48) English A: “In its steps (two short and one elongated), the rŭchenitsa resembles the Czech national dance, polka. But in twisting the body (especially the movements of the hands and feet and squatting) the rŭchenitsa very much resembles the Russian kazachok (fast 2/4 meter), the Slovenian dance hoshie (2/4) [Example 12], and the Hungarian csárdás.” Goldberg (2024) [5.18] “Полка (чеш. рulka, фр. polka) стара- нен чешки народен танц, възникнал през 30-те години на 19 в., с характерен ритъм: в умерено темпо. Познат е в Чехия под различни имена: dupak, madera, okroczak.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 262]

musical object.text: Source: “This is a crucial intervention with stakes for music analysis as well as musical experience: the fundamental musical object is in fact something always already in a process of changing.” (Stover commentary (2024), [1.2])

ubo-akwara.text: English A: “The Igbo has ubo-akwara/Ubo that is made from the strings of palm tree/That one has completely gone extinct.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Ndị Igbo nwere ụbọ-akwara/Ụbọ, nke eji akwara were kwe/Nke ahu alago laa pii.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

gong gd\u00e9.text: English: “Geria’s examples all apply to the trompong, an instrument forefronted in prestigious court gamelan—the palegongan, semar pagulingan, and the gong gdé. I show both the kepatihan (cipher notation) provided and my own modified 3-line staff for the trompong and, when needed, a single-line staff for jegogan. Geria notated his examples on particular pitches in a five-tone pélog, conventionally numbered 1,2,3,5, and 6. But they could be played at any transposition.” Tenzer (2024)  [3.1] Balinese A: “gamelan gong ber-laras pélog lima nada, berfungsi untuk mengiringi upacara keagamaan, tari upacara, spt baris, topéng, rejang, dan péndét, terdiri atas trompong, réyong, gangsa jongkok barangan, gangsa jongkok demung, panyacah, calung, jégogan, kempyung, kempli, bendé, kendang, genta orag, dan céngcéng kopyak”  Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 145, Bidang Istilah Musik]

cool.text: English A: “However, with bossa nova, there was an aesthetic shift in the relationship between melody and harmony. Before the bossa nova “revolution,” harmony functioned mainly as support for a relatively autonomous melody. The emergence of bossa nova, with its emphasis on a “parlando” style and colloquial singing, as well as its use of complex harmonic progressions, represented a break with the romantic style of the time, which had become cliché. Bossa nova favored a cool and more restrained diction, with artistic and literary intentions.” (Stover (2024) [2.9]) Portuguese A: “Entretanto, com a bossa nova houve um deslocamento estético nesta relação entre melodia e harmonia na canção. Antes da "revolução" bossanovista a harmonia funcionava principalmente como suporte para uma melodia relativamente autônoma. O aparecimento da bossa nova, com sua ênfase num estilo "parlando" e canto coloquial, bem como seu uso de progressões harmônicas complexas, representou uma ruptura com o estilo romântico mais antigo. Nos anos sessenta, a expressão melodramática tornara-se cliché. Bossa nova privilegiava uma dicção mais "cool" e contida com intenções artísticas e literárias.” (Ulhôa (1999))

wali.text: English: “Tulak is to refuse, and wali to return or go back. The opening 3-note pattern with a down-then-leap-up contour (162) repeats, but once the polos 6 in the middle is reached, matching the gending, the contour pattern inverts to up-then-leap-down(126; dotted box) and returns to its point of origin.” Tenzer (2024) [4.9] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\ucf58\ud2b8\ub77c\ubca0\uc774\uc2a4 kon.text: Korean A: “그에 대해서는 콘트라베이스의 네 개의 피치카토가 준비됩니 다. 그러므로 어디가 준비인가, 어디가 진짜 음인가 하는 것도 늘 상대적인 것입니다. 그리고 이 첫머리에서는 D음이 '하우프트톤' 인 것입이다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “About this tone [Bb], the four pizzicati by the contrabass prepares it. Therefore, it is all relative when it comes to determining what is a tone and what prepares the tone. And in this opening, the D tone is a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1]

genggong.text: English A: “genggong (a jew’s harp) plus rebab, suling and kendang (identified earlier).” (Tenzer (2024) [2.1]) Balinese B: “Adapun jenis-jenis gambelan Bali yang tercantum dalam Prakempa ialah gambelan SmarPagulingan (Barong Singa), Smar Patangian, Smar Palinggihan (Joged Pingitan), Smar Pandirian (Barong Ket), Melad Prana (Gambuh), Angklung, Bebonangan,Gambang, Genggong, Slunding dan sebuah gambelan sakral yang terbuat dari logam taru wuku yang belum diketahui ujudnya (alinea: 41, 51, 55, 65, 67 dan 80).” Bandem (1986) [p. 15] Balinese C: “1) gamelan untuk mengiringi tari godogan, terdiri atas génggong, kempur, kendang, céngcéng, suling, dan kajar; 2) instrumen tiup dr pelepah enau.” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 144, Bidang Istilah Musik]

polos.text: English: “Geria’s cipher notation is given, as well as modified staff notation using two two-line staves with the ubit-ubitan above and the slower moving gending line below. On the ubit-ubitan staff the stems-down part is known as polos (basic). The stems-up part is the sangsih (different or complementary). As most Balinese music has an end-accented character, the staff notation places the beginning of a four-note group apart and unbeamed at the end of each pattern. The three tones that complete it on repeat are shown at the beginning.” Tenzer (2024) [4.2] English B: “To introduce some cross-cultural perspective, Example 3 reproduces my typology of ubit-ubitan patterns, based also on sensitivity to contour but differently than Geria (Tenzer 2000a, 225; Tenzer 2000b). I separate ubit-ubitan into two collections, ubit telu (ubit “three”, shown at left) and ubit empat (ubit “four”, shown at right). This is such a quotidian distinction for Balinese that Geria did perhaps not even consider invoking it. In ubit telu patterns, three contiguous scale-tone pitches are used, and the polos and sangsih parts always share the middle pitch. In ubit empat a fourth pitch is added such that each part has its own two pitches, and when the low part sounds its lower pitch, the high part always sounds its higher one. This generates dyads that protrude from the texture as cross-rhythms when patterns repeat. Aside from this, though, the collections of ubit telu and ubit empat patterns are identical from the standpoint of the contours of the lower three pitches in each.” (Tenzer (2024) [5.3])

\ud5e4\ud14c\ub85c\ud3ec\ub2c8 hetelopon.text: Korean A: "그래서 제가 느낀 것입니다만, 어쩌면 빗나간 생각인지 도 모르겠으나 '헤테로포니'라는 말이 있잖습니까. 그걸 지극히 명 하게 말하자면, 주(호)가 되는 선율과 동시에 장식적인 것이 존재한 나는 것입니다. 하나의 본질적인 것이 동시에 다양한 상을 취하 면서 공존해가는 것이 헤테로포니 형태라고 생각합니다만, 선생님의 지금 말씀으로 미루어보자면 그 '하우프트톤'과 헤테로포니는 관계 가 있지 않을는지요?" (Yun (1991) - Korean, 149) English A: "I have sensed from your description, maybe I am off-topic here, but do you know the term “heterophony”? To put it concisely, it means the coexistence of the main melody and an embellishing melody. I think, in heterophony, an essential idea simultaneously takes various appearances [상, 像] and they coexist. Based on what you have described, wouldn’t there be a correlation between the Hauptton concept and heterophony?" (Park (2024)  [2.1])

\u0443\u0441\u0443\u043b/usul.text: Bulgarian A: “В турската (персо-арабската) музика се среща ⅝ 6 такт при същата бързина с разложени елементи във веселите завършъци на пешрефите или шаркиите, изпълнявани без думи (само с инструмент), и се нарича усул джурджина.” Hristov (1925) [p. 43] ”Думата „усул" ( корен, принцип ) в арабската музика се употребява в смисъл на ритъм, такт. Джурджина е турска дума и значи веселост.” Hristov (1925) [p. 43, footnote] English A: “In Turkish (Persian-Arabic) music 5/16 meter is found, with the same tempo of subdivided elements, in the cheerful endings of the peşrevs or şarkıs performed without words (only instrumentally), and it is called usul curcuna.” Goldberg (2024) [5.3] “In Arabic music the word “usul” (root, principle) is used with the meaning of rhythm, meter. Curcuna is a Turkish word, and it means merriment.” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 18] **Types of усул/usul: усул джурджина/usul curcuna,  мандра усул/mandra usul or farmer’s usul (мандренски усул/mandrenki usul) (See Goldberg (2024) [5.20] and Hristov (1925) [p. 49]) Bulgarian B: “Усул (араб. начин, метод) ритъм, B който се бият ударните инструменти в арабската, турската и персийската музика. Мелодиите обикновено се придружават два малки тимпана, единият с по-глуха звучност, ударът върху който се казва дум (dum), другият с по-светла звуч- HOCT - тек (tek). Тези два удара се ре- дуват в най-различни последователности, очертаващи голямо разнообразие от так- тове, между които 5, 7, 9, 13-временни. Chetrikov (1979) [p. 348-349]

repetition.text: Source: “Based upon this distinctive character, Ulhôa makes the point that Brazilian popular song produces a circular feel (in contrast to what she calls the linear feel of much Western art music). However, when all the layers stress, for example, the first beat of a pattern, it may also produce a circular feel, in fact—see, for example, Snead’s analysis of how repetition in many African American musics makes the groove cut back to its own beginning (Snead 1984).” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [4]) Definition: “Music. The repeating of a passage; a repeated passage; = repeat n. 1a; (also) the repeating of a note or chord. Frequently in sign (mark, strike, etc.) of repetition: = repeat” (Oxford English Dictionary, “repetition” III.5.b.)

vogais.text: English A: “Melody is generally associated with the human voice; we think of it in terms of the continuous sound of singing. Singing, in turn, uses verbal language, whose minimum components are vowels and consonants. A song made only with vowels intoned in a continuous melodic line produces a melody in its closest state to human expression.” (Stover (2024) [2.3]) Portuguese A: “A melodia está geralmente associada à voz humana, pensamos nela em termos do som contínuo do canto. O canto por sua vez utiliza a linguagem verbal, cujos componentes mínimos são as vogais e consoantes. Um canto feito somente com vogais, entoadas numa linha melódica contínua produz uma melodia no seu estado mais próximo da sensibilidade humana.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u4e61 xi\u0101ng.text: Chinese A: 区域；地方. 泛指城市以外的农村地区。 (Hanyu dacidian (乡, 2–3)  Chinese B: “中华人民共和国境内主要从事农业、其人口分布情况比城镇分散的农村基层行政区域单位。新中国成立后,乡是农村基层行政区域单位。1958年实现农村人民公社化,撤销乡建制,实行人民公社政社合一体制。1982年宪法改变政社合一管理体制,恢复乡作为农村基层行政区域单位,其规模以原人民公社的范围为基础,设立乡人民代表大会和乡人民政府。” Beijing daxue faxue (1999) p. 520 English: Regional (see 乡韵 xiāngyùn )

eighth tone.text: Source: “Carrillo justified this sixteenth-tone limit for his microtonal system by arguing that it was practical. Within a single composition, he pointed out, sixteenth tones could be multiplied to form eighth tones, quarter tones, semitones, and whole tones, and so could be reconciled with a variety of microtonal and traditional instruments (Carrillo 1938, 24).” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.4]

angkus prana.text: Balinese A: “Swara patut salendro, swara patut pelog, ika swara kaingkup dening sarira, marmanya ingaranan angkus prana.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “The sound of the slendro scale, the sound of the pelog scale, they are the essence of sound, which is called angkus prana.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.4])

\ud55c\uad6d\uc758 \uc804\ud1b5\uc545\ua.text: 한국의: Korean 악기: musical instruments Korean A: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

Eri Obo.text: English A: “You can also find this (ubọ-aka) in Ikwere/It is popular there/They call it Eri Obo/In ikwere, the place that is formerly Igweocha, now Port Harcourt, It is a common practice to play it (ubọ-aka/Obo).” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “O nwekwalụ ebe ihe a dị n'Ikwere, Ọ dị rinne Ihe a na-akpọ ya bụ Eri Ọbọ/N'ikwere, ee, ebe wụbụ Igweocha, Port Harcourt/ A na-akpọ ya rii nne.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

guru dakin.text: English A: “In contrast, the bera pada that follow the däkum ata Sinhala verses contain drum vocables associated with dawula drums (e.g., jeṃgu jeṃ) as well as actual Sinhala words with referential meaning (e.g., guru dakin, meaning “witness the teacher”), and the bera pada that follow the upat kavi Sinhala verses use non-lexical phrases that are mostly not part of the established drum vocabulary (e.g., kunḍala kura kata).” (Peiris (2024) [4.4])

\u5999\u5473 my\u014d aji.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 今 度 は 器 楽 曲 に 移 り ま し て 、 す べ て の 器 楽 曲 は ま ず 声 楽 から 受 け 継 い で 、 そ れ を 発 展 さ せ た も の とい っ て も い い わ け で す 。 た と え ば 「 ⽝ 等 」と い い ま し て 、 横 笛 を ⾧ く し た 形 の 韓 国 の 民 族 楽 器 が あ り ま し て 、 そ れ で 奏 さ れ る 節 回 し は 歌 唱 を 受 け 継 い だ も の で す 。そ し て 、 そ こ に は 線 的 な ⾳ 楽 の 妙 味 が ある わ け で す.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5])

entona\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “A complete study of musical prosody—including intonation, accent, melody, rhythm, and specific interpretative practices—is beyond the limits of this article, which is limited to discussing melody, melody and spoken language, and the relationship between melody and accompaniment in Brazilian popular song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Um estudo completo da prosodia musical - incluindo entonação, acento, melodia, ritmo e práticas interpretativas específicas - foge aos limites deste estudo, que se limita a discutir melodia, melodia e língua falada e a relação melodia e acompanhamento na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Entonação do som, ou Altura. É a sua posição na escala dos sons. Quanto mais elevado fôr o número de vibrações por segundo, mais agudo será o som.” (Cosme (1957), 46)

ordem temporal.text: English A: “What is quite prominent in sub-Saharan African music is the establishment of a temporal order based on the interaction of multiple parts that produce a polyrhythmic texture. The structure of its rhythmic organization is based on asymmetrical groupings of minimum time units or “fastest pulses,” as explained by Kwabena Nketia in The Music of Africa (1974). There is no vertical alignment at the beginning of the measure, as in European notions of meter [compasso].” (Stover (2024) [4.4]) Portuguese A: “O que é bastante proeminente na música africana, sub-saarana, é o estabelecimento de uma ordem temporal, baseada na interação de partes múltiplas que produzem uma textura polirítmica. A organização rítmica se estrutura a partir de agrupamentos assimétricos de unidades de tempo mínimas ou "pulso mais rápido", como explica Kwabena Nketia no seu livro The Music of Africa (1974). Não existe um alinhamento vertical dos inícios dos tempos, como nas noções europeias de compasso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

rhythmic tolerance.text: Source: “This is a possibility here because a perceptual structure of considerable “rhythmic tolerance,” as Johansson (2010) has named it, is established from the very beginning of this performance. Thus, the temporal flexibility for experiencing two divergent streams as one coherent structure is considerable.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [3])

tone color.text: Source: “The artistic act of a singer interpreting and directing a story through sound is not an undirected improvisation, but—as in music composition—is carried out within a framework of three musical elements: tone color, mode, and rhythmic pattern.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “Timbre; hence tone-coloured adj., tone-colouring.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “tone color”)

\u80fd no.text: Japanese A: “"しかし、私の音楽が長時間緊張感を保っているということは、全くそのとおりなんです。私の音楽の根本をなしている線的な要素が、巧妙に持続性を持っており、そのナチュール自体が、持続の無限な可能性を持っているのです。たとえば能の音楽とか歌舞伎のように、何時間同じ線を聴いても絶対飽きない秘密がこれなんです." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3]) Japanese B: “役者が歌いながら演ずる。“猿楽”とも言 い、明治以後は“能楽”とも言う、室町時代初,大和猿楽に属する 結崎座の観阿弥清次、及びその子世阿弥元清が*猿楽能を向上発達せ しめて芸術的に優れたものにした、その座を観世座と称した。これに つれて同じく大和猿楽に属する外山座(宝生座)、円満井座(金春座), 坂戸座(金剛座)もこれに合流して、ここに能の4座を作り上げた。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 141]

angindira.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan angindra artinya pencarian atau pangalihan gending-gending (wiwitan) namanya. Pukulan sendiri dan agak bervariasi yang memberi tanda pembukaan lagu. Makanya banyak pukulan trompong. Seperti: 1. wiwitan, 2. nabhe (nguluin), 3. ngembat, 4. nyiliasih, 5. ngoret, 6. ngantu, 7. ngunda, 8. nerumpuk.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Playing andira means to look for or seek the beginning (wiwitan) of a composition. There are many ways for the trompong, playing alone, to do this. For example: 1. wiwitan, 2. nabhe (nguluin), 3. ngembat, 4. nyiliasih, 5. ngoret, 6. ngantu, 7. ngunda, 8. nerumpuk.” Tenzer (2024) [III.9]

p\u00e9log.text: English A: “Geria’s examples all apply to the trompong, an instrument forefronted in prestigious court gamelan—the palegongan, semar pagulingan, and the gong gdé. I show both the kepatihan (cipher notation) provided and my own modified 3-line staff for the trompong and, when needed, a single-line staff for jegogan. Geria notated his examples on particular pitches in a five-tone pélog, conventionally numbered 1,2,3,5, and 6. But they could be played at any transposition.” Tenzer (2024)  [3.1] English B: “The sound of the slendro scale, the sound of the pelog scale, they are the essence of sound, which is called angkus prana.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.4]) Balinese B: “Swara patut salendro, swara patut pelog, ika swara kaingkup dening sarira, marmanya ingaranan angkus prana.” (Geria (n.d.)) Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Iti swara ring pangider-ideran, inamet ring Swara Genta Pinara Pitu. Panca swara patut Pelog, panca swara patut Slendro. Iki inangge ring tabuh-tabuhan, mwang swara patut pitu. Apan Swapiaki wus pinarah ti denira Sang Kawi, marmanya hana Dasa Swara umungguh ring pangider-ideran. Mangkana wetnya.” (Bandem (1986), 42) English C (Chat GPT Translation): “These are the sounds in circular motion (swara ring pangider-ideran), embodied in the Seven Tones of the Sacred Bell (Swara Genta Pinara Pitu). The Panca Swara (Five Sounds) are aligned with Pelog, and the Panca Swara are aligned with Slendro. These are used in musical instruments (tabuh-tabuhan) and correspond to the seven musical tones. Since the system has been arranged by Sang Kawi (the sacred poet/sage), the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds) are positioned within the circular motion of sound. Thus, this is how it manifests.”  Balinese D: “Iti swara papatutan tiga, ring luhur swara patut Pelog, ring madya swara patut Pitu, ring sor swara patut Slendro. Tri swa-ra patutan iki kang inangge salwiring tatabuhan sami, mwang salwiring wirama katekatekeng sarwa Pupuh Kakidungan.” (Bandem (1986), 44) English D (ChatGPT Translation): “These sounds are arranged into three categories: These three divisions of sound are used in all musical instruments (tatabuhan) and serve as the foundation for all rhythms (wirama), as well as the various forms of sung poetry (Pupuh Kakidungan).”

co-articulating.text: Source: “In addition, while Keil wanted to direct attention to the vital effects produced by musicians co-articulating the same beat and thus contributing to the same auditory stream (Bregman 1994), métrica derramada asks musicians (and listeners) to refer to the same beat in two different streams.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [6])

mode.text: 악조 akjo / 조 jo (Korean) 音调 yīndiào / 调 diào (Chinese) Source: “The artistic act of a singer interpreting and directing a story through sound is not an undirected improvisation, but—as in music composition—is carried out within a framework of three musical elements: tone color, mode, and rhythmic pattern.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “A term in Western music theory with three main applications, all connected with the above meanings of modus: the relationship between the note values longa and brevis in late medieval notation; interval, in early medieval theory; and, most significantly, a concept involving scale type and melody type. The term ‘mode’ has always been used to designate classes of melodies, and since the 20th century to designate certain kinds of norm or model for composition or improvisation as well.” (Powers, Harold S., Frans Wiering, James Porter, James Cowdery, Richard Widdess, Ruth Davis, Marc Perlman, Stephen Jones, and Allan Marett. "Mode." Grove Music Online. 2001)

jit.text: Sinhalese A: “tat-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? jit-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? ton-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? nam-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki?” Peiris (2024) [9] English A: “Unto whom is the syllable tat a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable jit a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable ton a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable nam a salutation?” Peiris (2024) [9] English B: mnemonic syllable for a drum stroke (Peiris (2025))

\uc9c4\uc591\uc870 jinyangjo.text: Korean A: “자진모리伽倻琴散調는 대개 진양조, 중모리, 중중모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리 6樂章으로 되어 있고, 一般 的으로 羽調, 界面調, 平調를 使用하고 있다.” (Shin (2018) , 248) English A: “Gayageum sanjo typically comprises six movements: jinyangjo, jungmori, jungjungmori, jajinmori, hwimori, and danmori; it commonly utilizes Ujo, Gyemyeonjo, and Pyeongjo.” (Kim (2024)  [3.2]) English B: 1. a jangdan indicating slow tempo 2. musical piece (Pyǒn (2012) 157)Korean B: 판소리, 산조, 민요, 전라도무악※에서 쓰이는 장단의 하나. 진 양이라고도 한다. 민속악 장단 중 가장 느린 장단으로 한 장단 은 6박 또는 6박을 한 각으로 하는 2~4개의 각으로 구성되기도 한다. (Pyǒn (2012) 157)

Acordes fundamentales.text: Spanish A: “Son los que tienen sus sonidos en intervalos simultáneos de 3.ª, que es el orden más sencillo. Según unos autores, no hay más acordes fund. que los perfectos y el de 7.ª dominante; según otros, lo son también los de 7.ª contradominante y los de 9.ª mayor y 9." menor.” Lacál (1900) [p. 5] Spanish B: “Son aquellos cuyos sonidos aparecen en el orden más sencillo, esto es, en intervalos simultáneos de tercera. Según algunos teóricos no existen más acordes fundamentales que los perfectos y el de séptima dominante: según otros, son acordes fundamentales todos los de séptima, contra dominante ó de segundo grado, (de segunda ó tercera especie)” Pedrell (1890) [p. 5]

\u7fbd y\u01d4.text: Chinese A: “《礼记·乐记》：“宫爲君，商爲臣，角爲民，徵爲事，羽爲物；五者不亂，則無怗懘之音矣。” Hanyu dacidian  (宫) Chinese B: “《宋书·谢灵运传论》：“欲使宫羽相變，低昂互節。若前有浮聲，則後須切響。” Hanyu dacidian  (羽) English: Pentatonic pitch class 4 Synonymous terms: la (sung jianpu 简谱), 6 (written jianpu 简谱), 五/四 (gongchepu 工尺谱) Lam (2024) Ex. 2.2 Lam (2024) Ex. 2.1

nerumpuk.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan nerumpuk artinya membuat penimbunan atau pengumpulan barang sesuatu yang dicintai. Merupakan pukulan di atas sebuah nada yang diulang berkali-kali biasanya dengan ritme yang bergerak makin lama makin cepat atau sebaliknya.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Nerumpuk means to hoard or bundle together beloved possessions. A tone is repeated several times in a rhythm that gets slower or faster bit by bit.” Tenzer (2024) [III.5] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u5531\u8bcd ch\u00e0ngc\u00ed.text: Chinese: “亦作“唱辭”。戏曲或歌曲里供歌唱的文字部分.” Hanyu dacidian (唱词) English: Among all genres of vocal music, the element involving spoken sounds is known as chàngcí (literally, “sung words”). That is, what is in opera known as “libretto” and in songs known as “lyrics” are in a more general sense for all vocal genres collectively known as chàngcí. (Qian (2024)) For further discussion, see Qian (2024), section 2.

\u0435\u043b\u0435\u043d\u0441\u043a\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Вторият вид 7/16 такт се образува от втори вид 5/16 с прибавка в края на още една кратка част и служи за основа на обикновено хоро, което се играе във всички краища на България. В Македония е основата на македонското хоро. При песни със същия такт в Еленско играят хоро "еленско хоро", в Добруджа — мъжка ръченица и пр.” Hristov (1925) [p. 47-48] English A: “The second type of 7/16 meter is formed from the second type of 5/16 with the addition of one more short part at the end; this meter also serves as the basis of an ordinary horo that is danced in all regions of Bulgaria. In Macedonia it is the basis for makedonsko horo. In songs with the same meter in the Elena region they dance the horo called “elensko horo,” in Dobrudzha—mŭzhka rŭchenitsa, etc.” Goldberg (2024) [5.14] See also: хоро/horo

\uc21c\uc218\ud55c \uc74c sunsuhan eum.text:
순수한 + 음 eum  순수한: pure (see also: 순수성 sunsuseong) 
 Korean A: “그러니까 그런 이미지네이션이 여기저기서 포착될 뿐이지요. 그러나 나는 작곡가로서 그런 판타지를 갖는 것이 창작에 커다란 힘이 되고 있어요. 순수한 음만으로 1960년대부터 70년대 초기까지 작곡을 해봤지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 159] English A: “In other words, those imaginations are only captured here and there. As a composer, however, those fantastical stories greatly aid my creative process. I had been composing with pure sounds [absolute music?] from the 1960s until the early 1970s.” Park (2024) [5.3]

Melod\u00eda.text: Spanish A: “pero [el canon] afectaba únicamente la velocidad o la lentitud de un tema, haciendo más aprisa o más despacio una melodía, lo que nada tenía en el fondo que pudiera sugerir la metamorfosis como yo la entiendo: pues la modificación era fácilmente reconocible”  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] (See also Canon) English A: “But canon affected only the speed or the length of a theme, made a melody quicker or slower, without having anything at its basis that could suggest metamorphosis as I understand it. Its modification was easily recognizable.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “La dulzura, primor y blandura de la voz y canto suave y armonioso.” Palatín (1990) [p. 75] Spanish C: “De la acertada sucesión de distintas frases y periodos compuestos de notas musicales, resulta lo que se llama melodía. Colocando unas notas al lado de otras, siguiendo un orden, un modelo intelectual, casando de este modo ó del otro los tonos, fórmase un conjunto, una serie que se extiende en el tiempo, y resulta un a buena melodía ó una mala melodía.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 279]

Igbo tonal language.text: Source: “Furthermore, the ubọ-aka has the potential for inclusion in African music education in schools, colleges, and higher institutions of learning. It can be used to teach traditional scales, melodic and rhythmic patterns, interval relationships, and the Igbo tonal language due to its eight metal keys, which, according to Eze, are linguistically tuned and representative of the Igbo traditional modal structure.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.5]

\u0445\u0440\u043e\u043d\u043e\u0441 \u0.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] “В старогръцката теория се говори покрай „chronos protos" за величина на „chronos alogoi" — ирационално удължено време. „Така обикновен pyrchihios” Hristov (1925) [p. 42, Footnote] English A: “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6] “In ancient Greek theory, alongside “chronos protos” is mentioned a value of “chronos alogoi”—an irrationally elongated beat. Thus an ordinary “pyrrhus” with an irrational elongation of the second part produces [eighth note and dotted eighth note] (the form of the above meter).” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 16]

Cook (1995).text: Cook, Scott. “‘Yue Ji’ 樂記 -- Record of Music: Introduction, Translation, Notes, and Commentary.” Asian Music 26, no. 2 (1995): 1–96. https://doi.org/10.2307/834434.

\u65e5\u672c\u7684\u306a\u3082\u306e Nih.text: Japanese A: “しかもこれによってわれわれは、「音楽における日本的なもの」の１つの側面を確実にとらえることができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 15] English A: “Furthermore, with this melodic construction based on nuclear tones we can reliably consider this as one aspect of “Japaneseness in music.”” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [10]

gamelan bebarongan.text: English A: “The technique of playing gendér in the gamelan bebarongan [much like the pelegongan, and used to accompany the dance of the lion-dragon barong] is called untal-antil [to wave back-and-forth like the barong’s tail].” (Tenzer (2024) [II.6]) Balinese/Indonesian A: “Pukulan gendér babarongan, untal antil namanya.” (Geria (n.d.))

\uad81\uc911\uc74c\uc545 gungjungeumak.text: Korean A: “이제 생각해 보아야할 문제는, 판소리에서 악조를 판별하는 데 있어서 구성음(출현음)을 중요 하게 볼 것이냐, 주요 선을 골격과 시김을 중요하게 볼 것이냐 하는 점이다. 그리고 이는 판소리 의 음악 특성이 고려되어야 한다. 궁중음악이나 양반들 풍류음악의 경우에는 음악 자체에 시김이 크게 강조되지 않는다. 농현과 추성, 퇴성 등을 하지만, 농현의 깊이가 깊지 않고, 추성과 퇴성의 정도 역시 마찬가지이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 247] English A: “The crucial consideration is therefore whether to prioritize the constituent notes or the primary melodic structure and sigim[sae] in identifying the mode in pansori, taking into account the musical attributes of pansori. Sigim[sae] is not a significant focus in court or aristocratic entertainment music. [When looking at instrumental court music’s modal theory by comparison,] the vibration of string, called nonghyeon 농현 [string play], is the shallowest, and chuseong 추성 [a slow rise in pitch] and toeseong have similar qualities.” Kim (2024) [3.32]

gend\u00e9r.text: English A: “gendér (metallophone played with a round-headed mallet in each hand),” (Tenzer (2024) [2.1]) Balinese B: “1) instrumen berbilah pipih dr perunggu dg bilah bergantung pd pelawah dan ditopang dg tumpuan besi agar tidak bersentuhan antara bilah yg satu dan bilah yg lain, dimainkan dg kedua belah tangan yg menggunakan panggul sambil memukul sakaligus menutup dg tangan; 2) gangsa;” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 144, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\uc18c\ub098\ud0c0 \ud615\uc2dd sonata h.text: 형식: form Korean A: “니시무라 시(時)에 대한 사고방식이 형식관(形式觀)에 반영된 예로서 서양에는 소나타 형식이 있습니다만, 소나타 형식이라고 하면 제1주제부가 있고 제2주제부가 있다. 이들은 대립된 구간(區間)이며 제2주제 부분은 제1주제와 다른 시간을 독자적으로 형성하 는 것이기 때문에 순간에 세계를 갖는 음양과는 전혀 다르다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157-158] English A: “The Sonata form might be one example that reflects the Western formalistic view of time. In Sonata form, there are primary and secondary theme areas. They are contrasting sections that independently develop [the sense of] time. Therefore, it is completely different from yin and yang, which contain an eternity in a moment.” Park (2024) [4.2]

\u76c6\u8e0a\u5504 bon\u2019odori uta.text: 盆踊+唄 唄: song Japanese A: “この関係をもっと明らかにするために掲げたのがＢの例で、この盆踊唄は終始dis―aisという４度音程の支配下にある。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 2] English A: “I have brought out example B in order to make this relationship clearer. This bon-odori song from beginning to end is under the control of the interval of a fourth between D♯ and A♯.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.2] “Bon-odori 盆踊り refers to a dance (odori) for the o-bon festival, one held in (usually) July or August, at which ancestral spirits are venerated. It is cognate with the Chinese Zhongyuan or Hungry Ghost Festival, and to the Korean Baekjung.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 3] Japanese B: “民俗芸能の一、お盆の期節に寺の庭や町の広場で老 若男女大勢集まって踊ること、全国にわたり広く行われており、歌を歌って踊るだけのものから、三味線、笛、太鼓などの囃子を用いるも の、種々の衣装や装飾物を用いるもの、また踊りの輪の中心に高い櫓 を築き、歌手が櫓の上で歌うもの、大道を練り歩くものなど地方によ って千差万別である。” Tanabe (1975) [”盆踊,” p. 167-168]

deng.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Dari 10 (sepuluh) nada yang dijiwai oleh Smara dan Ratih sebagai Dewa Percintaan bersumber pada 7 (tujuh) buah nada yang urutan nadanya sebagai berikut: ding, dong, deng, ndung, dung, dang, nding. Ketujuh nada di atas merupakan sumber bunyi dalam gambelan Bali dan menurut Prakempa bunyi (suara) itu disebut Genta Pinara Pitu (bunyi berjarak tujuh) (alinea : 7 - 10).” Bandem (1986) [p. 13] Balinese D: “1) salah satu nada pd laras ding-dong; 2)  nada ketiga dr gamelan gong pancanada; 3) salah satu saih yg digunakan pd perangkat gamelan Slonding dr Desa Asak, Kabupaten Amlapura, dg urutan nada 124 5 6; 4) nada yg timbul jika semua lubang pd tutupan suling ditutup, dua jari bawah dibuka akan menimbulkan nada dung, satu jari berikutnya dibuka akan menimbulkan nada dang, jari nomor dua dr atas dibuka akan menimbulkan nada ding, dan jari yg paling atas dibuka akan menimbulkan nada dong.” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 158, Bidang Istilah Musik, “ndéng”]

\u697d\u8b5c gakufu.text: 楽 gaku +譜 譜: (sheet) music, (musical) note, (musical) score Japanese A: “譜２５のＡは、任意に拾いあげた民謡の一例を、楽譜の上段には終止音gとdにより、それぞれ支配的な楽句を区分し、下段には終止音間の４度音程と５度音程によって、それぞれの占める楽句を区分したものである。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] Japanese B: “楽 曲 を ⼀ 定 の 記 譜 法 に し た が っ て 紙 ⾯ 上 に 記 し た も の 。 現 在 は 主 と し て * 五 譜 を さ す が 、 広 く は こ れ に 限 ら な い 。 → 記 譜 法” (Tomosha (2002), 135) English A: “Example 25A (Example 1) takes an arbitrarily-chosen example of a folk song, and above the notation divides the various musical phrases into those controlled by the ending note G and those controlled by D. Below it, it divides the phrases bounded by the interval of a fourth from those bounded by a fifth.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1]

srada.text: Balinese A: “smara ngaran laki, ratih ngaran wadu, swaraning smara ngaran kama nada, swaraning ratih ngaran kama sraga. Rikalanya anunggal swara ika, hana swara karenga ngararengih ngalup manis, kadi reng pangucapira sanghyang smara ratih, patemuan nira murda, ring murda panunggara nira sanghyang ardanareswari, apan sira wenang surup sinurup, ganti gumanti, matemahan ring windu nada candra.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: ““Semara” indicates male, “Ratih” indicates female, the voice of Semara is called kama nada, [kama = desire; nada = tone] the voice of Ratih is called kama sraga [sraga = form]. When these voices become one, there is a tinkling, sweet sound, like the vibrations of Sang Hyang Semara and Ratih’s words at their summit, at the highest realm of Sang Hyang Ardanareswari [a manifestation of Siva and his consort Parvati unifying male and female] because he can go in and out, again and again, on the tones of Windu Chandra [windu is a point, an essence; chandra can suggest brightness or the moon].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.6])

\ub2e8\uc6d0\uc801 dan-wonjeog.text: Korean A: " 나의 음악은 단원적(monistisch)입니다. 내음악은 사 음악적이 아니며 다원적인 음악이 아닙니다. 예를 들면 알로이 스 추머만의 음악은 다원적인 음악이지요. 근원을 달리하는 음악 요소가 동시에 흐르면서 질서를 유지하고, 대립하면서도 마침내는화합하여 음악적으로 크게 향상한다는 것이지요. " (Yun (1991) - Korean 149–150) English A: "My music is monistic (monistisch). My music is not polyphonic or pluralistic. For example, Bernd Alois Zimmermann’s music is pluralistic. Elements from different roots flow together, maintain order, oppose, but ultimately come together to greatly elevate the music." (Park (2024) [2.1])

Nota.text: Spanish A: “La diferencia fundamental entre estos procedimientos y los de mis “Leyes de metamorfosis” consiste en que en los ejemplos que he citado de los más eminentes maestros clásicos se alteran las melodías con sonidos que no contiene el original, y en mis “Leyes de metamorfosis” no se agrega ni se quita ni una sola nota de las que escribieron los autores, y eso no sólo en su parte melódica, sino también en la armónica y en la rítmica. En la rítmica y la melódica hay todo un mundo de posibilidades jamás presentidas antes de la revolución del Sonido 13.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 18] English A: “The fundamental difference between these procedures and those of my “Laws of Metamorphosis” is that in the examples I have cited by the most eminent classical maestros, melodies are altered with sounds not contained in the original. In my “Laws of Metamorphosis,” not a single note is added or removed from what the author wrote originally, neither in its melodic aspect, nor even in its harmonic and rhythmic aspects. In the rhythmic and melodic domains there is a whole world of possibilities never anticipated before the revolution of Sonido 13.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 18] Spanish B: “Cualquiera de los caracteres de que usan los músicos en la practica de su arte.” Palatín (1990) [p. 78] Spanish C: “Signo ó carácter de música que sirve para designar y determinar el sonido, su entonación (según su colocación en el pentágrama), su duración  (según su figura) y su efecto expresivo (según el matiz que lo precisa).” Pedrell (1890) [p. 313]

\uc131\uc545\uc774 seong-ag-i.text: Korean A: “그래요. 엄격한 아악의 음악 짜임새와 철학적 내용, 거기서 유창하게 흐르는 선적인 아름다움을 보여주는 이를테면 남도창이라 든가 가곡이라는 형식의 일련의 성악이 있는데, 그런 데서 많은 걸 배웠어요. 거기서 나아가 선적인 움직임에 대한 음악적 이론을 대체적으로 체계지은 것이지요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: “Yes. I learned a lot from A-ak’s strict organization and philosophical content, and vocal music’s smoothly flowing linear beauty, such as Namdo Chang and Gagok [가곡], or other vocal genres.(4) Based on these, I organized my own musical theory of linear motion." (Park (2024) [1.4])

\u5546 sh\u0101ng.text: Chinese A: “《礼记·乐记》：“宫爲君，商爲臣，角爲民，徵爲事，羽爲物；五者不亂，則無怗懘之音矣。” Hanyu dacidian  (宫) Chinese B: “《老残游记》第十回：“如兩人同彈此曲，則彼此宫商皆合而爲一。” Hanyu dacidian  (商) English: Pentatonic pitch class 1 Synonymous terms: re(sung jianpu 简谱), 2 (written jianpu 简谱), 尺 (gongchepu 工尺谱) Lam (2024) Ex. 2.2 Lam (2024) Ex. 2.1

\u015babda p\u016bj\u0101va.text: English A: “The first set of sung verses presented here—in Paragraphs 9 and 12—belongs to the genre known as däkum ata, which is performed as an “offering of sound” (śabda pūjāva) during a Bera Pōya Hēvisi ritual. Each line in these verses contains eighteen poetic morae. Although this repertoire is more closely associated with dawula drums (Example 3), in the recording featured here—Videos 1 and 2—they are performed with gäṭa beraya drums (Example 4).” Peiris (2024) [8] English B: “ “sound offering,” a type of ritual” (Peiris (2025)

tercina.text: Portuguese A: “É uma realização imediata e espontânea das nossas maneiras de dançar, mais sensuais, provindas do clima talvez, e do amolecimento fisiológico das raças que se caldearam pra nos formar e formaram também o remeleixo, o requebro, o dengue. É o movimento dengoso do corpo na dança que deformou a rítmica da polca primeiramente na rítmica da habanera em seguida no do maxixe. Acresce ainda que em habaneras e danzones é comum o elemento da tercina (ver se a tercina ocorre no primeiro tempo).” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Here, syncopation is of immediate, constant, and directly choreographic application. In America, syncopation does not come from European syncopation. It is an immediate and spontaneous realization of our ways of dancing, more sensual, perhaps stemming from the climate, and the physiological softening of the races that melded to form us and also formed the remeleixo, the requebro, the dengue. It is the languid body movement in dance that deformed the rhythm of the polka first into the rhythm of the habanera and then into that of the maxixe. Furthermore, in habaneras and danzones, the element of triplet (check if the triplet occurs on the first beat) is common.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

gamelan pelegongan.text: English A: “Gamelan pelegongan is an ensemble similar to semar pegulingan that accompanies the iconic legong dance genre] is called tadah rawit [this means “of small and beautiful character,” a resonance much like the characterization of semar pegulingan in II.2 above.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.5]) See semar pagulingan

\uae30\uc545\uace1 giaggog.text: Korean A: “그게 이번에는 기악곡으로 옮겨가는데, 모든 기억 곡은 먼저 성악곡으로부터 이어받아 그것을 발전시킨 것이라고 해도 좋겠지요. 예를 들면 '대금'이라는 횡적을 길게 한 형태 의 한국 민족악기가 있는데, 그걸로 연주하는 가락은 가창을 이어받 은 것이지요. 그런데 거기에는 선적인 음악의 묘미가 있어요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: “And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5])

\uc545\uc870 akjo.text: Korean A: “한국음악학에서 판소리 악조에 대한 논의는 오랜 기간 여러 학자들에 의해 시도되었다. 그러 나 여전히 공통의 합의가 이루어지지 못하고, 여러 다른 악조론으로 음악을 분석하고 있다. 그 중 가장 대표적인 판소리 악조론은 백대웅과 이보형의 이론으로, 계면조에 대해서는 이견이 없 으나, 이들의 서로 다른 우조와 평조에 대한 해석이 후속 학자들에 의해 활용되고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 234] English A: “Although Korean musicologists have long debated the melodic modes in pansori, there is a lack of consensus regarding the identification of the pansori modes, which they have attempted to define based on different modal theories. The theories of Baek Daewoong (1974–2011) and Lee Bohyeong (b. 1937) are the representative views of pansori scales. While Baek and Lee concur on the criteria for Gyemyeonjo, they diverge on the modes for Ujo and Pyeongjo.” Kim (2024) [1.1] Korean B: “선율의 구조적 특징을 나타내게 만드는 음악적 요소, 악조종의(樂調總義)에 나 오는 악조란 곡조의 선율구조를 결정짓는 모드(mode: 선법) 및 어느 선법(旋法)에 나오는 궁 (宮) 곧 중심음의 높낮이를 표시하는 키(key: 調)를 포괄하는 말이다. 다시 말해서, 중국의 오조(五調: 궁조·상조각조·치조·우조)는 다섯 선법명(旋法名)이고, 중국 5조의 치조(微調) 와 같다고 설명한 평조(平調)와 중국 5조의 우조(羽調)와 같다는 계면조(界面調)는 모두 선법명 이다. 그리고 속악(樂) 즉 향악(樂)에 사용된 7조, 곧 일지(一指)·이지(二)·삼지(三指)· 사지(四指) 속칭 황지(横指)·오지(五指) 속칭 우조(羽調)·육지(六指) 속칭 팔조(八調)·칠지(七 指) 속칭 막조(調)는 모두 중심음의 높낮이와 관련된 조명(調名)이다.” Song (2010) [p. 212]

\u63a1\u8b5c saifu.text: Japanese A: “つぎに掲げた譜２９はこの点を充分考慮した上で田中正平博士によって採譜されたものである.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “Example 29, which I’ll bring up next, was transcribed by the scholar Tanaka Shōhei after he had thought thoroughly about these points.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.1] Japanese B: “transcribing in musical notation, copying down (a tune)” (Japan Dict, https://www.japandict.com/採譜?lang=eng)

\uc815\uc5f0\ud55c \ubbf8\ud559\uc774 je.text: 정연한: well-organized; neat 미학: aesthetics Korean A: "단 거기에 도 물론 음을 만들고 음악을 지속시켜가는 것 자체의 질서, 정연한 미학이 없어서는 안되지요. 그 한 가지를 나는 동양인으로서 맨 먼저 발견했지요. 그것이 '하우프트톤'입니다. " (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "However, there still needs to be its own organizing principles [自体の秩序] and polished aesthetics [整然とした美学] for making and sustaining sound. I discovered one of those principles first as an East Asian composer. That is Hauptton. " (Park (2024) [2.4])

Zhongguo ci xue (1996).text: Zhongguo ci xue da cidian 中国词学大辞典. Ma Xingrong 马兴荣, Wu Xionghe 吴熊和, and Cao Jiping 曹济平 (eds.). Hangzhou: Zhejiang jiaoyu chuban she 杭州:浙江教育出版社, 1996.

\u4f5c\u66f2\u306e\u30de\u30c6\u30ea\u30.text: Japanese A: "日本の作曲家たちは、従来、作曲のマテリアルは、現代でも古い西洋の伝統的な形式観に何かしら沿っているのではないでしょうか。" (Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "Perhaps Japanese composers follow the old Western traditional formalism even though the compositional materials [マテリアル] might be modern." (Park (2024) [2.3])

Andrade (1989).text: Andrade, Mário de, Oneyda Alvarenga, and Flávia Camargo Toni. Dicionário Musical Brasileiro. [Brasília]: Ministério da Cultura, 1989.

\u90a6\u697d h\u014dgaku.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) Japanese B: “①広義には日本音楽の別名・洋楽に相対して言う。例、“邦楽鑑賞”、“邦楽の時間”(放送の場合)など、②近世邦楽に限 定して用いる名称。*神楽、*雅楽、*声明などを除き、琵琶楽、尺八 楽、筝曲,三味線音楽、民謡などを言う。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 165-166]

significado musical.text: English A: “In music of the classical-romantic European tradition, the articulation of the phrase can be inferred from the written score, at least in its most obvious aspects, such as duration, metric placement, harmonic rhythm, cadences, melodic direction, and so on. However, much of the musical meaning only emerges during the moment of performance. In performance, and especially in the case of popular song, singers use their interpretative skills to articulate and highlight the emotional content of each song.” (Stover (2024) [5.11]) Portuguese A: “Na música de tradição européia clássico-romântica, a articulação da frase pode ser inferida na partitura escrita, pelo menos nos seus aspectos mais óbvios, como duração, colocação métrica, ritmo harmônico, cadências, direção melódica, etc. Entretanto, muito do significado musical só emerge durante o momento da performance. Na performance, e, principalmente no caso da canção popular, cantores usam sua habilidade interpretativa para articular e salientar o conteúdo emocional de cada canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uae34\uc7a5 ginjang.text: Korean A: "그러나 나의 음악이 장시 긴장감을 유지하고 있다는 것은 사실입니다. 내 음악의 근본을 이부 고 있는 선적인 요소가 교묘히 지속성을 갖고 있는데, 그 본성 자체 가 지속의 무한한 가능성을 갖고 있어요. 예컨대 노나 가부키처럼 몇 시간씩 같은 선을 들어도 절대 물리지 않는 비밀이 이거지요." (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

Dong (1993).text: Dong, Haowen 董浩文. Zhongguo xiaoxue jiaoxue baike quanshu yinyue juan 中国小学教学百科全书 音乐卷. Xu Hanwan 徐汉文, Mao Kuangping 茅匡平, Peng Qiwan 彭其畹 (eds.). Shenyang: Shenyang Publishing House 沈阳:沈阳出版社, 1993.

\u97f3\u697d\u53f2 ongakushi.text: 音楽 ongaku + 史: history Japanese A: “そこで音楽史の順序とは逆に、もっとも身ぢかに存在するものから調べてゆくことにする。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 8] English A: “Thus in opposition to the usual order of music history, I have decided to begin my investigation from what exists close at hand.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [5.1]

monistic.text: Source: “As suggested, “tone,” for Yun, encompasses all number of embellishments, mutations, disturbances, and even redirections and superimpositions, what I will describe below as a monistic whole any given span of which should be thought of as an adumbration or perspective.” (Stover commentary (2024), [1.3]) Definition: “Of, relating to, or of the nature of monism; holding or advocating any of the doctrines or theories of monism.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “monistic”)

\u30af\u30bb kuse.text: Japanese A: “これはクセとよばれる部分の一部であるが、その４度音程をもつ上下動の中にも明瞭に核音の支配をうかがい知ることができる。これと同じ旋律的な弱吟という発声法によるクセの他の部分では、これよりもはるかに一語一音符的な（syllabic）スタイルによっており、” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “This is one part of something that might be called the kuse, and within the up-and-down motion across the interval of a fourth, we can clearly perceive the control of nuclear tones. In another part of the kuse, whose method of vocalization is called melodic yowagin, it is in a far more syllabic style (one word to one note) even than this.”Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.2]

rhythmic dissonance.text: Source: “Andrade theorizes syncopation in Brazilian music as a structural background pattern rather than a rhythmic dissonance that needs to resolve, which Menezes and Pires connect to theorizations of timeline patterns in African musics ([1.7]). Such structures function analogously to the backbeat pattern that underpins much Anglophone popular music.” Biamonte commentary (2024) [6]

anerang sasi.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat pat anerang sasi ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “if four it is called anerang sasi, [the clarity of moonlight];” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug babarangan Anutasih ngaran. Yaning gage-Bus ges der pewayahau umbans taruns ngarang tan pa selat Anunggalpati ngaran. Yaning gebug selat siki Chandrapra-ba ngaran. Yaning gebug selat kalih Paduarsa ngaran. Yaning gebug selat telu Dahanamuka ngaran. Yaning gebug selat pat Anerang sasih ngaran. Yaning gebug selat lima Anerang Wisaya ngaran. Yaning gebug selat nem Gana wedana ngaran.” (Bandem (1986), 68)

stage design.text: Source: “The translator’s choice of Shin Eun-Joo’s article on pansori is perfectly suited to presenting such an introduction. Pansori is one of the most important genres in Korean traditional music. Although frequently compared to Western classical opera due to their shared vocal and theatrical attributes, pansori is essentially an epic, narrative storytelling vocal performance executed by a singer and a drum accompanist without stage design or theatrical costumes. Unlike court or ritual music, pansori was first circulated among commoners and the lower class, and later enjoyed by all classes as a principal form of entertainment.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “Stage design represents the sum of the visual elements of theatrical production combining all forms of scenery, lighting, makeup and costumes (and sometimes the actual space in which the production is presented) to create an illusion of a place, space and time. Stage design is an ephemeral theatrical art, capable of realizing its full potential only in the context of a performance.” (Boetzkes, Manfred, Evan Baker, and Nicholas John. "Stage design." Grove Music Online. 2002)

\u4e50\u8bf4 yu\u00e8shu\u014d.text: English: ““Yuèshuō樂說” (literally “musical speech”) refers to speaking within traditional Chinese vocal musics. […] This concept covers all vocal sounds that differ from strict “singing” due to being recitative in style, such as various “shūo說,” “bái白,” “sòng誦,” “yīng吟” and other speaking sounds (which staff notation cannot accurately label) in vocal passages.” Qian (2024)

\u8981\u7d20 y\u014dso.text: Japanese A: “このどちらもが、日本の音階と旋律法のヨーロッパとの違いはもちろん、アジア音楽の中での、特異性をきわめて明確に規定する要素なのであるが、ここではまず前者について考えて見よう。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] English A: “For both of these, the differences between Japanese musical [scalar] rules and those of Europe are of course the elements make Asian music seem so extremely peculiar.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1, brackets added separately] Japanese B: “この音 には装飾音が欠けています。しかし、三 連符の頭の休符がそれにかわる働きをし ます。それに続いてメリスマ的な要素が ありますね。これはもう少し発展した「ハ ウプト・トン」のあり方なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English B: “There is no decorative tone for this. But the first rest of the triplet substitutes its role. It is followed by a melismatic element. This is a more developed figure of a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\uc9c4\uc591\uc7a5\ub2e8 jinyang jangdan.text: Korean B: “우조의 특징은 자진모리장단의 우조 대목에 나타나는 특징으로, 그 는 '자진모리-우조'라고 적음으로서 다른 장단의 우조 대목과 구별하였다. 또한, 가야금산조에 서 진양장단의 우조가 판소리에서 자진모리장단의 우조와 같이 La-re-mi 골격임을 지적함으로 서, 우조를 La-re-mi 골격으로 보았을 때 가야금산조와 판소리가 서로 통함을 드러내었다. 그 리고 La-re-mi 골격의 판소리 우조는 Sol-do-re 골격의 판소리 평조에 비하여 한 음씩 위인 점에서, 1970년대 김윤덕이 우조에 대해 "한 음 위의 조"라고 증언한 것과 연결 지었다.” Shin (2018) [p. 242] English B: “Lee’s description of Ujo’s traits recalls those of scenes in jajinmori jangdan. Lee specifies “jajinmori-Ujo” to distinguish it from Ujo scenes in other jangdan. Additionally, he notes that Ujo based on jajinmori jangdan in pansori has the same La-re-mi structure as Ujo in jinyang jangdan in gayageum sanjo; this indicates that gayageum sanjo and pansori strongly correspond with each other. The La-re-mi structure in pansori Ujo is also related to Kim Yundeok’s 1970s statement that Ujo is “a mode higher than a whole step,” since it is a step higher than the Sol-do-re structure in pansori Pyeongjo (Lee 2002, 218).” Kim (2024) [3.15]

\u8bcd\u724c c\u00ed p\u00e1i.text: Chinese A: “填词所用的曲调名称。最初的词,配合音乐歌唱,每首词都有固定的腔调,或者按词制调,或者依调填词。曲调名称(即词牌)一般根据词的内容而定。但到后来主要是依调填词,曲调和词的内容不一定有联系,各个调名只作为文字和音韵结构的定式,形成字数、句式、平仄、押韵等不同的各种格式,不再起标志乐调的作用。词牌各不相同,每个词牌都要求一首词要“调有定句,句有定字,字有定声”(明徐师曾《文体明辨序》)。一般必须按谱下字,不能随意改变。” Tang songci (1990) (p. 1154) Chinese B: “词学术语。指词所依据歌唱和创作的曲调名称。唐宋时没有“词牌”之称,多称“曲”或“调”。宋以后词脱离了音乐歌唱,词调也就变成了词的格律招牌。明清时俗称南北曲的曲调名为“曲牌”、“牌名”,故亦称词调为“词牌”。参见“词调”条。” Songci da (2003) (p.9) Chinese C: “词牌的来源十分复杂,大致主要有:1.取自乐府诗题。如〔乌夜啼〕、〔风入松〕、〔长相思〕等;2.取自唐代乐曲名。如〔荷叶杯〕、〔万年欢〕、〔菩萨蛮〕等;3.根据原词的内容而定名。如〔渔歌子〕原咏渔家生活,〔更漏子〕原咏夜间景况;4.摘取本词中的某几字。如〔秦楼月〕出自“秦娥梦断秦楼月”之句,〔人月圆〕出自“华灯盛照人月圆时”之句;5.取别人诗句中的某几字。如〔醉春风〕出自李白诗句“丝管醉春风”,〔看花回〕出自刘禹锡诗句“无人不道看花回”;6.词人自制。词人自度曲,则根据已意定出词牌名称,如姜夔的〔扬州慢〕、〔石湖仙〕;等等。” Zhongguo wenxue (1991) (p.3219) For further discussion, see also:  Zhongguo da baike (2020) (宋词) Hanyu dacidian  (词牌) English: “Every lyric poetry (ci) in ancient China could be sung. How? Once the tunes (cipai) were set, one could fill it out with lines and words in accordance with the tone patterns.” Li (2024)

Tantrism.text: Source: “Ambiguity has a positive valuation and reflects blends of indigenous beliefs with layers of accreted mysticism of Indic and Islamic origin, including Tantrism. Utama (2016) documents Tantrism’s embedded persistence in many of today’s Balinese material symbols, food, music, dance, and rituals, even if only priests or erudite persons could name these connections.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.6]) Definition: “(Adherence to) the doctrine or principles of the Tantras, involving mantras, meditation, yoga, and ritual.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “Tantrism”)

melodias.text: English A: “Song melodies would not be syncopated, the ambivalence emerging from their counterposition with the accompaniment, which would accentuate the beat. Instead, the melodic flow would be non-metrical, its accentuation driven by a “musical fantasy, pure virtuosity, or prosodic precision … a subtle compromise between recitative and strophic singing” (36).” (Stover (2024) [1.6]) Portuguese A: “As melodias das canções não seriam sincopadas, a ambivalência emergindo da contraposição com o acompanhamento, que acentuaria o tempo. O fluir da melodia seria não-métrico, a acentuação sendo dirigida por uma "fantasia musical, puro virtuosismo, ou precisão prosódica ... um compromisso sutil entre o canto recitativo e estrófico" (p. 36).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “1. Organização de sons musicais combinando diversos intervalos e valores rítmicos. 2. No sentido de “melodioso, bem timbrado”…” (Andrade (1989), 329)
