\uc870\uc131 joseong.text: English A: “This translation presented unique challenges, particularly regarding the original author’s use of Western musical concepts such as letter names, solfège, staff notation, and the concepts of key (joseong 조성), half cadence (ban-jongji 반종지), and cadence (jongji 종지).” (Kim (2024) [0.4])

Fuga.text: Spanish A: “Ejemplos de este género se encuentran a menudo en las obras de Bach, especialmente en su Ofrenda musical y su Arte de la fuga, las maravillas más estupendas que produjo el clasicismo en los campos de la técnica musical del sistema de los 12 sonidos.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 16] English A: “Examples of this kind are often encountered in the works of Bach, especially in his Musical Offering and his Art of the Fugue, the greatest wonders classicism produced under the musical techniques of the twelve-note musical system.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 16] Spanish B: “Pieza de Música la cual se compone segun ciertas reglas de armonia y de modulacion de un canto llamado Tema, ó Intento, haciendole pasar succesiva y alternativamente de una parte á otra. Ver las principales reglas de la Fuga, las cuales unas le son propias, y las otras comunes con la imitiacion…” Palatín (1990) [p. 65-66] Spanish C: “Cuando dos voces ó más voces caminan una después de otra con una misma cantinela, la figura ó ejercicio musical que de ello resulta se llama Fuga, cuyo principal objeto es el enlace de un tema entre sí.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 193, see also Tema]

s\u00edncopa.text: English A: “When this accepted natural order is questioned and the musical phrase begins on a weak beat and continues onto the next strong beat, it is said that a “syncopation” has occurred.” (Stover (2024) [1.3]) Portuguese A: “Quando esta ordem aceita como natural é questionada e a frase começa num tempo fraco e se prolonga no tempo forte seguinte se diz que surgiu uma "síncopa".” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “The academic concept of syncopation, that is, “sound articulated over a weak beat or weak part of a beat, prolonged over the strong beat or strong part of the next beat” (the definition given by Aurélio) does not always correspond to what actually happens in performance situations.” (Stover (2024) [1.4]) Portuguese B: “O conceito escolar de síncopa, como colocado anteriormente, isto é, "som articulado sobre um tempo fraco ou parte fraca de um tempo, prolongado sobre o tempo forte ou a parte forte do tempo seguinte" (definição do Aurélio) nem sempre corresponde ao que acontece de fato em situaçoes de performance.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese C: “Termo que indica a escrita de um tempo fraco de um compasso prolongado ate outro empo de maior ou igual duração.A nossa síncopa é uma entidade insubdivisível. Entidade propriamente rítmica quer apareça na melodia quer no acompanhamento. Na curopéia em geral, infinita maioria dos casos é melódica. E quando é acompanhante vem sempre seqüência de síncopas não vem uma isolada MF N 1 que nem maxixe.” (Andrade (1989) 475–78) Portuguese D: “Articulação de uma nota em tempo fraco e prolongada sôbre o tempo forte. As síncopas são regulares e irregulares.” (Cosme (1957) 111) (See also: Andrade (2013))

intervalos.text: English A: “In popular song, melody and lyrics closely influence each other. There are elements in the lyrics, especially their narrative or lyrical quality, that suggest different types of melody, and there are particularities in the melody, especially its melodic contour and the types of intervals used that define the character of the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Na canção popular melodia e letra interferem estreitamente uma sobre a outra. Existem elementos na letra, especialmente sua qualidade narrativa ou lírica que conduzem a diferentes tipos de melodia; existem particularidades na melodia, especialmente seu contorno melódico e tipos de intervalos empregados que marcam o caráter da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “A distância existente entre duas notas. Há também intervalos simples e compostos: são simples, quando estão contidos no âmbito de uma oitava justa, e compostos, quando a ultrapassam.” (Cosme (1957) 62)

\u4e00\u8a9e\u4e00 ichigo ichi.text: Japanese A: “これはクセとよばれる部分の一部であるが、その４度音程をもつ上下動の中にも明瞭に核音の支配をうかがい知ることができる。これと同じ旋律的な弱吟という発声法によるクセの他の部分では、これよりもはるかに一語一音符的な（syllabic）スタイルによっており、” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “This is one part of something that might be called the kuse, and within the up-and-down motion across the interval of a fourth, we can clearly perceive the control of nuclear tones. In another part of the kuse, whose method of vocalization is called melodic yowagin, it is in a far more syllabic style (one word to one note) even than this.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.2]

semara.text: Balinese A: “smara ngaran laki, ratih ngaran wadu, swaraning smara ngaran kama nada, swaraning ratih ngaran kama sraga. Rikalanya anunggal swara ika, hana swara karenga ngararengih ngalup manis, kadi reng pangucapira sanghyang smara ratih, patemuan nira murda, ring murda panunggara nira sanghyang ardanareswari, apan sira wenang surup sinurup, ganti gumanti, matemahan ring windu nada candra.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: ““Semara” indicates male, “Ratih” indicates female, the voice of Semara is called kama nada, [kama = desire; nada = tone] the voice of Ratih is called kama sraga [sraga = form]. When these voices become one, there is a tinkling, sweet sound, like the vibrations of Sang Hyang Semara and Ratih’s words at their summit, at the highest realm of Sang Hyang Ardanareswari [a manifestation of Siva and his consort Parvati unifying male and female] because he can go in and out, again and again, on the tones of Windu Chandra [windu is a point, an essence; chandra can suggest brightness or the moon].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.6]) Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Iti swara patut Slendro, Panca Brahma ngaran, Panca Brahma peraganira Sang Hyang Ratih arupa Kumbang. Smararatih maka angga Sang Hyang Predana Purusa Jati, marmanya Smara angawe katuridan, Ratih angawe prapaneaning manah .Mangkana witnya.” (Bandem (1986), 44) English C (Chat GPT Translation): “Additionally, the Slendro tuning system is called Panca Brahma (Five Divine Beings). Thus, this is how it originates.”

anerang wisaya.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat panca, anerang wisaya ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “ if five, it is called anerang wisaya [the clarity of sense perception], ” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug babarangan Anutasih ngaran. Yaning gage-Bus ges der pewayahau umbans taruns ngarang tan pa selat Anunggalpati ngaran. Yaning gebug selat siki Chandrapra-ba ngaran. Yaning gebug selat kalih Paduarsa ngaran. Yaning gebug selat telu Dahanamuka ngaran. Yaning gebug selat pat Anerang sasih ngaran. Yaning gebug selat lima Anerang Wisaya ngaran. Yaning gebug selat nem Gana wedana ngaran.” (Bandem (1986), 68)

Semitono/medio tono.text: Spanish A: “En cuanto al perfecto menor, que tiene sobre el bajo un intervalo de tres semitonos, y sobre la nota alta de éste, uno de cuatro, tendrá al metamorfosearse al duplo, uno de seis semitonos sobre el bajo, en vez de tres, y sobre la nota alta de éste, uno de ocho semitonos en vez de cuatro.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 24] English A: “The minor triad has an interval of three semitones above the bass, and above that, an interval of four semitones. Under metamorphosis to the double, the first interval will reach six semitones above the bass, and the second, another eight semitones.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 24] Spanish B: “La distancia que hay entre ciertos puntos de la música, como la que hay entre el Mi y el Fa. Se divide en Semitono mayor, que consiste en la proporcion sexquidecimaquinta, como 16 con 15; y el Semitono menor, que consiste en la proporcion sexquivigésimacuarta, como 25 con 24. El semitono menor no sale de los limites del mismo signo.” Palatín (1990) [p. 92–93] Spanish C: “Semitono ó medio tono. Los grados ó notas de la escala no guardan entre sí igual distancia; unos están separados más que otros. El espacio mayor se llama Tono, el menor está del grado 3°. al 4°., y del 7°. al 8°., y se llama SEMITONO. La escala diatónica, ya empiece por el do, ya por cualquier otra nota, consta, pues, de 5 tonos y 2 semitonos.- Cada tono se divide en dos semitonos, y el sonido intermedio puede obtenerse subiendo el de la nota inferior por medio de un sostenido, ó bajando con un bemol el de la nota superior.” Lacál (1900) [p. 477]

eka sruti.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug sanunggal, eka sruti ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “If only one is struck, eka sruti [one sound] is the name.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8])

\u5f26 gen.text: Japanese A: “たとえば長唄の「老松」では、かりに本調子を３本にとると（三味線の第１弦をＨに合わせる）、譜２６のようになる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “For example, in the nagauta “Oimatsu (Old Pine),” if we take honchōshi on the third string (in which it matches the first string of the shamisen, which is tuned to B), it will be transcribed as in example 26 (Example 3).” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1] Japanese B: “① 弦 楽 器 の 発 ⾳ 源 と な る ⽷ 。 絃 とも 書 く 。 材 質 で は 、 ⽵ や ⽊ の 繊 維 な ど 植 物 性 の も の ， ガ ッ ト （ ⽺ 腸 ） 、 な ど 動 物 性 の も の 、鉄 、 銅 、 真 鍮 （ ょ う ） 、 銅 鉄 な ど ⾦ 属 性 の も の 。プ ラ ス チ ッ ク や ナ イ ロ ン な ど 化 学 物 質 性 の も の が あ る 。 形 態 で は 、 よ じ っ た も の 、 よ じ ら な い も の 、 1 つ の 弦 に 他 の 弦 を 巻 い た 巻 弦 な ど が ある 。 ヨ ー ロ ッ パ 、 西 ア ジ ア で は 古 代 よ り ガ ッ ト 弦 や 絹 弦 が 主 流 で 、 中 世 以 降 鍵 盤 楽 器 な ど で ⾦ 属 弦 が 主 流 と な る 。② 管 楽 器 や 打 楽 器 に 対 し て 弦 楽 器 を 総 称 す る語 .” (Tomosha (2002), 220)

\uc885\uc9c0\uc74c jongjieum.text:
종지 jongji + 음 eum  
 Korean A: “그러나 판소리 우조를 "평조와 그 구성음은 같고 주음만 다른 악조" 또는 "때로는 주음의 4도 아래 음인 솔로 종지하기도 하는데, 이 경우는 평 조와 구별이 쉽지 않다"라고 설명하고 있는 것으로 미루어, 판소리 우조와 평조를 주음(종지음) 만 다를 뿐 큰 차이가 없는 같은 조로 인식하고 있는 듯하다.” Shin (2018) [p. 236] English A: “This connects to Baek’s theory, although Kim believes that Ujo and Pyeongjo in pansori consist of the same notes, differing only in the tonic (the cadential note), that "The tonic [of Ujo] is the only distinction; the rest of the notes are the same as in Pyeongjo” (Kim 2015). Alternatively, “when the cadential note is a fourth below the tonic, it is challenging to discern from Pyeongjo” (Kim 2015).” Kim (2024) [2.3]

court music.text: 아악 aak (Korean) 雅楽 gagaku (Japanese) Source: “The translator’s choice of Shin Eun-Joo’s article on pansori is perfectly suited to presenting such an introduction. Pansori is one of the most important genres in Korean traditional music. Although frequently compared to Western classical opera due to their shared vocal and theatrical attributes, pansori is essentially an epic, narrative storytelling vocal performance executed by a singer and a drum accompanist without stage design or theatrical costumes. Unlike court or ritual music, pansori was first circulated among commoners and the lower class, and later enjoyed by all classes as a principal form of entertainment.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “Gagaku, the ancient traditional music of the Japanese court, today comprises the following repertories: tōgaku, komagaku, saibara, rōei and Shintō ritual music and dance. The two Chinese characters used to write gagaku (literally ‘elegant music’) were originally used in China to signify Confucian ritual music.” (Marett, Allan. "Japan - Court music." Grove Music Online. 2001)

repeti\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “The melody of a popular song is generally composed of the repetition or grouping of short melodic motifs: melodic-rhythmic formulas that function as “blocks of meaning,” as Gino Stefani (1987) puts it, ready to be incorporated, repeated, combined, or associated in creating the song.” (Stover (2024) [2.1]) Portuguese A: “A melodia da canção popular é geralmente composta a partir da repetição ou agrupamento de motivos melódicos curtos, espécie de fórmulas melódico-rítmicas que funcionam como "blocos de significação", como coloca Gino Stefani, prontos para serem incorporados, repetidos, combinados ou associados na feitura da canção. “ (Ulhôa (1999))

ambiguity.text: Source: “Ambiguity and enigma are aspects of learning and knowledge in the intertwined Balinese and Javanese cultural spheres, even more so in the past as knowledge production was decentralized. Ambiguity has a positive valuation and reflects blends of indigenous beliefs with layers of accreted mysticism of Indic and Islamic origin, including Tantrism.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.6]) Definition: “Originally and chiefly with reference to language: the fact or quality of having different possible meanings; capacity for being interpreted in more than one way; (also) lack of specificity or exactness.” (Oxford English Dictionary “ambiguity” 1a)

Hynes-Tawa (2024).text: Hynes-Tawa, Liam. 2024. “Koizumi Fumio on Nuclear Tones.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

\ubbf8\uc138\ud55c \uc2dc\uac04 misehan.text:
미세한 + 시간 미세한: minute, fine, tiny 시간: time 
 Korean A: “'하우프트톤'의 경우, 음과 양의 상대시 변화는, 미세한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 시작하며 기대한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 이르기까지 여러 단계가 있습니 다. 거기에는 순간에 영원이 반영되고, 영원을 순간으로서 포착한 수가 있어요. 그것이 동양인의 '시'(時)에 대한 사고방식으로서, 서양인의 '시'의 사고방식과는 전혀 다른 점이지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u97f3\u4e50 y\u012bn yu\u00e8.text: Chinese A: “這樣離不開舞的音樂，因為實際上不過是禮的附庸，所以我們不能夠把牠當作是一種獨立的藝術。你們承認音樂是一種獨立的藝術，那末，你們便不能夠把牠當作是禮的附庸。” Li (2024) [1.17] English A: “If we consider our spiritual world our upper realm (shangjie), we can also understand Music as a language of the upper realm.” Li (2024) [1.17] (See also: 上界 shàng jìe) Chinese B: “你們承認音樂是一種獨立的藝術，那末，你們便不能夠把牠當作是禮的附庸.” Li (2024) [1.4] English B: “Since Music, in this sense, was but a subsidiary of Ritual, we cannot consider it to be an autonomous art. If you consider Music to be an autonomous art, you cannot consider it to be a subsidiary of Ritual.” Li (2024) [1.4] (See also: 礼 lǐ) Chinese C: “后浑称“音樂”，指用有组织的乐音表达人们的思想感情、反映社会生活的一种艺术.” Hanyu dacidian (音乐, 2)

cad\u00eancias.text: English A: “In music of the classical-romantic European tradition, the articulation of the phrase can be inferred from the written score, at least in its most obvious aspects, such as duration, metric placement, harmonic rhythm, cadences, melodic direction, and so on. However, much of the musical meaning only emerges during the moment of performance. In performance, and especially in the case of popular song, singers use their interpretative skills to articulate and highlight the emotional content of each song.” (Stover (2024) [5.11]) Portuguese A: “Na música de tradição européia clássico-romântica, a articulação da frase pode ser inferida na partitura escrita, pelo menos nos seus aspectos mais óbvios, como duração, colocação métrica, ritmo harmônico, cadências, direção melódica, etc. Entretanto, muito do significado musical só emerge durante o momento da performance. Na performance, e, principalmente no caso da canção popular, cantores usam sua habilidade interpretativa para articular e salientar o conteúdo emocional de cada canção.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “1. Procedimento harmônico de encadeamento de acordes para finalização de uma obra, seção ou frase.” (Andrade (1989) 79) Portuguese C: “1) Pequeno trecho melódico, livre, escrito em caracteres menores e cujo valor não figura na divisão dos compassos. 2) Cadência, do latim cadere, cair, emprega-se, em Harmonia, para designar os repousos que caracterizam as terminações de membros de fase, ou períodos. 3) Nas bandas militares, emprega-se, com relação ao andamento nacional, cadência 120.” (Cosme (1957), 22)

\ubd88\uad50\uc801\uc778 \ucca0\ud559 bu.text: 불교 + 철학 불교: Buddhism 철학: philosophy Korean A: ““이 곡은 무(無)에서 태어나서 무로 끝나지요. 그건 불교적인 철학입니다…” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 155] English A: “This piece is born within nothingness [無] and ends as nothingness. That is the Buddhist philosophy.” Park (2024) [4.1]

m\u00fasica erudita.text: Portuguese A: “Mas o que me faz afirmar que a síncopa europeia é uma especulação prática de música erudita é não só a quase inexistência do movimento sincopado na música popular europeia (com exceção de portugas e ciganas {sobre estes ver Lavignac V}) como por ela não ser corrente mesmo na música coreográfica de criação erudita.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “But what makes me assert that European syncopation is a practical speculation of classical music is not only the almost nonexistence of the syncopated movement in European popular music (with the exception of Portuguese and Gypsy (Lavignac 1913)) as it is not common even in the choreographic music of the Western classical tradition.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

tat.text: Sinhalese A: “tat-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? jit-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? ton-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki? nam-ki akura kāṭada namaskārayaki?” Peiris (2024) [9] English A: “Unto whom is the syllable tat a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable jit a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable ton a salutation? Unto whom is the syllable nam a salutation?” Peiris (2024) [9] English B: mnemonic syllable for a drum stroke (Peiris (2025))

gangsa pemad\u00e9.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug sarwa gangsa, kantil rswa ngaran.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The gangsa parts, including the kantil, are called reswa.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.9])

voz.text: English A: “Melody is generally associated with the human voice; we think of it in terms of the continuous sound of singing. Singing, in turn, uses verbal language, whose minimum components are vowels and consonants. A song made only with vowels intoned in a continuous melodic line produces a melody in its closest state to human expression.” (Stover (2024) [2.3]) Portuguese A: “A melodia está geralmente associada à voz humana, pensamos nela em termos do som contínuo do canto. O canto por sua vez utiliza a linguagem verbal, cujos componentes mínimos são as vogais e consoantes. Um canto feito somente com vogais, entoadas numa linha melódica contínua produz uma melodia no seu estado mais próximo da sensibilidade humana.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “1. Conjunto dos sons cmitidos pelo homem resultante da combinação integrada dos movimentos da musculatura respiratória, da vibração das cordas vocais que se situam na laringe, e das cavidades frontais, do nariz, da boca, da traquéia e da caixa torácica que funcionam como caixas de ressonância.Além das diferenças de timbres entre as vozes, há diferenças de registros entre a fala e o canto. A voz falada usa a amplitude de um intervalo de quin-ta, sendo que os homens falam uma oitava abaixo das mulheres e crianças.Os registros para a voz cantada - soprano, mezzosoprano, contralto, tenor, barítono, baixo - são determinados pelo conjunto do aparelho vocal e dosagens de hormônios. (DM)2. Voz é também sinônimo de linha melódica, no domínio popular caipira.Assim escutei o termo, na barranca do Moji Guaçu. (MA)” (Andrade (1989) 567) Portuguese C: “A voz humana subdivide-se em três tipos: agudo, médio e grave.” (Cosme (1957) 132)

nationalism.text: Source A: “For present-day music theorists working in a scholarly tradition that privileges European classical music, the logic of Hristov’s nationalism and many of the conceptual components of his theory may be familiar, while some of the historical and musical particulars of early twentieth-century Bulgaria may be less widely known, making for a potentially productive example of music theory’s ideological commitments.” (Goldberg (2024) [0.3]) Source B: “Instead, I wish to highlight Hristov’s role in crafting a narrative surrounding rhythm in Bulgarian folk music and in aligning it with a nationalist agenda.” (Boyd commentary (2024) [4]) Definition: “Ideology according to which all people owe a supreme loyalty to their nation and which holds that each nation should be embodied in a separate state. Nationalist sentiment, drawing upon and extolling a common culture, language and history, can be a powerful unifying force. With the possible exception of independence movements against colonialism and imperialism, nationalism is essentially conservative.” (Oxford Reference)

metaphysics.text: Source A: “Yun suggests there is a fundamentally “intuitive” aspect of East Asian thinking that “transcends the logical/illogical distinction” (and later, the rational/irrational distinction) of European Enlightenment metaphysics.” (Stover commentary (2024)[1.4] Source B: “But Geria gradually passes from Prakempa’s metaphysical style to a discourse on the play of tones and the concrete sensations they produce. Having sculpted these worlds as continuous, even a non-Balinese reader can connect the umwelt of precolonial Bali to an international emergent music theory based on earthly perception and cognition.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.6]) Definition: “most generally, the philosophical investigation of the nature, constitution, and structure of reality” (”Metaphysics,” The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy)

Qian (2024).text: Qian, Rong. 2024. “Report: My Footsteps and Related thoughts on the Systematic Construction of Linguistics of Music in the 21st Century.” Music Theory Online, forthcoming.

\u5f4e\u66f2 wankokyu.text: Japanese A: “だから、私の音楽はすべてが流れる、流暢に流れる、その線のたゆまない繰り返しだと言えます。その流暢に流れている線が直線ではなくて、湾曲しているんです。しかも湾曲の仕方が多様なんです。その湾曲の中にもいろいろな部分があって、この湾曲の中にさらに部分、部分、部分があって、それ自体がこの湾曲から比べれば、一つの世界になる。その一つの世界の中に、また世界がある。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese 54) English A: “Therefore, people speak about my music as flowing, smoothly flowing, an endless repetition of the line. The smoothly flowing line is not a straight line but is a curved line (彎曲). And there are various ways a line can be curved. "Within a curve, there are various parts. The part and the curve each contain a universe within itself. It means that within a universe, there is another universe." (Park (2024) [2.4])

\u30e8\u30fc\u30ed\u30c3\u30d1\u306e\u97.text: ヨーロッパ Yōroppa: Europe/European 音楽理論 ongaku riron: music theory Japanese A: “核音の比較音楽学的意味については第４節でのべるが、西洋音楽一般についてはこれにあたるものを見ない。したがってヨーロッパの音楽理論の用語には、これを表現する適切な言葉がないのである。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 5] English A: “I will discuss the meanings of nuclear tones in comparative musicology in section 4, but in Western music, we do not generally see things like this. Therefore, in European music theory terminology, there is no word that appropriately expresses this.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3]

Villepastour commentary (2024).text: Villepastour, Amanda. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4 (2024).

melo\u0301dicas.text: Portuguese A: “Ora pois, se nos faltam dados positivos de fórmulas e de datas como estabelecer prioridade de criação e de imposição na América e no Brasil, de certas manifestações rítmicas e melódicas já agora definitivamente nossas?” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 1] English A: “Now then, if we lack positive data on formulas and dates, how can we establish priority of creation and imposition in America and Brazil, of certain rhythmic and melodic manifestations that are now definitively ours?” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “O mesmo que melodiosa, ou a qualidade da obra cm que há muitas melodias. "Nessc grupo de obras, o músico esbanja a musicalidade que lhe custara bastante a descobrir em si. Nas primeiras, percebe-se a melódica epidérmica dos que começam. Exemplo típico é a Elegia pra violoncelo (...)." (Andrade, M. de. "Introdução", in: Gallet, L. Estudos de folclore, 1934, p. 16). (DM-MA)” (Andrade (1989), 329)

\u5531\u8154 ch\u00e0ngqi\u0101ng.text: Definitions: Chinese A: “戏曲、曲艺中念(说)白之外的人声 歌唱部分称为唱腔。在戏曲、曲艺音乐中占有重要地位,对于人物思想感情的抒发、人物性格的刻划、戏剧矛盾的展开、戏剧高潮的形成,以及对整个节目的音乐布局都起着重要的作用。” Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (”唱腔,” p. 41) Chinese B: “戏曲、曲艺音乐的主要组成部分,相对于器乐伴奏而言,指其中人声歌唱的部分。一般可分为抒情性唱腔、叙事性唱腔和戏剧性唱腔。抒情性唱腔的特点是字少声多,旋律性强,长于抒发内在的感情;叙事性唱腔的特点为字多声少,朗诵性强,适用于叙述、对答的场合;戏剧性唱腔多为节拍自由的散板,节奏的伸缩有极大灵活性,长于表现激昂强烈的感情。完整的演出要求交替协和运用以上三种唱腔。” Biaoyan cidian (2005)  (p.36) For further discussion, see also: Zhongguo baike (1990)  (p. 601),  Zhongguo da baike (2020) (戏曲音乐), Hanyu dacidian (唱腔) English: “Our Sino-Tibetan language family is a tonal language, and the fluctuation of the tone of speech inevitably affects the generation of chàngqiāng唱腔 (vocal melodies of any genre).” Qian (2024)

microtonal.text: Source A: “My inclination, partially based on recent findings by Schellenberg and Gick (2020) and Li (2021) on Cantonese, is that aspects of the text (chàngcí) are found in microtonal variations within the singing voice. Yet, these microtonal variations are not included in what might be accepted as an accurate transcription of the melody. My opinion is that the chàngqiāng (vocal music) is to be found in the recorded voice rather than in the transcription because it is the former that includes the vocal inflections.” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [10] Source B: “Carrillo centered his Sonido 13 mythology on the sixteenth tone because it was the smallest usable interval in his microtonal system. He wanted to compose with not only equal-tempered sixteenth tones of the ratio 962, but also equal-tempered fifteenth tones (902), fourteenth tones (842), thirteenth tones (782), and so on, up to and including the familiar semitones and whole tones of the twelve-note scale.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.5]  Definition: “Instruments specially constructed or adapted for performing music in microtonal tuning systems or to give accurate tuning in temperaments other than the ‘standard’ 12-note Equal temperament (ET). […] Although some specialists limit the meaning of ‘microtonal’ to intervals that are less than a quarter-tone, others more logically apply it to all intervals that are smaller than the semitone, adopting the term ‘macrotonal’ for the few tunings that use larger intervals (primarily nine-, ten- and 11-note).” (Oxford English Dictionary, “microtonal instruments”)

verse.text: Source: “This article aims to broaden common understandings of music theory through the lens of orally transmitted ritualistic verses from Sri Lanka, which are sung or recited along with drumming. I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “Metrical composition, form, or structure; language or literary work written or spoken in metre; poetry, esp. with reference to metrical form. Opposed to prose.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “verse”)

n\u2019u\u0323di\u0323.text: English A: “It seems to me that it is through traveling, That this music spread through Africa. Because when each community, collects their own/It is in their own unique style/They do not bring it back the way it is in another place, to make it available.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Ọ dị m ka ọ site na njem/Ka ihe a si gazuo Afrika/Maka ndị nke wete nke ha/Ọ dị n’ụdị ha/Ha agaghị eje wete ya otu ahu, wenata ya, ọ di.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

\u30ea\u30ba\u30e0 rizumu.text: Japanese A: “リズム・旋律法・多声性・楽器編成などあらゆる点でその他のジャンルと異なる” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 14] English A: “All aspects such as rhythm, melodic system, polyphony, and instrumental organization differ from other genres.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [8.2] Japanese B: “⾳ 楽 を 成 ⽴ さ せ る 基 本 要 素の ひ と つ 。 リ ズ ム は 時 間 的 現 象 に お け る 運 動 の秩 序 で あ り 、 時 間 芸 術 と し て ⾳ 楽 が 成 ⽴ す るた め の 必 須 要 素 と な る 。 リ ズ ム は ま た * 拍 節（ * 拍 ⼦ ） と 密 接 に 関 係 。 拍 節 と の 関 連 に お いて 、 * ⾃ 由 リ ズ ム 、 拍 節 リ ズ ム 、 な ど の 分 類 がな さ れ る 。” (Tomosha (2002), 742) See more in attached pdf.

\u00a0\ub2eb\ud78c \uc74c\uc758 dadhin e.text: 닫힌: closed 음의: tones (see 음 eum) Korean A: "그러니까 동양의 음악은 언제 시작해도 좋고 언제 멈추어도 좋다는 종래의 전통음악의 사고방식으로 곡을 쓴다면 그런 닫힌 음의 세계로부터 해방될 수 있지 않을까 해요. " (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: " I think one would be freed from the world of enclosed tones [閉ざされた音] if one composes with the traditional East Asian way of thinking that music can begin and end at any point in time." (Park (2024) [2.4])

funcional.text: English A: “In fact, bossa nova fulfills in urban samba the modernist-nationalist ideal advocated by Andrade: that of making the “functional” “aesthetic.”” (Stover (2024)[2.10]) Portuguese A: “De fato, a bossa nova cumpre no samba urbano o ideal modernista-nacionalista preconizado por Mário: a de tornar "estético" o "funcional".” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u4e3b\u8981\u97f3 Shuyo-on.text: Japanese A: “流 れ る 線 の 中 に 重 要 な ⾳ が あ り 、 そ れを 囲 む ⾳ す べ て が 「 主 要 ⾳ 」 だ” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: “Within a flowing line [流れる線], there is one important tone [音]. With this tone in the center, I call all sounds that surround it Hauptton [主要音].” (Park (2024) [1])

modernization.text: Source: “Many embraced this “modernization” and rejected their native cultures. Still others attempted to re-embrace their native cultures, but without decolonizing their minds from the unconscious hegemony of Western philosophy.” (Shumays commentary (2024) [4.3]) Definition: “A theory of social development originating in the United States in the 1960s as an alternative to Marxism, which proposes that all societies necessarily evolve from a simple to a complex structure and towards a goal of industrialization.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “modernization theory”)

matriz oral.text: English A: “First of all, popular melodies are “singable music,” and second, they emerge from an “oral matrix” connected to the singing voice and a primary sense of pleasure.” (Stover (2024) [2.1]) Portuguese A: “Em primeiro lugar, melodias populares são "música cantável", e em segundo lugar, emergem de uma "matriz oral" conectada à voz cantante e a um sentido de prazer primário.” (Ulhôa (1999))

lalonggoran.text: Balinese A: “Di bawah ini adalah semua ubit-ubitan palegongan yang berpokok misalnya di dalam gagaboran atau di dalam lalonggoran dan kale, atau pangecet.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Below are palegongan-style ubit-ubitan for gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet contexts.” Tenzer (2024) [4.3] “Gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet are the names for different kinds of gong-cycle forms in dance pieces of the gamelan palegongan repertoire.” Tenzer (2024) [4.4] Balinese B: “rangkaian suatu gending yg merupakan satu kesatuan dan hanya terdapat di Kabupaten Buleleng” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 155, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\u30d5\u30eb\u30fc\u30c8 fur\u016bto.text: Japanese A: “フルート・ソロはDの音を直接スタート しないで、下からまず上がってくる。と いうと、Bの音が準備になる。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “The flute solo does not begin right on D but rises from below. Bb thus prepares it [the note D].” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “広義には歌口の角の部分に向けて発射された奏者の息から発生する空気の渦を発音の原理とした管楽器をさし、さらには、その原理を「横笛」に応用した楽器全般をさすが、ここでは、ヨーロッパ音楽史に木管楽器の一部門として発展した横笛に説明を限定する。” (Tomosha (2002), 605)

mordentes.text: English A: “The emphasis on the melody is so striking that all the notes that compose it are essential to the song’s identity, including those that would be considered surface-level ornaments in the European classical-romantic music that has so influenced popular Brazilian music. What could be considered superfluous for melodic evaluation, such as notes that are foreign to the basic harmonic structure of the song (grupetos, mordants, appoggiaturas) have a functional importance in popular Brazilian song.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “A ênfase na melodia é tão marcante que todas as notas que a compõem são essenciais para a identidade da canção, incluindo aquelas que seria consideradas ornamentos superficiais na música clássico-romântica européia que tanto influenciou a música brasileira popular. O que poderia ser considerado supérfluo para a avaliação melódica, como notas extranhas à estrutura harmônica básica na canção (grupetos, mordentes, appoggiaturas) têm uma importância funcional na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “In “Canção da América,” the words expand by leaps with or without portamento, melisma, tremolo, the most diverse appoggiaturas, mordents and grupetos, highlighting the emotional content of the song: the heart cries for escape—the feeling trapped in the chest—and to reestablish the bonds of friendship you have to listen to your heart, no matter what happens. (Carvalho 1990, 325–30).” (Stover (2024) [5.7]) Portuguese B: “Em "Canção da América" as palavras expandidas por saltos com ou sem portamento, melisma, tremolo, appoggiaturas as mais diversas, mordentes e grupetos, realçam o conteúdo emocional da canção: o coração chora pela partida - o sentimento preso no peito - e para reestabelecer os laços de amizade tem-se que ouvir o coração, não importa o que aconteça. (p. 325-10).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese C: “Um ornamento composto de duas pequenas notas, precedendo à nota real, da qual subtrai o seu valor. mordente diz-se superior ou inferior, conforme tenha a segunda nota acima ou abaixo da nota real.” (Cosme (1957), 75)

\uc8fc\uc694\uc74c\ud5a5 juyoeumhyang.text: Korean A: “단음적인 의미, 단선적 인 의미지요. 그러나 이제 단선율이라는 요소가 겹치면 주요음향이 되는 겁니다. 선이 다발(훗)이 되어 흐르게 되는 거지요. 따라서 하나하나로 보면 주요음이고, 다발이 되어 흐르면 주요음향인 겁니 다. 그리고 그 하나하나가 비슷하다는 거지요. 비슷비슷하면서도 전체가 동일성을 갖는다는 말입니다.” (Yun (1991) - Korean, 149) English A: "It refers to a singular note and a singular melodic line. But when linear elements are stacked, they become Hauptklang [主要音響].(7) Lines become a bundle and begin to flow. In short, each line is Hauptton, and when it is bundled and flows it is Hauptklang. In other words, each of the lines is analogous while the whole is uniform." (Park (2024) [1.7])

discrep\u00e2ncia.text: English A: “It is significant that both the lyrics and the music, at the moment of major “discrepancy” between the sung melody and the accompaniment, articulate an anacrusis announcing the main point made by the lyrics (“a rosa do amor tem sempre que crescer / a rosa do amor não vai despetalar / Pra quem cuida bem da rosa / Pra quem sabe cultivar”).” (Stover (2024) [5.4]) Portuguese A: “ É significativo que tanto a letra quanto a música, no momento de maior "discrepância" entre a melodia cantante e o acompanhamento, articulam uma anacruse anunciadora do ponto principal feito pela letra (a rosa do amor tem sempre que crescer/a rosa do amor não vai despetalar/Prá quem cuida bem da rosa/Prá quem sabe cultivar).” (Ulhôa (1999))

Tang songci (1990).text: Tang songci baike da cidian 唐宋词百科大辞典. Wang Hong 王洪 (ed.). Beijing: Xueyuan chuban she 北京:学苑出版社, 1990.

\uc14b\uc787\ub2e8\uc74c\ud45c sesitdane.text: Korean A: “이 음에는 장식음이 없습니다. 그러나 셋잇단음표 첫머리의 쉼표가 그걸 대신하는 역할을 하지요. 그에 이어 장식선율적인 요소 가 있지요. 이것은 좀더 발전한 '하우프트톤'의 자태입니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “There is no decorative tone for this. But the first rest of the triplet substitutes its role. It is followed by a melismatic element. This is a more developed figure of a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1]

tunjung arip.text: English A: “Suling playing style is called tunjung arip, its sound is called merdukomala.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.11]) See suling  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang sasulingan, tunjung arip, merdukomala nama swaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Tunjung is lotus and arip is sleepy; suggesting that the flute finger holes opening and closing are like the lotus. Merdukomala is the name of an Old Javanese poetic meter; its constituent words merdu and komala both index sweetness, softness.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.10]) *Lexical field: Natural world (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) Balinese D: “Iti gagebug Angklung.Gagebug Angklung Kumbang atarun Gambans Faclah asih aran, ing sata. Mwah tingkahing sagebug arambavan, Angen trag tunu ngaran, Geleng pengasuh araning swara Mwang tandang Rere-baban, Bhuta ngawa sari ngaran, Madukaralalita araning swara.Mwang tandang Sasulingan Tunjung arip ngaran, Karna manu-hara araning swara. Mwang tandang Angenggong, Hametbet lati ngaran, Madukara santun araning swara, denya samar nyata ngaran. Mwah tandang angebug Cengceng, Edan ulangun ngaran, banyu runtuh araning swara. Mwah tandang angebug Kaklentangan Kaget asih ngaran. Nyan wustuning gagebug.” (Bandem (1986), 70) English D (Chat-GPT Translation): “The Striking Techniques of the Angklung (Iti Gagebug Angklung) The striking techniques of the Angklung include various rhythmic patterns and symbolic names.

Metam\u00f3rfosis.text: Spanish A: “En el sentido idiomático, “metamórfosis” o “metamorfosis” significa transformar una cosa en otra. Por esta causa adopté tal término para designar las transformaciones melódicas, armónicas y rítmicas, a que pueden someterse las composiciones musicales.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 14-15] “…con mi “Ley de metamorfosis” pueden efectuarse cambios en la melodía, en la armonía y el ritmo, sin agregar ni suprimir ni una sola nota.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] English A: “In its idiomatic sense, “metamorphosis” means the transformation of one thing into another. I adopt the term in this way to designate the melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic transformations to which musical compositions can be subjected.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 14-15] “With my “Law of Metamorphosis,” changes in melody, harmony, and rhythm can be carried out without adding or removing a single note.”  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20]

thick description.text: Source A: “At the end of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century, ethnomusicology from abroad introduced into musicological circles in mainland China a trend towards writing “thick description” of music as culture.” Qian (2024) [2.5] Source B: “Qian argues that the disconnect between music analysis and thick description (ethnography) may be bridged by the linguistics of music. Indeed, analyzing language requires digging into ethnicity and culture in a way that analysis of non-linguistic sounds does not.” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [11]

dura\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “In measured tonal music, although dynamics play a central role, duration and frequency (both in pitch class and harmony) also contribute to musical accentuation.” (Stover (2024) [5.10]) Portuguese A: “Na música medida tonal, embora a dinâmica tenha um papel central, duração e freqüência (tanto em classe de altura quanto harmonia) também contribuem para a acentuação musical.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Limite de existência no tempo: a extensão temporal de um som. (2) Sucessão não interrompida de momentos, sucessão que flui com uniformidade. A substância própria da música, isto é, a forma de nossa vida psíquica.

\u30bd\u30ca\u30bf\u5f62\u5f0f sonata ke.text: Japanese A: “「時」の考え方が形式観に反映した 例として西洋ではソナタ形式があります が、ソナタ形式ですと、第一主題部があ り、第二主題部がある。これらは対立し た区間であり、第二主題の部分は第一主 題と異なった時間を独自に形成するわけ ですから、瞬間に世界を持つ陰陽とは全 く異なるということですね。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “The Sonata form might be one example that reflects the Western formalistic view of time. In Sonata form, there are primary and secondary theme areas. They are contrasting sections that independently develop [the sense of] time. Therefore, it is completely different from yin and yang, which contain an eternity in a moment.” Park (2024) [4.2] Japanese B: “古典派以降の器楽楽章でもっとも重要な形式。転謝、主題労作などを通じて大規模で高度な緊張をはらんだ弁証法的な造形を可能にする。ソナタ、交響曲。序曲、各種室内栄などさまざまなジャンルのとくに急速な第1楽 章，洗いでフィナーレや緩徐楽章、まれにスケルツキで使われる。典型的な構造は3部分かられる.” (Tomosha (2002), 374)

dialectical relation.text: Source: “Yun explicitly contrasts this process of selection, variation, or adumbration with Western compositional methods, in which form and content are in a dialectical relation.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.7]) Definition: “an argumentative exchange involving contradiction or a technique or method connected with such exchanges.” (”Dialectic,” The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy)

\u0442\u043e\u043d\u0430\u043b\u043d\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Събраният по този начин материал да се систематизира: 1) по такт, 2) по сложение на периодите, 3) по тоналност, 4) по амбитус (тонов обем), 5) по общ характер на песента (любовна, елична, обредна и пр.). Всички тия особености да се пренесат в подходящи карти-диаграми.” Hristov (1925) [p. 36] English A: “The material collected in this way should be systematized: (1) by meter, (2) by composition of the periods, (3) by tonality, (4) by ambitus (tonal range), (5) by general character of the song (love, epic, ritual, etc.). All these features should be communicated in suitable diagrammatic charts.” Goldberg (2024) [2.10] Bulgarian B: “Тоналност (ит. tonalita, op. tonalité, нем. Топагt) положението на лада по височина, т. е. лад с наименована тоника. Върху всеки тон може да се построи мажорен или минорен лад*. Наименованието на Т. се образува от, името на основния тон (тониката) и ладовото наклонение (мажор или минор). Напр. Т. До-мажор (C-dur) е мажорен лад, построен от тона до; Т. Ре-мажор (D-dur) e мажорен лад, построен от тона ре; Т. ла-минор (a-moll) минорен лад, построен от тона ла; T. ре-минор(d-moll) е минорен лад, построен от тона ре и т. н.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 333]

Consonancia.text: Spanish A: “’Según el común sentir, –dijo nuestro P. Eximeno,–es un intervalo apacible.’–Propoción que guardan entre sí los varios sonidos, y de la cual resulta el modo grato, delicioso y suave con que hieren el tímpano, sonando simultáneamente…Las consonancias se dividen en perfectas é imperfectas. Son perfectas por excelencia la octava, la quinta, y la cuarta: son imperfectas la tercera y la sexta porque existen bajo dos formas, la mayor y la menor.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 109]  Spanish B: “Acorde de dos ó mas sonidos que se oyen simultáneamente resultando agradables. - Será MAYOR Sİ la resonancia es de una fundamental con su 5.ª y su 3.ª superiores. Será MENOR si es la de una fundamental con su 5. y su 3." inferiores. - Será JUSTA Ó PERFECTA aquella cuyo intervalo es invariable como para la 8.", la 5." y la 4.ª - Será IMPERFECTA aquella cuyo intervalo puede ser mayor ó menor como la 3.ª y la 6.ª” Lacál (1900) [p. 135]

Escala menor mel\u00f3dica.text: Spanish A: “He aquí la llamada escala menor melódica, metamorfoseada al duplo.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 21] English A: “Here is the so-called melodic minor scale, metamorphosed to the double.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 21] Spanish B: “En el modo menor MELODICO, no existe ningún intervalo de tono y medio, pues para evitar el de 2. aumentada entre el 6.º y el 7.° grado, se altera un semitono hacia el agudo la sexta nota. Ej.: la, si, do, re, mi, fa sostenido, sol sostenido, do.” Lacál (1900) [p. 169-170]

\ub3c4 do.text: Korean A: “자아, 장식음입니다. 장식음으로부터 시작해서 점점 흔들림이 커지고 경우에 따라서는 비브라토가 4도까지 갑니다. 시작되는 음에 힘을 집중하기 위해서 장식음이 있는 것으로 그 자체에 의미는 없습니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “Now, it is a decorative tone. Beginning from the decorative tone, the trembling grows larger and, at times, the vibrato gets as wide as a fourth [4th scale degree]. The decorative tone exists to concentrate on the tone’s beginning, and it is meaningless by itself.” Park (2024) [4.1, brackets added separately]

\ub2e82\ub3c4 dan 2 do.text:
단+ 2 + 도 do  단: minor 
 Korean A: “백대웅의 판소리 평조길은 계이름으로 설명하면 "레, 미, 솔, 라, 도"의 5음으로, "솔, 라, 도 레, 미"의 우조길과 구분된다. 각 음의 기능과 특징 설명에서, 상청을 '오선보에서 우조와 구별 되는 음으로 우조의 상청보다 반음(단2도) 높다'” Shin (2018) [p. 240] English A: “Baek distinguishes between the re, mi, sol, la, and do of Pyeongjo-gil and the sol, la, do, re, and mi of Ujo-gil. In his description of the functions and features of each pitch, Baek claims that sangcheong [in Pyeongjo] “is a different note from the one in Ujo on the staff, and is a half step (minor 2nd) higher than sangcheong in Ujo" (Baek 1982, 1995, 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.10]

downbeat.text: Source: “Furthermore, Hornbostel, in his analysis, considers a rhythmic displacement in which some attacks by the xylophone (which according to his interpretation of the structure should be ‘upbeats’, therefore unaccented) are actually accented ‘downbeats’. And when the main theme returns in the choir, in another metric position, Hornbostel is led to consider that this entire theme is syncopated.” Menezes (2024) [1.17] Definition: “The explicit or implied impulse that coincides with the beginning of a bar in measured music, by analogy with the downstroke in conducting (the ‘thesis’ of Arsis, thesis). The term is mainly applied to music in a regular metre or articulated by metrical stress, where downbeats create a periodic occurrence and are usually given articulation through dynamic increase (i.e. Periodicals) or lengthening of durational value (i.e. Agogic accent).” (Grove Music Online, “downbeat”)

jublag.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug jublag kreti suci ngaran dirga.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The melodic movement of the jublag is sacred and enduring (kerta suci atau dirga—holy court of justice or long/prosperous).” (Tenzer (2024) [I.9]) Balinese C: “Nihan babarungan gagambelan kang manut tatanya. Yan Smar Pagulingan, ndyata : kempul sanunggal sawurnya paketutan nding, kempyung satungguh swaranya dong-deng, kajar sa-nunggal, suling ageng roro, suling babarangan roro, terompong babarangan sanunggal, curing pangageng sapasang, jublag sa-pasang, panyacah sapasang, gangsa ageng sapasang, gangsa manengah sapasang, sama ngumbang ngisep, gumanak tatiga, kangsi satungguh, ricik alit kalih tungguh, ricik manengah satungguh; jangkep kayeki.” (Bandem (1986), 82) English C (Chat-GPT): “The following describes the instrumentation in different types of Gamelan ensembles, according to their distinct musical functions and tonal characteristics. The Smara Pagulingan gamelan is characterized by its elegance and melodic fluidity, often used in refined settings. It consists of: Thus, this ensemble is considered complete (jangkep).”  Balinese D: “1) instrumen sj jégogan yg satu oktaf lebih tinggi nadanya, digunakan sbg pemangku lagu, dan menggarisbawahi melodi; 2) ricikan bilah dr perunggu, ber-bilah 4 sampai 7 (satu gembyang menurut larasan jenis gamelan yg digunakan) yg digantung, dl satu perangkat gamelan menggunakan 2 sampai 4 tungguh jublag, di perangkat gamelan gong kebyar menggunakan 2 tungguh ricikan jublag dg menggunakan 5 sampai 7 bilah pd tiap tungguh.” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 149, Bidang Istilah Musik]

canon.text: Canon (Spanish) Source: “Carrillo wrote his first music theory treatises in the 1910s, which were pedagogical and mostly staid, devoted to subjects Jadassohn had written about such as canon and fugue, orchestration, and harmony.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.2] Definition: “Strict (‘canonic’) imitation was so common and useful a procedure that the word ‘canon’ eventually came to mean the polyphonic texture of two or more voices created by the procedure, which is its primary meaning today.” (Grove Music Online, “canon”)

Qinqiang da cidian (2014).text: Qinqiang da cidian 秦腔大辞典. Wang Zhengqiang 王正强 (ed.). Shanghai: Shanghai cishu chuban she 上海:上海辞书出版社, 2014.

Disonancia.text: Spanish A: “Todo choque recibido por el sentido auditivo llámase en música disonancia. Para la física, son combinaciones disonantes las que representan las relaciones menos simples comparadas con las que representan los intervalos consonantes.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 139] See also Consonancia  Spanish B: “Falso acorde. Desacuerdo de voces ó de instrumentos. Si se producen simultáneamente tres ó más sonidos, se obtendrá un acorde que será agradable al oído si lo forman intervalos consonantes, ó puede causar disgusto más ó menos vivo si lo constituyen intervalos disonantes. No hemos de explicar aquí cómo deben prepararse y resolverse las disonancias, pero sí diremos que son un gran recurso para los comp. porque enriquecen la armonía adornándola con infinita variedad.” Lacál (1900) [p. 155]

\u5fae\u5206\u97f3 bibun-on.text: 微分: differential + 音 oto: note Japanese A: “このようなピッチの微分音的変化は、もとより時代がうつるにつれて加味されてきた表現法の技巧であると想像される。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 12] English A: “This sort of microtonal change in pitch is imagined to have been a technique of expressive principles that, from the beginning, had changed along with movement through the ages.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.2] Japanese B: “半⾳よ り も せ ま い ⾳ 程 。 全 ⾳ を 何 分 割 す る か に よ っ て 、三 分 ⾳ 、 四 分 ⾳ 、 な ど が あ る 。 イ ン ド や 西 ア ジ ア を は じ め 多 く の 民 族 ⾳ 楽 で 特 徴 的 に ⽤ い ら れ る 。 古 代 ギ リ シ ア の ⾳ 楽 理 論 で 重 要 な ⾳ 程 と して 論 じ ら れ 、 西 洋 で は 中 世 以 降 、 ⾳ 階 論 ・ ⾳ 律 論 を 論 じ る さ い に 問 題 に さ れ た が 、 や が て * 平 均 律 が 広 く 受 け い れ ら れ 、 実 際 の 演 奏 で 意 識 さ れ る 場 ⾯ は 減 っ た 。 2 0 世 紀 に な る と 現 代 的 な 作 曲 の 素 材 と し て 注 ⽬ さ れ た 。” (Tomosha (2002), 554) Japanese C: “そ れ が 、 先 ⽣ の 作 品 の 線 的 な 語 法 の も と に な っ て い る わ け で す ね 。 微 分 ⾳ 的 な 細 か い 揺 れ か ら 3 度 以 上 の シ ェ イ ク に ⾄ る よ う な 、 独 特 な 線 の 動 き は 、 韓 国 の 歌 唱 の ⽅ 法 か ら ⽣ み 出 さ れ た も の と 考 え て い い わ け で す ね 。(Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English C: “That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

tempos fortes.text: English A: “Meter allows several voices to present a homogeneous (musical) discourse by providing an internal organization of pulsations into strong beats, propelling energy, and weak, inertial beats.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “O compasso permite que várias vozes possam apresentar um discurso homogêneo ao propor a organização interna das pulsações em tempos fortes, propulsores de energia e tempos fracos e inerciais.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc120\uc801\uc778 \uc6c0\uc9c1\uc784\uc.text: 선적 seonjeog linear 음 eum 음악적: musical 이론: theory 대체적: general; broad Korean A: “그래요. 엄격한 아악의 음악 짜임새와 철학적 내용, 거기서 유창하게 흐르는 선적인 아름다움을 보여주는 이를테면 남도창이라 든가 가곡이라는 형식의 일련의 성악이 있는데, 그런 데서 많은 걸 배웠어요. 거기서 나아가 선적인 움직임에 대한 음악적 이론을 대체적으로 체계지은 것이지요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: “Yes. I learned a lot from A-ak’s strict organization and philosophical content, and vocal music’s smoothly flowing linear beauty, such as Namdo Chang and Gagok [가곡], or other vocal genres.(4) Based on these, I organized my own musical theory of linear motion." (Park (2024) [1.4])

\u043f\u0435\u043e\u043d/paeon.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: paeon, “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6] Bulgarian B: “Пеон (гр. раiéōn, по-късна форма от paian пеан*) четирисложна P стихотворна стъпка в петвременен такт, образувана от три кратки срички и една дълга. В зависимост от мястото на дългата сричка по отношение на трите кратки П. може да бъде четири вида: а) с дълга сричка в началото, известен под името П. първи (протос); б) с дълга сричка на второ място след първата кратка на- речен П. втори (девтерос); в) с дълга сричка на трето място, след втората крат- ка наречен П. трети (тритос); г) с дълга сричка накрая, след третата кратка наречен П. четвърти (тетартос).” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 249]

ataques.text: English A: “These metric spaces are very difficult to illustrate with conventional Western notation. Ethnomusicologists have created signs to express these “early” or “late” attacks.“ (Stover (2024) [5.5]) Portuguese A: “Estes espaços métricos são muito difíceis de demonstrar com a notação ocidental convencional. Etnomusicólogos têm criado sinais para expressar estes ataques "adiantados" ou "atrasados". “ (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “’Ataque de deo’, o mesmo que toque, o ‘toucher’ francês: ‘Senhor dum ataque de dedo curiosíssimo ele se conduz com destreza (…). Despoticamente ele vai empolgando a platéia e, com tal touché e tais detalhes (…)’.” (Andrade (1989), 30)

est\u00e9tico.text: English A: “In fact, bossa nova fulfills in urban samba the modernist-nationalist ideal advocated by Andrade: that of making the “functional” “aesthetic.”” (Stover (2024) [2.10]) Portuguese A: “De fato, a bossa nova cumpre no samba urbano o ideal modernista-nacionalista preconizado por Mário: a de tornar "estético" o "funcional".” (Ulhôa (1999))

obi.text: Igbo A: “A bịa na ihe gbasara ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, Anyị dị, Republican. Onye owụna, anyị nwere ofu obi, Mana onye ọbụna wụ onye Igbo nwe obi nke ya.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “When it comes to politics for instance, our system of government is Republican. Everyone, we all have one heart, but everyone who is Igbo also has their own unique nature.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

can\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “Song melodies would not be syncopated, the ambivalence emerging from their counterposition with the accompaniment, which would accentuate the beat. Instead, the melodic flow would be non-metrical, its accentuation driven by a “musical fantasy, pure virtuosity, or prosodic precision … a subtle compromise between recitative and strophic singing” (36).” (Stover (2024) [1.6]) Portuguese A: “As melodias das canções não seriam sincopadas, a ambivalência emergindo da contraposição com o acompanhamento, que acentuaria o tempo. O fluir da melodia seria não-métrico, a acentuação sendo dirigida por uma "fantasia musical, puro virtuosismo, ou precisão prosódica ... um compromisso sutil entre o canto recitativo e estrófico" (p. 36).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Composição em verso. Na Pequena história da música, Mário de Andrade analisa a canção curopéia: "O sóc. XVI é a fase dả canção. Porém agora o que se entende por canção não é uma toada de gênero popular, nem se inventou ainda a mania de imitar popularescamente o povo. Trata-se duma lorma desenvolvida e aprimorada, um pouco amaneirada mesmo, como pocsia. Poeticamente ha grande variedade na lorma das estrofes, cada estrofe em geral seguida por estribilho. O tamanho das canções também varia muito, e se algumas são pequeninas, outras não acabam mais, de tamanhas. Seus temas preferidos são o amor... c o amor. Em geral o amor. Porém amor cortês, cheio de delicadezas e grã-finismo de ex-Misica As es se ao sisturia tambi tratada, por todo o século, em polifonia que vai de duas até seis vozes. Em todo caso, dentro dessa con-cepçao polilônica, o madrigal itálico, a chanson francesa, a song inglesa, o lied alemão, trazem o germe da melodia acompanhada. Tanto o sentido individualista dos textos, como a evolução cada vez mais harmônica da polifo-nia, propunham, desde já, o canto solista acompanhado por ins- trumento.E a canção avassala a criação artística do tempo. Assim como o século anterior fora a fase da missa, o séc. XVI é a fase da canção. Se os artistas, ainda até o século XVIII escreverão muita música religiosa, o que os particulariza c define o espírito novo é a música profana."(Andrade (1989) 87)

m\u00fasica cant\u00e1vel.text: English A: “First of all, popular melodies are “singable music,” and second, they emerge from an “oral matrix” connected to the singing voice and a primary sense of pleasure.” (Stover (2024) [2.1]) Portuguese A: “Em primeiro lugar, melodias populares são "música cantável", e em segundo lugar, emergem de uma "matriz oral" conectada à voz cantante e a um sentido de prazer primário.” (Ulhôa (1999))

composition.text: composição (Portuguese) Composiciones musicales (Spanish) Source: “The artistic act of a singer interpreting and directing a story through sound is not an undirected improvisation, but—as in music composition—is carried out within a framework of three musical elements: tone color, mode, and rhythmic pattern.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “The activity or process of creating music, and the product of such activity.” (Blum, Stephen. "Composition." Grove Music Online. 2001)

ubitan telu.text: English: “IV.2 through IV.5 can be discussed together since they are similar and all paired with the same oscillating two-note gending pattern. Gagelut and gagulet are assonant synonyms meaning hug, embrace, or even wrestle. The patterns are of a subtype called ubitan telu (telu = three) in which the two parts use a total of three tones, sharing an inner tone; hence embracing. These are indeed ubiquitous in the repertoire. Kabelit and kabelet, similarly related as words, mean stuck, stubborn, unmoving. They are of subtype called ubitan empat (empat = four) in which the two parts use two different but scale-adjacent tones each. When sounded the lower tone of the polos and the upper tone of the sangsih coincide, creating a dyad that protrudes from the texture to create a syncopated  3+2+3 cross-rhythm (the greyed notes). While the inner tones jostle, this prominent interval is “stuck” in its place.” Tenzer (2024) [4.6] English B: “To introduce some cross-cultural perspective, Example 3 reproduces my typology of ubit-ubitan patterns, based also on sensitivity to contour but differently than Geria (Tenzer 2000a, 225; Tenzer 2000b). I separate ubit-ubitan into two collections, ubit telu (ubit “three”, shown at left) and ubit empat (ubit “four”, shown at right). This is such a quotidian distinction for Balinese that Geria did perhaps not even consider invoking it. In ubit telu patterns, three contiguous scale-tone pitches are used, and the polos and sangsih parts always share the middle pitch. In ubit empat a fourth pitch is added such that each part has its own two pitches, and when the low part sounds its lower pitch, the high part always sounds its higher one. This generates dyads that protrude from the texture as cross-rhythms when patterns repeat. Aside from this, though, the collections of ubit telu and ubit empat patterns are identical from the standpoint of the contours of the lower three pitches in each.” (Tenzer (2024) [5.3])

Iliev (1996).text: Iliev, Ilko. 1996. “Spravochnik Na angliĭskata terminologi︠i︡a v popul︠i︡arnata, tan︠t︡sova i Dzhazova Muzika.” Gabrovo: "Luna,".

Gudai hanyu (2007).text: Wang, Jianyin. 王剑引, Jianmin Liang, Wanli Yu, Weiliang Zhou, and Peiwei Wang. Gu Dai Han Yu Da Ci Dian =: Gudaihanyudacidian 古代汉语大词典. Ci hai ban 辞海版, Xin 1 ban 新一版, Di 1 ban 第一版. Shanghai: Shanghai ci shu chu ban she 上海辞书出版社, 2007.

\u5bae g\u014dng.text: Chinese A: “《礼记·乐记》：“宫爲君，商爲臣，角爲民，徵爲事，羽爲物；五者不亂，則無怗懘之音矣。” Hanyu dacidian  (宫) Chinese B: “清毛奇龄《竟山乐录·五声不并列》：“人聲層次雖多，然只五聲而止。如宫是第一聲，商是第二聲，從下而上，從濁而清，從低而高，從重而輕，宫是最下之一聲。”” Hanyu dacidian  (宫) English: Pentatonic pitch class 0 Synonymous terms: do (sung jianpu 简谱), 1 (written jianpu 简谱), 上 (gongchepu 工尺谱) Lam (2024) Ex. 2.2 Lam (2024) Ex. 2.1

devi.text: Sinhalese A: “tat jek kinaṃ takaṭa kaḍataka jeṃgu jeṃ takaṭa tat takaṭa – devi dakin” Peiris (2024) [12] English A: “[vocables. . .] – witness the deities.” Peiris (2024) [12] English B: “gods” (Peiris (2025)

commentary.text: Source: “What follows, then, is the expression of a wish to think of “commentary” not as the tantalizing promise to restore the unknown to the known, but rather as an attempt to work myself out of what I, as an academic in the West, already know—not in the sense of disproving or discarding particular “things” that I know, but of trying to bring out the unfinished edges of systems of knowing whose productivity has been well established.” (Wang commentary (2024) [1.6]) Definition: “A treatise consisting of a systematic series of comments or annotations on the text of a literary work; an expository treatise following the order of the work explained.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “commentary” 3a)

\u79e9\u5e8f chitsujo.text: Japanese A: “本当を言えばそれを全く切り離してぼくの音楽を聴いてもらいたいけれども、ぼくは、過去の自分の経緯があるから最も人間的な芸術家でいたいんです。ぼく はかつては、作曲とはほとんど天界に近 い位置で音だけを聴いて、それに秩序を 与えることだと思っていました。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “In fact, I would like the listeners to hear my music without any of these background stories. Because my past life experience has tangled twists and turns, I hope to be the most humanistic artist. In the past, I once thought that composing music is akin to listening to tones in a near-celestial position and imbuing them with an order.” Park (2024) [5.1]

program music.text: Source: “As such, assertions of music’s autonomy tend to shade over into a commitment to “art for art’s sake,” and perhaps to lead one to (or justify after the fact—which is the cart? which the horse?) a distaste for opera or program music and a comparative valorization, say, of string quartets by Brahms.” Martin commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “Music of a narrative or descriptive kind; the term is often extended to all music that attempts to represent extra-musical concepts without resort to sung words.” (Grove Music Online, “Programme music”)

gamelan gong kebyar.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2])

\u8df3\u8e8d\u9032\u884c ch\u014dyakushi.text: 跳躍: jump, leap + 進行: moving forward, onward movement Japanese A: “声楽の旋律が一般に順次進行に傾き、器楽の旋律がこれに対して跳躍進行を多く含むということは” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 10] English A: “That vocal melodies generally incline towards stepwise motion, and that instrumental melodies conversely include more leaping motion,” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.1] See also 旋律の跳躍 senritsu no chōyaku and 跳躍的な力 chōyaku tekina chikara

el\u00edpticas.text: Portuguese A: “A síncopa europeia me parece um produto exclusivamente musical, e ainda mais, uma verdadeira especulação teórica proveniente da subdivisão da unidade de tempo em quantidades irregulares em que as batidas fortes subsistem em seus lugares teóricos e se tornam pois musicalmente elípticas.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota. no. 9] English A: “European syncopation seems to me an exclusively musical product, and furthermore, a true theoretical speculation stemming from the subdivision of the time unit into irregular quantities where strong beats persist in their theoretical places and thus become musically elliptical.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

\uc9c4\uc591 jinyang.text: English A: “It presents four or more rhythmic patterns 장단 (jangdan) in “ascending orders of metrical speed” (Provine, Hwang, and Howard 2001)—from slow tempo (e.g., jinyang 진양) to fast rhythmic cycles (e.g., hwimori 휘모리)—demonstrating the performer’s technical proficiency and expressive abilities.” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) English B: “Jinyang jangdan “is the slowest of all the rhythmic cycles used. It consists of [twenty-four] beats which are divided into four six-beat subdivisions or simply [six] beats” (Lee and Lee 2007, 112).]” (Kim (2024) Footnote 19)

\u4e94(\u4e2a)\u97f3 w\u01d4 (g\u00e8) y.text: Chinese A: “五個音牠的職守無非是要那一般樂工平時練熟宮商角徵羽那五個音.” Li (2024) [1.4] English A: The duty of the Music Ministry was to ensure that the musicians mastered the five tones—gong, shang, jue, zhi, and yu. Li (2024) [1.4] Chinese B: “亦称“五声”。①　即宫、商、角、徵、羽。《淮南子》:“一律而生五音。”北宋沈括《梦溪笔谈》释《周礼·大司乐》所论:“凡声之高下,列为五等,以宫、商、角、徵、羽名之。为之主者曰宫,次二曰商,次三曰角,次四曰徵,次五曰羽,此为之序。”相邻两音间按所约定的音程关系,除角与徵、羽与宫(高八度的宫)之间为小三度外,其余均为大二度。②　泛指各种音乐。《道德经》第十二章:“五音令人耳聋。”③　主音后的调式名称。《坠形训》:“音有五声,宫其主也。”即是以宫为主音的宫调式。若商其主者,即是以商为主音的商调式等。④　以“五声”与喉、齿、牙、舌、唇的不同发音部位相配。最早见于南朝梁陈间顾野王《玉篇·五音声论》。历代相配的方法不一,《梦溪笔谈》中唇音宫、舌音商、牙音角、齿音徵、喉音羽的配法,比较符合口腔中的发音部位.” Qinqiang da cidian (2014)  Chinese C: “《周礼·春官·大司乐》:“文之以五声,宫、商、角、徵、羽。”五声或称五音,见《吕氏春秋·季春纪》、《淮南鸿烈·览冥训》。五音按照音的高低排列,形成五声音阶,其中每相邻两音间的音程,除角与徵、羽与宫(高八度)为小三度外,馀者均为大二度。大致相当于现代音乐简谱1(do)、2(re)、3(mi)、5(sol)、6(la)。后来又加上变宫、变徵,称为七音,或称七声,这样便形成七声音阶(见“七声”)。变宫、变徵大致相当现代简谱7(si)、和4(fa)。无论五音还是七音,各音间只有相对音高,无绝对音高,各音间的音程比是固定不变的,只要确定第一级音的音高,其他各级的音高也便确定了。” Zhongguo ci xue (1996) (p. 453) Chinese D: “《孟子·离娄上》：“不以六律，不能正五音。” Hanyu dacidian  (五音) For further discussion, see also: Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (”五声,” p. 412)

\u9577\u5504 nagauta.text: Japanese A: “この核音は、民謡よりもむしろ芸術音楽ことに能楽の謡や三味線声楽の長唄などでは非常にはっきりとした形で現われており、そのばあいの旋律は、ただある１つの核音をめぐって上下浮動するという状態である。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “These nuclear tones appear extremely clearly in Japanese art music, especially in the utai of nō music and shamisen vocal music like nagauta, even more than in folk songs. The melodies in those (art music) cases have the characteristic of revolving around only one nuclear tone, and bobbing up and down around it.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1] “Utai 謡, while etymologically meaning simply “song,” has come to refer specifically to the vocal music of the nō 能 theater tradition. It is accompanied by a hayashi 囃子 ensemble, which consists of a few drums and a flute.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 5] Japanese B: “1) 地唄の中の一種・組唄の後に現れた古い形式の唄。 組唄が短い唄を集めて作ったのに対して、一つの纏まった歌曲なので これを長唄と呼んだ、多くは当時の検校達の作曲である。[…] 2) 江戸長唄 の略、もと歌舞伎の伴奏として唄われた小唄が漸次発達し、また上方 長唄の“道成寺”や“越後獅子”等が江戸の歌舞伎舞踊として採り入 れられるなど、江戸時代後期において歌舞伎の発達と共に発展し来た った歌曲である。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 134]

medida m\u00e9trica.text: English A: “In Portuguese versification, the verse is the metric measure, while the syllables, the minimal pulsations, are combined in varied rhythmic groupings. Comparing this metric organization of spoken language with Western and non-Western musical metric organization, we can say that the prosody of Portuguese verse is more like a sub-Saharan African metric notion (composed of periods or “time lines” without recurring accents) than a classical-romantic European metric notion (whose measures of determined limits follow one another regularly [see Example 3.1 - translator’s note]).” (Stover (2024) [3.4]) Portuguese A: “Portanto, na versificação portuguesa, o verso é a medida métrica, enquanto as sílabas, as pulsações mínimas, são combinadas em agrupamentos rítmicos variados. Comparando esta organização métrica da língua falada e a organização métrica musical ocidental e não-ocidental podemos dizer que a prosódia do verso português está mais para uma noção métrica africana sub-saarana (composta de períodos ou "time lines" sem acentos recorrentes), que para uma noção métrica européia clássico-romântica (cujos compassos de limites determinados, se sucedem regularmente).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u6b63\u7ebf zh\u00e8ng xi\u00e0n/\u6b63.text: Definitions: Chinese: “(1) 琴的常规定弦。其弦序关系是: CDFGAcd。(2) 见*智化寺京音乐四调、*民 间工尺七调。” Zhongguo yinyue (1984) （”正调,” p. 502） English: “In Chaozhou zheng music, the qupai titled “Guo jiang long” 過江龍 (“River-crossing dragon”) alternates between zhengxian 正線 (home key) and fanxian 反線 (inverse key), which is t3 of the home key.” Lam (2024)

\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0438\u043d\u0441\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “До днес тя е непозната на чуждия музикален свят: сърби, хървати и чехи като записвачи между другото и на тези български, включително и македонски, песни са ги предали с нотни знаци в изкривен вид, в рамките на правилните европейски тактове, когато техните истински тактове с малки изключения са твърде различни от европейските.” Hristov (1925) [p. 33] English A: “To this day it is unknown to the foreign musical world: when transcribing these Bulgarian, including Macedonian, songs into musical notation, Serbs, Croats, and Czechs have rendered them in distorted form, in the frameworks of regular European meters, when their true meters with few exceptions are quite different from European ones.” Goldberg (2024) [2.2]

tadah rawit.text: English A: “Gamelan pelegongan is an ensemble similar to semar pegulingan that accompanies the iconic legong dance genre] is called tadah rawit [this means “of small and beautiful character,” a resonance much like the characterization of semar pegulingan in II.2 above.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.5]) *Lexical field: Emotions or character (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

amebet lati.text: English A: “The technique of plucking the genggong is called amebet lati; its sound is samas nyata.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.15]) See genggong  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang anyetat genggong disebut amebet lati, samas nyata nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The genggong is a jew’s harp made with a wooden tongue set in a small frame held in the mouth. One vibrates the tongue by jerking a stick tied to a cord attached to the tongue; the sound is resonated by the oral cavity. Amebet means tide or wave, and lati is lips, thus, a wave of sound coming from the lips. Samas means four hundred and nyata means to drain or to dry—is Geria saying that after so many yanks one’s mouth is dry? None of my Balinese interlocutors know.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.14]) *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\ud750\ub974\ub294 \uc18d\uc5d0 heuleune.text: 흐르는: flowing Korean A: “흐르는 속에 이 있고, 그 음을 둘러싼 음 모두가'주요음'이다.” (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146) English A: “Within a flowing line [流れる線], there is one important tone [音]. With this tone in the center, I call all sounds that surround it Hauptton [主要音].” (Park (2024) [1])

\u0434\u0440\u043e\u0431\u0438/drobi.text: Bulgarian A: “Елементите в горните тактове може да отбележим и с два пъти пoголяма стойност (½); ще имаме в такъв случай същите тактове (мерки), означени с . осмини дроби.” Hristov (1925) [p. 38] English A: “We can also notate the elements in the above meters with doubled note values (eighth notes); in such a case we will have the same meters (time signatures) represented with eighth-note subdivisions.” Goldberg (2024) [3.3]

agrupamento.text: English A: “The melody of a popular song is generally composed of the repetition or grouping of short melodic motifs: melodic-rhythmic formulas that function as “blocks of meaning,” as Gino Stefani (1987) puts it, ready to be incorporated, repeated, combined, or associated in creating the song.” (Stover (2024) [2.1]) Portuguese A: “A melodia da canção popular é geralmente composta a partir da repetição ou agrupamento de motivos melódicos curtos, espécie de fórmulas melódico-rítmicas que funcionam como "blocos de significação", como coloca Gino Stefani, prontos para serem incorporados, repetidos, combinados ou associados na feitura da canção. “ (Ulhôa (1999))

\u00e1tonas.text: English A: “Although each word may have its stressed and unstressed syllables, it is the logic of the sentence that prevails. Depending on its location in a verse or phrase, an accented word or syllable may have its accent nullified, or the phrase may vary in terms of syllable limits, and its syllables may even be prosodic or metric, as in the word luar, which can be counted as a monosyllabic word, like “luar,” or two-syllable, like “lu-ar” (Carvalho 1970).” (Stover (2024) [3.3]) Portuguese A: “Embora cada palavra possa ter suas sílabas tônicas e átonas, é a lógica da sentença que prevalece. Dependendo da sua localização num verso ou frase, uma palavra ou sílaba acentuada pode ter seu acento negligenciado, ou variar em termos de limites silábicos, podendo inclusive as sílabas serem prosódicas ou métricas, como na palavra luar, que pode ser contada como palavra monossilábica, como luar, ou dissílaba, como lu-ar (Carvalho 1970).” (Ulhôa (1999))

thesis.text: Portuguese A: “Ora em nossa música americana (jazz, maxixe e em geral toda síncopa brasileira e mesmo no tango platino) o que se dá é um verdadeiro descolocamento do acento forte que passa do lugar teórico para um lugar onde ele não devia cair, verdadeira antecipação rítmica da thesis.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Now in our American music (jazz, maxixe, and in general all Brazilian syncopation and even in the Argentine tango) what happens is a true displacement of the strong accent which passes from the theoretical place to a place where it should not fall, a true rhythmic anticipation of the thesis.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

\u5f31\u541f yowagin.text: Japanese A: “これはクセとよばれる部分の一部であるが、その４度音程をもつ上下動の中にも明瞭に核音の支配をうかがい知ることができる。これと同じ旋律的な弱吟という発声法によるクセの他の部分では、これよりもはるかに一語一音符的な（syllabic）スタイルによっており、” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “This is one part of something that might be called the kuse, and within the up-and-down motion across the interval of a fourth, we can clearly perceive the control of nuclear tones. In another part of the kuse, whose method of vocalization is called melodic yowagin, it is in a far more syllabic style (one word to one note) even than this.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.2]

\u2f00\u69d8\u2fb3 y\u012b sama y\u012bn.text: Japanese A: “流 れ て い る 線 の 中 に 重 要 な ⾳ が あ り そ の ⾳ を 中 ⼼ と し て 、 そ れ を 囲 ん で い る ⾳ す べ て を 称 し て 私 は 「 主 要 ⾳ 」 と ⾔ い 、 学 者 た ち は「 ⼀ 様 ⾳ 」 と 呼 ん で い ま す 。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 52) English A: "Within a flowing line [流れる線], there is one important tone. With this tone in the center, I call all sounds that surround it Hauptton, and the scholars call them sonic oneness." (Park (2024) [1.6])

nonisochronous.text: Source: “Several scholars have convincingly argued against the essentialisms inherent in this reductive narrative: Africa as a monolithic musical culture; rhythm in African musics as a parameter separable from dance, melody, and timbre; and conceptualizing nonisochronous rhythmic and metric patterns in these musics as dissonances; see Agawu (2003) and (2023), London (2012), Nzewi (1991), Perchard (2015), and Stover (2009).” Biamonte commentary (2024) [2] Definition: “Taking place in or occupying [UN]equal times; [UN]equal in metrical length; [UN]equal in duration, or in intervals of occurrence, [UNLIKE] the vibrations of a pendulum; characterized by or relating to vibrations or motions of [UN]equal duration; vibrating [NON]-uniformly.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “isochronous”)

\ub9cc\uace1 mangog.text: Korean A: "그러니까 나의 음악을 두고 모든 것이 흐른다, 유창하게 흐른다, 그 선의 끊임없는 되풀이다라고 말들 하지요. 그 유창하게 흐르고 있는 선이 직선이 아니라 만곡하고 있는 겁니다. 게다가 만곡 방식이 다양하거든요. 그 만곡 속에 여러 부분이 있고, 이 한 부분 의 만곡 속에 다시 부분, 부분이 있어서 그 자체가 이 만곡과 비교 하면 하나의 세계가 된다, 그 하나의 세계 속에 또 세계가 있다는 것이지요." (Yun (1991) - Korean, 152) English A: Therefore, people speak about my music as flowing, smoothly flowing, an endless repetition of the line. The smoothly flowing line is not a straight line but is a curved line (彎曲). And there are various ways a line can be curved. "Within a curve, there are various parts. The part and the curve each contain a universe within itself. It means that within a universe, there is another universe." (Park (2024) [2.4])

padu arsa.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat kalih padu arsa ngaran, ,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “if two in-between the name is padu arsa [united desire]” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8])

cengceng.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “yan swaran cengceng , wetu saking banyu arnawasruti ngaran, anudantya ngaran yan ring anggsarira, adalan ring untengan asilat.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The cengceng sound is borne from the water arnawa sruti, in the body its name is anudantya, centered on the subtle energy in the tongue.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.10]) Balinese C: “céngcéng instrumen yg bentuknya bulat pipih, salah satu sisinya cekung dan menonjol pd sisi yg lain, berfungsi untuk mengikuti ritme kendang, sbg pamurba irama dan mengatur dinamika lagu” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 136, Bidang Istilah Musik]

ngubeng.text: English A: “In the large and important repertoire of “classical” pelegongan style, a significant preponderance of ubit-ubitan patterns follow a few simple rules known to all gamelan players: they last two beats at a rate of four tones per beat, and are classified either stable (ngubeng) or motile (majalan), depending on the direction of the underlying melody.” (Tenzer (2024) [5.4])

nota\u00e7\u00e3o tradicional.text: English A: “The resulting rhythm becomes so subtle that it is almost impossible to register it through traditional notation.” (Stover (2024) [1.1]) Portuguese A: “ Esta rítmica se torna tão sutil que é quase impossível registrá-la através da notação tradicional.” (Ulhôa (1999))

letra.text: English A: “In popular song, melody and lyrics closely influence each other. There are elements in the lyrics, especially their narrative or lyrical quality, that suggest different types of melody, and there are particularities in the melody, especially its melodic contour and the types of intervals used that define the character of the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Na canção popular melodia e letra interferem estreitamente uma sobre a outra. Existem elementos na letra, especialmente sua qualidade narrativa ou lírica que conduzem a diferentes tipos de melodia; existem particularidades na melodia, especialmente seu contorno melódico e tipos de intervalos empregados que marcam o caráter da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Texta poético musicado.” (Andrade (1989), 283).

\u8aaa sh\u016bo.text: Chinese A: 叙说；讲述. Hanyu dacidian (說, 1) English: “Vocal sounds that differ from strict “singing” due to being recitative in style.” Qian (2024) (See also 乐说 yuèshuō)

Sistema de los 12 sonidos.text: Spanish A: “Ejemplos de este género se encuentran a menudo en las obras de Bach, especialmente en su Ofrenda musical y su Arte de la fuga, las maravillas más estupendas que produjo el clasicismo en los campos de la técnica musical del sistema de los 12 sonidos.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 16] English A: “Examples of this kind are often encountered in the works of Bach, especially in his Musical Offering and his Art of the Fugue, the greatest wonders classicism produced under the musical techniques of the twelve-note musical system.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 16]

\u697d\u53e5 gakuku.text: 楽 gaku+句 句: section (i.e. of text); phrase Japanese A: “譜２５のＡは、任意に拾いあげた民謡の一例を、楽譜の上段には終止音gとdにより、それぞれ支配的な楽句を区分し、下段には終止音間の４度音程と５度音程によって、それぞれの占める楽句を区分したものである。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] Japanese B: “通 常 そ れ ⾃ 体 で は 完 結 し な い 、 ご く 短 い ⾳ 楽 的 ま と ま り 。 し ば し ば * 楽 節 と 同 義 。” Tomosha (2002) [p. 142] English A: “Example 25A (Example 1) takes an arbitrarily-chosen example of a folk song, and above the notation divides the various musical phrases into those controlled by the ending note G and those controlled by D.
