Below it, it divides the phrases bounded by the interval of a fourth from those bounded by a fifth.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1]

\u8bcd c\u00ed.text: Chinese A: “中國舊日的詞，首首都是可以拿來唱的。怎樣唱？就是有了一個詞牌的音樂之後，你便可以填上一些詞句，不計這些詞句是雄壯，抑或衰澀，是歡樂，抑或愁苦，你都可以依照同一樣的音樂把牠唱出來。” Li (2024) (See also: 词牌 cí pái) English A: “Every lyric poetry (ci) in ancient China could be sung. How? Once the tunes (cipai) were set, one could fill it out with lines and words in accordance with the tone patterns.” Li (2024)  Chinese B: “语言组织中的基本单位，能独立运用，具有声音、意义和语法功能.” Hanyu dacidian  (词, 4)

egwu.text: Igbo A: “Egwu mụ ete aka, nwee nkeji dị iche iche. Doo anya, tọ ụtọ.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “My songs become longer, and have different sections, become clearer and sweet.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] Igbo B: “Na emekwa ya n'egwu m/Na-akpọkwa ya n'egwu” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) English B: “I use it in my musical ensemble/I perform it in songs.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo C: “ịgụ egwu na Igbo ma ọ bụ ikwe ukwe ma ọ bụ ịbụ abụ” (Laz Ekwueme Interview Part 2, 0:04) English C: “Singing in Igbo or singing choral music or chanting psalms…” (Laz Ekwueme Interview Part 2, 0:04) Igbo D: “n’onu ukwe, ma ọ bụ n’onu abụ, ma ọ bụ onu ịgụ egwu.” (Laz Ekwueme Interview Part 2, 4:08) English D: “as choral music, or as chants, or as songs” (Laz Ekwueme Interview Part 2, 4:08)

Zhongguo da baike (2020).text: Zhongguo Da Baike Quanshu Shujuku 中国大百科全书数据库, accessed September 24, 2024, https://h.bkzx.cn/.

tuning.text: Source: “Generally, the tuning of the Ubọ-aka can vary; it can start from any frequency and be arranged in any style the performer may want. I have taught my students the tuning principles and they are free to tune in any style they want. However, the size of the calabash and the length of the prongs determine the range that is possible from the lowest note to the highest note.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [5.1] Definition: “To adjust the tones of (a musical instrument) to a standard of pitch; to bring into condition for producing the required sounds correctly; to put in tune.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “tune”)

parceria r\u00edtmica.text: English A: “Both in these “melôs” and in the case of rap in Portuguese, two prosodic issues appear. First is the use in Portuguese of a metric typical of English, that is, of regularly spaced thetic accents, which contributes to a sensation of regular measures. And second, there is the issue of successive ruptures typical of rap, produced by scratches, which makes music more of a “rhythmic partnership” than an complete interconnection between lyrics and melody (see Rose 1997, 207–8).” (Stover (2024) [3.5]) Portuguese A: “Tanto nestas "melôs", quanto no caso do rap em português vão aparecer duas questões prosódicas: primeiro, a utilização no português de uma métrica própria do ingles, isto é, de acentuações téticas regularmente espaçadas, o que contribui para uma sensação de compassos regulares. Segundo, é a questão das rupturas sucessivas próprias do rap, produzidas pelos "scratchs", o que faz da música mais uma "parceria rítmica" do que um todo interligado de letra e melodia (vide Rose 1997: 207-8).” (Ulhôa (1999))

meter.text: такта/takta (Bulgarian) 节拍 jiépāi (Chinese) Source: “The intuition present in this passage is impressive for exposing—perhaps for the first time by a Brazilian musicologist—the theoretical formalization, albeit incipient, of a displaced but consistent accent in relation to the main meter, functioning as a regular, tensioning, and complementary element to the meter. The formulation of a second rhythmic support point emerges, which is structured and constant, yet displaced in relation to the main beat. What Andrade seeks to describe—without a clear formulation—is a type of accent displacement that does not occur as a deviation or rupture of the musical discourse, but as a rule of the structure, which, appearing constantly in the performance of musicians from various American cultures, gains a different status from European syncopation.” Menezes (2024) [1.7] Definition: “More generally, the temporal hierarchy of subdivisions, beats and bars that is maintained by performers and inferred by listeners which functions as a dynamic temporal framework for the production and comprehension of musical durations. In this sense, metre is more an aspect of the behaviour of performers and listeners than an aspect of the music itself..” (Grove Music Online, “metre”)

\u0434\u0430\u0439\u0440\u0435/da\u00efr.text: Bulgarian A: “На пръв поглед безмензурните ни песни приличат на персо-арабските пешрефи, защото и в тях думите се твърде протакат и при слушане изглежда, че и те са без такт. В същност пешрефите имат точно определен такт, който чрез биене на дайре и др. ударни инструменти се уяснява. При записане безмензурните песни за по-лесно изпълнение се подвеждат под някой определен такт.” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “At first glance our unmeasured songs resemble Persian-Arabic peşrevs, because the words in these songs are also quite protracted, and upon listening it appears as though they also lack meter. In actuality peşrevs have a precisely defined meter that is clarified through beating on the daire and other percussion instruments. When transcribing unmeasured songs for easier performance, they are misrepresented as having a particular meter.” Goldberg (2024) [4.1] “The daire is a handheld frame drum.” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 14] Bulgarian B: “(тур. d aire от араб. кръг, окръж- ност) турско наименование на ударния инструмент тамбурина". Употребява се и у нас.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 80]

\uac70\ubb38\uace0 geomungo.text: English A: “Sanjo may be played with a variety of traditional Korean string or wind instruments, including gayageum 가야금 (twelve-string zither), geomungo 거문고 (six-string zither), ajaeng 아쟁 (bowed zither), and daegeum 대금 (bamboo flute).” (Kim (2024) [0.1])

ritual music.text: 아악 aak (Korean) 雅楽 gagaku (Japanese) Source: “The translator’s choice of Shin Eun-Joo’s article on pansori is perfectly suited to presenting such an introduction. Pansori is one of the most important genres in Korean traditional music. Although frequently compared to Western classical opera due to their shared vocal and theatrical attributes, pansori is essentially an epic, narrative storytelling vocal performance executed by a singer and a drum accompanist without stage design or theatrical costumes. Unlike court or ritual music, pansori was first circulated among commoners and the lower class, and later enjoyed by all classes as a principal form of entertainment.” Lee commentary (2024) [3]

\u30e8\u30fc\u30ed\u30c3\u30d1 Y\u014dro.text: Japanese A: “このどちらもが、日本の音階と旋律法のヨーロッパとの違いはもちろん、アジア音楽の中での、特異性をきわめて明確に規定する要素なのであるが、ここではまず前者について考えて見よう。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] English A: “For both of these, the differences between Japanese musical rules and those of Europe are of course the elements make Asian music seem so extremely peculiar.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1]

\ub2e4\ub8e8 daru.text: Korean A: “본청은 하청과의 4도 진행 및 상본청과의 2도 진행이 자주 나타나고, 평조길에서 종지음은 하청이되 본청으로 종지하기도 한다고 하였다. 상본청은 평조길의 가장 특징적인 음이며 여러 성질로 사용된다. 상본청이 여러 성질을 나타내는 점은 우조길에서와 동일한데, '우조에서와 같이 꿋꿋하게 내기도 한다'라고 한 것에서 드러나 듯, 이 음을 꿋꿋하게 내는 것은 우조의 성질이고, 평조의 성질로는 '흘러내리거나, 가볍게 떨거나, 계 면길의 다루와 같이 상청이 장식음으로 붙는 것'이 평조 상본청의 성질이라고 할 수 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 241] English A: “In Pyeongjo-gil, boncheong frequently appears in fourths sequences with hacheong and seconds sequences with sangboncheong; the cadential note in these cases is hacheong, but the sequences sometimes conclude with boncheong. The most recognizable note in Pyeongjo, sangboncheong, is employed in a variety of ways, similarly to Ujo. Sangboncheong in Pyeongjo “flows down, trembles softly, and has decorative notes like daru in Gyemyeon-gil;” in Ujo-gil, sangboncheong “has a firm timbre” (Baek 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.8]

\u90a6\u697d\u5668 H\u014dgaku-ki.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) See also: 邦楽 hōgaku

tensividade passional.text: English A: “Luiz Tatit, in his work on song, discusses in detail the role vowels and consonants play in the song. According to Tatit (1996), vowels are responsible for what he calls “passionate tensivity” [tensividade passional], produced both by the stabilization of the melodic curve and by the discursive intonation of speech. In another process of tensividade, which he describes as “somatic” or “thematic,” consonants generate movements, outline rhythms, build characters, establish genres.” (Stover (2024) [2.6]) Portuguese A: “Luiz Tatit no seu trabalho sobre a canção discute bem o papel das vogais e consoantes na canção. Segundo Tatit (1986, 1996), as vogais são responsáveis pelo que chama de "tensividade passional", produzida tanto pela estabilização da curva melódica quanto pela entoação discursiva da fala. Num outro processo de tensividade, agora "somática" ou "temática", as consoantes geram movimentos, delineiam rítmos, constroem personagens, estabelecem gêneros.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “The intensity, which Tatit would call passionate tenseness, is intensified by the “participatory discrepancy” between solo and accompaniment.” (Stover (2024) [5.6]) Portuguese B: “A tensão, que Tatit chamaria de tensividade passional, é intensificada pela "discrepância participativa" entre solo e acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u9053 d\u00e0o.text: Chinese A: “因為在文人看來，道是造分天地，化成萬物的一樣東西，凡屬可以行道的詩書易禮，都是道的工具，固不僅音樂是如是。你們要把音樂的獨立生命奪回來，自然要把「樂是禮的附庸」之說打破，即是要把「音樂是道的一種工具」之說打破，必要把這一類的學說打破，然後音樂的獨立生命綫有着落.” Li (2024) [1.5] English A: “For the literati, the Way generated Heaven, the Earth, and ten thousand things (wanwu). Like Music—Poetry, Literature, and Ritual were means for the literati to unite with the Way. If you wish to retrieve the lost autonomy of Music, you must not only dismiss the idea that Music is a subsidiary of Ritual, but also dismantle such kind of thought as Music is an instrument of the Way.” Li (2024) [1.5] Chinese B: “中国古代哲学的重要范畴。用以说明世界的本原、本体、规律或原理。道的原始含义指道路、坦途，以后逐渐发展为规范、规律。老子最先把道看作宇宙的本原和规律。他认为道是天地万物化生的根源并蕴涵于天地万物之中，成为万物共同的本质。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) （道） Chinese C: “淨土論註上曰：「道者通也。以如此因，得如此果。以如是果，酬如是因。通因至果，通果酬因。故名為道。」” Ding (1969) (十三画) Chinese D: “《老子》：“有物混成，先天地生……可以为天下母。吾不知其名，字之曰道。”” Hanyu dacidian  (道)

Bauer commentary (2024).text: Bauer, Amy. 2024. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

buta anggawasari.text: English A: “Rebab playing style is called buta anggawasari; its sound is semara nada.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.10]) See rebab, see semara nada  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang rarebaban, buta anggawasari namanya. Semara nada nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Buta are potentially malevolent spirits that can be benevolent if properly placated; anggawasari combines anggawa, to bring, and sari, nectar or essence; thus, the essence-bringing buta. Nada are tones and semara is romantic or often erotic love. Geria thus associates the rebab with powerful human and unseen forces.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.9]) *Lexical field: Cultural practice or unseen phenomenon (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

cantar.text: Portuguese A: “A contaminação se deu e por ela se criaram fórmulas de cantar já especificamente americanas. Porém esta afirmativa não basta. O problema das origens permanece intrincado e sem bases atuais com que possa ser resolvido.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 1] English A: “Contamination occurred and through it formulas of singing were created that are already specifically American. However, this statement is not enough. The problem of origins remains intricate and without current bases on which it can be resolved.” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “Formular melodias, frases musicais, com ou sem letra. Or-ganizar notas segundo regras estabelecidas ou improvisando, seguindo a inspiração do momento. (DM)” (Andrade (1989), 98)

translation.text: Source: “This article aims to broaden common understandings of music theory through the lens of orally transmitted ritualistic verses from Sri Lanka, which are sung or recited along with drumming. I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “The action or process of translating a word, a work, etc., from one language into another.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “translation”)

\u8abf ch\u014d.text: Japanese A: “これはヨーロッパの調性音楽が、次第に従来の長・短調組織からぬけだして、自由な音語を使うようになってから、もっともひろい意味での調性の中心になる音という意味に使われていたものを、伝統音楽のばあいに適用したものと解することができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “It is understood that Mr. Itō applied the word “central tone” as something commonly used in Japanese traditional music, in the same way European music used it in a free pitch language after it gradually began to pull away from its original major- and minor-key organization of tonal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4] Japanese B: “ある音を主音とした音階をその音の調という、例、老越を 主音とした音階は“老越調”、ハの音を主音とした音階は“ハ調”と言 うがごとし。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 117]

Andrade (2013).text: Arquivo Mário de Andrade. 2013. Música, doce música. Nova Fronteira.

versifica\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “In Portuguese versification, the verse is the metric measure, while the syllables, the minimal pulsations, are combined in varied rhythmic groupings. Comparing this metric organization of spoken language with Western and non-Western musical metric organization, we can say that the prosody of Portuguese verse is more like a sub-Saharan African metric notion (composed of periods or “time lines” without recurring accents) than a classical-romantic European metric notion (whose measures of determined limits follow one another regularly [see Example 3.1 - translator’s note]).” (Stover (2024) [3.4]) Portuguese A: “Portanto, na versificação portuguesa, o verso é a medida métrica, enquanto as sílabas, as pulsações mínimas, são combinadas em agrupamentos rítmicos variados. Comparando esta organização métrica da língua falada e a organização métrica musical ocidental e não-ocidental podemos dizer que a prosódia do verso português está mais para uma noção métrica africana sub-saarana (composta de períodos ou "time lines" sem acentos recorrentes), que para uma noção métrica européia clássico-romântica (cujos compassos de limites determinados, se sucedem regularmente).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u0442\u0430\u0442\u0430\u0440\u0441\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Тактът на ръченицата се среща и в татарската музика и никъде в други страни.” Hristov (1925) (p. 49) English A: “The meter of the rŭchenitsa is also found in Tatar music and nowhere in any other countries.” Goldberg (2024) [5.20]

\uc77c\uc6d0 il-won.text: Korean A: "그러나 나의 음악 은 모든 흐름, 본류이건 지류이건 모두가 일원적입니다. "일원'이란 여기서는 약간 적합치 않습니다만, 가정해서 그 말을 쓴다 면 그런 식으로 선적인 형태가 같은 원칙, 같은 미학적 입장에서 흐르고 있고, 그 많은 흐름의 하나하나의 형태가 동일성을 갖는다는 겁니다. 게다가 그것이 분단적으로 사용되더라도 모이면 그 동일성의 근원이 획득되는 거지요." (Yun (1991) - Korean 150) English A: "But in my music, all flows are uniform, whether it is the mainstream or branch. “Uniform” [一元] may not be the best word. To use it here because of the lack of a better term, various lines flow through according to the same principle and aesthetic perspective, and the individual lines are in accordance with each other. In addition, even when a single line is used separately [分斷的], when combined, the uniformity emerges from them." (Park (2024) [2.1])

actant.text: Source: “On the other side of the metaphor is the naming of a sensation from the perspective of the recipient of tickling, a gesture, as Adam Phillips (1993, 9) elaborates from Darwin, that seems to require an actant and a recipient (“It is the pleasure [the child] cannot reproduce in the absence of the other.”). And yet Geria writes: “Its sound is pangirik [tickling].” If we take this to mean that the sound tickles, the musician is then the tickler. Except, of course, the tickling is not enacted directly on the listener’s body, but rather on the body of the instrument (which is sometimes the musician’s own body, as in the case of singing) as a kind of intermediary substitute for the listener’s body.” (Wang commentary (2024) [2.5]) Definition: “Literary Theory. Any of various narrative roles or functions which may be fulfilled by one or more characters or other entities in a text.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “actant” 2)

\uc9c8\uc11c jilseo.text: Korean A: “사실은 그런 걸 완전히 배제해버리고 나의 음악을 들어주길 바랍니다만, 나는 과거 내 자신의 복잡한 곡절이 있기 때문에 가장 인간적인 예술가이기를 바랍니다. 일찍이 나는 한때 작곡이란 거의 천상계(天上界)에 가까운 위치에서 음만을 듣고 그에 질서를 부여 하는 것이라고 생각했었지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 158] English A: “In fact, I would like the listeners to hear my music without any of these background stories. Because my past life experience has tangled twists and turns, I hope to be the most humanistic artist. In the past, I once thought that composing music is akin to listening to tones in a near-celestial position and imbuing them with an order.” Park (2024) [5.1]

\u0445\u043e\u0440\u043e/horo.text: Bulgarian A: “При същата бързина на елементите от две тройни групи се получава един жив (бърз) 6/16 такт с две ударения. Ако всяка тройна група сметнем за триола, ще имаме в такъв случай вместо 6/16 един 2/8 такт (с два пъти аргументирани нотни стойности -- 2/4). Този такт служи за основа на обикновено живо българско хоро (рондо) подобно на тарантелата.” Hristov (1925) [p. 46] English A: “At the same tempo of elements, two triple groups produce a lively (fast) 6/16 meter with two beats. If we consider each triple group to be a triplet, we will have in this case a 2/8 meter instead of 6/16 (or with duply augmented note values, 2/4). This meter serves as the basis for the ordinary lively Bulgarian horo (rondo) similar to the tarantella.” Goldberg (2024) [5.9] “Horo and igra are names for types of Bulgarian dances. Both typically involve dancing in one or more lines or open circles, which dancers form by holding hands, belts, or shoulders.” Goldberg (2024) [Footnote 8] Bulgarian B: “Хоро (от гр. horós xopo, хоровод, хоро- воден танц с пеене) танцов ансамбъл, съставен от неопределен брой играчи, на- ловени един за друг в дълга върволица, които изпълняват едновременно и в такт едни и същи стъпки от танца. Х. е най-обик- новена форма на български народен танц. То се играе по всички краища на страната и дава възможност на голям брой играчи да вземат участие в танцовото изпълнение. Груповото изпълнение твърде много улес- нява играчите, които по такъв начин взаимно контролират стъпките си, такта, ритъма и пр. Х. може да бъде отворено или затворено. Във всяко отворено Х. се раз- личават три части: чело, среда и опашка.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 373] Bulgarian C: “Масов народен танц, изпълняван от мьже и, жени, млади и стари, хванати выв верига, в затворен или отворен крьг, в колона или лькатушно. Играе се в различни брзини с движение вляво, вдясно, напред и назад. Ръцете са заловени - спуснати надолу или свити горе, на пояс, на плетеница, на рамо. Най-широко раз-пространение има х., наричано право или обикновено в 2/4 такт с движение вдясно. Х. с голямо разнообразие в стьпки и ритьм са: Пайдушка, Грьнчарско, Копаница,Еленино и др. 2. Мястото, където се сбират да играят хоро — „на хорото", „хорище".” (Krŭstev (1967) p. 440)

\uc74c\ud1b5\uc77c eumtong-il.text: 통일: unification; sense of unity Korean A: “'음의 통일체이지 요. 흐르는 선 가운데 중요한 음이 있고, 그 음을 중심으로 그것음 둘러싸고 있는 음 모두를 일컬어 나는 '주요음'이라 하는데, 학자들 은 음통일체'라고 하고 있어요. “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 149) English A: “Within a flowing line [流れる線], there is one important tone. With this tone in the center, I call all sounds that surround it Hauptton, and the scholars call them sonic oneness." (Park (2024) [1.6])

ratih.text: Balinese A: “smara ngaran laki, ratih ngaran wadu, swaraning smara ngaran kama nada, swaraning ratih ngaran kama sraga. Rikalanya anunggal swara ika, hana swara karenga ngararengih ngalup manis, kadi reng pangucapira sanghyang smara ratih, patemuan nira murda, ring murda panunggara nira sanghyang ardanareswari, apan sira wenang surup sinurup, ganti gumanti, matemahan ring windu nada candra.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: ““Semara” indicates male, “Ratih” indicates female, the voice of Semara is called kama nada, [kama = desire; nada = tone] the voice of Ratih is called kama sraga [sraga = form]. When these voices become one, there is a tinkling, sweet sound, like the vibrations of Sang Hyang Semara and Ratih’s words at their summit, at the highest realm of Sang Hyang Ardanareswari [a manifestation of Siva and his consort Parvati unifying male and female] because he can go in and out, again and again, on the tones of Windu Chandra [windu is a point, an essence; chandra can suggest brightness or the moon].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.6]) Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Iti swara patut Slendro, Panca Brahma ngaran, Panca Brahma peraganira Sang Hyang Ratih arupa Kumbang. Smararatih maka angga Sang Hyang Predana Purusa Jati, marmanya Smara angawe katuridan, Ratih angawe prapaneaning manah .Mangkana witnya.” (Bandem (1986), 44. See also: p. 13) English C (Chat GPT Translation): “Additionally, the Slendro tuning system is called Panca Brahma (Five Divine Beings). Thus, this is how it originates.”

staff notation.text: Source: “Qian pushes for the use of IPA because pinyin was designed specifically for Mandarin and cannot capture the full range of sounds of other Sinitic tongues. But what of staff notation’s ability to represent traditional music? Staff notation has not presented an issue with studies of Mandopop or Cantopop because of their conformity to diatonic keys, but for locally-made instruments, surely this would no longer be the case.” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [9] Definition: “Musical notation in which position on the staff or stave (see staff n.1 II.20) is used to indicate the pitch of notes, especially as distinct from Tonic sol-fa.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “staff notation”)

classe de altura.text: English A: “In measured tonal music, although dynamics play a central role, duration and frequency (both in pitch class and harmony) also contribute to musical accentuation.” (Stover (2024) [5.10]) Portuguese A: “Na música medida tonal, embora a dinâmica tenha um papel central, duração e freqüência (tanto em classe de altura quanto harmonia) também contribuem para a acentuação musical.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc0c1\ubcf8\uccad sangboncheong.text: Kim (2024) Ex. 2–1 Korean A: “때문에 백대웅의 이론을 활용하여 판소리 악조를 분석할 경우, 본청과 상청의 음정이 장3도인 경우에는 우조로, 본청과 상청의 음정이 완전4도인 경우에는 평조로 판별한다. 이를 상본청과 상청의 음정 간격 으로 다시 설명하면, 상본청과 상청의 음정이 장2도인 경우에는 우조로, 상본청과 상청의 음정 이 단3도인 경우에는 평조로 해석되는 것이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238] English A: “Therefore, if the gap between boncheong and sangcheong is a major 3rd, it is analyzed as Ujo according to Baek’s theory. If the interval between the two notes is a perfect 4th, it is Pyeongjo. In other words, a major 2nd between sangboncheong and sangcheong is Ujo, and a minor 3rd is Pyeongjo.” Kim (2024) [3.8]

n\u00e3o-m\u00e9trico.text: English A: “Song melodies would not be syncopated, the ambivalence emerging from their counterposition with the accompaniment, which would accentuate the beat. Instead, the melodic flow would be non-metrical, its accentuation driven by a “musical fantasy, pure virtuosity, or prosodic precision … a subtle compromise between recitative and strophic singing” (36).” (Stover (2024) [1.6]) Portuguese A: “As melodias das canções não seriam sincopadas, a ambivalência emergindo da contraposição com o acompanhamento, que acentuaria o tempo. O fluir da melodia seria não-métrico, a acentuação sendo dirigida por uma "fantasia musical, puro virtuosismo, ou precisão prosódica ... um compromisso sutil entre o canto recitativo e estrófico" (p. 36).” (Ulhôa (1999))

semitone.text: Source: “Carrillo justified this sixteenth-tone limit for his microtonal system by arguing that it was practical. Within a single composition, he pointed out, sixteenth tones could be multiplied to form eighth tones, quarter tones, semitones, and whole tones, and so could be reconciled with a variety of microtonal and traditional instruments (Carrillo 1938, 24).” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.4] Definition: “The smallest Interval of the modern Western tone system; in Equal temperament, the 1/12 part of an octave, or 100 cents. The notational system allows three types of semitone to be distinguished: the diatonic, which is the same as a minor 2nd (e.g. e–f, c♯–d); the chromatic, which is the difference between a major 2nd and a minor 2nd (hence an augmented unison, e.g. f–f♯, d♭–d); and the enharmonic, which is a doubly diminished 3rd (e.g. g♭♭–e, b♯–d♭, b𝄪–d′).” (Grove Music Online, “semitone”)

dengue.text: Portuguese A: “É uma realização imediata e espontânea das nossas maneiras de dançar, mais sensuais, provindas do clima talvez, e do amolecimento fisiológico das raças que se caldearam pra nos formar e formaram também o remeleixo, o requebro, o dengue. É o movimento dengoso do corpo na dança que deformou a rítmica da polca primeiramente na rítmica da habanera em seguida no do maxixe. Acresce ainda que em habaneras e danzones é comum o elemento da tercina (ver se a tercina ocorre no primeiro tempo).” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Here, syncopation is of immediate, constant, and directly choreographic application. In America, syncopation does not come from European syncopation. It is an immediate and spontaneous realization of our ways of dancing, more sensual, perhaps stemming from the climate, and the physiological softening of the races that melded to form us and also formed the remeleixo, the requebro, the dengue. It is the languid body movement in dance that deformed the rhythm of the polka first into the rhythm of the habanera and then into that of the maxixe. Furthermore, in habaneras and danzones, the element of triplet (check if the triplet occurs on the first beat) is common.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

T\u00f3nica.text: Spanish A: “…es decir, que así como en el ejemplo 44 se conservó el Do como tónica, se vayan conservando en cada caso las tónicas respectivas; aunque no hay razón alguna en contra de quien prefiera servirse únicamente de la clave que indico para Do mayor, pero en ese caso no se conservarán las tónicas. Si se conserva inamovible únicamente la nota Do para todas las tonalidades, la impresión no será la misma que si se conservara en cada caso la tónica de la obra metamorfoseada.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 26] English A: “In other words, just as C was preserved as tonic in Example 44, other tonics can be preserved. Although there is no reason not to work solely with the guide I indicate for C major, in that case, one will not be preserving tonics. When one holds C fixed for all tonalities, the impression will not be the same as when one preserves, in each instance, the tonic of the metamorphosed work.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 26] Spanish B: “Nombre de la cuerda principal sobre la cual el tono se establece.” Palatín (1990) [p. 100] Spanish C: “Tónica es el nombre con que se distingue el primer grado de la escala, cuya escala, toma, á su vez, el nombre de la nota que en ella sea tónica ó primer grado.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 459]

reswa.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan nalutur artinya, penatas irama atau penatas lampah, reswa namanya. Pukulan ini sama artinya dengan pukulan nugtug.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Nalutur is mastery of rhythm, the showing of light, or reswa; it is also attainment, or reaching a goal. It is also called nugtug.” Tenzer (2024) [III.4]

\u95773\u5ea6 ch\u014d 3 do.text: 長 + 3 + 度 do  長: major Japanese A: “Bbは、ただの準備の音です。しかし、 このDを生ませるために長3度が生じま す。長3度は明るい音程です。それで、 暗い音から明るい音になります。という ことは、少しずつ光が入ってくるという。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “The Bb is just a tone for preparation. But, in order to create D, a major third is created. A major third is a bright interval. So, a dark tone becomes a bright tone. It is like light is peeking through little by little.” Park (2024) [4.1]

Imitaciones.text: Spanish A: “Podrían incluirse, si acaso, en el campo de las metamorfosis, las imitaciones por movimiento contrario, pues éstas, aunque no alteran las relaciones de los intervalos, son, sin embargo, diferentes del tema que imitan.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] English A: “Imitations by contrary motion could perhaps be included within the domain of metamorphosis, because although they do not alter intervallic relationships, they nevertheless differ from the themes they imitate.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “La acción ó efecto de imitar, y en este sentido es el uso del mismo canto, ó canto semejante, en muchas partes que lo hacien oir una despues de otra á el Unison, á la Quinta, Cuarta, Tercera, ó á otro cualquier intervalo que sea.” Palatín (1990) [p. 70] Spanish C: “Acción de imitar y su efecto. –Frase melódica ó armónica que pasa alternativamente de un instrumento o2 de una voz á otra, valiéndose de procedimientos sugeridos por la fuga ó la música de estilo fugado––La imitación de lo real es uno de los elementos de lo que se puede llamar el placer estético y de aquí la escuela realista, según la cual el arte sólo sería la pintura de la realidad, la reproducción de las cosas tal cual son, una objetividad, lo exterior, lo particular porque no son música. No es digno de observación que la música no pueda servirse de la naturaleza más que usurpando de un modo ridiculo en los dominios de la pintura?––Imitación vale lo mismo que Réplica.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 227]

Zhongguo gudian (1991).text: Zhongguo gudian wenyi shiyong cidian 中国古典文艺实用辞典Yu Rujie 俞汝捷 (ed.). Beijing: Zhongguo qingnian chuban she 北京:中国青年出版社, 1991.

Fado.text: Portuguese A: “Rodney Gallop, no seu admirável estudo sobre o Fado (380, abril de 1933 p. 208 e 209) estudando a rítmica do Fado (que aliás considera melhor em 4/4) cita justo um caso de síncopa no primeiro tempo que é tipicamente uma habanera americana, ida naturalmente por intermédio do Brasil. E reconhece outras cantigas portuguesas no mesmo ritmo citadas por Fernandes Tomás (“Velhas Canções e Romances”) como originárias do Brasil negróide.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 23] English A: “Rodney Gallop, in his admirable study on Fado, studying the rhythm of Fado (which he actually considers better in 4/4), cites precisely a case of syncopation on the first beat, which is typically an American habanera, naturally brought through Brazil. And he recognizes other Portuguese songs in the same rhythm mentioned by Fernandes Tomás (“Velhas Canções e Romances”) as originating from black Brazil.” Menezes (2024) [1.10] Portuguese B: “Canção popular portuguesa, dançada ou não, acompanhada por violão e muito popular no Brasil durante o século passado. O fado c legitimamente português, embora as evidências indiquem uma origem brasileira. Segundo A. Pimentel, era desconhecido em Portugal nas primeiras décadas do século passado, só aparecendo na década de quaren-ta. Por outro lado, já se encontram registros sobre o fado, como uma das danças populares mais comuns no Brasil, a partir de 1822, o que levou Mário de Andrade a concluir que o fado tom origem brasilcira, e daqui foi levado para Portugal com a volta da família real aquele país. (DM-MA)” (Andrade (1989) 210–213) Portuguese C: “Forma musical portuguêsa, de origem colonial-brasileira, como evolução do lundu.

\u66f2\u8c03 q\u01d4di\u00e0o.text: Chinese A: “音乐术语。亦称“旋律”。指若干乐音的有组织进行。即在一定的调式和节拍的基础上,按一定的音高、时值和音量构成的具有逻辑因素和音乐意义的单声部进行。” Zhongguo qu xue (1997) (p. 677) Chinese B: “歌曲或戏曲的调子.” Hanyu dacidian (曲调, 2) English: Melody. ”In Chapter 3 of A General Treatise on Music, Li (1930/1933, 24–37) discussed four foundational elements of Music: Rhythmus (shengdiao 聲調), Takt (jiepai節拍), Harmonie (heyin和音), and Melodie (qudiao曲調 or yuediao樂調). Li’s understanding of these elements echoed his thoughts on Music as a language of the upper realm.” Li (2024) [Footnote 28]

\u0441\u043b\u043e\u0432\u0435\u043d\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “По стъпките (две кратки и една протегната) ръченицата прилича на чешкия народен танц полка. А по чупене на тялото (особени движения на ръцете, краката и приклякане) ръченицата прилича твърде много на руския казачок, на словенския танц хошие на маджарския чардаш.” Hristov (1925) (p. 48) English A: “In its steps (two short and one elongated), the rŭchenitsa resembles the Czech national dance, polka. But in twisting the body (especially the movements of the hands and feet and squatting) the rŭchenitsa very much resembles the Russian kazachok (fast 2/4 meter), the Slovenian dance hoshie (2/4) [Example 12], and the Hungarian csárdás.” Goldberg (2024) [5.18]

car\u00e1ter.text: English A: “In popular song, melody and lyrics closely influence each other. There are elements in the lyrics, especially their narrative or lyrical quality, that suggest different types of melody, and there are particularities in the melody, especially its melodic contour and the types of intervals used that define the character of the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Na canção popular melodia e letra interferem estreitamente uma sobre a outra. Existem elementos na letra, especialmente sua qualidade narrativa ou lírica que conduzem a diferentes tipos de melodia; existem particularidades na melodia, especialmente seu contorno melódico e tipos de intervalos empregados que marcam o caráter da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

text-setting.text: Source: “Qian Rong’s translation offers a new perspective to Western scholars on singing in tone languages because her article was not originally composed for an English-language audience, but addresses Mandarin text-setting for a Mandarin-speaking audience. Most English-language scholarship on text-setting in tone languages must introduce and explain the language and the music within the same text.” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [1] Definition: “The composition of vocal music to a given text. Music with one note per syllable is known as ‘syllabic setting’ and that with many notes per syllable as ‘melismatic setting’; text-setting in which new syllables are enunciated at regular intervals (regardless of the number of notes per syllable) is referred to as ‘isochronic’.” (King, Jonathan. "Text-setting." Grove Music Online. 2001)

\u88c5\u98fe\u97f3 s\u014dshokuan.text: 装飾 + 音 oto  装飾: ornament, decoration Japanese A: “この音 には装飾音が欠けています。しかし、三 連符の頭の休符がそれにかわる働きをし ます。それに続いてメリスマ的な要素が ありますね。これはもう少し発展した「ハ ウプト・トン」のあり方なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “There is no decorative tone for this. But the first rest of the triplet substitutes its role. It is followed by a melismatic element. This is a more developed figure of a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “装飾: 音楽における装飾は、旋または和音に色彩豊かな装いをほどこし、飾る働きをもつ。しかし実際には、洋の東西を問わずどの時代の音楽にも装飾が認められるように、装筋はたんなる「飾り」という以上に音楽を構成する不可な要素であり、その作品の性格付けに深くかかわるものと考えられる。つまり装前は、律、和声、リスムをさまざまに強調し、特徴づけることを通して、「音楽の内容を明らかにするのに役立つ」（C.PE.バッハ).” (Tomosha (2002), 370)

\uc74c\uc0c9 eumsaek.text: Korean A: “그러므로 여기서 나는 羽調와 界面調에 나오는 構成音을 찾아보고, 또 旋律型(Melodic Pattern), 音程, 弄絃(音色) 等을 比較하여 伽倻琴散調에 있어서 羽調와 界面調의 特性을 밝히려 한다.” (Shin (2018) 248) English A: “In order to distinguish the qualities of Ujo and Gyemyeonjo in gayageum sanjo, I will thus search for the constituent notes that are present in both modes and compare the melodic pattern, pitch, and nonghyeon (i.e., timbre). (Kim (2024) [3.2] and Footnote 29: [The term “timbre” (음색) in parentheses is added by the original author.]”) Korean B: “평조길의 틀은 그 키(key)를 높이고 성음(음색)을 씩씩하게 하면 그 구성음의 성질이 우조와 같은 씩씩한 느낌을 갖게 된다.” Shin (2018) [p. 246] English B: “Pyeongjo-gil elevates its key and intensifies its seongeum (vocal timbre), giving the qualities of the constituent notes energetic feelings similar to those of Ujo (Baek 1996, 58).” Kim (2024) [3.25]

acentua\u00e7\u00f5es t\u00e9ticas.text: English A: “Both in these “melôs” and in the case of rap in Portuguese, two prosodic issues appear. First is the use in Portuguese of a metric typical of English, that is, of regularly spaced thetic accents, which contributes to a sensation of regular measures. And second, there is the issue of successive ruptures typical of rap, produced by scratches, which makes music more of a “rhythmic partnership” than an complete interconnection between lyrics and melody (see Rose 1997, 207–8).” (Stover (2024) [3.5]) Portuguese A: “Tanto nestas "melôs", quanto no caso do rap em português vão aparecer duas questões prosódicas: primeiro, a utilização no português de uma métrica própria do ingles, isto é, de acentuações téticas regularmente espaçadas, o que contribui para uma sensação de compassos regulares. Segundo, é a questão das rupturas sucessivas próprias do rap, produzidas pelos "scratchs", o que faz da música mais uma "parceria rítmica" do que um todo interligado de letra e melodia (vide Rose 1997: 207-8).” (Ulhôa (1999))

metrical anchor.text: Source: “This, in Oddekalv’s words, leads the listener to anticipate a so-called metrical anchor: “a metrically defining event with which to make sense of it all” (184). ” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [2])

\u30e8\u30fc\u30ed\u30c3\u30d1\u306e\u8a.text: ヨーロッパ Yōroppa: Europe/European 調性 chōsei: tonal/tonality 音楽 ongaku: music Japanese A: “これはヨーロッパの調性音楽が、次第に従来の長・短調組織からぬけだして、自由な音語を使うようになってから、もっともひろい意味での調性の中心になる音という意味に使われていたものを、伝統音楽のばあいに適用したものと解することができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “It is understood that Mr. Itō applied the word “central tone” as something commonly used in Japanese traditional music, in the same way European [tonal] music used it in a free pitch language after it gradually began to pull away from its original major- and minor-key organization of tonal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4, brackets added separately]

Li (2024).text: Li, Edwin K. C. 2024. “Music as Language of the Upper Realm: Li Tsing-chu’s A General Treatise on Music (1930/1933).” Music Theory Online, forthcoming.

ultrachromaticism.text: Source: “Hába was writing microtonal music by 1918 at the latest, but set down his thoughts in a systematic way in Czech several years later (Hába 1922), expanding them in the definitive Neue Harmonielehre des diatonischen, chromatischen, Viertel-, Drittel-, Sechstel- und Zwölftel-Tonsystems (1927). Wyschnegradsky’s own writings on quarter- tone music and what he called “infra-” and “ultrachromaticism” followed soon afterward.” Bauer commentary (2024) [3.1] Definition: “After writing La journée de l’existence (1916–17), for reciter, large orchestra and mixed chorus, he conceived a scheme for ‘ultrachromatic’ synthesis using intervals of one sixth and one twelfth of a tone, in addition to quarter-tones.” (Grove Music Online, “Vyschnegradsky [Vïshnegradsky], Ivan (Aleksandrovich)”)

\u97d3\u56fd\u306e\u4f1d\u7d71\u697d\u56.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

\ud615\uc774\uc0c1\ud559\uc801 hyeongisa.text: Korean A: “윤형이상학적인 것은 아니지만 예컨대 「예악」은 아악의 요소를 갖고 있습니다. 한국에서도 그렇고 일본에서도 그렇지만 아악은 거의 인간세계를 초월한 세계를 표현합니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 159] English A: “It is not metaphysical, per se. For example, Reak contains elements from A-ak. It is the case in both Korea and Japan that A-ak largely expresses the world mostly beyond the human realm for me.” Park (2024) [5.2]

\u4e50 yu\u00e8.text: Chinese A: “亦泛指音乐舞蹈.” Hanyu dacidian  (乐, 2). See also, 乐 “lè.” Chinese B: “《礼记·乐记》：“乐者，音之所由生也。” Gudai hanyu (2007) (乐) English: “Yue is that which carries virtue -- it may do so through the simplicity of the harmony, the sincerity of the lyrics employed in song, or the correctness of the movements of the dancers -- but above all, yue is a higher stage than yin by virtue of the fact that it carries the message of virtue.” Cook (1995)  “In all cases, the arising of music (yin) is born in the hearts of men. The movement of men's hearts is made so by (external] things. They are touched off by things and move, thus they take shape in [human] sound (sheng). Sounds respond to each other, and thus give birth to change. Change forms a pattern, and this is called music (yin). The music is brought close and found enjoyable, and reaches the point of shields and axes, feathers and pennants, and this is called Music (yue).” Cook (1995) (1.1) (See: 声 shēng, 音 yīn) For further discussion, see Li (2024) [2.7]

hegemony.text: Source: “We can go a step further. Japan, like most countries in the Global South colonized by Europeans, accepted European cultural hegemony.” (Shumays commentary (2024) [4.3]) Definition: “Social or cultural predominance or ascendancy; predominance by one group within a society or milieu, or by a particular set of social or cultural ideas, way of doing things, or item, esp. to the exclusion of others. In Marxist theory (esp. that of Gramsci): a dominant ideology which imposes or reinforces (through conditioned consent) a certain social order.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “hegemony”)

proemin\u00eancia \u00e0 direita.text:
proeminência + direita proeminência: prominence direita: right-hand 
 English A: “In Western music, a phrase is said to be anacrustic when it begins before and ends after the first beat of the measure. For each anacrustic beginning we have an equivalent unstressed or “feminine” ending. Linguists call this anacrustic sensation “right-hand prominence,” in reference to the direction of accentuation in each phrase (Ester Scarpa, personal communication).” (Stover (2024) [3.2]) Portuguese B: “Na música ocidental se diz que uma frase é anacrústica quando começa antes e termina depois do primeiro tempo do compasso. Para cada início anacrústico temos uma terminação átona ou "feminina" equivalente. Os lingüistas chamam esta sensação anacrústica de "proeminência à direita", numa referência à direção da acentuação em cada frase (Ester Scarpa, comunicação pessoal).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc624\ud398\ub77c opera.text: Korean A: “니시무라 선생님께서 옥중에서 쓰신 오페라 말씀입니다만, 선생 님은 건강도 상했고, 오페라 자체는 연주될 전망조차 없었으며, 그 작품 자체를 옥중에서 밖으로 내보낼 수 있을지 없을지 모르는 그런 속에서 어떻게 의식을 초월해서 단숨에 쓰시게 되었는지요?” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 160] English A: “Regarding the opera you had composed while in prison [Die Witwe des Schmetterlings (Butterfly Widow)], at the time, you were in poor health, there was no perspective for its performance, and you weren’t even sure whether you could transport the score outside of the prison cell. How were you able to overcome senses [意識] and compose in these circumstances with one stroke?” Park (2024) [6.1] Korean B: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English B: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

Teixidor (2009).text: Teixidor, José. Tratado fundamental de la Música (1804c). Edited by Josep Pavía i Simó. Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas, 2009.

\u6b63\u78ba\u306a\u30d4\u30c3\u30c1 sei.text: 正確: accurate, correct, precise, exact + ピッチ: pitch Japanese A: “江戸時代以後の音楽は一般に楽器（ことに三味線・箏・尺八）の影響によって、声楽であっても、比較的正確なピッチをもっているので、この核音のあり方を譜面の上でとらえることができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “Music from after the Edo period [1603 – 1867 CE] generally has influence from instrumental music (especially that of the shamisen, koto, or shakuhachi), and so even the vocal music has comparatively precise pitches, so one can determine the nuclear tones on its sheet music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.1]

bolero.text: Portuguese A: ““Notam-se em alguns fonogramas movimentos sincopados bem claros.” Tais são os de números 14594 e 14595, onde se encontra, pronunciadamente o tempo de bolero em 3/8. Roq. Pinto, Rondonia, 89.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 76] English A: ““Clear syncopated movements can be noticed in some phonograms.” Such are those of numbers 14594 and 14595, where the bolero rhythm in 3/8 is distinctly found. Roq. Pinto, Rondônia, 89.” Menezes (2024) [1.20] Portuguese B: “Dança da Andaluzia (Espanha) que deu origem, em Cuba, a canto acompanhado de instrumento. Sanchez de Fuentes observa que já em 1810 o bolero era conhecido em Cuba, ainda em compasso ternário c preferencialmente no modo menor. Após um período de esquecimento, foi retomado e escrito também em dois-por-quatro caracterizando-se como gêncro cubano: canto em três partes, sendo a primeira delas uma introdução instrumental da guitarra, podendo ser, a terceira destas partes, no modo maior. O acompanhamento da guitarra se dá geralmente por meio de rasgucios cujo ritmo o autor exemplifica Ja saTaL/Ta (El folk-lor en la musica cubana, 1923, p. 79). (DM-MA)Dançou-se o bolero nos teatros do Rio de Janciro no Império: "O balé satis-fazia, os dançarinos são em sua maioria franceses, embora tanto eles quanto as dançarinas procurem fazer mais trejeitos do que propriamente arte; quanto mais sensual é a dança, maior é o aplauso, pois, já que o bolero e o fandango não satisfazem mais a massa, então são levados ao palco as danças imorais dos negros." (Weech, J. Reise ucber England, v. 1, 1831, p. 353).(MA)” (Andrade (1989), 67) Portuguese C: “Dança espanhola, provavelmente inventada pelo célebre dançarino de Cádiz Sebastião Cerezo, cêrca de1780. Sua música é em tempo ternário masderado, acompanhada por castanhi-da mistura do espanhol e do negro. Sua música é em tempo binário, em dois por quatro.” (Cosme (1957) 19)

grupetos.text: English A: “The emphasis on the melody is so striking that all the notes that compose it are essential to the song’s identity, including those that would be considered surface-level ornaments in the European classical-romantic music that has so influenced popular Brazilian music. What could be considered superfluous for melodic evaluation, such as notes that are foreign to the basic harmonic structure of the song (grupetos, mordants, appoggiaturas) have a functional importance in popular Brazilian song.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “A ênfase na melodia é tão marcante que todas as notas que a compõem são essenciais para a identidade da canção, incluindo aquelas que seria consideradas ornamentos superficiais na música clássico-romântica européia que tanto influenciou a música brasileira popular. O que poderia ser considerado supérfluo para a avaliação melódica, como notas extranhas à estrutura harmônica básica na canção (grupetos, mordentes, appoggiaturas) têm uma importância funcional na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “In “Canção da América,” the words expand by leaps with or without portamento, melisma, tremolo, the most diverse appoggiaturas, mordents and grupetos, highlighting the emotional content of the song: the heart cries for escape—the feeling trapped in the chest—and to reestablish the bonds of friendship you have to listen to your heart, no matter what happens. (Carvalho 1990, 325–30).” (Stover (2024) [5.7]) Portuguese B: “Em "Canção da América" as palavras expandidas por saltos com ou sem portamento, melisma, tremolo, appoggiaturas as mais diversas, mordentes e grupetos, realçam o conteúdo emocional da canção: o coração chora pela partida - o sentimento preso no peito - e para reestabelecer os laços de amizade tem-se que ouvir o coração, não importa o que aconteça. (p. 325-10).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese C: “Do italiano gruppetto, plural gruppetti, ornamento musical formado por uma dupla apojatura superior ou inferior, contornando a nota principal. "Visava só ao cícito vocal, fazendo de todas ocasiões c situações dramáticas pretexto para interminável sucessão ou antes dedução de volatas, fiotiture, gruppetti e trinados encadeados." (Taunay, A. d'-Escragnolle, Uma grande glória brasileira..., 1930, p. 29). (DM-MA)” (Andrade (1989), 246) Portuguese D: “Três ou mais notas, em caracteres menores, sempre em graus conjuntos, que se associam a certas notas reais.” (Cosme (1957) 56)

\uc694\uc131 yoseong.text: English A: “Yoseong 요성 and toeseong 퇴성 are subcategories of sigimsae. Yoseong denotes a vibrating or wavering sound, comparable to the Western musical technique of vibrato but executed in a uniquely Korean style. Toeseong denotes a technique wherein the pitch descends towards the end of a note, thereby enhancing the expressiveness of the performance.” (Kim (2024) [0.4]) Korean B: “판소리에서 평조라는 것은 기본 선율들이 Sol-do-re-do와 같은 경우가 많으므로 기본 선율형에서 이 들의 구성음이 Sol, La, do, re, mi(fa)로 되었고, 종자음 do가 '청'이라 이르므로 이것이 중심음으로 인식되며, 구성음 가운데 Sol, do, re가 출현빈도가 많은 중요음이 되고, Sol에서 떠는목(요성)을 쓰고, re에서 흘러내리는목(퇴성)을 쓰는 시김새로 된 토리로 보고자 하는 것이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 244] English B: “Lee covers note sets and cadence notes (i.e., the functions of each tone), frequency of occurrence (i.e., weight of each note and main melodic structures), and sigimsae (e.g., yoseong and toeseong) in explaining Ujo and Pyeongjo. Lee’s explanation is related to his theory of tori; he lists four components as criteria for distinguishing the tori of folk songs, constituent note set, each constituent note’s function, weight, and sigimsae (Lee 2000, 521–25).” Kim (2024) [3.19] English C: 1. a kind of sigimsae 2. vibrating sound (Pyǒn (2012) 172)Korean C: 흔들어서 내는 소리 요롱, 농현 (Pyǒn (2012) 172)

n\u2019\u1ecdbara.text: Igbo A: “Onye na akpọ ụbọ, Ụmụ ihe nịịle a na dịkwanụ n’ọbara. Onye na akpọ ụbọ mụta nwa, Ndụ o biri, Ka o si che echiche, Ka o si meso mmadụ omume, Udị ọru ọ nọ na-arụ, Udị egwu ọ nọ na-ege, Ọ ya aba nwa ya n’ọbara. Ọ ihe a na-akpọ DNA.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “A person who plays the ubo, things like this are mostly in the bloodline. Once a person who plays the ubo has a child, the life he lived, how he thinks, how he treats his fellow human beings, the kind of work he does, the kind of music he listens to, will be in that child’s blood. That is what is called DNA.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

equal temperament.text: Source: “On a central, one-line staff, Carrillo placed all pitches belonging to the register of Middle C, and above and below that staff, in relation to two small ledger lines, he placed pitches of other registers. By using this notation, Carrillo could flexibly accommodate any of the equal temperaments in his arsenal.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.6] Definition: “A tuning of the scale based on a cycle of 12 identical 5ths and with the octave divided into 12 equal semitones, and consequently with 3rds and 6ths tempered, uniformly, much more than 5ths and 4ths (see Temperaments §1). Equal temperament is now widely regarded as the normal tuning of the Western, 12-note chromatic scale.” (Grove Music Online, “equal temperament”)

linha.text: English A: “Melody is generally associated with the human voice; we think of it in terms of the continuous sound of singing. Singing, in turn, uses verbal language, whose minimum components are vowels and consonants. A song made only with vowels intoned in a continuous melodic line produces a melody in its closest state to human expression.” (Stover (2024) [2.3]) Portuguese A: “A melodia está geralmente associada à voz humana, pensamos nela em termos do som contínuo do canto. O canto por sua vez utiliza a linguagem verbal, cujos componentes mínimos são as vogais e consoantes. Um canto feito somente com vogais, entoadas numa linha melódica contínua produz uma melodia no seu estado mais próximo da sensibilidade humana.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “O mesmo que verso ou pé.” (Andrade (1989), 286)

\uc0dd\uba85\ub825 saengmyeongnyeok.text: Korean A: “달리면서 이번에는 생명력을, 긴장력을 높이기 위해서 비브라토를 만들어냅니다. 비브 라토에 의해서 집중력과 긴장감을 증가시키지요. 그리고 장식용적인 요소가 추가됩니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “As it runs, it creates vibratos in order to heighten its lifeforce and tension. Through vibrato, the concentration and tension are increased. And melismatic elements are added.” [4.1]

la-minor.text: Source: “The song utilizes a minor scale, emphasizing a droning pitch of la, the first note of the scale. In Nigeria, la-minor is commonly known (not do-minor).” Carter-Ényì (2024) [4.1]

semar pagulingan.text: English A: “Geria’s examples all apply to the trompong, an instrument forefronted in prestigious court gamelan—the palegongan, semar pagulingan, and the gong gdé. I show both the kepatihan (cipher notation) provided and my own modified 3-line staff for the trompong and, when needed, a single-line staff for jegogan. Geria notated his examples on particular pitches in a five-tone pélog, conventionally numbered 1,2,3,5, and 6. But they could be played at any transposition.” Tenzer (2024)  [3.1] English B: “The technique of playing trompong in gamelan semar pagulingan [a court ensemble playing a delicate and refined repertoire] is called iber-iberan. The names of the ways to play it are the same as those for number 1 above.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.2]) Balinese/Indonesian B: “Pukulan trompong semar pagulingan, iber-iberan namanya. Banyak jenisnya sama dengan nomor 1 (satu) di atas.” (Geria (n.d.)) Balinese C: “Catur ngaran patpat, muni-muni ngaran gagambelan. Nyata gagambelan Smar Pagulingan ngaran Smara Aturu, gendingnya Pagambuhan maka gagambelan Barong Singa, Gagambelan Smar Patangian ngaran Smara Awungu, gendingnya pasesen-donan maka gagambelan Legong Keraton. Gambelan Smar Palinggyan ngaran Smara Alungguh, gendingnya maka gagam-belan Joged Papingitan. Gambelan Smar Pandirian ngaranSmara Ngadeg gendingnya Pakakintungan maka gagambelan Barong Ket.” (Bandem (1986), 80) Balinese D: “Nihan babarungan gagambelan kang manut tatanya. Yan Smar Pagulingan, ndyata : kempul sanunggal sawurnya paketutan nding, kempyung satungguh swaranya dong-deng, kajar sa-nunggal, suling ageng roro, suling babarangan roro, terompong babarangan sanunggal, curing pangageng sapasang, jublag sa-pasang, panyacah sapasang, gangsa ageng sapasang, gangsa manengah sapasang, sama ngumbang ngisep, gumanak tatiga, kangsi satungguh, ricik alit kalih tungguh, ricik manengah satungguh; jangkep kayeki.” (Bandem (1986), 82) English D (Chat-GPT): “The following describes the instrumentation in different types of Gamelan ensembles, according to their distinct musical functions and tonal characteristics. The Smara Pagulingan gamelan is characterized by its elegance and melodic fluidity, often used in refined settings. It consists of: Thus, this ensemble is considered complete (jangkep).”  Balinese D: “gamelan gong yg berfungsi untuk mengiringi raja- raja sewaktu di peraduan zaman dulu, mengiringi tari leko, tari gandrung, instrumennya terdiri atas trompong, gender, gangsa, jublag, calung, kempur, kajar, kelenang, dan suling” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 170, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\uc6b0\uc870 Ujo.text: English A: “A typical example of this is the conflicting and overlapping definitions provided by gugak (the national music of Korea) scholars of the modes: Ujo is described as a pentatonic scale comprised of a-c-d-e-g with little vibrato or glissando (Lee and Lee 2007, 134);(6) Pyeongjo is defined as a pentatonic scale of g-a-c-d-f but with vibrato or ornamentation causing the f to fall to or be pitched closer to e (Lee and Lee 2007, 134).” (Kim (2024) [0.2]) Korean B: “한국음악학에서 판소리 악조에 대한 논의는 오랜 기간 여러 학자들에 의해 시도되었다. 그러 나 여전히 공통의 합의가 이루어지지 못하고, 여러 다른 악조론으로 음악을 분석하고 있다. 그 중 가장 대표적인 판소리 악조론은 백대웅과 이보형의 이론으로, 계면조에 대해서는 이견이 없 으나, 이들의 서로 다른 우조와 평조에 대한 해석이 후속 학자들에 의해 활용되고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 234] English B: “Although Korean musicologists have long debated the melodic modes in pansori, there is a lack of consensus regarding the identification of the pansori modes, which they have attempted to define based on different modal theories. The theories of Baek Daewoong (1974–2011) and Lee Bohyeong (b. 1937) are the representative views of pansori scales. While Baek and Lee concur on the criteria for Gyemyeonjo, they diverge on the modes for Ujo and Pyeongjo.” Kim (2024) [1.1] Korean C: “① 중국 5조 중의 다섯째 선법명(旋法名), 「율려신서』(律呂新書)의 60조에 의하면, 12율을 옮겨가며 한 번씩 중심음으로 삼아 우선법(羽旋法)을 만들기 때문에 60조에서 우조(羽調) 곧 우선법은 열두 번 나온다. 종묘제향의 종현(終獻)에는 정대업지악(定大 業之樂)을 연주한다. 정대업지악의 악조(樂調)는 황종청궁(黃鍾清宮) 계면조(界面調) 즉 중국 5조의 우조이다. 계면조는 5조 중의 우조이다.” Song (2010) [p. 251] Korean D:  English D:

Tonos enteros.text: Spanish A:  “La llamada escala cromática, y que en su forma clásica procede por semitonos, en su metamorfosis al duplo quedará por tonos enteros.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22-23] English A: “The so-called chromatic scale, which in its classical form proceeds by semitones, proceeds by whole tones under its metamorphosis to the double.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22-23]

metric cycle.text: Source: “In a passage highlighted by Andrade, Horbostel is analyzing the rhythmic structure of a recording of Fang (Pangwe) music from Central Africa, for xylophone and chorus. Recognizing a constant metric cycle of twelve time units, he expresses uncertainty about the possibility of gathering these units into a time signature formula and grouping them between bars.” Menezes (2024) [1.15]

Movimiento contrario.text: Spanish A: “Podrían incluirse, si acaso, en el campo de las metamorfosis, las imitaciones por movimiento contrario, pues éstas, aunque no alteran las relaciones de los intervalos, son, sin embargo, diferentes del tema que imitan.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] English A: “Imitations by contrary motion could perhaps be included within the domain of metamorphosis, because although they do not alter intervallic relationships, they nevertheless differ from the themes they imitate.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “El que hacen las parates armónicas ascendiendo mientras otras descienden ó viceversa.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 295]

Duplo.text: Spanish A: “Las metamorfosis presentadas en las escalas que anteceden son todas al duplo, lo que significa que donde hay un intervalo de tono se escribirán dos tonos; que donde hay uno y medio se escribirán tres, y que donde hay dos se escribirán cuatro, que donde hay un semitono se escribirá un tono, etc..”Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22] English A: “The metamorphoses presented in the previous scales are all doublings, which means that where there is an interval of a whole tone, two whole tones are written; where there are three semitones, three whole tones are written; where there are two whole tones, four whole tones are written; where there is one semitone, one whole tone is written; etc.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22]

\u043d\u0430\u0446\u0438\u044f/natsiya.text: Bulgarian A: “Българската музика — това трябва да се отбележи — е запазена в една чиста, непокварена, примитивна форма - обстоятелство, което се дължи на простата случайност, дето България се е намирала далеч от съседството на някоя културна нация.” Hristov (1925) (p. 34) English A: “This is due to the inherent capacity of each nation to preserve everything that hands cannot destroy. Bulgarian music—this must be noted—is preserved in a pure, uncorrupted, primitive form—a circumstance that is due to the pure chance that Bulgaria was located far from any cultured nation.” Goldberg (2024) [2.4]

\u9670 kage.text: Japanese A: “「ハウプト・トン」は二つあるときも多いのです。二つあれば、それは陰陽関 係を持ちます。たとえば、動と静の関係 であったりします。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1]

tone levels.text: Source: “While the underlying connection between the tuning of the ubọ-aka and the Igbo speech tones is not discussed, probably because of space constraints, it would be a great subject for further exploration. As the Igbo language has three tone levels (Liberman et al. 1992), would be it possible that the intervals among the three tone levels in some way shape the musical intervals among the pitches of the ubọ-aka, similar to the tone-melody relationship in Cantonese vocal music?” Chow commentary (2024) [3]

\u97f5/\u97fb y\u00f9n.text: Chinese A: 和谐的声音. Hanyu dacidian  (韻, 1) Chinese B: 气韵；神韵. Hanyu dacidian  (韻, 7) Chinese C: “美丽,标致。张元干《点绛唇》:“韵底人人,天与多磨折。休分说、放灯时节,闲了花和月。”(2-1090)辛弃疾《小重山·茉莉》:“越惜越娇痴。一枝云鬓上,那人宜。莫将他去比荼䕷,分明是、他更韵些儿。”(3—1884)无名氏《玉交枝·蜡梅》:“蕙子兰孙小样儿,化工簇就寄南枝。笑他兰蕙,虽韵带轻肥。”(5-3638)” Tang songci (1990) p. 255 Chinese D: “诗歌特定位置上的相应复现的语音序列。主要在诗行末尾,故称脚韵或韵脚。韵具有两种重要作用: 1,韵是语音的复现,因此是美感满足的源泉。语音本身和语音的巧合使读者得到乐趣,与这种乐趣相联系的是音乐感,是节奏与拍节——人类所共有的脉搏律动感。[...] ; 2,韵是诗歌实际结构的重要因素,它自然地标志着意思的开始和终结,以此帮助组织诗歌。因此,韵是强化意义、“穿连”诗歌的韵律手段。头韵和腹韵的韵律效果特别明显。韵的使用使诗歌便于记忆。” Waiguo wenxue (1990) p. 268 English: Charm (see 乡韵 xiāngyùn )

\u043c\u044a\u0436\u043a\u0430 \u0440\u0.text: Bulgarian A: “Вторият вид 7/16 такт се образува от втори вид 5/16 с прибавка в края на още една кратка част и служи за основа на обикновено хоро, което се играе във всички краища на България. В Македония е основата на македонското хоро. При песни със същия такт в Еленско играят хоро "еленско хоро", в Добруджа — мъжка ръценица и пр.” Hristov (1925) [p. 47] English A: “The second type of 7/16 meter is formed from the second type of 5/16 with the addition of one more short part at the end; this meter also serves as the basis of an ordinary horo that is danced in all regions of Bulgaria. In Macedonia it is the basis for makedonsko horo. In songs with the same meter in the Elena region they dance the horo called “elensko horo,” in Dobrudzha—mŭzhka rŭchenitsa, etc.” Goldberg (2024) [5.14] See: ръченица/rŭchenitsa

nhazia.text: Igbo A: “ I ya-anụ ihe, I nụ ka ọ si hazi ya, M kpọ egwu ya, kpọtaya, M wee kpọzie nhazia, Site na, nke mbụ, igwe nke mbụ, ruo n’igwe nke ikpeazu.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “You would hear something, how he tunes it (ubọ-aka). When I play his music, and play it well, I will now play the scale, from the first, the first prong, to the last prong.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

\u8ee2\u8abf tench\u014d.text: 転+調 chō  転: revolve, turn around, change Japanese A: “その際の核音は、e（１０小節）－h（２）―e（３）―h（５）―e（２）―h（４）―e（３）―h（２）―転調fis（５）―e（２）以下同様。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 4] English A: “In this case, the nuclear tones would be E (for 10 measures) – B (2) – E (3) – B (5) – E (2) – B (4) – E (3) – B (2) – modulation, F♯ (5) – E (2), and it continues afterward in the same way.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.2] Japanese B: “曲 の 途 中 で 、 る 調 （ 先 ⾏ 調 ） か ら 別 の 調 （ 後 続 調 ） に 調 が 変 わ る こ と 。 も っ と も ⼀ 般 的 で 単 純 な 転 調 は * 近 親 調 （ 属 調 ， 下 属 調 、 平 ⾏ 調 な ど ） へ の 転 調 の か た ち を と る 。 転 調 に さ い し て は 、 先 ⾏ 調と 後 続 調 の 両 者 に 共 有 さ れ る 和 ⾳ が 仲 介 ・ 橋 渡し の 役 割 を は た す こ と が 多 い 。 こ の 仲 介 の 和 が 、 両 ⽅ の 調 の あ い だ に あ っ て 、 役 割 の 読 み 替 え （ 転 義 ） の 対 象 と な る 。 役 割 を 読 み 替 え ら る 和 ⾳ は 、 両 ⽅ の 調 の そ れ ぞ れ に 固 有 の 和 ⾳  であ る 場 合 も あ る （ 全 ⾳ 階 的 転 調 ） 。 ま た 、 前 後い ず れ か の 調 に と っ て 半 ⾳ 階 的 変 化 ⾳ を 含 む 和 ⾳ で あ る 場 合 も あ る （ 半 ⾳ 階 的 転 調 ） 。 さ ら に* 異 名 同 ⾳ 的 転 換 に よ る 読 み 替 え が お こ な わ れ る 場 合 も あ る （ 異 名 同 ⾳ 的 転 調 ).” (Tomosha (2002), 441)

\u7dda\u7684 sen-teki.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 、 先 ⽣ の 作 品 の 線 的 な 語 法 の も と に な っ て い る わ け で す ね 。 微 分 ⾳ 的 な 細 か い 揺 れ か ら 3 度 以 上 の シ ェ イ ク に ⾄ る よ う な 、 独 特 な 線 の 動 き は 、 韓 国 の 歌 唱 の ⽅ 法 か ら ⽣ み 出 さ れ た も の と 考 え て い い わ け で す ね .” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

babaru.text: English: “Geria likely meant babaru to mean a whiplike inner force or strength. This is doubly apt. Here the boxed motive recurs transposed up a step, then inverts (dotted box) to return to the starting point. In one sense the pattern conveys a directed kinetic motion Balinese call majalan, and always fits with gending whose goal tones change for every iteration of the pattern (moving 5-6-5 3 in the example). It conveys energetic motion and is often played at fast tempi.” Tenzer (2024) [4.12] *Lexical field: Emotions or character, Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\uc7a53\ub3c4 jang3do.text:
장 + 3 + 도 do  장: major 
 Korean A: “Bb은 단지 준비의 음입니다. 그러나 D를 만들어내기 위해서는 장3도가 생겨납니다. 장3도는 밝은 음정이지요. 그래서 어두운 음으 로부터 밝은 음이 됩니다. 그건 조금씩 빛이 비쳐드는 것이지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “The Bb is just a tone for preparation. But, in order to create D, a major third is created. A major third is a bright interval. So, a dark tone becomes a bright tone. It is like light is peeking through little by little.” Park (2024) [4.1] Korean B: “백대웅이 설명하고 있는 우조길 각 음의 특징 중 가장 주목해야 할 음은 상청이다. 그는 상청에 대해 '우조길의 특징을 평조길과 구별하게 하는 음'이라고 제시하고 있으며, '본청과 장3 도의 음정관계라는 점이 큰 의미를 갖는다(평조길은 완전4도)'라고 설명한다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238] English B: “When examining the qualities of each note in Ujo-gil as Baek describes them, it is crucial to focus on the characteristics of sangcheong. Baek claims that the sangcheong “distinguishes Pyeongjo-gil from Ujo-gil” and that “it is crucial that the interval between boncheong and sangcheong is a major 3rd (a perfect 4th in the case of Pyeongjo-gil)” (Baek 1982, 1995, 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.4]

Biaoyan cidian (2005).text: Biaoyan cidian 表演辞典. Peng Wanrong 彭万荣 (ed.), Yang Xiaoyun 杨晓云and Wang Huating 王华庭 (co-eds.). Wuchang: Wuhan University Press 武昌:武汉大学出版社, 2005.

augmentation.text: Aumentación (Spanish) Source: “By referencing canonical composers such as Bach, Beethoven, and Wagner, Carrillo framed his musical laws as a continuation, and a radicalization, of techniques such as contrapuntal augmentation and diminution, which had suffused the musical works and theoretical treatises he most admired.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [3.7] Definition: “The term describes the restatement of a cantus firmus in note values longer than when it was first sounded in a composition, a device found, for example, in a number of motets of the late Middle Ages and many masses and motets of the Renaissance.” (Grove Music Online, “augmentation (ii)”)

acentos brasileiros.text: English A: “Beginning with a strophic text, a melody is created with “Brazilian accents,” identified by Andrade as “syncopated anticipation, passing from one measure to another, with cadential movements” (Andrade 1944, 27).” (Stover (2024) [4.6]) Portuguese A: “Para um texto estrófico é criada uma melodia com "acentos brasileiros", identificados por Mário como "antecipação sincopada, passando dum compasso para outro, em movimentos cadenciais" (p. 27).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u6b4c\u62ab\u8b1b uta-hik\u014d.text: Japanese A: “しかし、事実はもっと複雑であって、一方では次節にのべるような比較音楽学的な考察から、また他方では、雅楽輸入以前に起源を持ち、しかも現在多少とも面影をとどめていると考えられる、神楽歌や歌披講などの旋律にも明らかに核音の機能が認められるという事実から、声明にだけこの傾向の原因をもとめるわけにはゆかない.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 13] English A: “On the one hand, from the perspective of comparative-musicological investigations that I will discuss in the next section; and also on the other hand from the fact that the function of nuclear tones is clearly recognized even in the melodies of kagura song and uta-hikō, which hold origins from before the importation of gagaku and furthermore are thought to retain a trace of these functioning nuclear tones in the present; we cannot go so far as to say that this is a tendency that seeks its origins only in vocal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [8.2] English B: “Uta-hikō 歌披講 is unaccompanied melodic recitation of Japanese poetry, which survives in the utakai hajime 歌会始め event, where new poems are presented to and by the imperial family on New Year’s Day. Uta-hikō is, however, though to have started in the Heian period, and so Koizumi may not be correct to place it before the importation of gagaku. On the other hand, it still may well preserve an older singing style, or at least be descended from one.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [Footnote 16] Japanese B: “和歌を朗詠する作法、平安時代中期の書*和漢朗 詠集(藤原公任著)*新撰朗詠集(藤原基俊著)を見ると漢詩も和歌 も同じく朗詠されていたらしい。しかるに康平三年 (1060)藤原長家 が和歌行事の宗家を称してから和歌披講の作法を確立してこれを漢詩 の朗詠から引き離した […] 今日では綾小路流は主として宮中の歌御会に用いられ、冷泉流は民間に行 われる、いずれも読師,講師,発声記,講頌によって施行 され、旋律には甲調と乙調の二種あるが、綾小路流ではこの他に甲 調を五度高く唱う上甲調があり、冷泉流では高さによって甲の 甲、甲の乙、乙の甲、乙の乙の四種に区別されている。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 16-17]

iche.text: English A: “This is why they have adapted the ubọ-aka to be for the Igbo/If you observe, you will see the uniqueness.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Ọ bụ ya ka ha jiri were ụbọaka, ọ bụlụ nke Igbo. Ị nekwa ya anya, ifu ihe dị iche.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo B: “gosi ife dị iche iche, ife dị iche na fa nabo n’asụsụ Igbo.” (Laz Ekwueme Interview Part 2, 1:27) English B: “shows the differences, The difference between the two of them in Igbo language” (Laz Ekwueme Interview Part 2, 1:27)

\u65cb\u5f8b\u7dda senritsusen.text: 旋律 senritsu +線 線: line, stripe, stria Japanese A: “このようなばあい、終止音は一方からは単に楽曲の終止音としての意味ばかりでなく、旋律線の上下動における中核的な意味を持つという理由で、他方では、連続的にくり返されるべき性質の「数え唄」や「網引唄」の中には、かならずしも終止音に終らない旋律も多いという理由で（そのばあいですら旋律線の中核的意味を失わない）、終止音とよぶより中核音または単に核音とよぶ方が適当ではないだろうか。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “In cases like these, the ending note on the one hand holds meaning not only as a simple ending note to the piece, but also holds meaning as a central nucleus of upward and downward movement in the melodic line. On the other hand, among songs like “Counting Song” and “Net-Pulling Song” whose melodies tend to be repeated continuously, there are many songs with melodies that certainly do not end on the ending note (even in those cases, the ending notes do not lose the meaning of a central nucleus of the melodic line). For that reason, rather than calling them ending notes, it may be more appropriate to call them central nuclear tones or simply nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1]

\ubbfc\uc694 minyo.text: Korean A: “또한, 판소리의 평조는 민요의 남부경토리(성주풀이토리)와 동일하고, 가야금산조의 평조와 연결되되, 함동정월류 가야금산조의 석화제 대목이 평조에 해당하며, 현행 가곡과 비교하면 가곡의 계면조가 평조와 통한다고 하였다.” Shin (2018) [p. 243] English A: “Further, Pyeongjo in pansori is equivalent to Nambugyeong-tori (Seongjupuri-tori) in folk songs, connected to Pyeongjo in gayageum sanjo such as Seokhwajje 석화제 scenes of Ham-Dongjeongweol ryu 류 [school] gayageum sanjo, and corresponds to Gyemyeonjo in contemporary gagok.” Kim (2024) [3.8] English B: folk song (Pyǒn (2012) 114)Korean B: 특정한 작사자나 작곡자가 없이 민중들 사이에서 저절로 생겨 나서 전해지는 노래. 민중들의 사상, 생활, 감정을 담고 있으며 전파 정도와 세련도에 따라 토속 민요와 통속민요로 구분한다. 경기민요, 남도민요, 동부민요, 서도민요, 제주민요 등이 있다. (Pyǒn (2012) 114)

d\u00e4kkiya.text: English A: “Taking the five instruments– dawula drum (double headed cylindrical drum), other drums, horanǟwa (small quadruple-reed shawm), nāgasinnam (larger shawm),and däkkiya drum (hour-glass shaped variable tension drum)” (Peiris (2024) [6.6]) Sinhalese A: “dawul bhēri horanǟ nāsinnam däkki mepasa gattayi – räňgu” (Peiris (2024) [6.6]) English B: “type of drum” (Peiris (2025))

\u1ee5t\u1ecd.text: Igbo A: “ Egwu mụ ete aka, nwee nkeji dị iche iche. Doo anya, tọ ụtọ.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “My songs become longer, and have different sections, become clearer and sweet.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

\ub3d9\uc591\uc758 \uc804\ud1b5\uc74c Do.text:
동양의 + 전통 + 음 eum  동양의: Eastern (East Asian), Oriental 전통: tradition, heritage 
 Korean A: “동양의 전통음악에 이의 원형이 있어요. 항상 그 모델은 상대성을 갖고 있어서 하나의 요소가 늘 중심이 된다. 원칙적으로는 이렇게 되는 거지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “East Asian traditional music has its original model. One element always becomes the center because this model always possesses relativity. This is how it goes, at least in principle.” Park (2024) [4.1]

Stover commentary (2024).text: Full Reference in Chicago (Example below): Li, Edwin K. C. 2024. “Music as Language of the Upper Realm: Li Tsing-chu’s A General Treatise on Music (1930/1933).” Music Theory Online, forthcoming.

Chetrikov (1979).text: Chetrikov, Svetoslav/СВЕТОСЛАВ ЧЕТРИКОВ. 1979. Muzikalen Terminologichen Rechnik/Музикален терминологичен речник. “Muzika” Publishing House Sofia/ИЗДАТЕЛСТВО „МУЗИКА" СОФИЯ.

n\u2019obodo.text: Igbo A: “Bịa mụta ụbọ, Bịa mụta ọja, Bịa mụta ufie. Ọ ị nọlụ n’obodo, Ị na-amụta ya.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “ Come and learn the ụbọ, Come and learn the ọja, Come and learn the ufie. The point is, when you are in the community, you learn.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

adiantados.text: English A: “These metric spaces are very difficult to illustrate with conventional Western notation. Ethnomusicologists have created signs to express these “early” or “late” attacks.“ (Stover (2024) [5.5]) Portuguese A: “Estes espaços métricos são muito difíceis de demonstrar com a notação ocidental convencional. Etnomusicólogos têm criado sinais para expressar estes ataques "adiantados" ou "atrasados". “ (Ulhôa (1999))

\ud0a4 ki.text: Korean A: “평조길의 틀은 그 키(key)를 높이고 성음(음색)을 씩씩하게 하면 그 구성음의 성질이 우조와 같은 씩씩한 느낌을 갖게 된다.” Shin (2018) [p. 246] English A: “Pyeongjo-gil elevates its key and intensifies its seongeum (vocal timbre), giving the qualities of the constituent notes energetic feelings similar to those of Ujo (Baek 1996, 58).” Kim (2024) [3.25]

angelangkah gunung.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat pitu, angelangkah giri ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “if seven it is called angelangkah gunung [mountain-sized stride],” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8])

re-creation.text: Source: “When a long story is arranged as a pansori version, it goes through a process of re-creation (or adaptation), which interprets and stages the music with different content and plot, depending on the individual who worked on that version. This helps establish a school of performance.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “The action or process of creating again or in a new way; the result of this process, a new creation.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “re-creation”)

\uc608\uc220\ubbfc\uc694\ub77c\uace0 Yes.text: 예술: art 민: folk; ethnic group Korean A: “ 그리고 한국에는 엄격한 입장을 취하는 아악과는 변도 로, 송정음악도 사원음악도 아니면서 일반대중과 상류사회가 공유해 온, 서양에서 볼 수 있듯이 지식사회에서 즐겨온 음악세계가 있어 요. 그리고 또 예술가곡• 예술민요라고 합니다만 그런 것이 또 있어 요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean,147) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3])

nalutur.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan nalutur artinya, penatas irama atau penatas lampah, reswa namanya. Pukulan ini sama artinya dengan pukulan nugtug.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Nalutur is mastery of rhythm, the showing of light, or reswa; it is also attainment, or reaching a goal. It is also called nugtug.” Tenzer (2024) [III.4] *Lexical field: Emotions or character (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\uc194\ub85c sollo.text: Korean A: “플루트 솔로는 D음에서 직접 시작하지 않고 아래에서 우선 올라옵니다. 그러면 B음이 준비됩니 다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “The flute solo does not begin right on D but rises from below. Bb thus prepares it [the note D].” Park (2024) [4.1]

m\u00fasica popular europeia.text: Portuguese A: “Mas o que me faz afirmar que a síncopa europeia é uma especulação prática de música erudita é não só a quase inexistência do movimento sincopado na música popular europeia (com exceção de portugas e ciganas {sobre estes ver Lavignac V}) como por ela não ser corrente mesmo na música coreográfica de criação erudita.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “But what makes me assert that European syncopation is a practical speculation of classical music is not only the almost nonexistence of the syncopated movement in European popular music (with the exception of Portuguese and Gypsy (Lavignac 1913)) as it is not common even in the choreographic music of the Western classical tradition.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

kale.text: Balinese A: “Di bawah ini adalah semua ubit-ubitan palegongan yang berpokok misalnya di dalam gagaboran atau di dalam lalonggoran dan kale, atau pangecet.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Below are palegongan-style ubit-ubitan for gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet contexts.” Tenzer (2024) [4.3] “Gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet are the names for different kinds of gong-cycle forms in dance pieces of the gamelan palegongan repertoire.” Tenzer (2024) [4.4]

kepatihan.text: English: “Geria’s examples all apply to the trompong, an instrument forefronted in prestigious court gamelan—the palegongan, semar pagulingan, and the gong gdé. I show both the kepatihan (cipher notation) provided and my own modified 3-line staff for the trompong and, when needed, a single-line staff for jegogan. Geria notated his examples on particular pitches in a five-tone pélog, conventionally numbered 1,2,3,5, and 6. But they could be played at any transposition.” Tenzer (2024)  [3.1]

acompanhamento.text: English A: “Song melodies would not be syncopated, the ambivalence emerging from their counterposition with the accompaniment, which would accentuate the beat. Instead, the melodic flow would be non-metrical, its accentuation driven by a “musical fantasy, pure virtuosity, or prosodic precision … a subtle compromise between recitative and strophic singing” (36).” (Stover (2024) [1.6]) Portuguese A: “As melodias das canções não seriam sincopadas, a ambivalência emergindo da contraposição com o acompanhamento, que acentuaria o tempo. O fluir da melodia seria não-métrico, a acentuação sendo dirigida por uma "fantasia musical, puro virtuosismo, ou precisão prosódica ... um compromisso sutil entre o canto recitativo e estrófico" (p. 36).” (Ulhôa (1999))
