\u0440\u044a\u0447\u0435\u043d\u0438\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Първият вид 7/16 такт се образува от един пайдушки такт с прибавка в началото на още една кратка част и служи за основа на народната игра, наречена обикновена ръченица (чупница, чепница, пешачка, сопица и др.).” Hristov (1925) [p. 47] English A: “The first type of 7/16 meter is formed from one paidushka measure with the addition of one more short part at the beginning, and this meter serves as the basis for the national dance, called rŭchenitsa (chupnitsa, chepnitsa, peshachka, sopitsa, etc.).” Goldberg (2024) [5.13]Chupnitsa чупницаchepnitsa чепницаpeshachka (Sofia region) пешачкаsopitsa сопица Bulgarian B: “Ръченица (от думата ръченик - дълга бяла ленена или копринена кърпа с ресни, с която се пребражда младоженката, преди да я заведат на венчило) характерен народен импровизационен танц B 7a/16 размер, тривременна стъпка, много бързо темпо, разпространен в цялата страна, познат още и под следните местни имена: посеница, тестеменка, тестемеличка, посадня, прескума, пешачка, наръченица, сопица, кършеница, чупница, чепница, чекурлянка, посварник и др.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 290] Bulgarian C: “РЪЧЕНИЦА, ПЕШАЧКА , ЧУПНИЦА, ПОСАДНИК.НА ПЛЕШЕНЕ. Рьченицата е най-разпространеннят на-роден танц в България. Играе се в такт 7/16. Изпълнява се поединично, по двойки, групово и на хоро. Играят я на закрито — в стаи и по чардаци, — на открито и по пьтя по време на веселия и сватби.” (Krŭstev (1967) p. 383–84)

lineage.text: Source: “Professional Yoruba drummers are born into an inherited craft lineage for drumming, where they carry the name of the defied progenitor of drumming, Àyàn. Similarly, Peiris’s primary research partner, Muddanave Sunil, was born into a caste-based lineage of male ritual dancers and drummers. In this article, Peiris does not tell us how Sunil learned, but this may be central to discussions about theorizing. Lineage-based learning generally starts very young and is often informal or learned in situ rather than formally taught and does not involve notation.” (Villepastour commentary (2024) [2.6]) Definition: “Lineal descent from an ancestor; ancestry, pedigree.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “lineage”)

pulse.text: време/vreme (Bulgarian) Source: “Hornbostel was identifying processes that would later be named (e.g. by David Locke 1982), among others, as offbeat timing, types of musical structures built on various rhythmic points or displaced from the regular metric pulse, common to various African musical styles. The process identified by Andrade in note #9, if applied to this example, would account for this incomprehension by Hornbostel.” Menezes (2024) [1.17] Definition: “Used synonymously with Beat to refer to regularly recurring articulations in the flow of musical time.” (Grove Music Online, “pulse”)

\u043d\u0435\u0442\u0430\u043d\u0446\u04.text: нетанцови + песни/pesni  нетанцови: non-dance Bulgarian A: “Значи разликата между такта на обикновената ръченица и този на македонското хоро или мъжката ръченица е в положението на протегнатата част, при ръченицата тя е в края, а при македонското — в началото. В такта на македонското хоро и ръченицата има твърде много и нетанцови песни (коледарски, седенкови и др.).” Hristov (1925) [p. 48] English A: “Thus, the difference between the meter of the ordinary rŭchenitsa and that of the makedonsko horo or mŭzhka rŭchenitsa is in the position of the elongated beat; in the rŭchenitsa it is at the end, and in the makedonsko horo—at the beginning. In the meter of the makedonsko horo and the rŭchenitsa there are also very many non-danced songs (caroling [koledarski/коледарски], textile-working [sedenkovi/седенкови ], and others).” Goldberg (2024) [5.15]

costumes.text: Source: “The translator’s choice of Shin Eun-Joo’s article on pansori is perfectly suited to presenting such an introduction. Pansori is one of the most important genres in Korean traditional music. Although frequently compared to Western classical opera due to their shared vocal and theatrical attributes, pansori is essentially an epic, narrative storytelling vocal performance executed by a singer and a drum accompanist without stage design or theatrical costumes. Unlike court or ritual music, pansori was first circulated among commoners and the lower class, and later enjoyed by all classes as a principal form of entertainment.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “The history of costume on the Western operatic stage is traced by referring to a variety of sources: original costumes, contemporary illustrations, commemorative portraits, designers’ drawings, inventory lists and wardrobe accounts, theatrical costume books, and memoirs, essays and programmes.” (Jowers, Sidney Jackson. "Costume." Grove Music Online. 2002)

proverb.text: Source: “The ubọ-aka serves as a medium of communication, transmitting the society’s folkways and traditions orally from one generation to another. The music conveys information, storytelling, proverbs, and idiomatic statements, allowing the listeners to learn about the mores and norms of the society.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.3] Definition: “A short, traditional, and pithy saying; a concise sentence, typically metaphorical or alliterative in form, stating a general truth or piece of advice; an adage or maxim.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “proverb”)

\ud310\ud0c0\uc9c0 pantaji.text: Korean A: “내가 음악을 생각하고 판타지를 펼칠 수 있다는 자유만이 거기에 있었어요. 신체적인 조건은 극도로 나빠도 그런 판타지를 펼치는 자유는 있었지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 161] English A: “There existed only freedom to think about my music and to unfold my fantasy. Even though my physical condition was extremely poor, I had the freedom to unfold fantasy.” Park (2024) [6.3]

\uc791\uace1 jaggog.text: Korean A: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

Xiandai hanyu fenlei (2007).text: Xiandai hanyu fenlei dacidian 现代汉语分类大词典. Shanghai上海: Shanghai cishu chubanshe 上海辞书出版社, 2007.

polyphony.text: 多声性 ōzei-sei (Japanese) 复音音乐 fùyīn yīnyuè (Chinese) Source: “In this note, Andrade is studying the article “African Negro Music” by Erich M. Hornbostel (1928). As the director of the Phonographic Archive in Berlin, Hornbostel was a pioneer in the academic study of African music. In this article, Hornbostel identifies some characteristics that he considers fundamental, which will be further developed by later authors: a highly developed rhythmic structure and, in vocal music, the predominance of responsorial singing and polyphony.” Menezes (2024) [1.14] Definition: “A term used to designate various important categories in music: namely, music in more than one part, music in many parts, and the style in which all or several of the musical parts move to some extent independently.” (Grove Music Online, “polyphony”)

\u8aa6 s\u00f2ng.text: Chinese A: 朗读；念诵。背诵. 述说。宜于诵读的韵文，如诗歌、顺口溜之类. Hanyu dacidian (誦, 1–4) Chinese B: “①读出声音来;朗读: 诵诗/诵经。 ②背诵: 熟读成诵/过目成诵。” Xiandai hanyu fenlei (2007) p. 552 English: “Vocal sounds that differ from strict “singing” due to being recitative in style.” Qian (2024) (See also 乐说 yuèshuō)

\uc0c1\ub300\uc131 sangdaeseong.text: Korean A: “동양의 전통음악에 이의 원형이 있어요. 항상 그 모델은 상대성을 갖고 있어서 하나의 요소가 늘 중심이 된다. 원칙적으로는 이렇게 되는 거지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “East Asian traditional music has its original model. One element always becomes the center because this model always possesses relativity. This is how it goes, at least in principle.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u7121 mu.text: Japanese A: ““全くの無から何かの音が生まれる 無に終わるんです。それは仏教的な哲学 尹そうです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 56] English A: “This piece is born within nothingness [無] and ends as nothingness. That is the Buddhist philosophy.” Park (2024) [4.1]

taka\u1e6da.text: English A: “The second word in each line— takaṭa—is, as mentioned, a standard motif that is typically played on the drum using the stroke sequence tat-dit-dit, indicated with box 1 in Example 12.” (Peiris (2024) [4.7]) English B: mnemonic syllable for a drum stroke (Peiris (2025))

timbre.text: 音色 yīnsè (Chinese) 음색 eumsaek (Korean) Timbre (Spanish) Source A: “Fundamentally, pansori is a performance-oriented, rather than composer-centric, genre. It privileges the performer’s artistic discretion in realizing embellishment tones, singing technique, vocal tone and timbre, as well as body gestures.” Lee commentary (2024) [5] Source B: Source: “I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “A term describing the tonal quality of a sound; a clarinet and an oboe sounding the same note at the same loudness are said to produce different timbres. […] The frequency spectrum of a sound, and in particular the ways in which different partials grow in amplitude during the starting transient, are of great importance in determining the timbre.” (Campbell, Murray. "Timbre (i)." Grove Music Online. 2001)

monism.text: Source: “Yet I find in Yun’s characterization a profound resonance with a different line of Western philosophical thought: Baruch Spinoza’s monism. For Spinoza, any aspect of reality (whether material or a product of thought) is a mode or singular coming-into-being of an eternal substance of which everything in the universe is composed.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.7]) Definition: “The most distinctive aspect of Spinoza’s system is his substance monism; that is, his claim that one infinite substance—God or Nature—is the only substance that exists.” (”Benedict de Spinoza: Metaphysics,” Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy)

\u0430\u043a\u0446\u0435\u043d\u0442/akt.text: Bulgarian A: “Разликата между първата и втората група тактове е доста съществена. Докато акцентите в първата група се падат на двойни и тройни елементи, т. е. на т. нар. кратки и протегнати части, във втората група всеки елемент се явява като отделно тактово време със самостоятелен акцент.” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “The difference between the first and second group of meters is quite substantial. Whereas the accents in the first group fall on duple and triple elements, i.e., on so-called short and elongated parts, in the second group each element manifests as a separate metric beat with independent accent.” Goldberg (2024) [3.6] Bulgarian B: “подчертаване на някой тон или акорд с по-голяма сила в сравнение с обкръжаващите го. А. биват реални и въображаеми. Реалните А. се основават на физическа промяна в силата на тона, а въображаемите, без наличието на такава промяна, се възприемат от слушателя само по силата на музикалната логика. Очебиещ пример за това са А., които се чувствуват при паузите, при свирене на орган и др. п. Произходът на думата А. показва, че акцентите са в близка връзка с просодията*.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 17]

\uac00\uc57c\uae08 gayageum.text: English A: “Sanjo may be played with a variety of traditional Korean string or wind instruments, including gayageum 가야금 (twelve-string zither), geomungo 거문고 (six-string zither), ajaeng 아쟁 (bowed zither), and daegeum 대금 (bamboo flute).” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) Korean B: “사부(部)에 드는 향악기(鄉樂器)의 하나. ① 가야금은 도설(圖說)에 나온 다. ② 『삼국사』(三國史)에 "가야금은 쟁(箏)의 제도와 조금 다를 뿐 대개 같고, 『나고기」(羅古記)에 이르기를, '가야국(加耶國) 가실왕(嘉實王)이 당나라의 악기를 보고 만들었다'라고 하였다"라고 전한다. 가야금은 동목(桐木: 오 동나무)으로 만들고, 장식목과 염미(染尾: 부들)는 현금(玄쪽)과 같다.” Song (2010) [p. 25]

primitive.text: Source A: “As we know from the practice of comparative musicology in the late nineteenth- and early twentieth-centuries, musics described as “primitive” typically come from cultures that (Western European) researchers deemed to be inferior, lacking the advancements present in their own cultures. Yet Hristov, a Bulgarian himself, takes great pride in the so-called “primitive” elements of Bulgarian folk music. Indeed, notions of primitivism take on a different connotation when employed by the communities they describe; but still, Hristov’s logic appears to affirm rather than disrupt modernist-colonialist ideologies surrounding teleology, progress, and extractivism, given that he frames the music as a resource for “modern contemporary composers looking for new compositional elements” ([1.1]).” (Boyd commentary (2024) [5]) Definition: “With the. That which is primitive or recalls an early or ancient period; (with plural agreement) simple, unsophisticated, or crude things or people as a class.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “primitive” I.2.c.)

circular.text: Source: “Based upon this distinctive character, Ulhôa makes the point that Brazilian popular song produces a circular feel (in contrast to what she calls the linear feel of much Western art music). However, when all the layers stress, for example, the first beat of a pattern, it may also produce a circular feel, in fact—see, for example, Snead’s analysis of how repetition in many African American musics makes the groove cut back to its own beginning (Snead 1984).” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [4]) Definition: “Moving or occurring in a round or cycle of repetition.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “circular” 4a)

prosody.text: Source: “Among many important theoretical contributions is this 1999 article on “métrica derramada,” which approaches the issue of musical microtiming from the perspective of the speech prosody of Brazilian Portuguese.” (Stover (2024) [0.1]) Definition: “The theory and practice of versification; (in technical use) the branch of knowledge which deals with the forms of metrical composition, and formerly also with the pronunciation of words, esp. as this relates to versification; (more generally) the patterns of rhythm and sound used in poetry.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “prosody”)

\u76f8\u5bfe\u6027 s\u014dtaisei.text: Japanese B: “東洋 の伝統音楽にこの原型があります。常に そのモデルは相対性を持っていて、一つ のものが常に中心になり、原則的にはこ うなるんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English B: “East Asian traditional music has its original model. One element always becomes the center because this model always possesses relativity. This is how it goes, at least in principle.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u4e0a\u4e0b\u52d5 j\u014dged\u014d.text: Japanese A: “このようなばあい、終止音は一方からは単に楽曲の終止音としての意味ばかりでなく、旋律線の上下動における中核的な意味を持つという理由で、他方では、連続的にくり返されるべき性質の「数え唄」や「網引唄」の中には、かならずしも終止音に終らない旋律も多いという理由で（そのばあいですら旋律線の中核的意味を失わない）、終止音とよぶより中核音または単に核音とよぶ方が適当ではないだろうか。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “In cases like these, the ending note on the one hand holds meaning not only as a simple ending note to the piece, but also holds meaning as a central nucleus of upward and downward movement in the melodic line. On the other hand, among songs like “Counting Song” and “Net-Pulling Song” whose melodies tend to be repeated continuously, there are many songs with melodies that certainly do not end on the ending note (even in those cases, the ending notes do not lose the meaning of a central nucleus of the melodic line). For that reason, rather than calling them ending notes, it may be more appropriate to call them central nuclear tones or simply nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1]

verticaliza\u00e7\u00e3o m\u00e9trica.text: English A: “One of the basic principles of European rhythmic construction, which was in the process of being developed at the time of the discovery of Brazil, as Manuel Veiga would say, is the concept of meter (compasso), or the metric verticalization of musical structure.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “Um dos princípios básicos da concepção rítmica europeia, em processo de estruturação na época do achamento do Brasil, como diria Manuel Veiga, é a concepção de compasso, ou verticalização métrica da estrutura musical.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “One of the basic principles of European rhythmic conception is the notion of the measure [compasso], or the metric verticalization of musical structure (Copland 1974).” (Stover (2024) [4.2]) Portuguese B: “Um dos princípios básicos da concepção rítmica européia, é a noção de compasso, ou verticalização métrica da estrutura musical (Copland 1974).” (Ulhôa (1999))

gambang.text: English A: “ gambang (an instrument, also common in Java, with wooden slats for keys)” (Tenzer (2024) [2.1]) English B: “As well as being an instrument, in Bali gambang also names an ensemble usually comprising four gambang and two bronze metallophones. Kesa mura means irregular and free, which likely connotes the fact that gamelan gambang music is not regulated by gongs and conventional gong structures. Banyu marga means flowing water, suggesting the continuous rippling texture of gamelan gambang music.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.12]) Balinese C: “Adapun jenis-jenis gambelan Bali yang tercantum dalam Prakempa ialah gambelan SmarPagulingan (Barong Singa), Smar Patangian, Smar Palinggihan (Joged Pingitan), Smar Pandirian (Barong Ket), Melad Prana (Gambuh), Angklung, Bebonangan,Gambang, Genggong, Slunding dan sebuah gambelan sakral yang terbuat dari logam taru wuku yang belum diketahui ujudnya (alinea: 41, 51, 55, 65, 67 dan 80).” Bandem (1986) [p. 15] Balinese D: “gamelan sakral berbelah empat belas, bentuknya pipih panjang-panjang de bamba, dimainkan dg kedua belah tangan memakai panggul bercabang dua.” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 141, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\u795e\u697d kagura.text: 神+楽 gaku  神: god, deity, divinity, spirit Japanese A: “しかし、事実はもっと複雑であって、一方では次節にのべるような比較音楽学的な考察から、また他方では、雅楽輸入以前に起源を持ち、しかも現在多少とも面影をとどめていると考えられる、神楽歌や歌披講などの旋律にも明らかに核音の機能が認められるという事実から、声明にだけこの傾向の原因をもとめるわけにはゆかない.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 13] English A: “On the one hand, from the perspective of comparative-musicological investigations that I will discuss in the next section; and also on the other hand from the fact that the function of nuclear tones is clearly recognized even in the melodies of kagura song and uta-hikō, which hold origins from before the importation of gagaku and furthermore are thought to retain a trace of these functioning nuclear tones in the present; we cannot go so far as to say that this is a tendency that seeks its origins only in vocal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [8.2] English B: “Kagura 神楽 is music and dance connected to Shinto ritual, which has close ties to and overlaps with gagaku.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [Footnote 15] Japanese B: “神を祭るための楽舞、これに*御神楽、*代神楽, *里神楽(里神楽は俗に“おかぐら”と呼んでいる) の三種の別がある。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 33-34]

atonality.text: 自由な音語 jiyūna otogo (Japanese) Source: “When Carrillo contrasted his ideas with Schoenberg’s, he set out to define not only a technical theory of atonality, but also a conception of how atonal music would connect with, and follow logically from, music of the past.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.10] Definition: “A term that may be used in three senses: first, to describe all music which is not tonal; second, to describe all music which is neither tonal nor serial; and third, to describe specifically the post-tonal and pre-12-note music of Berg, Webern and Schoenberg.” (Grove Music Online, “atonality”)

pulso mais r\u00e1pido.text: English A: “What is quite prominent in sub-Saharan African music is the establishment of a temporal order based on the interaction of multiple parts that produce a polyrhythmic texture. The structure of its rhythmic organization is based on asymmetrical groupings of minimum time units or “fastest pulses,” as explained by Kwabena Nketia in The Music of Africa (1974). There is no vertical alignment at the beginning of the measure, as in European notions of meter [compasso].” (Stover (2024) [4.4]) Portuguese A: “O que é bastante proeminente na música africana, sub-saarana, é o estabelecimento de uma ordem temporal, baseada na interação de partes múltiplas que produzem uma textura polirítmica. A organização rítmica se estrutura a partir de agrupamentos assimétricos de unidades de tempo mínimas ou "pulso mais rápido", como explica Kwabena Nketia no seu livro The Music of Africa (1974). Não existe um alinhamento vertical dos inícios dos tempos, como nas noções europeias de compasso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc120\uc801 \uc5b4\ubc95\uc758\u00a0seo.text: 선적 seonjeog (linear) 어법: grammar (see 보편적 인 어법 bopyeonjeog in eobeob) Korean A: “그것이 선생님 작품의 선적 어법의 밑바탕 이 되어 있군요. 미분음적인 미세한 흔들림으로부터 3 도 이상의 전음(숍)에 이르는 독특한 선의 움직임은 한국의 가창.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

leading tone.text: Source: “Elsewhere in the chapter, Carrillo argued that the whole-tone scale should play an important role in modern music, and he defended this view by appealing to an opposition between the whole-tone and chromatic scales. While every pitch in the chromatic scale could function as a leading tone, Carrillo noted, the unaccompanied whole-tone scale possessed no semitones, and thus no possible leading tones. In the absence of semitones, he concluded, “there is no possible tonality.”” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.2]

\u6574\u7136\u3068\u3057\u305f\u7f8e\u5b.text: Japanese A: “ただ、そこにもちろん音楽をつくる、音楽を続けていくこと自体の秩序や軽然とした美学がなければならないわけです. そのひとつを私は東洋人として一番最初に見つけました。それが「ハウプト・トン」です。" (Yun (1984) - Japanese 54) English A: "However, there still needs to be its own organizing principles [自体の秩序] and polished aesthetics [整然とした美学] for making and sustaining sound. I discovered one of those principles first as an East Asian composer. That is Hauptton. " (Park (2024)  [2.4])

\ub0ae\uac8c natge.text: Korean A: “이보형이 정리한 판소리 평조의 특징은 중중모리장단의 평조 대목에 나타나는 특징으로, 그 는 '중중모리-평조'라고 적음으로서 다른 장단의 평조 대목과 구별하였다. 구성음에서 mi와 fa는 유동적인 음으로, mi로 적을 수도 있고, fa로 적을 수도 있는, 다시 말해 창자들이 조금 높게 부를 수도 조금 낮게 부를 수도 있는 음으로 해석하였다. 이는 백대웅의 우조, 평조 이론과 가장 크게 차이를 보이는 부분으로, 이 음은 백대웅의 우조와 평조 이론에서 '상청'음에 해당하 는 음인데, 백대웅은 상청의 반음 높고 낮음에 따라 우조와 평조를 구분하였다. 그러나 이보형 은 이 음을 유동적인 것으로 파악하였고, 출현 빈도가 많은 중요음이 아닌 관계로 이 음의 높고 낮음이 악조를 변별하는 데 영향을 끼치지 않는다고 보았다.” Shin (2018) [p. 243] English A: “Lee’s Pyeongjo in pansori has the same features as Pyeongjo sequences in jungjungmori jangdan; to set it apart from the other Pyeongjo scenes, he refers to it as “jungjungmori-Pyeongjo.” According to Lee, mi and fa are flexible constituent notes; depending on the pansori performer, these notes could be sung a little higher or lower. This is where Lee’s theories of Ujo and Pyeongjo diverge most prominently from Baek’s. These flexible notes [mi or fa] are sangcheong in Baek’s Ujo and Pyeongjo theories. Baek distinguishes Ujo and Pyeongjo based on whether sangcheong is a high or low half step. Lee, however, considers these notes (mi or fa) fluid; whether they are high or low does not affect the mode because they are not important or frequently appearing notes.” Kim (2024) [3.17]

stock.text: Source: “The performers begin by singing two verses with Sinhala words (Paragraph 2.2, Video 1) using a stock melody commonly heard in the tradition, accompanied by a stock accompaniment pattern on the drums.” (Peiris (2024) [2.1]) Definition: “figurative in reference to intellectual or literary topics: Kept in stock for use; commonly used or brought forward, constantly appearing or recurring, in conversation, discussion, or composition; belonging to a staple or stock-in-trade of subjects, arguments, phrases, quotations, etc.; hence, commonplace, trite, conventional. Also with reference to fictional characters of a standardized or conventional type.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “stock”)

requebro.text: Portuguese A: “É uma realização imediata e espontânea das nossas maneiras de dançar, mais sensuais, provindas do clima talvez, e do amolecimento fisiológico das raças que se caldearam pra nos formar e formaram também o remeleixo, o requebro, o dengue. É o movimento dengoso do corpo na dança que deformou a rítmica da polca primeiramente na rítmica da habanera em seguida no do maxixe. Acresce ainda que em habaneras e danzones é comum o elemento da tercina (ver se a tercina ocorre no primeiro tempo).” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Here, syncopation is of immediate, constant, and directly choreographic application. In America, syncopation does not come from European syncopation. It is an immediate and spontaneous realization of our ways of dancing, more sensual, perhaps stemming from the climate, and the physiological softening of the races that melded to form us and also formed the remeleixo, the requebro, the dengue. It is the languid body movement in dance that deformed the rhythm of the polka first into the rhythm of the habanera and then into that of the maxixe. Furthermore, in habaneras and danzones, the element of triplet (check if the triplet occurs on the first beat) is common.” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “Em Portugal, o mesmo que ornamento ou fioritura e-xecutados com a voz. "Regala-me o teu cantar/ O teu cantar me regala;/ Regala-me estar te ouvindo/ Requebres que dás à fala." No Alentejo é também o estribilho de uma modinha. (Fradinho, M. Maneiras de dizer alentejanas, Rev. Lusitana, 31 (1/4): 126, 1933). (DM-MA)” (Andrade (1989) 438)

\uc2e4\ub0b4\uc545\uace1 silnae-aggog.text: 실내: chamber orchestra 악곡: composition; music; song  Korean A: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

\ubb18\ubbf8\uac00 myomiga.text: Korean A: “그게 이번에는 기악곡으로 옮겨가는데, 모든 기억 곡은 먼저 성악곡으로부터 이어받아 그것을 발전시킨 것이라고 해도 좋겠지요. 예를 들면 '대금'이라는 횡적을 길게 한 형태 의 한국 민족악기가 있는데, 그걸로 연주하는 가락은 가창을 이어받 은 것이지요. 그런데 거기에는 선적인 음악의 묘미가 있어요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: “And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5])

tempos fracos.text: English A: “Meter allows several voices to present a homogeneous (musical) discourse by providing an internal organization of pulsations into strong beats, propelling energy, and weak, inertial beats.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “O compasso permite que várias vozes possam apresentar um discurso homogêneo ao propor a organização interna das pulsações em tempos fortes, propulsores de energia e tempos fracos e inerciais.” (Ulhôa (1999))

habanera.text: Portuguese A: “É uma realização imediata e espontânea das nossas maneiras de dançar, mais sensuais, provindas do clima talvez, e do amolecimento fisiológico das raças que se caldearam pra nos formar e formaram também o remeleixo, o requebro, o dengue. É o movimento dengoso do corpo na dança que deformou a rítmica da polca primeiramente na rítmica da habanera em seguida no do maxixe. Acresce ainda que em habaneras e danzones é comum o elemento da tercina (ver se a tercina ocorre no primeiro tempo).” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Here, syncopation is of immediate, constant, and directly choreographic application. In America, syncopation does not come from European syncopation. It is an immediate and spontaneous realization of our ways of dancing, more sensual, perhaps stemming from the climate, and the physiological softening of the races that melded to form us and also formed the remeleixo, the requebro, the dengue. It is the languid body movement in dance that deformed the rhythm of the polka first into the rhythm of the habanera and then into that of the maxixe. Furthermore, in habaneras and danzones, the element of triplet (check if the triplet occurs on the first beat) is common.” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “Canção e dança introduzidas em Cuba, pelos negros africanos, que se tornou depois muito popular na Espanha e América Latina. Compasso binário, 2/4, primeiro tempo especialmente acentuado, andamento lento, em fragmentos de quatro, oito ou dezesscis compassos.” (Andrade (1989) 253) Portuguese C: “Dança cubana. Segundo alguns estudiosos, a habanera deu a ritmica à dança popular brasileira, o Maxixe.” (Cosme (1957) 58)

folkways.text: Source: “The ubọ-aka serves as a medium of communication, transmitting the society’s folkways and traditions orally from one generation to another. The music conveys information, storytelling, proverbs, and idiomatic statements, allowing the listeners to learn about the mores and norms of the society.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.3] Definition: “(Usually inplural) the traditional behaviour of a people or group.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “folkways”)

\u8abf\u6027 ch\u014dsei.text: Japanese A: “これはヨーロッパの調性音楽が、次第に従来の長・短調組織からぬけだして、自由な音語を使うようになってから、もっともひろい意味での調性の中心になる音という意味に使われていたものを、伝統音楽のばあいに適用したものと解することができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “It is understood that Mr. Itō applied the word “central tone” as something commonly used in Japanese traditional music, in the same way European [tonal] music used it in a free pitch language after it gradually began to pull away from its original major- and minor-key organization of tonal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4, brackets added separately] Japanese B: " 広 義 に お い て は 、⽀ 配 的 な 中 ⼼ ⾳ を 有 す る ⾳ 体 系 を 、 狭 義 に お いて は 、 ⾧ 短 調 い ず れ か の 主 和 ⾳ を も つ 和 声 的 な ⾳ 体 系 を さ す 。 前 者 の 旋 律 的 調 性 は 、 旋 法 性 を も 包 含 す る 概念 で あ り 、 お も に 2 0 世 紀 以 降 の 無 調 ⾳ 楽 や ⾮ ⾳⾼ 的 な ⼀ 部 の 民 族 ⾳ 楽 な ど に 対 ⽴ す る も の と して ⽤ い ら れ る 。 た だ し 、 明 ら か に 中 ⼼ ⾳ が あ て も 、 そ の 背 後 に な ん ら か の ⾳ 階 シ ス テ ム の 存 在 が な け れ ば 調 性 的 と は い え な い 。 ま た 、 逆 に 全 ⾳ 階 的 な シ ス テ ム を 基 盤 に し な が ら も 、 中 ⼼ ⾳ の 働 き が 弱 い も の を * 汎 調 性 と よ ぶ 。⼀ ⽅ ， 後 者 の 和 声 的 調 性 は 、 施 法 性 を 含 ま な い 概 念 で あ る 。 ゆ え に 、 お よ そ 1 7 世 頃 に ヨ ー ロ ッ パ に あ ら わ れ 、 現 在 の ポ ピ ュ ラ ー ⾳ 楽 に ま で ⽤ い ら れ て い る 、 ⾧ 短 調 を 基 盤 に し た 機 能 和 声 的 ⾳ 楽 の ⾳ 体 系 の み を さ す 。 こ の 場 合 ， ⾳ ⾼ の み な ら ず リ ズ ム や 強 弱 と い っ た 要 素 も 、 主 和 ⾳ を と り ま く ヒ エ ラ ル キ ー の 確 ⽴ 、 す な わ ち 調 性 感 の 確 ⽴ に ⼤ き く 関 与 す る の が 特 徴 で あ る 。” (Tomosha (2002), 415)

rap.text: English A: “Both in these “melôs” and in the case of rap in Portuguese, two prosodic issues appear. First is the use in Portuguese of a metric typical of English, that is, of regularly spaced thetic accents, which contributes to a sensation of regular measures. And second, there is the issue of successive ruptures typical of rap, produced by scratches, which makes music more of a “rhythmic partnership” than an complete interconnection between lyrics and melody (see Rose 1997, 207–8).” (Stover (2024) [3.5]) Portuguese A: “Tanto nestas "melôs", quanto no caso do rap em português vão aparecer duas questões prosódicas: primeiro, a utilização no português de uma métrica própria do ingles, isto é, de acentuações téticas regularmente espaçadas, o que contribui para uma sensação de compassos regulares. Segundo, é a questão das rupturas sucessivas próprias do rap, produzidas pelos "scratchs", o que faz da música mais uma "parceria rítmica" do que um todo interligado de letra e melodia (vide Rose 1997: 207-8).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u504f\u97f3 pi\u0101ny\u012bn.text: Chinese A: “指五声、六声、七声音阶中除宫、商、角、徵、羽五个正音之外的任何一个音.” Jianming yinyue (1985) (p. 417) Chinese B: “在五声性的六声或七声调式中,除宫商角徵羽舌音外的清角、变徵、闰、变宫等音称为偏音。在简谱的记谱中,清角音相当于4音,变徵音为#4音,变宫音为7音,闰为b7音.” Dong (1993) (p. 128) English: “Zhengyin 正音 refers to the proper pentatonic positions, and pianyin 偏音 refers to their semitone alterations. The pianyin prefix 變 bian (lit. change) lowers the position by one semitone; the opposite, 清qing (lit., clarity), raises the position by one semitone.” Lam (2024)  “pianyin 偏音, encompassing semitone alterations of pentatonic positions in both directions,” Lam (2024)

deung.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “peméro yg terletak antara ndéng dan ndung” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 158, Bidang Istilah Musik, “ndeung”]

\uc5f0\uc8fc\uac00 yeonjuga.text: Korean A: “끝으로 선생님 작품은 연주가라는 매체를 통하여 청중 에게 전달되므로 연주가와의 깊은 신뢰관계와 연주가의 전인적에 대한 신뢰에 밑받침되어 이루어지는 것이라고 생각됩니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 163] English A: “In closing, your compositions reach the listening public through performers [musicians], which, I think, is grounded upon a deeply trusting relationship between you and the performers and faith in the performer’s whole personality.” Park (2024) [7.2, brackets added separately]

Carter-\u00c9ny\u00ec (2024).text: Carter-Ényì, Quintina. 2024. “On the Ubọ-Aka of the Igbo: An Interview with Gerald Eze.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

m\u00fasica folcl\u00f3rica inglesa.text: Portuguese A: “A música africana se enriqueceu prodigiosamente aqui, ao contato da música ibérica. Da mesma forma com que os negros da América do Norte se apoderaram de certos caracteres da música folclórica inglesa, especialmente escocesa, também na América do Sul o fenômeno se deu.” Andrade (2013)  English A: “African music became immensely enriched here, through contact with Iberian music. In the same way that African-Americans appropriated certain characteristics of English folk music, especially Scottish, so too did this phenomenon occur in South America.” Menezes (2024) [1.4]

high modernism.text: Source A: “But the actual content of those musical styles are seldom explicitly present in his music; rather, Yun folds traditional ideas—say, the gestural impetus of an A-ak court melody—into a “more general grammar” that also reflects his training in high-modernist compositional techniques in Europe.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.1]) Source B: “Yun’s Hauptton technique could be understood as his response to the high-modernist trend of 1950s and 60s Germany, in particular, dodecaphony and avant-garde experimentalism.” Park (2024) [1.4]

\u666e\u904d\u7684\u306a\u8a9e\u6cd5 fuh.text: Japanese A: “で 、 そ う い っ た 韓 国 の 楽 器 だ と か 歌 唱 法 を 、 そ の ま ま の 形 で 先 ⽣ は 作 品 の 中 で お 使 い に な る わ け で は な く て 、 よ り普 遍 的 な 語 法 と し て 昇 華 さ れ 、 理 論 的 な 体 系 づ け を な さ っ た わ け で す ね 。 そ し て 、そ こ か ら ⽣ ま れ た の が 、 先 ⽣ の 作 品 の ⾻ 格 を 形 成 す る 「 ハ ウ プ ト ・ ト ン （ 主 要 ⾳ ） 」の 技 法 で あ る わ け で す ね ." (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "So, you do not directly use Korean instruments or singing styles in your compositions but transform them into more general grammar [普遍的な語法] and construct a theoretical framework. And an idea derived from it is your Juyo-um (Hauptton, [主要音]) technique, which structures your compositions." (Park (2024)  [1.6])

ngembat.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) Balinese B: “memukul trompong yg berjarak satu oktaf yg nadanya dipukul bersama” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 140, Bidang Istilah Musik, “embat”]

Modificaciones arm\u00f3nicas.text: Spanish A: “No conozco ningún ejemplo en el cual se hayan operado modificaciones melódicas, armónicas y rítmicas, sin alterar los modelos, y con mi “Ley de metamorfosis” pueden efectuarse cambios en la melodía, en la armonía y el ritmo, sin agregar ni suprimir ni una sola nota.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] English A: “I do not know any example in which melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic modifications have been used without altering the models. With my “Law of Metamorphosis,” changes in melody, harmony, and rhythm can be carried out without adding or removing a single note.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20]

\u7d76\u5bfe\u97f3\u9ad8 zettai ototaka.text: 絶対: absolute, unconditional, unmistakable + 音高: pitch (of a sound) Japanese A: “しかし鎌倉・室町時代に興った能楽の譜では、この点がはなはだ不正確で、絶対音高を表示する譜面によってはとらえることが困難である。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “However, in the sheet music of nō, which became prosperous in the Kamakura [1185 – 1333 CE] and Muromachi [1336 – 1573 CE] periods, the notes are extremely imprecise, and it is difficult to capture absolute pitch from what is displayed in the sheet music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.1] Japanese B: “相 対 ⾳ 感 に 対 し て ⽤ い ら れ る ⽤ 語 。 あ る ⾳ が 単 独 で 与 え ら れ た と き ， 他 の ⾳ に ⾳ 程 的 に 関 係 づ け ず に ， ⾳ 名 を 正 し く 断 定 で き る 能 ⼒ 。 絶 対 ⾳ 感 を 有 す る ⼈ の 多 く が 、 ⾳ を 聞 く と 、 た と え ば 瞬 時 に そ の ⾳ を 出 す ピ ア ノ の 鍵 盤 が 思 い 浮 か ぶ と 表 現 す る 。 通 常 の 絶 対 ⾳ 感 は 、 楽 ⾳ に 対 し て の み そ の 能 ⼒ を有 す る 。⼀ ⽅ の 対 象 が 素 べ た た 絶 対 ⾳ 感 をる ⼈ で は 、 ⾳ の 対 象 が 楽 ⾳ に 限 定 さ れ ず 。 と か ク ラ ク シ ョ ン な ど の ⽣ で 意 に お い て も を ⽿ に し た 瞬 間 に 。 そ の ⾳ 名 を 正 確 に 名 指 し き る 。 → 相 対 ⾳ 感.” (Tomosha (2002), 362–363)

gagejer.text: English: “Gagejer (from gejer, to shake) is an anomaly in that (according to several people I asked) it does not appear anywhere in the repertoire, though perhaps it did in Geria’s lifetime or his own compositions. Like IV.1 the parts do not interlock.” Tenzer (2024) [4.7] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

poetic meter.text: Source A: “This article aims to broaden common understandings of music theory through the lens of orally transmitted ritualistic verses from Sri Lanka, which are sung or recited along with drumming. I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2]) Source B: “In his analysis of the interaction between musical and poetic meters in rap flows, Oddekalv emphasizes the role of stressed syllables in establishing competing structural cues in the rapped part of a musical whole: “When there are multiple rhythmic events from different layers which communicate the same general category (like a beat or a sub-beat), but the events do not share the exact same temporal position . . . stressed syllables have a crucial structuring role” (Oddekalv 2022, 183).” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [2])

Temas con variaciones.text: Spanish A: “…o sea que la mentalidad de los compositores estaba dominada por la idea de escribir temas con variaciones, idea absolutamente excluída de mis Leyes, pues la característica de ellas es que jamás se agrega ni suprime ninguna nota a las composiciones originales metamorfoseadas.”  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] English A: “Composers’ thinking has been dominated by the idea of writing themes and variations, an idea absolutely excluded from my Laws, because their defining characteristic is that no note is ever added or removed from compositions that are metamorphosed.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] Spanish B: See Tema. “Variaciones: Bajo esta apalabra se entiende el glosar y adornar una pieza de Música reconociendo el fondo de ella.” Palatín (1990) [p. 104]

\u043d\u0435\u0434\u0435\u043b\u0438\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “В нашата народна музика неправилният такт се образува от равни първични времена (хронос протоси), неделими на по-малки части, и противно на европейските неправилни тактове тук тези неделими части се свиват в по-големи части чрез съединение на две или три от тях (кратки и удължени тактови части).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: “In our folk music irregular meter is formed from equal primary elements (chronoi protoi) that cannot be divided into smaller parts, and contrary to European irregular meters, here these indivisible parts are bound together into larger parts by combining two or three of them (short and elongated metric parts).” Goldberg (2024) [4.4]

\ub192\uac8c nopge.text: Korean A: “이보형이 정리한 판소리 평조의 특징은 중중모리장단의 평조 대목에 나타나는 특징으로, 그 는 '중중모리-평조'라고 적음으로서 다른 장단의 평조 대목과 구별하였다. 구성음에서 mi와 fa는 유동적인 음으로, mi로 적을 수도 있고, fa로 적을 수도 있는, 다시 말해 창자들이 조금 높게 부를 수도 조금 낮게 부를 수도 있는 음으로 해석하였다. 이는 백대웅의 우조, 평조 이론과 가장 크게 차이를 보이는 부분으로, 이 음은 백대웅의 우조와 평조 이론에서 '상청'음에 해당하 는 음인데, 백대웅은 상청의 반음 높고 낮음에 따라 우조와 평조를 구분하였다. 그러나 이보형 은 이 음을 유동적인 것으로 파악하였고, 출현 빈도가 많은 중요음이 아닌 관계로 이 음의 높고 낮음이 악조를 변별하는 데 영향을 끼치지 않는다고 보았다.” Shin (2018) [p. 243] English A: “Lee’s Pyeongjo in pansori has the same features as Pyeongjo sequences in jungjungmori jangdan; to set it apart from the other Pyeongjo scenes, he refers to it as “jungjungmori-Pyeongjo.” According to Lee, mi and fa are flexible constituent notes; depending on the pansori performer, these notes could be sung a little higher or lower. This is where Lee’s theories of Ujo and Pyeongjo diverge most prominently from Baek’s. These flexible notes [mi or fa] are sangcheong in Baek’s Ujo and Pyeongjo theories. Baek distinguishes Ujo and Pyeongjo based on whether sangcheong is a high or low half step. Lee, however, considers these notes (mi or fa) fluid; whether they are high or low does not affect the mode because they are not important or frequently appearing notes.” Kim (2024) [3.17]

discontinuidades temporais.text: English A: “The continuity of this sound flow is transformed, driven, broken by another musical parameter, rhythm, which gives the melody vitality and character (Toch 1985). Rhythm is characterized by temporal discontinuities. In singing, it is the consonants that break the fluidity of melodic speech.” (Stover (2024) [2.5]) Portuguese A: “A continuidade deste fluxo sonoro é transformada, impulsionada, quebrada por um outro parâmetro musical, o rítmo, que dá à melodia vitalidade e caráter (Toch 1985). O rítmo se caracteriza por discontinuidades temporais. No canto são as consoantes que vêm quebrar a fluidez do discurso melódico.” (Ulhôa (1999))

Bandem (1986).text: Bandem, I. Made. Prakempa: Sebuah Lontar Gambelan Bali. Akademi Seni Tari Indonesia Denpasar, 1986.

can\u00e7\u00e3o instrumental.text: Portuguese A: “Na infinita maioria dos casos ocorre dentro do conceito de lied. É na canção, e principalmente na canção exclusivamente instrumental (o que é importante para esta observação) que ocorre síncopas. (dar exemplos). [Estudar os flamengos e os ante-monteverdianos pra ver a síncopa neles].” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “In the vast majority of cases, it occurs within the concept of lied. It is in the song, and mainly in the exclusively instrumental song (which is important for this observation), that syncopations occur. (Studying the Flemish and pre-Monteverdian to see the syncopation in them).” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

ngunda.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngunda artinya, pengumpulan barang sesuatu di dalam pekerjaannya.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngunda is to distribute something accumulated through work to others.” Tenzer (2024) [III.8] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions(Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u65cb\u5f8b\u306e\u8df3\u8e8d senritsu.text: 旋律 senritsu + 跳躍: jump, leap Japanese A: “ただ筝曲や尺八のような器楽には、非常に自由な旋律の跳躍が見られ、核音の支配から脱しているかのように思える.” [Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 9] English A: “In instrumental music such as pieces for the koto or shakuhachi, we can see extraordinary freedom of melodic leaps, and so one may think that they have broken away from the control of their nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [6.1] See also 旋律構成 senritsu kōsei and 跳躍的な力 chōyaku tekina chikara and 旋律線 senritsusen and 旋律 senritsu

\u4e0a\u6607\u6027 j\u014dsh\u014dsei.text: Japanese A: “このようにな ります。しかし これよりももっ と動的な場合も あるし、もっと 静的な場合もあ ります。また上 昇性を持つ場合 と下行性を持つ 場合があります。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “But there are cases where it is more active or more static. Also, there are cases where it has a tendency upward and downward.” Park (2024) [4.1]

Acorde perfecto menor.text: Spanish A: “En cuanto al perfecto menor, que tiene sobre el bajo un intervalo de tres semitonos, y sobre la nota alta de éste, uno de cuatro, tendrá al metamorfosearse al duplo, uno de seis semitonos sobre el bajo, en vez de tres, y sobre la nota alta de éste, uno de ocho semitonos en vez de cuatro.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 24] English A: “The minor triad has an interval of three semitones above the bass, and above that, an interval of four semitones. Under metamorphosis to the double, the first interval will reach six semitones above the bass, and the second, another eight semitones.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 24] See also Acorde, Pedrell (1890) [p. 5] Spanish B: “Es al armonía que resulta de una nota, de su 3.ª y de su 5.ª. Ej: […] do, mi b. sol; ACORDE PERFECTO menor.” Lacál (1900) [p. 5]

m\u00fasica instrumental.text: English A: “Métrica derramada appears frequently in the performance of popular Brazilian music, not only in songs such as samba, bossa nova, and so-called MPB, but also in essentially instrumental music. In instrumental choro, for example, there is a relative independence of parts, which intertwine without merging into a synchronized sound mass in terms of temporal division.” (Stover (2024) [5.1]) Portuguese A: “A métrica derramada aparece muito na performance da música brasileira popular, não só na canção como no samba, na bossa nova e na chamada MPB, como também em música essencialmente instrumental. No choro instrumental, por exemplo, existe uma relativa independência das partes, que se entrelaçam sem se fundirem numa massa sonora sincronizada em termos de divisão temporal.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u5e55 maku.text: Japanese A: “あの曲は四ヵ月ぐらいでしょうか。 あのオペラは一幕もので一時間かかる曲 なんですが、ドイツで拉致される前、そ の曲の初め十分ぐらいできていたんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 60] English A: “The opera is in one act and takes about one hour to perform. Before I was kidnapped in Germany, the first 10 minutes’ worth was completed.” Park (2024) [6.2]

\u0442\u0430\u043a\u0442\u043e\u0432\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Това личи от запазените д о днес метрични и ритмични особености в нея , от чудните закономерности в строежа а тактове И периодите, които ни напомнят по-скоро някогашните тайнствен от отдалечените орфеични и питагорейски времена.” Hristov (1925) (p. 33) English A: “This is apparent from the metric and rhythmic features that are preserved in it to this day, from the wondrous regularities in the composition of its measures and periods, which remind us more of the once-secret numbers of distant Orphean and Pythagorean times.” Goldberg (2024) [2.2] Bulgarian B: “measure = размер, такт: 2/4, 3/4, 4/4 и т.н.” (Iliev (1996) 80)

Bera P\u014dya H\u0113visi.text: English A: “The first set of sung verses presented here—in Paragraphs 9 and 12—belongs to the genre known as däkum ata, which is performed as an “offering of sound” (śabda pūjāva) during a Bera Pōya Hēvisi ritual. Each line in these verses contains eighteen poetic morae. Although this repertoire is more closely associated with dawula drums (Example 3), in the recording featured here—Videos 1 and 2—they are performed with gäṭa beraya drums (Example 4).” Peiris (2024) [8] English B: “ritual performed on a full moon night” (Peiris (2025)

Peiris (2024).text: Peiris, Eshantha. “Embedded Music Theory: Oral Poetry, Rhythmic Language, and Drumming in Sri Lanka.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4 (2024).

\u043d\u043e\u0442\u043d\u0438 \u0437\u0.text: Bulgarian A: “До днес тя е непозната на чуждия музикален свят: сърби, хървати и чехи като записвачи между другото и на тези български, включително и македонски , песни са ги предали с нотни знаци в изкривен вид, в рамките на правилните европейски тактове.” Hristov (1925) (p. 33) English A: “To this day it is unknown to the foreign musical world: when transcribing these Bulgarian, including Macedonian, songs into musical notation, Serbs, Croats, and Czechs have rendered them in distorted form, in the frameworks of regular European meters...” Goldberg (2024) [2.2]

\u97f3\u7a0b ontei.text: 音 oto+程 程: extent, degree, measure; (span of) time Japanese A: “大部分の箇所では互に４度音程をなすこれら核音だけが、音階の主要音であり、抑制された旋律的表現が、これら核音の微妙なピッチの上下変化をもたらしている。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11]  Japanese B: “2 つ の ⾳ の さ の 隔 た り⾳ 程 の 種 類 は 、 五 線 譜 上 の 際 だ り を あ ら わ す 「 度 数 」 と 、 そ の 度 数 の 種 類 を あ ら わ す 「 完 全 ・ ⾧ ・ 短 ・ 増 ・ 減 」 な ど の ⽤ 書 の 細 み 合 わ せ に よ っ て 別 さ れ る （ 譜 例 ） 。 ま た ⾳ 程 に は 、 同 時 に 響 く ⾳ ど う し の 「 垂 直 ⾳ 程 」と 、 連 続 し て 響 く ⾳ ど う し の 「 ⽔ 平 ⾳ 程 」 と が あ る .” Tomosha (2002) [p. 124] English A: “In most places, only nuclear tones that make up the interval of a fourth with each other are the chief notes of the scale. Restrained melodic expression brings subtle changes of pitch to these nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.2] Japanese C: “Bbは、ただの準備の音です。しかし、 このDを生ませるために長3度が生じま す。長3度は明るい音程です。それで、 暗い音から明るい音になります。という ことは、少しずつ光が入ってくるという。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English C: “The Bb is just a tone for preparation. But, in order to create D, a major third is created. A major third is a bright interval. So, a dark tone becomes a bright tone. It is like light is peeking through little by little.” Park (2024) [4.1]

m\u00e9trica derramada.text: English A: “In this text I expand on some aspects raised by Andrade, putting up for discussion a hypothesis about musical prosody in Brazilian popular song, the concept of fluid meter [métrica derramada], which refers both to aspects of synchronization between singing and accompaniment and to issues of accentuation in the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.7]) Portuguese A: “Neste texto amplio alguns aspectos levantados por Mário de Andrade, colocando para discussão uma hipótese sobre a prosódia musical da canção brasileira popular, o conceito de métrica derramada, que se refere tanto a aspectos de sincronização entre canto e acompanhamento como a questões de acentuação na canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u7ae5\u5504 warabeuta.text: 童: child + 唄: song (謡 utai) Japanese A: “まず童唄、民謡の類は、すでにわれわれの出発点であった。長唄については上に述べた通り、この核音の支配が顕著にあらわれているが、譜２７は哥沢の例で、hとeとに現われた核音は、明瞭に旋律構造の骨格をなしている。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 8] English A: “First, our points of departure were children’s songs and folk songs. As I have said above about nagauta, nuclear tones strikingly control the melodies, but example 27 (Example 4) is an example of utazawa, and the pitches B and E clearly make up the skeleton of the melody’s construction as its nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [5.2]

\ubcf4\ud3b8\uc801 \uc778 \uc5b4\ubc95 b.text: 보편적 : universal 어법: grammar Korean A: “그러니까 선생님은 그런 한국의 악기라든가 가창법을 그 형태 그대로 선생님 작품 가운데 쓰는 것이 아니라 더욱 보편적 인 어법으로 승화시켜서 이그러니까 선생님은 그런 한국의 악기라든가 가창법을 그 형태 그대로 선생님 작품 가운데 쓰는 것이 아니라 더욱 보편적 인 어법으로 승화시켜서 이론적 체계를 세운 것이군요. 그리고 거기 서 생겨나는 것이 선생님 작품의 뼈대를 형성하는 '주요음'(Haupt ton)의 기법이군요.론적 체계를 세운 것이군요. 그리고 거기 서 생겨나는 것.” (Yun (1991) - Korean, 148) English A: "So, you do not directly use Korean instruments or singing styles in your compositions but transform them into more general grammar [普遍的な語法] and construct a theoretical framework. And an idea derived from it is your Juyo-um (Hauptton, [主要音]) technique, which structures your compositions." (Park (2024) [1.6])

remeleixo.text: Portuguese A: “É uma realização imediata e espontânea das nossas maneiras de dançar, mais sensuais, provindas do clima talvez, e do amolecimento fisiológico das raças que se caldearam pra nos formar e formaram também o remeleixo, o requebro, o dengue. É o movimento dengoso do corpo na dança que deformou a rítmica da polca primeiramente na rítmica da habanera em seguida no do maxixe. Acresce ainda que em habaneras e danzones é comum o elemento da tercina (ver se a tercina ocorre no primeiro tempo).” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Here, syncopation is of immediate, constant, and directly choreographic application. In America, syncopation does not come from European syncopation. It is an immediate and spontaneous realization of our ways of dancing, more sensual, perhaps stemming from the climate, and the physiological softening of the races that melded to form us and also formed the remeleixo, the requebro, the dengue. It is the languid body movement in dance that deformed the rhythm of the polka first into the rhythm of the habanera and then into that of the maxixe. Furthermore, in habaneras and danzones, the element of triplet (check if the triplet occurs on the first beat) is common.” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “1. Requebro, bambolcio. (DM)2. Baile popular, derivado da doença nervosa de mesmo nome que se caracteriza por freqüentes movimentos convulsivos. (DM-MA)” (Andrade (1989) 438)

Kim (2024).text: Kim, Seokyoung. 2024. “Translation of Shin Eun-Joo’s “Two Theories of Ujo and Pyeongjo in Pansori: Comparing Baek Daewoong’s and Lee Bohyeong’s Theories of Pansori Modes” (2018).” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

Geria (n.d.).text: Geria, Gusti Putu Madé. Undated. Set of handwritten notebooks in the collection of I Madé Bandem.

\u5442 ryo.text: Japanese A: “これはやがて明らかになるように、中国や朝鮮に見られる系統と同じものであって、いわゆるとよばれる旋法の影響が濃厚なことを現わしている.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 15] English A: “This will eventually become clear, but it shows that its lineage is the same as that seen in China and Korea—in other words, its melodic construction is heavily influenced by the mode called ryo.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [9.2] English B: “The ryo 呂 scale is primarily a major pentatonic scale, which is also sometimes extended to a Lydian or Mixolydian diatonic scale. Its opposite within the gagaku modal system is ritsu 律, whose pentatonic form has a perfect fourth rather than a major third above the tonic, and whose diatonic form is Dorian.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [Footnote 18]

saltos.text: English A: “A quality of characteristically melodic phrases is their lyricism. Even an instrumental phrase can have a melodic quality when its musical notes flow in a sequence of scale degrees relatively close to each other so as not to break the melodic movement. A lyrical melody usually has an undulating melodic contour. Leaps between notes are used economically, for emphasis or expression.” (Stover (2024) [2.4]) Portuguese A: “Uma qualidade de frases característicamente melódicas é o seu lirismo. Mesmo uma frase instrumental pode ter uma qualidade melódica quando as notas musicais fluem numa seqüência de graus relativamente próximos uns dos outros de modo a não quebrar o movimento. Uma melodia lírica tem um contorno melódico usualmente ondulado. Saltos entre as notas são usados de forma econômica, para ênfase ou expressão.” (Ulhôa (1999))

tone melody.text: Source: “Yuen-ren Chao was the first to write about Mandarin text-setting in English (to my knowledge) and has, therefore, had a profound influence on global scholarly thought on the subject. Chao noted that speech-like genres, such as vendors’ cries and children’s rhymes, show stricter tone-melody alignment than musical genres (Chao 1956).” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [2]

hexatonic.text: Source: “For instance, Tracey’s alto kalimba is modeled after the mbira nyunga nyunga. Instead of following the original tuning of the mbira nyunga nyunga, which is hexatonic, it is tuned to the G diatonic scale. Over time, the Zimbabwean term mbira has been generalized to represent all thumb pianos, including those found in Africa and South America (Kubik and Cooke 2001).” Chow commentary (2024) [1] Definition: “A term applied to any music, mode or scale based on a system of six different pitches to the octave.” (Wilson, Charles. "Hexatonic." Grove Music Online. 2001)

\u5668\u697d\u66f2 utsuwa raku kyoku.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 今 度 は 器 楽 曲 に 移 り ま し て 、 す べ て の 器 楽 曲 は ま ず 声 楽 から 受 け 継 い で 、 そ れ を 発 展 さ せ た も の とい っ て も い い わ け で す 。 た と え ば 「 ⽝ 等 」と い い ま し て 、 横 笛 を ⾧ く し た 形 の 韓 国 の 民 族 楽 器 が あ り ま し て 、 そ れ で 奏 さ れ る 節 回 し は 歌 唱 を 受 け 継 い だ も の で す 。そ し て 、 そ こ に は 線 的 な ⾳ 楽 の 妙 味 が ある わ け で す.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5]) Japanese B: “楽器によって演奏される音楽。「声楽」の対語。伎楽（ぎがく）妓楽とも。” (Tomosha (2002), 164)

\u55ae\u97f3\u97f3\u6a02 d\u0101ny\u012b.text: Chinese: “希臘人曾定下了許多的音樂法則，雖然就當日的單音音樂來說，不論那一個法則都是持之有故，言之成理，但是應用到現時的複音音樂，大都是沒有多大的用處，就祇把牠應用到區區的曲調上面，亦是用不着。” Li (2024)  English: “The Greeks established numerous musical principles which, in the context of their monophonic music, were logical and well-founded. Yet, when applied to contemporary polyphonic music, most of these principles lose their relevance.’ Li (2024) [1.13]

natural.text: Source: “In Rectificación básica al sistema musical clásico, Carillo railed at the falsity of equal temperament—“How horrendous! To deliberately stain the purity of natural sounds!” (Carillo 1930, 13)—much like György Eszter’s music teacher in Lázló Kraznahorkai’s The Melancholy of Resistance, who—upon discovering the historical lie that constituted well-temperament suffers an existential crisis of faith from which he never recovers (Kraznahorkai 1998, 63ff.)” Bauer commentary (2024) [4.2] Definition: “Existing in, determined by, conforming to, or based on nature.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “natural”)

\uc0c1\uccad sangcheong.text: Kim (2024) Ex. 2–1 Korean A: “백대웅이 설명하고 있는 우조길 각 음의 특징 중 가장 주목해야 할 음은 상청이다. 그는 상청에 대해 '우조길의 특징을 평조길과 구별하게 하는 음'이라고 제시하고 있으며, '본청과 장3 도의 음정관계라는 점이 큰 의미를 갖는다(평조길은 완전4도)'라고 설명한다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238] English A: “When examining the qualities of each note in Ujo-gil as Baek describes them, it is crucial to focus on the characteristics of sangcheong. Baek claims that the sangcheong “distinguishes Pyeongjo-gil from Ujo-gil” and that “it is crucial that the interval between boncheong and sangcheong is a major 3rd (a perfect 4th in the case of Pyeongjo-gil)” (Baek 1982, 1995, 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.4] English B: 1. tone in high range 2. name of the 4th string of geomungo (Pyǒn (2012) 49) Korean B:

anacr\u00fastica.text: English A: “Brazilian Portuguese, like many other languages, uses syllabic stress as a means of phonological identification. One of the main characteristics of its accentuation patterning is the presence of a large number of paroxytonic words. This gives the language, and consequently the metric/prosodic structuring of its musical paradigm, an anacrustic tendency or feel.” (Stover (2024) [3.1]) Portuguese A: “O português brasileiro, como muitas outras línguas, usa o acento silábico como um meio de identificação fonológica. Uma das características principais de seu padrão de acentuação é a presença de um número grande de palavras paroxítonas. Isto dá à língua, e consequentemente ao paradigma musical para estruturação métrica/prosódica uma tendência ou sensação anacrústica.” (Ulhôa (1999))  English B: “In Western music, a phrase is said to be anacrustic when it begins before and ends after the first beat of the measure. For each anacrustic beginning we have an equivalent unstressed or “feminine” ending. Linguists call this anacrustic sensation “right-hand prominence,” in reference to the direction of accentuation in each phrase (Ester Scarpa, personal communication).” (Stover (2024) [3.2]) Portuguese B: “Na música ocidental se diz que uma frase é anacrústica quando começa antes e termina depois do primeiro tempo do compasso. Para cada início anacrústico temos uma terminação átona ou "feminina" equivalente. Os lingüistas chamam esta sensação anacrústica de "proeminência à direita", numa referência à direção da acentuação em cada frase (Ester Scarpa, comunicação pessoal).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u0427\u0435\u0442\u0432\u043e\u0440\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “ В Сливенско, Ямболско, също в Болград играят особена пайдушка наречена ючата, ескийската, в Берковско като обикновено хоро, а в Брезнишко и Трънско — „Четворка"” Hristov (1925) [p. 44] English A: “In the Sliven and Yambol regions, as well as in Bolgrad, they dance a specific paidushka, called yuchata or eskiiskata; in the Berkovitsa region paidushka is danced as a normal horo, and in the Breznik and Trŭn regions, as a “chetvorka.”” Goldberg (2024) [5.6]

espa\u00e7os.text: English A: “These rhetorical gestures, as well as the spaces between musicians’ attacks or note endings in a musical performance, contribute greatly to making people move their bodies in specific ways and to hearing the “grain” of the song.” (Stover (2024) [5.8]) Portuguese A: “Estes gestos retóricos, bem como os espaços entre os ataques ou finais de nota dos músicos numa performance musical contribuem enormemente para fazer as pessoas moverem seus corpos de maneira específica, e para escutar o "grão" da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u30d7\u30ed\u30bb\u30b9 purosesu.text: Japanese A: “西洋人が持っていた形式観はないわけなんです。西洋音楽には曲を組み立ててゆくプロセスについてのはっきりしたモデルがあります。そしてそのモデルを越えて音楽は続いてゆかないのです。だから、東洋の感性をそういう伝統的な西洋のフォルムの考え方が支配してしまうのはとても危険なことです.”(Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "East Asian traditional music does not possess Western-style formalism. In Western music, there are clear process [プロセス] to assemble a composition based on clear models. Outside of these models, music cannot be sustained. " (Park (2024)  [2.3])

Dodecaphony.text: Source: “Yun’s Hauptton technique could be understood as his response to the high-modernist trend of 1950s and 60s Germany, in particular, dodecaphony and avant-garde experimentalism.” Park (2024) [1.4]

\u0435\u0440\u0430\u0432\u0435\u043d \u0.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: unequal dactylic rhythm, “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6]

guru.text: Sinhalese A: “tat jek kinaṃ takaṭa kaḍataka jeṃgu jeṃ takaṭa tat takaṭa – guru dakin” Peiris (2024) [12] English A: “[vocables. . .] – witness the teacher.” Peiris (2024) [12]

\u0434\u0432\u043e\u0439\u043d\u0438/dvo.text: Bulgarian A: “Разликата между първата и втората група тактове е доста съществена. Докато акцентите в първата група се падат на двойни и тройни елементи, т. е. на т. нар. кратки и протегнати части, във втората група всеки елемент се явява като отделно тактово време със самостоятелен акцент.” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “The difference between the first and second group of meters is quite substantial. Whereas the accents in the first group fall on duple and triple elements, i.e., on so-called short and elongated parts, in the second group each element manifests as a separate metric beat with independent accent.” Goldberg (2024) [3.6]

ultramodernism.text: Source: “Within this global movement, which I call ultramodernism, Carrillo acted as one participant, alongside peers I have mentioned such as Cowell, and many others I have not mentioned, such as Ivan Wyschnegradsky (1893–1979).” Cannon-Brown (2024) [3.8]

\uc7a52\ub3c4 jang 2 do.text:
장 + 2 + 도 do  장: major 
 Korean A: “때문에 백대웅의 이론을 활용하여 판소리 악조를 분석할 경우, 본청과 상청의 음정이 장3도인 경우에는 우조로, 본청과 상청의 음정이 완전4도인 경우에는 평조로 판별한다. 이를 상본청과 상청의 음정 간격 으로 다시 설명하면, 상본청과 상청의 음정이 장2도인 경우에는 우조로, 상본청과 상청의 음정 이 단3도인 경우에는 평조로 해석되는 것이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238] English A: “Therefore, if the gap between boncheong and sangcheong is a major 3rd, it is analyzed as Ujo according to Baek’s theory. If the interval between the two notes is a perfect 4th, it is Pyeongjo. In other words, a major 2nd between sangboncheong and sangcheong is Ujo, and a minor 3rd is Pyeongjo.” Kim (2024) [3.8]

\ud1f4\uc131 toeseong.text: English A: “Yoseong 요성 and toeseong 퇴성 are subcategories of sigimsae. Yoseong denotes a vibrating or wavering sound, comparable to the Western musical technique of vibrato but executed in a uniquely Korean style. Toeseong denotes a technique wherein the pitch descends towards the end of a note, thereby enhancing the expressiveness of the performance.” (Kim (2024) [0.4]) Korean B: “판소리에서 평조라는 것은 기본 선율들이 Sol-do-re-do와 같은 경우가 많으므로 기본 선율형에서 이 들의 구성음이 Sol, La, do, re, mi(fa)로 되었고, 종자음 do가 '청'이라 이르므로 이것이 중심음으로 인식되며, 구성음 가운데 Sol, do, re가 출현빈도가 많은 중요음이 되고, Sol에서 떠는목(요성)을 쓰고, re에서 흘러내리는목(퇴성)을 쓰는 시김새로 된 토리로 보고자 하는 것이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 244] English B: “Lee covers note sets and cadence notes (i.e., the functions of each tone), frequency of occurrence (i.e., weight of each note and main melodic structures), and sigimsae (e.g., yoseong and toeseong) in explaining Ujo and Pyeongjo. Lee’s explanation is related to his theory of tori; he lists four components as criteria for distinguishing the tori of folk songs, constituent note set, each constituent note’s function, weight, and sigimsae (Lee 2000, 521–25).” Kim (2024) [3.19] English C:  a kind of sigimsae. slightly descending end of a sound (Pyǒn (2012) 177)Korean C: 어떤 음을 낸 다음 음의 끝을 아래로 끌어내리는 소리 (Pyǒn (2012) 177)

Adornos.text: Spanish A: “Las notas marcadas con asteriscos son adornos al mismo tema.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 17] English A: “The notes marked with asterisks are ornaments on the same theme.”Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 17] Spanish B: “Se llaman asi las apoyaturas, y otros gracejos que se agregan á las notas.” Palatín (1990) [p. 38]  Spanish C: “Con este nombre, ó el de FLOREOS, se designan las notas accesorias que embellecen la melodía, que son el ornato del canto, pero sin constituir la parte principal. Generalmente se consideran cuatro espeies: TRINO, GRUPETO, MORDENTE Y APOYATURA, y se indican por signos convencionales encima ó debajo de las notas, llamándose adorno superior ó inferior, según el sitio que ocupa.” Lacál (1900) [p. 9] (See also Pedrell (1890) [p. 8])

comparative.text: Source: “Music Theory has yet to catch up with field of Linguistics in being fully comparative, and is at least 108 years behind that field in my estimation: dating to the 1916 publication of Saussure’s Le Cours de linguistique générale, which established a theoretical framework rooted in the comparison of different languages, the arbitrariness of the sign, and the description of language as a communication system.” (Shumays commentary (2024) [1.3]) Definition: “Involving comparison of different branches of a science or subject of study; as comparative anatomy, comparative philology, etc.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “comparative”)

\u5ea6 do.text: Japanese A: “大部分の箇所では互に４度音程をなすこれら核音だけが、音階の主要音であり、抑制された旋律的表現が、これら核音の微妙なピッチの上下変化をもたらしている。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] Japanese B: “ 全 ⾳ 階 的 ⾳ 階 の 各 段 階 。 主 ⾳ を 第 1 度 と し 、 そ の 上 に 向 か っ て 第 2 度 ， 第 3 度 . . . と 数 え る 。② * ⾳ 程 を 測 る 単 位 。 五 線 譜 上 で は 同 じ 線 ま た は 間 （ ⽕ ） に あ る ⾳ ど う し の ⾳ を 1 度 と よ び 、 そ こ か ら 線 ま た は 間 が 隔 た る に し た が っ て 2 度 ，3 度 ・ ・ ・ ・ ・ と 数 え る” Tomosha (2002) [p. 443] English A: “In most places, only nuclear tones that make up the interval of a fourth [scale degree] with each other are the chief notes of the scale. Restrained melodic expression brings subtle changes of pitch to these nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.2, brackets added separately] Japanese C: “まず、装飾音です。装飾音から始めて、 だんだん揺れが大きくなって、場合によ ってはヴィヴラートが4度までいきます。 スタートする音に力を集めるために、装 飾音があるわけで、それ自体に意味はな いわけです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English C: “Now, it is a decorative tone. Beginning from the decorative tone, the trembling grows larger and, at times, the vibrato gets as wide as a fourth [scale degree]. The decorative tone exists to concentrate on the tone’s beginning, and it is meaningless by itself.” Park (2024) [4.1, brackets added separately]

meditation.text: Source: “Nri is a significant historic place in the history and mythology of the Igbo people as a cultural center, particularly because of the Nri priests and oracles’ leadership in odinaani (or odinala), which comprises Igbo religion and spirituality and related customs. The importance of the ubọ-aka for the Nri people in traditional practices, including prayer and meditation, is emphasized in Ezegbe’s dissertation (1977).” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.1] Definition: “The action or practice of profound spiritual or religious reflection or contemplation; spec. a variety of private devotional exercise consisting of the continuous application of the mind to the contemplation of a particular religious text, truth, mystery, or object.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “meditation”)

gnomic.text: Source: “Prakempa (and the related Aji Gurnita lontar)(2) are gnomic and cosmological, and unlikely to have been intended for any public.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “Of the nature of, or consisting of, gnomes or general maxims. Also spec. with reference to Old English verse. gnomic poet, a composer of gnomic verses.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “gnomic”)

\u30ca\u30c1\u30e5\u30fc\u30eb nach\u016.text: Japanese A: “"しかし、私の音楽が長時間緊張感を保っているということは、全くそのとおりなんです。私の音楽の根本をなしている線的な要素が、巧妙に持続性を持っており、そのナチュール自体が、持続の無限な可能性を持っているのです。たとえば能の音楽とか歌舞伎のように、何時間同じ線を聴いても絶対飽きない秘密がこれなんです." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

Zhongguo wenxue (1991).text: Zhongguo wenxue da cidian di we juan 中国文学大辞典 第五卷. Ma Liangchun 马良春, Li Futian 李福田 (eds.). Tianjin: tianjin renmin chuban she 天津:天津人民出版社, 1991.

choro.text: English A: “Métrica derramada appears frequently in the performance of popular Brazilian music, not only in songs such as samba, bossa nova, and so-called MPB, but also in essentially instrumental music. In instrumental choro, for example, there is a relative independence of parts, which intertwine without merging into a synchronized sound mass in terms of temporal division.” (Stover (2024) [5.1]) Portuguese A: “A métrica derramada aparece muito na performance da música brasileira popular, não só na canção como no samba, na bossa nova e na chamada MPB, como também em música essencialmente instrumental. No choro instrumental, por exemplo, existe uma relativa independência das partes, que se entrelaçam sem se fundirem numa massa sonora sincronizada em termos de divisão temporal.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B:  Portuguese C: “É o nome dado a pequenos conjuntos populares, formados com instrumentos de origem européia e africana. Tocam para dança ou simplesmente para audição. Encontram-se aproximações com o jazz norte-ameri-cano. O chôro vem apresentando peças vocais ligadas ao samba. Chôro é também a designação de bailaricos populares, conhecidos como assustados ou arrasta-pés. Recentemente, inventaram que o chôro é uma forma de composição - conceito evidentemente errado.” (Cosme (1957) 28)

semara nada.text: See semara  English A: “Rebab playing style is called buta anggawasari; its sound is semara nada.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.10]) See rebab, see buta anggawasari  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang rarebaban, buta anggawasari namanya. Semara nada nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Buta are potentially malevolent spirits that can be benevolent if properly placated; anggawasari combines anggawa, to bring, and sari, nectar or essence; thus, the essence-bringing buta. Nada are tones and semara is romantic or often erotic love. Geria thus associates the rebab with powerful human and unseen forces.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.9]) *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions(Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

merdukomala.text: English A: “Suling playing style is called tunjung arip, its sound is called merdukomala.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.11]) See suling  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang sasulingan, tunjung arip, merdukomala nama swaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Tunjung is lotus and arip is sleepy; suggesting that the flute finger holes opening and closing are like the lotus. Merdukomala is the name of an Old Javanese poetic meter; its constituent words merdu and komala both index sweetness, softness.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.10])

\u043c\u044f\u0440\u043a\u0430/myarka.text: See also мерки/myerki  Bulgarian A: Напротив, мярката на пайдушката 5/16, двойната мярка 7/16 (ръченица и македонско хоро),3 9/16 (тропливата игра или радомирското хоро), 11/16 (хайдушка игра) и др. там никак не се срещат. Hristov (1925) (p. 35) English A: “To the contrary, the time signature of 5/16 (paidushkata), both 7/16 time signatures (rŭchenitsa and makedonsko horo), 9/16 (troplivata igra or radomirskoto horo), 11/16 (haidushka igra), etc., are in no way found there.” Goldberg (2024) [2.7] Bulgarian B: “Мярка термин, използуван от първите български музиканти през миналия век (Байданов и др.) със значение на размер * (такт*). Напр. мярка 3/4, мярка 4/4 и др.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 205]

mel\u00f4s.text: English A: “Both in these “melôs” and in the case of rap in Portuguese, two prosodic issues appear. First is the use in Portuguese of a metric typical of English, that is, of regularly spaced thetic accents, which contributes to a sensation of regular measures. And second, there is the issue of successive ruptures typical of rap, produced by scratches, which makes music more of a “rhythmic partnership” than an complete interconnection between lyrics and melody (see Rose 1997, 207–8).” (Stover (2024) [3.5]) Portuguese A: “Tanto nestas "melôs", quanto no caso do rap em português vão aparecer duas questões prosódicas: primeiro, a utilização no português de uma métrica própria do ingles, isto é, de acentuações téticas regularmente espaçadas, o que contribui para uma sensação de compassos regulares. Segundo, é a questão das rupturas sucessivas próprias do rap, produzidas pelos "scratchs", o que faz da música mais uma "parceria rítmica" do que um todo interligado de letra e melodia (vide Rose 1997: 207-8).” (Ulhôa (1999))

aling-aling.text: English: “An aling-aling is a wall at the gateway to almost all Balinese homes that forces someone coming in to turn immediately left or right. Its purpose is to prevent buta kala (malevolent powers believed to travel only in straight lines) from entering. This is one of two of Geria’s ubit-ubitan that does not feature interlocking rhythms. The three-note motive 123 in the polos (523 in the sangsih) repeats throughout, constantly backing up and trying again like a buta kala ramming into an aling-aling. At the end, at last, the 3 of the sangsih and polos aligns with the gending.” Tenzer (2024) [4.5] *Lexical field: cultural practice or unseen phenomenon (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) Balinese B: “Tatorekan, 1, hanyekati, 2, hagegelut, 3, hababelit, 4, uder-uderan, 5, tulak wangsul, 6, aling-aling, 7, habeburu, 8, hate-tungkangan, 9, ajejepit, 10, anyarang paksi ngaran. Mangkana kramanya,denya anati mantra lingga mwang catur mantralingga. Mangkana kalinganya.” (Bandem (1986), 70) English B (Chat-GPT Translation): “Rhythmic Variations (Tatorekan) These are the ten fundamental rhythmic movements in Angklung performance: Thus, these are the techniques and rhythmic principles. This system follows Mantra Lingga (sacred sound structures) and Catur Mantra Lingga (fourfold sacred sound principles). Thus, it is understood.”

\u4e00\u5143 Ichigen.text: Japanese A: "しかし私の音楽はすべての流れ、本流も支流もすべてが一ル的なんです。一九」というのはここではちょっと当てはまりませんけれども、仮定して言葉を使うとすれば、そういうように線的な形態が同じ原則、同じ美学的な立場で流れていて、そのたくさんの流れの、一々の形態が同一性を持っているのです。しかも、それが分断的に使用されても、集めればその同一性の根源が得られるわけです。" (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) English A: "But in my music, all flows are uniform, whether it is the mainstream or branch. “Uniform” [一元] may not be the best word. To use it here because of the lack of a better term, various lines flow through according to the same principle and aesthetic perspective, and the individual lines are in accordance with each other. In addition, even when a single line is used separately [分斷的], when combined, the uniformity emerges from them." (Park (2024) [2.1])

movimento em graus conjuntos.text: English A: “Finally, another interpretive move may be a change in frequency; higher notes have more tension and are more prominent than lower notes; leaps attract more attention than stepwise movement. Therefore, when considering the interpretive practice of song, we must keep in mind that musical prosody is not just a matter of strong or weak beats.” (Stover (2024) [5.11]) Portuguese A: “Finalmente, outro movimento interpretativo pode ser uma mudança em frequência; notas mais agudas apresentam mais tensão e aparecem mais que notas mais graves; saltos atraem mais atenção que movimento em graus conjuntos. Portanto, ao considerar a prática interpretativa da canção, devemos ter em mente, que a prosódia musical não é somente uma questão de tempos fortes ou fracos.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u6b4c\u821e\u4f0e kabuki.text: Japanese A: “"しかし、私の音楽が長時間緊張感を保っているということは、全くそのとおりなんです。私の音楽の根本をなしている線的な要素が、巧妙に持続性を持っており、そのナチュール自体が、持続の無限な可能性を持っているのです。たとえば能の音楽とか歌舞伎のように、何時間同じ線を聴いても絶対飽きない秘密がこれなんです."
