(Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

rhyme scheme.text: Source: “The poetic meters and rhyme schemes of these verses likely helped dancer-drummer ritualists to compose and memorize them.” (Peiris (2024) [1.3])

asti aturu.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat kutus asti aturu ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “and if eight, asti aturu [sleeping elephant].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8])

Koizumi Fumio (1958).text: Koizumi Fumio 小泉文夫. [1958] 1977. Nihon dentō ongaku no kenkyū 日本傳統音楽の研究 [Research on Japanese Traditional Music], 10th printing. Ongaku no Tomo Sha.

\uc544\uc545 aak.text: Korean A: “윤형이상학적인 것은 아니지만 예컨대 「예악」은 아악의 요소를 갖고 있습니다. 한국에서도 그렇고 일본에서도 그렇지만 아악은 거의 인간세계를 초월한 세계를 표현합니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 159] English A: “It is not metaphysical, per se. For example, Reak contains elements from A-ak. It is the case in both Korea and Japan that A-ak largely expresses the world mostly beyond the human realm for me.” Park (2024) [5.2]  Korean B: “"그런 민족적 측면에 대해 좀더 구체적으로 여쭤보고 싶습니다만, 예를 들어 선생님은 한국의 아악에서 받으신 영향은 없으신지요? 저는 선생님 작품에서 그런 걸 느낍니다만·•··••." …"말씀하신 그대로입니다. 일본의 아악은 한국에서 전래된 부산 과 중국에서 전래된 부분이 있는데, 한국의 아악과는 내용상 약간 질이 달라요. " ( Yun (1991) - Korean, 147) English B: “"For example, have you been influenced by Korean A-ak [Korean ceremonial court music]? I can sense its influence in your pieces. . ." "Exactly as you said. Japanese court music has parts that are imported from Korea and parts that are from China. But its contents are qualitatively different from Korean A-ak." (Park (2024) [1.3]) Korean C: “구월양로연아악(九月養老宴雅樂)·동지(冬至雅樂)·정조아악(正朝雅樂)・ 광원양로연아악(八月養老麥雅樂) 우리나라 궁중음악의 한 갈래, 좁은 의미의 아악은 제례음악 을 뜻하지만, 근래 넓은 의미로는 궁중음악을 의미한다. ① 12율의 궁조(宮調: 궁선법)만을 쓴다고 악조총의(樂調總義)에 나온다. 아악은 궁·상·각·변치·치·우·변궁의 7음을 사용하 고, 아악의 음은 낮아서 황종이 12을 중에서 첫 음이라고 악조총의에 설명되었다.” Song (2010) [p. 204] English D: a ritual and ceremonial court music (Pyǒn (2012) 119) Korean D:

\u63fa\u308c y\u014dre.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 、 先 ⽣ の 作 品 の 線 的 な 語 法 の も と に な っ て い る わ け で す ね 。 微 分 ⾳ 的 な 細 か い 揺 れ か ら 3 度 以 上 の シ ェ イ ク に ⾄ る よ う な 、 独 特 な 線 の 動 き は 、 韓 国 の 歌 唱 の ⽅ 法 か ら ⽣ み 出 さ れ た も の と 考 え て い い わ け で す ね .” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4]) Japanese B: “本来，同一音高上の「震動」を意味した。①声楽では、同一音高の急速な反復。② 弦楽器では、弓を急速に上下して出す同一音の急速な反復。または弓を返さずに演奏される、急速な2音の交替。③ピアノでは、8度や5度などの音程を急速に反復するもの。または同一音の急速な連打。” (Tomosha (2002)p, 465)

pulsa\u00e7\u00f5es.text: English A: “Meter allows several voices to present a homogeneous (musical) discourse by providing an internal organization of pulsations into strong beats, propelling energy, and weak, inertial beats.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “O compasso permite que várias vozes possam apresentar um discurso homogêneo ao propor a organização interna das pulsações em tempos fortes, propulsores de energia e tempos fracos e inerciais.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “In Portuguese versification, the verse is the metric measure, while the syllables, the minimal pulsations, are combined in varied rhythmic groupings. Comparing this metric organization of spoken language with Western and non-Western musical metric organization, we can say that the prosody of Portuguese verse is more like a sub-Saharan African metric notion (composed of periods or “time lines” without recurring accents) than a classical-romantic European metric notion (whose measures of determined limits follow one another regularly [see Example 3.1 - translator’s note]).” (Stover (2024) [3.4]) Portuguese B: “Portanto, na versificação portuguesa, o verso é a medida métrica, enquanto as sílabas, as pulsações mínimas, são combinadas em agrupamentos rítmicos variados. Comparando esta organização métrica da língua falada e a organização métrica musical ocidental e não-ocidental podemos dizer que a prosódia do verso português está mais para uma noção métrica africana sub-saarana (composta de períodos ou "time lines" sem acentos recorrentes), que para uma noção métrica européia clássico-romântica (cujos compassos de limites determinados, se sucedem regularmente).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u4f5c\u66f2\u5bb6 sakkyokka.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

\ud1a0\ub9ac tori.text: Korean A: “판소리에서 평조라는 것은 기본 선율들이 Sol-do-re-do와 같은 경우가 많으므로 기본 선율형에서 이 들의 구성음이 Sol, La, do, re, mi(fa)로 되었고, 종자음 do가 '청'이라 이르므로 이것이 중심음으로 인식되며, 구성음 가운데 Sol, do, re가 출현빈도가 많은 중요음이 되고, Sol에서 떠는목(요성)을 쓰고, re에서 흘러내리는목(퇴성)을 쓰는 시김새로 된 토리로 보고자 하는 것이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 244] English A: “Lee covers note sets and cadence notes (i.e., the functions of each tone), frequency of occurrence (i.e., weight of each note and main melodic structures), and sigimsae (e.g., yoseong and toeseong) in explaining Ujo and Pyeongjo. Lee’s explanation is related to his theory of tori; he lists four components as criteria for distinguishing the tori of folk songs, constituent note set, each constituent note’s function, weight, and sigimsae (Lee 2000, 521–25).” Kim (2024) [3.19] English B: characteristic musical style or mode in specific region (Pyǒn (2012) 90) Korean B: 지역성이 가미된 대표적이고 특징적인 음악 어법을 지칭하는 용 어. 어떤 지방의 대표적인 기층 음악 어법. 특히 민속 음악에 있어서 각 지방의 특징 있는 기본 음악 표현 양식을 일컫는다.전라도의 민속 음악은 육자배기토리로 되었다든지 평안도의 무 가는 수심가토리로 되었다는 것이 그러한 말의 용례이다. 대개 는 각 지방의 대표적인 민요를 중심으로 표현하는데, 창부타령 토리는 주로 경기와 서울 지방의 민속 음악에 나타나며, 육자배 기토리는 전라도, 수심가토리는 평안도와 황해도, 메나리토리는 강원도와 경상도 그리고 함경도의 민속 음악에 나타난다. 토리 와 가까운 다른 말은 '조해'이다. 따라서 육자배기토리를 육자배 기조라고도 한다. '토리'나 '조'라는 말을 분석해 보면, 그 말에 는 선율의 음악 구조상의 문제인 선법적 개념과 표현하는 소리 의 성상의 구조인 창법적 개념이 복합되어 있다. 육자배기토 리로 되었다라는 말은 육자배기와 같은 선율 구조로 되어 있으 며 육자배기를 부르는 특징있는 창법으로 부른다는 뜻이다. (Pyǒn (2012) 91)

tanuva.text: English A: “These caesurae that are added into the poetic meter during performance are known as yati. While this sung elongation of syllables veils the rhythm implied by the poetic meter, the rhythmic structure of the melody remains closely tied to the poetic meter, as the melody (Sin. tanuva) needs to accommodate all the syllables in the text. While oral poets may have not consciously engaged with literary theories of yati when deciding which syllables to elongate in performance, the act of choosing which stock melody to use to sing a verse requires an implicit analytic understanding of how the morae in the poetic text are grouped.” Peiris (2024) [17] English B: “tune” (Peiris (2025))

angklung gamelan.text: English A: “The technique of playing gendér in the gamelan angklung is called capung manjus.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.8]) See angklung gamelan  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Pukulan gendér angklung, capung manjus namanya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The ubiquitous angklung gamelan has a four-tone scale and instruments with but four keys—a single octave. Though its music can be complex the instrument is quick to navigate. Capung manjus means bathing dragonfly; an idiom describing a “water-skimming” quick bath for a person as well.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.7]) Balinese C: “Iti Swara patutan Catur, ingambil ring Sapta swara Genta Pi-nara Pitu ngaran, iki kang rumanjing ring Angklung, apan sapta swara iki kewaseaken angwetuaken salwiring swara papatutan sami, marmanya hana papatutan tiga, Iwirnya; yan ring patut Pelog, Demung, Salisir mwang Sundari. Yan ring Patut Slendro yaika, Pudak Sategal, Sekar Kemoning mwang Asep Cina.Patutan iki kang umanjing ring Gender Pawayangan, RingPajogedan mwang ring sarwa Pupuh-pupuh sami.” (Bandem (1986), 58) English C (Chat GPT Translation): “These are the four classifications of sound (Swara Patutan Catur), derived from the Seven Tones of the Sacred Bell (Sapta Swara Genta Pinara Pitu). These sounds are present in the Angklung (a traditional bamboo instrument), as the seven tones have the power to produce all forms of classified sounds. Because of this, there are three main groupings, as follows: These classifications of sound are used in Gender Wayang (the metallophone used in shadow puppetry), in dance performances (Pajogedan), and in all forms of Pupuh (traditional sung poetry).”

Sonido.text: Spanish A: “Tal ampliación sólo será posible si el oído humano logra oír y distinguir claramente sonidos producidos por 131,072 vibraciones en un segundo.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 27] English A: “Such an expanded musical range will be possible only if the human ear manages to hear, and to distinguish clearly, sounds produced at 131,072 cycles per second.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 27] Spanish B: “…Ofrenda musical y su Arte de la fuga, las maravillas más estupendas que produjo el clasicismo en los campos de la técnica musical del sistema de los 12 sonidos.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 16] English B: “…Musical Offering and his Art of the Fugue, the greatest wonders classicism produced under the musical techniques of the twelve-note musical system.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 16] Spanish C: “El especial movimiento, impresion ó conmocion del aire herido y agitado de algun cuerpo ó del choque ó colusion de dos ó mas cuerpos que se persibe por el oido.” Palatín (1990) [p. 95-96] Spanish D: “Es un a sensación producida en los órganos auditivos por la víbracíon de los cuerpos en un medio elástico, tanto sólido ó líquido como gaseoso. De esto resulta que el sonido no se propaga en el vacío. El aire ú otro agente elástico, es el vehículo que trasmite al oido las vibraciones del cuerpo sonoro y nos las hace apreciar como sonido ó como ruido.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 425] Spanish E: Lacál (1900) [p. 490-497]:

\uc120\uc801 seonjeog.text: Korean A: “그것이 선생님 작품의 선적 어법의 밑바탕 이 되어 있군요. 미분음적인 미세한 흔들림으로부터 3 도 이상의 전음(숍)에 이르는 독특한 선의 움직임은 한국의 가창.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

Wang commentary (2024).text: Wang, Dan. “Commentary: Reversed Images.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4 (2024).

gagulet.text: English: “IV.2 through IV.5 can be discussed together since they are similar and all paired with the same oscillating two-note gending pattern. Gagelut and gagulet are assonant synonyms meaning hug, embrace, or even wrestle. The patterns are of a subtype called ubitan telu (telu = three) in which the two parts use a total of three tones, sharing an inner tone; hence embracing. These are indeed ubiquitous in the repertoire. Kabelit and kabelet, similarly related as words, mean stuck, stubborn, unmoving. They are of subtype called ubitan empat (empat = four) in which the two parts use two different but scale-adjacent tones each. When sounded the lower tone of the polos and the upper tone of the sangsih coincide, creating a dyad that protrudes from the texture to create a syncopated  3+2+3 cross-rhythm (the greyed notes). While the inner tones jostle, this prominent interval is “stuck” in its place.” Tenzer (2024) [4.6] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) See: gagelut

middle C.text: Source: “On a central, one-line staff, Carrillo placed all pitches belonging to the register of Middle C, and above and below that staff, in relation to two small ledger lines, he placed pitches of other registers. By using this notation, Carrillo could flexibly accommodate any of the equal temperaments in his arsenal.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.6] Definition: “A colloquial name for the note c′ whose pitch is 256 Hz when a′ = 440 Hz. It is probably so called because it is written on a leger line midway between two staves bearing a treble and bass clef respectively. It is also placed roughly at the middle of the keyboard; further, it is near the top of the male vocal range and near the bottom of the female range.” (Grove Music Online, “Middle C”)

\u65cb\u5f8b senritsu.text: Japanese A: “このようなばあい、終止音は一方からは単に楽曲の終止音としての意味ばかりでなく、旋律線の上下動における中核的な意味を持つという理由で、他方では、連続的にくり返されるべき性質の「数え唄」や「網引唄」の中には、かならずしも終止音に終らない旋律も多いという理由で（そのばあいですら旋律線の中核的意味を失わない）、終止音とよぶより中核音または単に核音とよぶ方が適当ではないだろうか。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] Japanese B: “⾳ の 連 続 的 な ⾼ 仏 変 化 が 、 リ ス ム と 組 み 合 わ さ れ 、 あ る ま と ま った ⾳ 楽 的 表 現 を ⽣ み だ し て い る も の 。 西 洋 ⾳ 楽 で は 、 旋 律 は * リ ズ ム や * 和 声 と と も に 、 ⾳ 楽 の 三 要 素 と よ ば れ て き た 。 し か し 旋 律 は リ ズ ム や 和 声 に 対 し て ⾃ ⽴ 性 を も っ て い る わ け で は な く 、 旋 律 は リ ズ ム と 不 可 分 の 関 係 で 成 ⽴ し 、 ま た 和 声 進 ⾏ が 律 線 の 輪 郭 を 決 定 す る こ と も あ る .” Tomosha (2002) [p. 368]Tomoshap368.pdf English A: “In cases like these, the ending note on the one hand holds meaning not only as a simple ending note to the piece, but also holds meaning as a central nucleus of upward and downward movement in the melodic line. On the other hand, among songs like “Counting Song” and “Net-Pulling Song” whose melodies tend to be repeated continuously, there are many songs with melodies that certainly do not end on the ending note (even in those cases, the ending notes do not lose the meaning of a central nucleus of the melodic line). For that reason, rather than calling them ending notes, it may be more appropriate to call them central nuclear tones or simply nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024)  [2.1]

\ub2e83\ub3c4 dan 3 do.text:
단+ 3 + 도 do  단: minor 
 Korean A: “때문에 백대웅의 이론을 활용하여 판소리 악조를 분석할 경우, 본청과 상청의 음정이 장3도인 경우에는 우조로, 본청과 상청의 음정이 완전4도인 경우에는 평조로 판별한다. 이를 상본청과 상청의 음정 간격 으로 다시 설명하면, 상본청과 상청의 음정이 장2도인 경우에는 우조로, 상본청과 상청의 음정 이 단3도인 경우에는 평조로 해석되는 것이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238] English A: “Therefore, if the gap between boncheong and sangcheong is a major 3rd, it is analyzed as Ujo according to Baek’s theory. If the interval between the two notes is a perfect 4th, it is Pyeongjo. In other words, a major 2nd between sangboncheong and sangcheong is Ujo, and a minor 3rd is Pyeongjo.” Kim (2024) [3.8]

\u6c38\u9060 eien.text: Japanese A: “「ハウプト・トン」における陰と陽の相 対的な変化は、微細な時間によるとらえ 方から巨大な時間によるとらえ方までい ろいろな段階があります。そこでは瞬間 に永遠が反映され、永遠を瞬間としてつ かむことができるわけです。それが東洋人の「時」の考え方で、西 洋人の「時」の考え方と全く違うところ なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u660e\u308b\u3044 akarui.text: Japanese A: “Bbは、ただの準備の音です。しかし、 このDを生ませるために長3度が生じま す。長3度は明るい音程です。それで、 暗い音から明るい音になります。という ことは、少しずつ光が入ってくるという。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “The Bb is just a tone for preparation. But, in order to create D, a major third is created. A major third is a bright interval. So, a dark tone becomes a bright tone. It is like light is peeking through little by little.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u7d42\u6b62\u97f3 sh\u016bshi-on.text: 終止+音 oto  終止: termination, cessation, stop Japanese A: “このようなばあい、終止音は一方からは単に楽曲の終止音としての意味ばかりでなく、旋律線の上下動における中核的な意味を持つという理由で、他方では、連続的にくり返されるべき性質の「数え唄」や「網引唄」の中には、かならずしも終止音に終らない旋律も多いという理由で（そのばあいですら旋律線の中核的意味を失わない）、終止音とよぶより中核音または単に核音とよぶ方が適当ではないだろうか。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “In cases like these, the ending note on the one hand holds meaning not only as a simple ending note to the piece, but also holds meaning as a central nucleus of upward and downward movement in the melodic line. On the other hand, among songs like “Counting Song” and “Net-Pulling Song” whose melodies tend to be repeated continuously, there are many songs with melodies that certainly do not end on the ending note (even in those cases, the ending notes do not lose the meaning of a central nucleus of the melodic line). For that reason, rather than calling them ending notes, it may be more appropriate to call them central nuclear tones or simply nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1]

Diat\u00f3nico.text: Spanish A: “Se aplica á uno de los tres generos del sistema músico, que procede por dos tonos y un semitono.” Palatín (1990) [p. 58] (See also Escala diatónica mayor) Spanish B: “Género de música que procede por tonos y que se aplica, sin embargo, á la escala moderna á pesar de contener dos semitonos.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 136] Spanish C: “Del griego Dia, entre, y tonos, tono. Lo que pro - cede por tonos y semitonos naturales. - Así se dice: ESCALA DIATÓNICA É INTERVALO DIATÓNICO. Algunos escritores han dicho que el sistema musical moderno emplea el género DIATÓNICO, El CROMÁTICO y el ENARMÓNICO. En nuestro concepto no es así: el único género que se emplea es el diatónico, aunque algunas veces lo modifiquen el cromático y muy raramente el enarmónico, que no se han aplicado exclusivamente a ninguna composición moderna, ni podrían formar por sí solos un verdadero género.” Lacál (1900) [p. 154] (See also: Escala diatónica mayor)

Timbre.text: Spanish A: “Se dice de la calidad del sonido por la cual es agrio ó dulce, sordo ó claro, seco ó agradable.” Palatín (1990) [p. 99] Spanish B: “Es cierta cualidad general del sonido qu es dificil definir, ni es de creer que pueda ser definida. Es pura cuestión de oído. Por el timbre distinguimos el sonido que resulta del choque de una piedra, del que resulta del choque de un cuerpo blando ó líuquido…” Pedrell (1890) [p. 455]  Spanish C: “Es una cualidad del sonido; pero independiente de la altura y de la intensidad. Cada instrumento, cada voz tiene su timbre especial como cada persona tiene su fisonomía. El la de una flauta, no tiene el mismo carácter que el la de una trompeta; y aun en un mismo inst. no resuena un sonido del mismo modo si se cambia el modo de producirlo; así, por ej., el la dado en un violín por la cuerda que vibre en toda su longitud, no es idéntico al la que se obtiene pisando con el 4°. dedo la cuerda del re.” Lacál (1900) [p. 535]

\ucef4\ud4e8\ud130 \uc74c\uc545 keompyut.text:
컴퓨터 + 음악 eumak  컴퓨터: computer 
 Korean A: “그러나 새로운 미디어의 음악, 예컨대 컴퓨터 음악, 그런 창작에서는 연주 가와의 관계가 없다고 생각됩니다만, 그런 점에 관해서 선생님의 의견은 어떠하신지요? 간단히 말해서 컴퓨터 음악을 어떻게 생각하 십니까?” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 163] English A: “But compositions in new media, for example, computer music, do not have much relationship with the performers. What do you think about this aspect? In short, what do you think about computer music?” Park (2024) [7.2]

gajah mina.text: English A: “Gajah mina is a legendary fish with an elephant’s head, a traditional image of which festoons cremation towers for people in certain Balinese lineages. The reyong’s main musical function is to embellish melody, and the character of gajah mina is understood as wanting to follow, accompany, escort—and in this case via cremation—to the next world.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.3]) See reyong  English B: “Reyong technique is called gajah mina [a legendary fish].” (Tenzer (2024) [II.3]) Balinese/Indonesian B: “Pukulan rareyongan, iwak magajah mina namanya.” (Geria (n.d.)) *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions and cultural practice or unseen phenomenon (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) Balinese C: “Iti haraning Gagebug.Yaning gagebug gong, Kaget atangi ngaran Bhuhloka nada ngaran. Yaning gagebug trompong Sekar Tanjungsusun nga-ran, denya angembat silih asih. Ikang gagebug babarangan Sad-pada angaras santun ngaran, mwang babancangan, Tadah rasmi araning swara. Ikang gagebug rariyongan I Gajahmina ngaran.Ikang gagebug giying, Tuntun Rasmi ngaran. Ikang gagebug pemade mwang kantil, I Talutur mwang sadulur ngaran. Ikang gagebug gender rambat Ekatanu mwang aninglas ngaran.” (Bandem (1986), 68)

atrasados.text: English A: “These metric spaces are very difficult to illustrate with conventional Western notation. Ethnomusicologists have created signs to express these “early” or “late” attacks.“ (Stover (2024) [5.5]) Portuguese A: “Estes espaços métricos são muito difíceis de demonstrar com a notação ocidental convencional. Etnomusicólogos têm criado sinais para expressar estes ataques "adiantados" ou "atrasados". “ (Ulhôa (1999))

oral transmission.text: Source: “This article aims to broaden common understandings of music theory through the lens of orally transmitted ritualistic verses from Sri Lanka, which are sung or recited along with drumming. I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “Competence in oral language; the ability to express oneself fluently and grammatically in speech. Also: the oral transmission of culture, ideas, etc.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “oracy”)

agent.text: Source: “In the context of Brazilian popular song, the vocalist is the agent that stretches the structural boundaries of the accompaniment. According to Ulhôa, the secret to this feel is that the vocalist turns to language-related features of the melody, phrasing the lyrics not solely according to the musical context but also according to the prosody of the words, or, in Ulhôa’s terminology, “one’s manner of accentuating words in speech.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [2]) Definition: “A person who or thing which acts upon someone or something; one who or that which exerts power; the doer of an action. Sometimes contrasted with the patient (instrument, etc.) undergoing the action.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “agent” 1a)

\uc81c1\uc8fc\uc81c\ubd80\ubd84 je1jujeb.text:
제1 + 주제 + 부분 제1: the first 주제: theme 부분: part 
 Korean A: “니시무라 시(時)에 대한 사고방식이 형식관(形式觀)에 반영된 예로서 서양에는 소나타 형식이 있습니다만, 소나타 형식이라고 하면 제1주제부가 있고 제2주제부가 있다. 이들은 대립된 구간(區間)이며 제2주제 부분은 제1주제와 다른 시간을 독자적으로 형성하 는 것이기 때문에 순간에 세계를 갖는 음양과는 전혀 다르다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157-158] English A: “The Sonata form might be one example that reflects the Western formalistic view of time. In Sonata form, there are primary and secondary theme areas. They are contrasting sections that independently develop [the sense of] time. Therefore, it is completely different from yin and yang, which contain an eternity in a moment.” Park (2024) [4.2]

\u0434\u0443\u043c\u0438\u0442\u0435/dum.text: Bulgarian A: “Голям научен интерес представлява тя и по своята старинност, което личи от извънредно оригиналния ритъм, от разнообразните тоналности, от тоновия обем (амбитуса), който често е диахорд, а тъй също от съдържанието на думите.” Hristov (1925) (p. 34) English A: “It also represents great scholarly interest in terms of its age, which is indicated by the exceptionally original rhythm, by the diversity of tonalities, by the tonal range (ambitus), which is often a diachord, as well as by the content of the lyrics.” Goldberg (2024) [2.5]

hazie.text: Igbo A: “M nwete ya, m ma na m hazite ya. Ọ ka e si ahazi ihe gbo. Ị hazie ya, ọ bụlu n’ichọ iji ya kwuo okwu, Ị hazicha ya, ị kwuonu okwu ahu Ihe ị kwuru dabaa, ị ma na ị hazitego ya.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “ When I get the music, I will know that the tuning is correct. That is how tuning is done in the olden days. When you tune it, if you want to do speech surrogacy with it, after tuning it, you use it to say what you want to say. If what you say sounds correct, then you know that the tuning is correct.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] Igbo B: “Tuning ya dị iche n’iche/O tu anyị si hazi nke anyị dị iche, e tu ha si hazi nke ha dị iche” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) English B: “Their tuning system is unique from ours/The way we tune ours is unique, the way they tune theirs is unique.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

\uc608\uc220\uac00\uace1 Yesulgagog.text: 예술: art  가곡 Gagok : Korean art song Korean A: “ 그리고 한국에는 엄격한 입장을 취하는 아악과는 변도 로, 송정음악도 사원음악도 아니면서 일반대중과 상류사회가 공유해 온, 서양에서 볼 수 있듯이 지식사회에서 즐겨온 음악세계가 있어 요. 그리고 또 예술가곡• 예술민요라고 합니다만 그런 것이 또 있어 요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean,147) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3])

yati.text: English A: “These caesurae that are added into the poetic meter during performance are known as yati. While this sung elongation of syllables veils the rhythm implied by the poetic meter, the rhythmic structure of the melody remains closely tied to the poetic meter, as the melody (Sin. tanuva) needs to accommodate all the syllables in the text. While oral poets may have not consciously engaged with literary theories of yati when deciding which syllables to elongate in performance, the act of choosing which stock melody to use to sing a verse requires an implicit analytic understanding of how the morae in the poetic text are grouped.” Peiris (2024) [17] English B: “designated elongation within poetic meter” (Peiris (2025))

\ud558\ud589\uc131 hahaengseong.text: Korean A: “그러나 이보다 더 동적인 경우도 있고 더 정적인 경우도 있어요. 또 상승성(上昇性)을 갖는 경우와 하행싱 을 갖는 경우가 있습니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “But there are cases where it is more active or more static. Also, there are cases where it has a tendency upward and downward.” Park (2024) [4.1]

Compositor.text: Spanish A: “…o sea que la mentalidad de los compositores estaba dominada por la idea de escribir temas con variaciones, idea absolutamente excluída de mis Leyes, pues la característica de ellas es que jamás se agrega ni suprime ninguna nota a las composiciones originales metamorfoseadas.”  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] English A: “Composers’ thinking has been dominated by the idea of writing themes and variations, an idea absolutely excluded from my Laws, because their defining characteristic is that no note is ever added or removed from compositions that are metamorphosed.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] Spanish B: “El que hace composiciones músicas.” Palatín (1990) [p. 51] Spanish C: “El que compone. –– El que sahe escribir composiciones músicas según las reglas del arte.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 106] Spanish D: “En general es el que produce obras de arte ó de literatura; pero se aplica casi exclusivamente al que compone música aplicando las reglas de la armonía, las del contrapunto, las cualidades de la voz, las de los instrumentos, etc. Los que hacen música sin conocer los preceptos cientificos, no son, en nuestro concepto, verdaderos compositores. Para merecer este título, débese dar pruebas de suficiencia en la música de capilla, en la dramática y en la instrumental.” Lacál (1900) [p. 131]

mbira.text: English A: “They call it mbira/It is popular in their place/It appears that mbira is more popular and available in Zimbabwe than the guitar./Because it is found in many places/They do not play with it/And they use it to communicate with the spirits/When the Shona people of Zimbabwe want to commune with their departed ancestors/It is mbira that they use.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Ha nwa na-akpọ ya Mbira/Be ha, ọ dị ri’nne,/Ọ na-adị m ka ọ dị be ha, ka Mbira ahu o dị be ha karia guitar. Maka o di rinne, Ha ejidighị ya egwu egwu/And ha na ndị mmuo na-eji ya akpakari ụka. Ndị Shona na Zimbabwe, ha chọrọ ifu ndị nna nna ha ndị ochie gagoro aga, Ọ bụ mbira ka ha na etinye aka na ya.”(Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

din\u00e2mica.text: English A: “Note that it is a prominent duration, and not a dynamic accentuation that achieves this, since, especially in Brazilian Portuguese, the accents of the words are quite attenuated by the “soft and sing-song” intonation of the pronunciation spoken in Brazil.” (Stover (2024) [5.5]) Portuguese A: “Observe-se que é uma proeminência e não uma acentuação dinâmica, uma vez que, especialmente no português brasileiro os acentos das palavras são bastante atenuados pela entoação "macia e cantada" da pronúncia falada no Brasil.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “In measured tonal music, although dynamics play a central role, duration and frequency (both in pitch class and harmony) also contribute to musical accentuation.” (Stover (2024) [5.10]) Portuguese B: “Na música medida tonal, embora a dinâmica tenha um papel central, duração e freqüência (tanto em classe de altura quanto harmonia) também contribuem para a acentuação musical.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese C: “Compreendem-se, como dinâmica, os sinais de intensidade.” (Cosme (1957), 42)

\uc7a5\uc2dd\uc74c jangsigeum.text:
장식 + 음 eum  장식: decoration, ornament 
 Korean A: “이 음에는 장식음이 없습니다. 그러나 셋잇단음표 첫머리의 쉼표가 그걸 대신하는 역할을 하지요. 그에 이어 장식선율적인 요소 가 있지요. 이것은 좀더 발전한 '하우프트톤'의 자태입니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “There is no decorative tone for this. But the first rest of the triplet substitutes its role. It is followed by a melismatic element. This is a more developed figure of a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1] Korean B: “그러나 백대웅의 이론에서 설명하고 있는 평조 각 음의 기능과 특징인, "하본청의 출현 빈 도가 적음, 하청과 본청의 4도 진행, 본청과 상본청의 2도 진행이 자주 나타남, 하청에 떠는 성질이 있음, 상본청은 본청으로 흘러내리거나, 가볍게 떨거나, 상청을 전타음처럼 사용하는 장식음을 가짐, 창자에 따라 상청의 음정이 불안하여 반음 낮게 노래하는 이도 있음"의 다섯 가지 특징을 표기하면 아래 <악보 8>과 같이 된다. 그리고 이는 이보형이 토리론으로 설명하는 판소리 중중모리-평조와 매우 상통한다.” Shin (2018) [p. 246] English B: “The individual notes that make up Pyeongjo have a set of purposes and features in accordance with Baek’s theory (Example 2.10). “1) haboncheong appears less often, 2) the frequent occurrence of the fourth interval progression between hacheong and boncheong and the second interval progression between boncheong and sangboncheong, 3) the property of vibration in hacheong, 4) sangboncheong flows down to boncheong, trembles lightly, or uses sancheong as an appoggiatura, and 5) some of the performers sing sangcheong a semitone lower because of its unstable pitch.” These five characteristics correlate to Lee’s jungjungmori-Pyeongjo, which he explains using a tori theory.” Kim (2024) [3.27]

\u58f0 sh\u0113ng.text: Chinese: “声音；声响. 指音乐、诗歌. 指言语.” Hanyu dacidian (声, 1–3) English: “The first of these is sheng, which will be translated as "sound" (on one or two occasions as "voices"). It is translated this way because what it represents is audible sounds which — while they may in themselves carry the most basic form of meaning or expressive content, such as with a human scream or the call of an animal — are considered only in isolation, not bearing any relation as yet to other sounds.” Cook (1995)  “In all cases, the arising of music (yin) is born in the hearts of men. The movement of men's hearts is made so by (external] things. They are touched off by things and move, thus they take shape in [human] sound (sheng). Sounds respond to each other, and thus give birth to change. Change forms a pattern, and this is called music (yin). The music is brought close and found enjoyable, and reaches the point of shields and axes, feathers and pennants, and this is called Music (yue).” Cook (1995) (1.1) (See: 音 yīn, 乐 yuè) For further discussion, see Li (2024) [2.7]

Zhongguo minjian (2006).text: Zhongguo minjian yishu da cidian 中国民间艺术大辞典. Liu Bo 刘波 (ed.). Beijing: Wenhua yishu chuban she 北京:文化艺术出版社, 2006.

tempo linear.text: English A: “In this case, the beginning of the measure is very important, as it presupposes a notion of linear time, of energy that progresses in an organized and predictable manner.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “Neste caso o início do compasso é muito importante pois pressupõe uma noção de tempo linear, de energia que progride organizada e previsivelmente.” (Ulhôa (1999))

varna.text: Sinhalese A: “pǟma palamu tavatatyana padayaṭa varna (වර්න ) noyek , bändī” (Peiris (2024) [6.4]) English A: “when this happened, other colors [timbres?] became tied to the first sound “tat”” (Peiris (2024) [6.4])

kaget asih.text: English A: “The technique of playing reyong in the gamelan angklung is called kaget asih.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.9]) See reyong, angklung gamelan  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Pukulan reyong angklung, kaget asih namanya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “This means sudden love or crush and evokes the same deft quickness as II.8 (capung manjus) The four tones of each octave of the angklung’s reyong are played by pairs of musicians—perhaps a matchmaking opportunity.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.8]) *Lexical field: Emotions or character (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) Balinese D: “Iti gagebug Angklung.Gagebug Angklung Kumbang atarun Gambans Faclah asih aran, ing sata. Mwah tingkahing sagebug arambavan, Angen trag tunu ngaran, Geleng pengasuh araning swara Mwang tandang Rere-baban, Bhuta ngawa sari ngaran, Madukaralalita araning swara.Mwang tandang Sasulingan Tunjung arip ngaran, Karna manu-hara araning swara. Mwang tandang Angenggong, Hametbet lati ngaran, Madukara santun araning swara, denya samar nyata ngaran. Mwah tandang angebug Cengceng, Edan ulangun ngaran, banyu runtuh araning swara. Mwah tandang angebug Kaklentangan Kaget asih ngaran. Nyan wustuning gagebug.” (Bandem (1986), 70) English D (Chat-GPT Translation): “The Striking Techniques of the Angklung (Iti Gagebug Angklung) The striking techniques of the Angklung include various rhythmic patterns and symbolic names.

accompanist.text: Source: “The translator’s choice of Shin Eun-Joo’s article on pansori is perfectly suited to presenting such an introduction. Pansori is one of the most important genres in Korean traditional music. Although frequently compared to Western classical opera due to their shared vocal and theatrical attributes, pansori is essentially an epic, narrative storytelling vocal performance executed by a singer and a drum accompanist without stage design or theatrical costumes. Unlike court or ritual music, pansori was first circulated among commoners and the lower class, and later enjoyed by all classes as a principal form of entertainment.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “A person who or thing which accompanies; esp. a person who provides a musical accompaniment.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “accompanist”)

\u5b8c\u5168\u306e\u97f3\u7a0b kanzen do.text: 完全+音程 ontei  完全: perfect Japanese A: “１つは旋律中の終止音それ自体の意味であり、他はこれら２つの終止音による完全４度の音程である。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] Japanese B: “⾳ 程 の 構 成 ⾳ の 振 動 数 ⽐が 単 純 で よ く と け 合 う ⾳ 程 。 完 全 1 度 （ 1 ：1 ） ， 完 全 4 度 （ 3 : 4 ） ， 完 ⾦ 5 度 （ 2 : 3 ） ，完 全 8 度 （ 1 ： 2 ） 。” Tomosha (2002) [p. 159] English A: “One is the meaning of ending notes themselves within melodies, while the other is the interval of the perfect fourth that is based around these two ending notes.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1]

daing.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “peméro yg terletak antara ndang dan nding” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 158, Bidang Istilah Musik, “ndaing”]

meganada.text: English A: “Drum technique or style is called geleng pangasuh, its sound is meganada.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.12]) Balinese/Indonesian A: “Pukulan kendang atau tandang kakendangan, geleng pangasuh, meganada nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Geleng is a word for head that also suggests focus and concentration; and asuh is diligent. The term suggests the watchful leadership role of the drum in the ensemble. Meganada literally means big sound, but it is also the name of the demon-king Rahwana’s powerful son (of the Ramayana epic).” (Tenzer (2024) [2.11]) *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions and cultural practice or unseen phenomenon (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u043f\u0430\u0439\u0434\u0443\u0448\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “5/16 такт, може да се изрази и с дробта. Ритъмът на тоя такт с протегната втора част служи за основа на народната игра „пайдушка" (ючата, четворка, ескийската).” Hristov (1925) [p. 42] English A: “The meter 5/16 can also be expressed with the fraction 2 128 (a meter with two and a half beats). The rhythm of this meter with an elongated second beat serves as the basis for the folk dance “paidushka” (yuchata, chetvorka, eskiiskata).” Goldberg (2024) [5.3] (See also: Footnote 16) Bulgarian B: “Пайдушко хоро (нар. муз.) бълг. нар. хоро в такт 5/8, бързо темпо, раз- пространено в цялата страна. Хват за длани. Характерен ритъм:” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 242, “Пайдушко хоро”] Bulgarian C: “Смесено хоро в 5/16. Известна в цяла-т а страна в най-различни варианти.” (Krŭstev (1967) p. 346)

\u043d\u0435\u0435\u0441\u0442\u0435\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Освен песни с точно определен такт в народната ни музика има твърде много песни, лишени от всякаква следа на какъвто и да е такт.Тези песни могат да се нарекат безмензурни (безтактови) и се отличават със съвършено волно движение (ad libitum) без определен ритъм.В безмензурните ни песни някои слогове са твърде много протегнати и правят декламацията неестествена. Друг съществен белег на тия песни са непрекъснатите сложни фиоритури (рулади).” Hristov (1925) [p. 39] English A: “In addition to songs with precisely defined meter, in our folk music there are rather many songs that are devoid of all traces of any kind of meter. These songs can be called unmeasured (unmetered), and they are distinguished by a completely free pulse (ad libitum) without a determinate rhythm. In our unmeasured songs some syllables are quite elongated, making the declamation unnatural. Another essential characteristic of these songs is the continuous use of complex fiorituri (roulades).” Goldberg (2024) [4.1]

Aumentaci\u00f3n.text: Spanish A: “Existe en el clasicismo musical algo que pudiera creerse relacionado con estas “Leyes de Metamorfosis”: los procedimientos por “aumentación” y “disminución,” que se emplean en el canon y la fuga, pero debe desecharse tal idea; pues positivamente no tienen semejanza con lo que constituye la base misma de mis “Leyes de metamorfosis.”” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] English A: “In classical music, there exist procedures that could be thought of as related to these “Laws of Metamorphosis”: the procedures of “augmentation” and “diminution” that are employed in canon and fugue. But such a notion must be discarded, because augmentation and diminution bear absolutely no relationship to the very foundation of my “Laws of Metamorphosis.”” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: Es un artificio de la composición Pedrell (1890) [p. 33] (See also: Lacál (1900) [p. 31])

ndi\u0323 mb\u1ee5.text: Igbo A: “Ifugo ya; hotel, hospitality. Ọ dị rii na ani Igbo. Ọ ka ndị mbụ si debe ndụ. Ụbọaka a bụ ihe a na-akpọ, na-agụ egwu…” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “You see it; hotel, hospitality… It has always been natural to the Igbo. This is how the ancestors planned life; ubọ-aka is the musical instrument that is played, while people sing.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

\uac00\ubd80\ud0a4 gabuki.text: Korean A: "그러나 나의 음악이 장시 긴장감을 유지하고 있다는 것은 사실입니다. 내 음악의 근본을 이부 고 있는 선적인 요소가 교묘히 지속성을 갖고 있는데, 그 본성 자체 가 지속의 무한한 가능성을 갖고 있어요. 예컨대 노나 가부키처럼 몇 시간씩 같은 선을 들어도 절대 물리지 않는 비밀이 이거지요." (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

\u043e\u0431\u0440\u0430\u0437\u0430/obr.text: Bulgarian A: “Сръбски музиколози (например Т . Маринкович) отбелязват песни с такта на ръченицата по един несвойствен на истинския ритъм начин, който съвсем изменя акцентовката и образа на песента.” Hristov (1925) (p. 50) English A: “Serbian musicologists (for example T. Marinković) notate songs with the meter of the rŭchenitsa in a way that is alien to the true rhythm, completely changing the accentuation and form of the song.” Goldberg (2024) [5.22]

Tema.text: Spanish A: “pero [el canon] afectaba únicamente la velocidad o la lentitud de un tema, haciendo más aprisa o más despacio una melodía, lo que nada tenía en el fondo que pudiera sugerir la metamorfosis como yo la entiendo: pues la modificación era fácilmente reconocible”  Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15](See also Canon) English A: “But canon affected only the speed or the length of a theme, made a melody quicker or slower, without having anything at its basis that could suggest metamorphosis as I understand it. Its modification was easily recognizable.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “Tema: Tomar por argumento uno, dos, ó mas compases para formar un discurso músical.” Palatín (1990) [p. 98] Spanish C: “En la antigua música de camera, llamábase Tema el cantabil sobre el cual se hacían variaciones.––En la técnica de la Fuga, es sinónimo de guía, antecedente ó soggetto, dux, como dicen los italianos. Pedrell (1890) [p. 445]

acento.text: English A: “A complete study of musical prosody—including intonation, accent, melody, rhythm, and specific interpretative practices—is beyond the limits of this article, which is limited to discussing melody, melody and spoken language, and the relationship between melody and accompaniment in Brazilian popular song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Um estudo completo da prosodia musical - incluindo entonação, acento, melodia, ritmo e práticas interpretativas específicas - foge aos limites deste estudo, que se limita a discutir melodia, melodia e língua falada e a relação melodia e acompanhamento na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999))

Song (2010).text: Song, Bang-song, Akhak Kwebŏm Yongŏ Ch'ongnam. Ch'op'an. Sŏul T'ŭkpyŏlsi: Pogosa, 2010.

raja.text: Sinhalese A: “tat jek kinaṃ takaṭa kaḍataka jeṃgu jeṃ takaṭa tat takaṭa – raja dakin” Peiris (2024) [12] English A: “[vocables. . .] – witness the monarch.” Peiris (2024) [12] English B: “king” (Peiris (2025)

\ud50c\ub8e8\ud2b8 peulluteu.text: Korean A: “플루트 솔로는 D음에서 직접 시작하지 않고 아래에서 우선 올라옵니다. 그러면 B음이 준비됩니 다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “The flute solo does not begin right on D but rises from below. Bb thus prepares it [the note D].” Park (2024) [4.1]

binary subdivision.text: binário (Portuguese) Source: “Thus, in Brazilian music, some musical events respond to the metric accentuation of the established measure as a reference, while others respond to a displaced and oscillating point, which generates a music that we end up calling structurally syncopated, formed by the superposition of a second sliding rhythmic support point that is not exactly fitted into the theoretical binary or ternary subdivision.” Menezes (2024) [1.10]

\ud558\ubcf8\uccad haboncheong.text: Kim (2024) Ex. 2–1 Korean A: “또한, 백대웅은 우조의 종류를 진우조, 평우조, 가곡성우조의 셋으로 정리하였다. 그 중 진우 조는 우조의 성격을 가장 분명하게 드러낸 것으로, 진우조에서는 특히 하본청과 상본청의 4도 골격(라-레)이 드러나며 분위기를 고조시키는데, 이는 청을 한 음 높이는 효과를 낸다고 하였 다.” Shin (2018) [p. 239] English A: “Furthermore, Baek assigns three subcategories to Ujo: Jin-ujo, Pyeong-ujo, and Gagokseong-ujo. Jin-ujo best expresses the nature of the Ujo; in particular, the fourth interval (la-re) between haboncheong and sangboncheong heightens the atmosphere with the impact of raising one step the tonic [cheong].” Kim (2024) [3.7] English B: “In accordance with Seolleongje, Baek explains that haboncheong (“la”) creates many leaps, stretches out, and sounds vigorous when employed above the octave. Seolleongje continuously stretches out with the high-pitched “la” (la') and develops leaps because it contains the notes sol, la, re, mi, sol', la', and do'. See Lee Bohyeong (1971, 176) for an explanation of Seolleongje.” Kim (2024) [Footnote 13]

homog\u00eaneo.text: English A: “Meter allows several voices to present a homogeneous (musical) discourse by providing an internal organization of pulsations into strong beats, propelling energy, and weak, inertial beats.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “O compasso permite que várias vozes possam apresentar um discurso homogêneo ao propor a organização interna das pulsações em tempos fortes, propulsores de energia e tempos fracos e inerciais.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc21c\uac04 sungan.text: Korean A: “순간에 영원이 반영되고, 영원을 순간으로서 포착한다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 155] English A: “A moment reflects eternity, and the eternity can be captured as a moment.” Park (2024) [4]

\u5bae\u5ef7\u2fb3\u697d\u00a0Ky\u016bte.text: Japanese A: “そ し て 韓 国 に は 厳 格 な⽴ 場 を と る 雅 楽 ⾳ 楽 と は 別 に 、 宮 廷 ⾳ 楽 で も 寺 院 ⾳ 楽 で も な い 、⼀ 般 ⼤ 衆 と 上 流 社 会 が 共 有 し て き た 、 西 洋 に ⾒ ら れ る よ う な 知 識 社 会 で 楽 し ん で き た ⾳ 楽 世 界 が ま だ あ り ま す 。 そ れ か ら ま た 芸 術 歌 曲 、芸 術 民 謡 と い い ま す か 、 そ う い う も の が あ り ま す " (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3])

\uc815\uc2e0 jeongsin.text: Korean A: “그렇지만 나는 원칙적으로 음악은 피가 흐르는 요소가 없어서는 안된다고 봐요 기계를 아무리 사용하더라도 기계에서 나오는 음악은 기계가 만드는 것이므로 거기서는 피가 흐르고 있지 않아요. 이건 대원칙으로서, 음악에는 인간의 피와 정신이 통하고 있지 않으면 안됩니다. 궁극적으로는 인간의 피와 정신이라고 생각 해요. 순수한 사고방식으로 말하자면 내가 죽더라도 인간의 피와 정신은 함께 남을 것입니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 163] English A: “No matter how much a machine can do, the music coming from the machine is made by the machine. No blood flows through the music. This is a fundamental principle. Music must channel human blood and spirit. Ultimately, I think music is human blood and spirit. To speak naively, a person’s blood and spirit will remain even after my death.” Park (2024) [7.2]

\ud53c pi.text: Korean A: “그렇지만 나는 원칙적으로 음악은 피가 흐르는 요소가 없어서는 안된다고 봐요 기계를 아무리 사용하더라도 기계에서 나오는 음악은 기계가 만드는 것이므로 거기서는 피가 흐르고 있지 않아요. 이건 대원칙으로서, 음악에는 인간의 피와 정신이 통하고 있지 않으면 안됩니다. 궁극적으로는 인간의 피와 정신이라고 생각 해요. 순수한 사고방식으로 말하자면 내가 죽더라도 인간의 피와 정신은 함께 남을 것입니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 163] English A: “No matter how much a machine can do, the music coming from the machine is made by the machine. No blood flows through the music. This is a fundamental principle. Music must channel human blood and spirit. Ultimately, I think music is human blood and spirit. To speak naively, a person’s blood and spirit will remain even after my death.” Park (2024) [7.2]

tango.text: tango platino (Portuguese) Source: “The pattern also appears in Example 5 ([1.19]), a transcription of Amerindian music transcribed by the French musicologist Marguerite Béclard d’Harcourt, who identifies the pattern with Indigenous and Black musics, as well as cakewalks, two-steps, and tangos.” Biamonte commentary (2024) [5] Definition: “A Latin American song and dance genre. The etymology of the word ‘tango’ is still much debated. During the 19th century in Spain and several Latin American countries the term designated various types of dances, songs and communal festivities. Fernando Ortíz and others claim the word is of African origin with the general meaning ‘African dance’. Others believe it is of Castilian origin, derived from the old Spanish word tañer (taño; ‘to play’ an instrument).” (Grove Music Online, “tango”)

\uae34\uc7a5\ub825 ginjangnyeok.text: See 긴장 ginjang  Korean A: “달리면서 이번에는 생명력을, 긴장력을 높이기 위해서 비브라토를 만들어냅니다. 비브 라토에 의해서 집중력과 긴장감을 증가시키지요. 그리고 장식용적인 요소가 추가됩니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “As it runs, it creates vibratos in order to heighten its lifeforce and tension. Through vibrato, the concentration and tension are increased. And melismatic elements are added.” [4.1]

\u0442\u0430\u043a\u0442\u043e\u0432\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Чрез нотна стойност бързината на този елемент може да се изрази тъй: = 400 - 432 М.М ити. 200- 216 M. M. Групирани по два и по три, тези елементи елементи образуват два вида тактови части: кратка — с два елемента и протегната - с три елемента.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “As a note value, the tempo of this element can be expressed thus: [sixteenth note] = 400–432 M. M. or [two beamed sixteenth notes] = 200–216 M. M. Grouped into twos and threes, these elements form two kinds of metric parts: short—with two elements ([two beamed sixteenth notes] = [one eighth note]) and elongated—with three elements ([three beamed sixteenth notes] = [one eighth note]).” Goldberg (2024) [3.1]short: кратка/kratka or Arsis арзис [5.3]elongated: протетната/protetnata or Thesis тезис [5.3] short: кратка/kratka or Arsis арзис [5.3] elongated: протетната/protetnata or Thesis тезис [5.3]

derramamento.text: English A: “The most obvious example of this “overflow” [derramamento] is samba, where there is a binary measure, but with the accent transferred from the beginning of the measure to its second half.” (Stover (2024) [4.5]) Portuguese A: “O exemplo mais evidente deste "derramamento" é o samba onde se tem um compasso binário, mas com a acentuação transferida do início do compasso para a sua segunda metade.” (Ulhôa (1999))

backbeat.text: Source: “Andrade theorizes syncopation in Brazilian music as a structural background pattern rather than a rhythmic dissonance that needs to resolve, which Menezes and Pires connect to theorizations of timeline patterns in African musics ([1.7]). Such structures function analogously to the backbeat pattern that underpins much Anglophone popular music. The rhythmic displacement of the backbeat occurs on a larger level than the syncopations in Example 1, but the technique of accent shift is similar.” Biamonte commentary (2024) [6] Definition: “Percussive accents on nominal weak beats, typically played on the snare drum on the second and fourth beats in 4/4 meter. The term came into common usage in the early 1950s in connection with rock ’n’ roll music (also known then as “beat music” or the “big beat”), although the backbeat originated in earlier American musics. It remains one of the most common and distinctive features of post-1950 popular music.” (Grove Music Online, “backbeat”)

gr\u00e3o.text: English A: “These rhetorical gestures, as well as the spaces between musicians’ attacks or note endings in a musical performance, contribute greatly to making people move their bodies in specific ways and to hearing the “grain” of the song.” (Stover (2024) [5.8]) Portuguese A: “Estes gestos retóricos, bem como os espaços entre os ataques ou finais de nota dos músicos numa performance musical contribuem enormemente para fazer as pessoas moverem seus corpos de maneira específica, e para escutar o "grão" da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

irregulares.text: Portuguese A: “A síncopa europeia me parece um produto exclusivamente musical, e ainda mais, uma verdadeira especulação teórica proveniente da subdivisão da unidade de tempo em quantidades irregulares em que as batidas fortes subsistem em seus lugares teóricos e se tornam pois musicalmente elípticas.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota. no. 9] English A: “European syncopation seems to me an exclusively musical product, and furthermore, a true theoretical speculation stemming from the subdivision of the time unit into irregular quantities where strong beats persist in their theoretical places and thus become musically elliptical.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

\u041c\u0435\u043b\u0446\u0435\u043b\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Петшестнадесетинният такт е съставен от пет тактови елемента/ които имат движение, както споменах вече по-рано, 400—432 на минута. Темпото на целия такт може да се отбележи с Мелцеловия метроном така: = 80.” Hristov (1925) [p. 42] English A: “The meter 5/16 is composed of five metric elements that have a pulse, as I already mentioned earlier, of 400–432 per minute. The tempo of the whole measure can be notated according to Maelzel’s metronome thus:  = 80.” Goldberg (2024) [5.2]

frase.text: English A: “When this accepted natural order is questioned and the musical phrase begins on a weak beat and continues onto the next strong beat, it is said that a “syncopation” has occurred.” (Stover (2024) [1.3]) Portuguese A: “Quando esta ordem aceita como natural é questionada e a frase começa num tempo fraco e se prolonga no tempo forte seguinte se diz que surgiu uma "síncopa".” (Ulhôa (1999))

fala.text: English A: “In Brazil, a musical performance is influenced primarily by one’s manner of accentuating words in speech, whose “prosodic values transfigure the melody” (Andrade 1972, 23).” (Stover (2024) [1.1]) Portuguese A: “No Brasil, a performance musical seria influenciada principalmente pela maneira de acentuar as palavras na fala, cujos "valores prosódicos … transfiguram a melodia" (p. 23).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u97d3\u56fd\u306e\u6b4c\u5531 Kankuni n.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 、 先 ⽣ の 作 品 の 線 的 な 語 法 の も と に な っ て い る わ け で す ね 。 微 分 ⾳ 的 な 細 か い 揺 れ か ら 3 度 以 上 の シ ェ イ ク に ⾄ る よ う な 、 独 特 な 線 の 動 き は 、 韓 国 の 歌 唱 の ⽅ 法 か ら ⽣ み 出 さ れ た も の と 考 え て い い わ け で す ね .” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

majalan.text: English: “Geria likely meant babaru to mean a whiplike inner force or strength. This is doubly apt. Here the boxed motive recurs transposed up a step, then inverts (dotted box) to return to the starting point. In one sense the pattern conveys a directed kinetic motion Balinese call majalan, and always fits with gending whose goal tones change for every iteration of the pattern (moving 5-6-5 3 in the example). It conveys energetic motion and is often played at fast tempi.” Tenzer (2024) [4.12] English B: “In the large and important repertoire of “classical” pelegongan style, a significant preponderance of ubit-ubitan patterns follow a few simple rules known to all gamelan players: they last two beats at a rate of four tones per beat, and are classified either stable (ngubeng) or motile (majalan), depending on the direction of the underlying melody.” (Tenzer (2024) [5.4])

\u53cd\u7ebf f\u01cen xi\u00e0n.text: (see 反调, see Zhongguo yinyue (1984) p. 47) English: “In Chaozhou zheng music, the qupai titled “Guo jiang long” 過江龍 (“River-crossing dragon”) alternates between zhengxian 正線 (home key) and fanxian 反線 (inverse key), which is t3 of the home key.” Lam (2024)

idiophone.text: Source: “Lamellaphones are classified under the category of idiophones by Hornbostel and Sachs (1961), who describe this category as musical instruments that make their sound by vibrating by themselves following an impact, such as striking or plucking. The Igbo people have a different method of categorization.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [2.2] Definiton: “A percussion instrument that consists simply of material such as metal or wood that is itself capable of producing sound, as opposed to a membranophone n., in which stretched skin or similar is used as the agent of sound.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “idiophone”)

\u043f\u043e\u043d\u0438\u0439\u0441\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: ionic rhythm, “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6]

antecedent-consequent.text: Source: “Alongside this unfolding, we hear a timbrally heterogeneous texture involving six wind or brass instruments playing what could be construed as a single Klangfarbenmelodie line or, perhaps, as a pair of shorter composite gestures in a kind of antecedent-consequent relation.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.9] Definition: “The names given to a pair of musical statements that complement one another by virtue of a rhythmic symmetry and, more important, a harmonic balance established by their juxtaposition.” (”Antecedent and consequent,” Grove Music Online)

\ub3d9 dong.text: Korean A: “'하우프트톤'은 둘이 있는 경우도 많아요. 둘이 있으면 그것은 음양 관계를 갖지요. 예컨대 동(動)과 정(静)의 관계이기도 합니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1]

wiwitan.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan angindra artinya pencarian atau pangalihan gending-gending (wiwitan) namanya. Pukulan sendiri dan agak bervariasi yang memberi tanda pembukaan lagu. Makanya banyak pukulan trompong. Seperti: 1. wiwitan, 2. nabhe (nguluin), 3. ngembat, 4. nyiliasih, 5. ngoret, 6. ngantu, 7. ngunda, 8. nerumpuk.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Playing andira means to look for or seek the beginning (wiwitan) of a composition. There are many ways for the trompong, playing alone, to do this. For example: 1. wiwitan, 2. nabhe (nguluin), 3. ngembat, 4. nyiliasih, 5. ngoret, 6. ngantu, 7. ngunda, 8. nerumpuk.” Tenzer (2024) [III.9]

\u97f3\u697d\u7406\u8ad6 ongaku riron.text: See ヨーロッパの音楽理論 Yōroppa no ongaku riron  Japanese A: “核音の比較音楽学的意味については第４節でのべるが、西洋音楽一般についてはこれにあたるものを見ない。したがってヨーロッパの音楽理論の用語には、これを表現する適切な言葉がないのである。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 5] English A: “I will discuss the meanings of nuclear tones in comparative musicology in section 4, but in Western music, we do not generally see things like this. Therefore, in European music theory terminology, there is no word that appropriately expresses this.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3] Japanese B: “ ⾳ 楽 の  諸要 素 に 関 す る 実 践 的 経 験 を 理 論 化 し た も の 。” (Tomosha (2002), 123)

decolonize.text: Source: “In fact, I find the text presented here as further evidence (feel free to accuse me of confirmation bias) of the claims I’ve made in my recent talk “The Politics of Musical Scales and the Decolonization of Music Studies” (Abu Shumays 2024): that when attempting to decolonize music theory or pedagogy it is insufficient to bring in diverse voices, particularly if those Black and Brown individuals from different countries and languages nonetheless received musical and scholarly training in Western-style academic institutions in their home countries.” (Shumays commentary (2024) [4.1]) Definition: “The process of eliminating the effects or influence of colonization or colonialism on the attitudes, assumptions, power structures, institutions, etc., of a people formerly made subject to colonial rule or (later also) of the society, nation, or culture of a former colonizer or colonial power; an instance of this.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “decolonization”)

\ub178 Noh.text: Korean A: "그러나 나의 음악이 장시 긴장감을 유지하고 있다는 것은 사실입니다. 내 음악의 근본을 이부 고 있는 선적인 요소가 교묘히 지속성을 갖고 있는데, 그 본성 자체 가 지속의 무한한 가능성을 갖고 있어요. 예컨대 노나 가부키처럼 몇 시간씩 같은 선을 들어도 절대 물리지 않는 비밀이 이거지요." (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

\u4e0a\u754c sh\u00e0ng j\u00ece.text: Chinese A: “如果我們把我們的靈界當作是我們的上界，那末，我們亦可以把音樂當作是上界的語言.” Li (2024) [1.17] “凡屬人類，至少都具有幾分的音樂性，所以我們亦可以把音樂當作是靈界的一種世界語言…或者不可以得到相當的了解，但是所謂音樂是靈界的世界語言云云，是指那些差不多有同一的文化程度的人們來說.” Li (2024) [1.18] English A: “If we consider our spiritual world our upper realm (shangjie), we can also understand Music as a language of the upper realm.” Li (2024) [1.17] “Consequently, we can perceive Music as a world language of the upper realm…when I refer to Music as the world language of the upper realm, I am addressing those who possess a similar level of literacy.” (For more on music literacy and the upper realm, see Li (2024) [1.18] For more on the upper realm, see Li (2024) Introduction Chinese B: “音乐理论家青主的思想即具有此种特征。他著有《乐话》、《音乐通论》，对音乐的本质、内容、形式、创作、表演、功能等一系列音乐美学问题作了系统的阐述，其主张是：音乐是“灵魂的语言”或“灵魂的一种世界语言”（即“上界的语言”）；音乐是心灵的表现，是主观的创造，并具有改善人类心灵的功能” Zhongguo da baike (2020) (音乐美学) Chinese C: “天界。指仙佛所居之地.” Hanyu dacidian (上界, 1)

upbeat.text: Source: “Furthermore, Hornbostel, in his analysis, considers a rhythmic displacement in which some attacks by the xylophone (which according to his interpretation of the structure should be ‘upbeats’, therefore unaccented) are actually accented ‘downbeats’. And when the main theme returns in the choir, in another metric position, Hornbostel is led to consider that this entire theme is syncopated.” Menezes (2024) [1.17] Definition: “In a measured Rhythm, that impulse that immediately precedes, and hence anticipates, the Downbeat, which is the strongest of such impulses (see ex.1); an anticipatory note or succession of notes, sometimes referred to as an ‘upbeat figure’, occurring before the first barline of a piece, section or phrase.” (Grove Music Online, “upbeat”)

\uadfc\ubcf8 geunbon.text: Korean A: "그러나 나의 음악이 장시 긴장감을 유지하고 있다는 것은 사실입니다. 내 음악의 근본을 이부 고 있는 선적인 요소가 교묘히 지속성을 갖고 있는데, 그 본성 자체 가 지속의 무한한 가능성을 갖고 있어요. 예컨대 노나 가부키처럼 몇 시간씩 같은 선을 들어도 절대 물리지 않는 비밀이 이거지요." (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

Acorde perfecto mayor.text: Spanish A: “Tal cosa significa que como el acorde perfecto mayor, por ejemplo, se obtiene contando del bajo hacia arriba, un intervalo de cuatro semitonos, y sobre la nota superior de éste, otro de tres semitonos, al metamorfosearse al duplo, en vez del intervalo de cuatro semitonos sobre el bajo, se escribirá uno de ocho, y sobre la nota de éste, en vez de uno de tres, irá uno de seis. De lo dicho se desprende que el acorde perfecto mayor…metamorfoseado al duplo, quedará así:” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 23-24] English A: “Take, for example, the major triad, which is obtained by counting an interval of four semitones above the bass, followed by another interval three semitones above that. Under metamorphosis to the double, instead of counting an interval of four semitones above the bass, we will count eight, and instead of counting three semitones above that note, we will count six. It follows that for a major triad…when metamorphosed to the double, will look like this:” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 23-24] See also Acorde disminuído, Pedrell (1890) [p. 5] Spanish B: “Es al armonía que resulta de una nota, de su 3.ª y de su 5.ª. Ej: do, mi, sol; ACORDE PERFECTO mayor…” Lacál (1900) [p. 5]

\u5fb7 d\u00e9.text: Chinese A: “因為樂不過是禮的附庸，所謂先王以作樂崇德，就是要用崇德的樂完成禮的全體大用.” Li (2024) [1.4] English A: “The former kings made Music to ennoble the Virtue (de), for they would like to use such ennobling Music to fulfill the comprehensive purpose of Ritual.” Li (2024) [1.4] A related concept: see Li (2024) Footnote 11, “mingde 明德 (the realizing or summoning of virtue)” Chinese B: “道教教义。“德”和“道”是道教教义核心的两个方面，组成一个整体。古时“德”与“得”通，学道而得道，是谓有德。《道教义枢·道德义》云：“道德一体，而其二义，一而不一，二而不二。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) (德) Chinese C: “《论语·述而》：“德之不修，學之不講，聞義不能徙，不善不能改，是吾憂也。” Hanyu dacidian  (德)

\uc0ac\uc6d0\uc74c\uc545\ub3c4 sawon-eum.text:
사원: sawon 
 Korean A: “ 그리고 한국에는 엄격한 입장을 취하는 아악과는 변도 로, 송정음악도 사원음악도 아니면서 일반대중과 상류사회가 공유해 온, 서양에서 볼 수 있듯이 지식사회에서 즐겨온 음악세계가 있어 요. 그리고 또 예술가곡• 예술민요라고 합니다만 그런 것이 또 있어 요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean,147) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3])

angurit.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan angurit yaitu artinya membuat garis-garis.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Angurit means to make lines.” Tenzer (2024) [III.3] ““Lines” refers to the grace notes and special technique for playing two adjacent notes with the same hand, glancing off one gong’s boss and using the momentum to propel it to the next one.” Tenzer (2024)  [3.4] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

samba can\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “The move in bossa nova melodies toward more restricted and narrow melodic range helped to strip away the melodramatic qualities of the samba canção of previous decades.” (Stover (2024) [2.10]) Portuguese A: “Este afastamento da melodia bossa nova para extensões mais restritas e estreitas ajuda-a a se despir das qualidades melodramáticas do samba-canção das décadas anteriores.” (Ulhôa (1999))

gagelut.text: English: “IV.2 through IV.5 can be discussed together since they are similar and all paired with the same oscillating two-note gending pattern. Gagelut and gagulet are assonant synonyms meaning hug, embrace, or even wrestle. The patterns are of a subtype called ubitan telu (telu = three) in which the two parts use a total of three tones, sharing an inner tone; hence embracing. These are indeed ubiquitous in the repertoire. Kabelit and kabelet, similarly related as words, mean stuck, stubborn, unmoving. They are of subtype called ubitan empat (empat = four) in which the two parts use two different but scale-adjacent tones each. When sounded the lower tone of the polos and the upper tone of the sangsih coincide, creating a dyad that protrudes from the texture to create a syncopated  3+2+3 cross-rhythm (the greyed notes). While the inner tones jostle, this prominent interval is “stuck” in its place.” Tenzer (2024) [4.6] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2) See: gagulet

Godakumura (1970).text: Godakumbura, C. E. Siṃhala nāṭaya hā saṅgītaya. : Sinhalese Dance and Music. (Archaeological Department), 1970.

perception.text: Source: “But Geria gradually passes from Prakempa’s metaphysical style to a discourse on the play of tones and the concrete sensations they produce. Having sculpted these worlds as continuous, even a non-Balinese reader can connect the umwelt of precolonial Bali to an international emergent music theory based on earthly perception and cognition.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.6]) Source: Tenzer (2024) Ex. 2 Lexical fields Definition: “The process of becoming aware of physical objects, phenomena, etc., through the senses; an instance of this.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “perception” 1.3.a)

\u30bd\u30ed soro.text: Japanese A: “フルート・ソロはDの音を直接スタート しないで、下からまず上がってくる。と いうと、Bの音が準備になる。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “The flute solo does not begin right on D but rises from below. Bb thus prepares it [the note D].” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “ソロ solo［伊］「単独に」の意。①ある楽器または声が単独でおこなう、独奏や独唱のこと。この場合，ピアノやオーケストラの伴奏をもつものも含む。②オーケストラで、特定の楽器奏者をきわだたせるときにおこなう指示。③協奏曲で，トゥッティに対する独奏部分。” (Tomosha (2002), 377)

constituent note.text: Source: “Another significant feature of the pansori modes discussed in the translated text is that each constituent note assumes individual attributes. This is most evident in Baek’s explanation of Ujo and Pyeongjo in Tables 2 and 3, where constituent notes are defined not only by particular intervals, but also by specific singing methods and techniques, frequency of occurrence, cadential function, melodic direction, and so on.” Lee commentary (2024) [6]

\uc911\uc911\ubaa8\ub9ac jungjungmori.text: Korean A: “자진모리伽倻琴散調는 대개 진양조, 중모리, 중중모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리 6樂章으로 되어 있고, 一般 的으로 羽調, 界面調, 平調를 使用하고 있다.” (Shin (2018) , 248) English A: “Gayageum sanjo typically comprises six movements: jinyangjo, jungmori, jungjungmori, jajinmori, hwimori, and danmori; it commonly utilizes Ujo, Gyemyeonjo, and Pyeongjo.” (Kim (2024)  [3.2]) English B: “Jungjungmori jangdan “is faster than jungmori . Its basic cycle is (12/8) with the accent on the ninth beat. This jangdan is used to accompany songs with a cheerful mood” (Lee and Lee 2007, 113).]”(Kim (2024) Footnote 20) Korean C: “이보형은 판소리 창자들이 흔히 평조라고 이르는 중중모리장단의 '기산영수', '화초타령' 대 목을 기준으로 판소리 평조의 특징을 다음과 같이 정리하였다.” Shin (2018) [p. 242] English C: “Based on the scenes of “Gisanyeongsu” “기산영수” [Gi Mountain and Yeong River] and “Hwacho taryeong” “화초타령” [The Song of the Flower] in jungjungmori jangdan, which pansori singers frequently refer to as Pyeongjo, Lee outlines the qualities of Pyeongjo in pansori.” Kim (2024) [3.16] English D: 1. a jangdan indicating normal tempo 2. musical piece Korean D: 판소리나 산조, 민요 등에서 쓰이는 장단. 조금 느린 3소박 4박 으로 되어 있다. 중중모리는 중간 속도 중에서도 중간에 해당하 는 장단으로 중모리 장단보다는 조금 빠르다. 민속악에서는 곡의 속도를 나타내는 용어로도 사용하며, 산조에서는 곡명을 가리키 기도 한다. 중중모리장단 (Pyǒn (2012) 156)

\uc885\uc9c0 jongji.text: English A: “This translation presented unique challenges, particularly regarding the original author’s use of Western musical concepts such as letter names, solfège, staff notation, and the concepts of key (joseong 조성), half cadence (ban-jongji 반종지), and cadence (jongji 종지).” (Kim (2024) [0.4]) Korean A: “이는, 민요에서 토리를 이야기할 때 단순히 출현음만을 제시하지 않고 떨고, 꺾고, 흘리는 등의 시김새와 음의 비중, 종지 등을 언급해야 하는 것과 마찬가지이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 248] English A: “When discussing tori in a folk song, it is important to not only list the individual notes but also include details like shaking, bending, falling, the value of each pitch, and the cadence.” Kim (2024) [3.32]

artha rasa.text: English: “Theories of poetic meter and rhyme scheme have been part of literary discourse for centuries (Hallisey 2003, 723–38); the value given to these ideas of sonic patterning is reflected in the fact that sung Sinhala poetry was prized as much for its sonic aesthetics (ṣ́abda rasa) as its semantic aesthetics (artha rasa).” Peiris (2024) [15]

panyacah.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug panyacah panasta slampah.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “A panyacah stroke is panasta slampah.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.9]) Balinese C: “Mwah yan Smar Patangian, ndyata : kempul satunggal sawur-nya manyomanan ndung, kemong gantung sanunggal swaranya ndung, kajar sanunggal sawurnya ndung, gupek roro lanang wadon, rebab sanunggal, suling ageng roro, suling babarangan roro sama ngumbang ngisep, gender ageng sapasang, jegogan sapasang, jublag sapasang, panyacah sapasang, kantil sapasang, gangsa manengah sapasang, gangsa alit apasang, nging sama ngumbang gisep, gumanak tatiga, genta orag apancer alit, kecek tigang wungkul alit, kecek manengah kalih wungkul, kecek ageng sawungkul, jangkep kayeki.” (Bandem (1986), 82) English C (Chat-GPT): “Smara Patangian Ensemble The Smara Patangian gamelan is more rhythmic and ceremonial, used in rituals and processions. It consists of: Thus, this ensemble is also considered complete (jangkep). This classification reflects the structural and tonal balance within different Balinese gamelan styles, each serving specific cultural and artistic purposes.”

\u82b8\u8853\u6b4c\u66f2 Jutsu uta kyoku.text: Japanese A: “そ し て 韓 国 に は 厳 格 な⽴ 場 を と る 雅 楽 ⾳ 楽 と は 別 に 、 宮 廷 ⾳ 楽 で も 寺 院 ⾳ 楽 で も な い 、⼀ 般 ⼤ 衆 と 上 流 社 会 が 共 有 し て き た 、 西 洋 に ⾒ ら れ る よ う な 知 識 社 会 で 楽 し ん で き た ⾳ 楽 世 界 が ま だ あ り ま す 。 そ れ か ら ま た 芸 術 歌 曲 、芸 術 民 謡 と い い ま す か 、 そ う い う も の が あ り ま す " (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3])

\u0440\u0430\u0434\u043e\u043c\u0438\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “И в сборниците на Куба и Кухач има български, македонски и др. песни, но и в тяхната автентичност може да се има толкова вяра, колкото в материалите от министерските сборници. Както в едните, той и в другите се срещат, макар рядко, песни с мерки 5/4 и 7/4, обаче само в бавно движение. Това са мерки, конто, може да се каже, се създават по изкуствен начин от записвачите, защото те не са основа на някакви известни народни танци. Напротив, мярката на пайдушката 5/16, двойната мярка 7/16 (ръченица и македонско хоро), 9/16 (тропливата игра или радомирското хоро), 11/16 (хайдушка игра) и др. там никак не се срещат.” Hristov (1925) [p. 35] English A: “There are also Bulgarian, Macedonian, and other songs in the collections by Kuba and Kuhač, but there can be as much faith in the reliability of this work as in the materials from the Ministry collections. In both sets of collections are found, though rarely, songs with the time signatures 5/4 and 7/4, but only at a slow tempo. These are time signatures that are created artificially, so to speak, by the transcribers, because they are not the basis for any known folk dances. To the contrary, the time signature of 5/16 (paidushkata), both 7/16 time signatures (rŭchenitsa and makedonsko horo), 9/16 (troplivata igra or radomirskoto horo), 11/16 (haidushka igra), etc., are in no way found there.” Goldberg (2024) [2.7] See also: хоро/horo

\u7dda\u7684\u306a\u52d5\u304d\u2f45\u30.text: Japanese A: “う で す 。 厳 格 な 雅 楽 の ⾳ 楽 の 組 み ⽅ と 、 哲 学 的 な 内 容 と 、 そ れ か ら 流 暢 に 流 れ る 線 的 な 美 し さ を 、 た と え ば 南 道 唱 と か 歌 曲 と い っ た 形 式 の ⼀ 連 の 声 楽 が あ り ま す が 、 そ う い う と こ ろ か ら た く さ ん 学 び ま し た 。 そ こ に 、 今 度 は 線 的 な 動 き ⽅ の ⾳ 楽 的 な 理 論 を ⼤ 系 づ け ま し た.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: “Yes. I learned a lot from A-ak’s strict organization and philosophical content, and vocal music’s smoothly flowing linear beauty, such as Namdo Chang and Gagok [가곡], or other vocal genres.Based on these, I organized my own musical theory of linear motion." (Park (2024) [1.4])

alinhamento vertical.text: English A: “What is quite prominent in sub-Saharan African music is the establishment of a temporal order based on the interaction of multiple parts that produce a polyrhythmic texture. The structure of its rhythmic organization is based on asymmetrical groupings of minimum time units or “fastest pulses,” as explained by Kwabena Nketia in The Music of Africa (1974). There is no vertical alignment at the beginning of the measure, as in European notions of meter [compasso].” (Stover (2024) [4.4]) Portuguese A: “O que é bastante proeminente na música africana, sub-saarana, é o estabelecimento de uma ordem temporal, baseada na interação de partes múltiplas que produzem uma textura polirítmica. A organização rítmica se estrutura a partir de agrupamentos assimétricos de unidades de tempo mínimas ou "pulso mais rápido", como explica Kwabena Nketia no seu livro The Music of Africa (1974). Não existe um alinhamento vertical dos inícios dos tempos, como nas noções europeias de compasso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u5de8\u5927\u306a\u6642\u9593 kyodaina.text:
巨大 + 時間 巨大: huge, gigantic, enormous 時間: time 
 Japanese A: “「ハウプト・トン」における陰と陽の相 対的な変化は、微細な時間によるとらえ 方から巨大な時間によるとらえ方までい ろいろな段階があります。そこでは瞬間 に永遠が反映され、永遠を瞬間としてつ かむことができるわけです。それが東洋人の「時」の考え方で、西 洋人の「時」の考え方と全く違うところ なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

appoggiaturas.text: English A: “The emphasis on the melody is so striking that all the notes that compose it are essential to the song’s identity, including those that would be considered surface-level ornaments in the European classical-romantic music that has so influenced popular Brazilian music. What could be considered superfluous for melodic evaluation, such as notes that are foreign to the basic harmonic structure of the song (grupetos, mordants, appoggiaturas) have a functional importance in popular Brazilian song.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “A ênfase na melodia é tão marcante que todas as notas que a compõem são essenciais para a identidade da canção, incluindo aquelas que seria consideradas ornamentos superficiais na música clássico-romântica européia que tanto influenciou a música brasileira popular. O que poderia ser considerado supérfluo para a avaliação melódica, como notas extranhas à estrutura harmônica básica na canção (grupetos, mordentes, appoggiaturas) têm uma importância funcional na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “In “Canção da América,” the words expand by leaps with or without portamento, melisma, tremolo, the most diverse appoggiaturas, mordents and grupetos, highlighting the emotional content of the song: the heart cries for escape—the feeling trapped in the chest—and to reestablish the bonds of friendship you have to listen to your heart, no matter what happens. (Carvalho 1990, 325–30).” (Stover (2024) [5.7]) Portuguese B: “Em "Canção da América" as palavras expandidas por saltos com ou sem portamento, melisma, tremolo, appoggiaturas as mais diversas, mordentes e grupetos, realçam o conteúdo emocional da canção: o coração chora pela partida - o sentimento preso no peito - e para reestabelecer os laços de amizade tem-se que ouvir o coração, não importa o que aconteça.
