(p. 325-10).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese C: “Nota ornamental que antecede às notas regulares de uma segunda superior ou inferior. Distinguem~se três espécies de apojaturas: a) apojatura longa ou expressiva; b) apojature breve; c) apojatura dupla ou sucessiva.” (Cosme (1957), 9)

\ubbf8\ubd84\uc74c mibun-eum.text: Korean A: “그것이 선생님 작품의 선적 어법의 밑바탕 이 되어 있군요. 미분음적인 미세한 흔들림으로부터 3 도 이상의 전음(숍)에 이르는 독특한 선의 움직임은 한국의 가창.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

narrativa.text: English A: “In popular song, melody and lyrics closely influence each other. There are elements in the lyrics, especially their narrative or lyrical quality, that suggest different types of melody, and there are particularities in the melody, especially its melodic contour and the types of intervals used that define the character of the song.” (Stover (2024) [1.8]) Portuguese A: “Na canção popular melodia e letra interferem estreitamente uma sobre a outra. Existem elementos na letra, especialmente sua qualidade narrativa ou lírica que conduzem a diferentes tipos de melodia; existem particularidades na melodia, especialmente seu contorno melódico e tipos de intervalos empregados que marcam o caráter da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u044f\u043c\u0431\u0430/yamba.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнен с размерите от старогръцката музика, пайдушковият такт се приближава донейде до ямба (⏑ – ), който е образуван също от едно кратко (арзис) и едно протегнато време (тезис). Но тук в ямба тезис е точно два пъти по-дълго време от арзиса и чрез ноти се предава чрез ауфтакт – 3/4, или 3/8.” Hristov (1925) [p. 42] English A: “Compared with the meters from ancient Greek music, the paidushka meter approaches to some extent the iamb (⏑ – ), which is likewise formed from one short (arsis) and one elongated beat (thesis). But in the iamb the thesis is a beat exactly twice as long as the arsis, and in note values it is rendered via an upbeat—3/4 or 3/8.” Goldberg (2024) [5.3]

\uc758\uc2dd uisik.text: Korean A: “니시무라 선생님께서 옥중에서 쓰신 오페라 말씀입니다만, 선생 님은 건강도 상했고, 오페라 자체는 연주될 전망조차 없었으며, 그 작품 자체를 옥중에서 밖으로 내보낼 수 있을지 없을지 모르는 그런 속에서 어떻게 의식을 초월해서 단숨에 쓰시게 되었는지요?” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 160] English A: “Regarding the opera you had composed while in prison [Die Witwe des Schmetterlings (Butterfly Widow)], at the time, you were in poor health, there was no perspective for its performance, and you weren’t even sure whether you could transport the score outside of the prison cell. How were you able to overcome senses [意識] and compose in these circumstances with one stroke?” Park (2024) [6.1]

\uc74c\uc545 eumak.text: Korean A: “이제 생각해 보아야할 문제는, 판소리에서 악조를 판별하는 데 있어서 구성음(출현음)을 중요 하게 볼 것이냐, 주요 선을 골격과 시김을 중요하게 볼 것이냐 하는 점이다. 그리고 이는 판소리 의 음악 특성이 고려되어야 한다. 궁중음악이나 양반들 풍류음악의 경우에는 음악 자체에 시김이 크게 강조되지 않는다. 농현과 추성, 퇴성 등을 하지만, 농현의 깊이가 깊지 않고, 추성과 퇴성의 정도 역시 마찬가지이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 247] English A: “The crucial consideration is therefore whether to prioritize the constituent notes or the primary melodic structure and sigim[sae] in identifying the mode in pansori, taking into account the musical attributes of pansori. Sigim[sae] is not a significant focus in court or aristocratic entertainment music. [When looking at instrumental court music’s modal theory by comparison,] the vibration of string, called nonghyeon 농현 [string play], is the shallowest, and chuseong 추성 [a slow rise in pitch] and toeseong have similar qualities.” Kim (2024) [3.32]

\u30d4\u30a2\u30cb\u30c3\u30b7\u30e2 pia.text: Japanese A: “まず低い音から始まります。凸の音で、 これは暗い音なんです。無から生まれる。 実はこれはピアニッシモなんですけれど も。これは暗示です。まだ音じゃないわ けなんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “First of all, it begins with a low pitch [Example 1]. With the Bb, it is a dark tone. It emerges from nothing. Although it is in pianissimo, it is an implication [暗示]. It is not yet a tone.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “ピアニッシモ pianissimo［伊］「とても弱く」。pp と略記.” (Tomosha (2002), 544)

\u697d gaku.text: Japanese A: “このどちらもが、日本の音階と旋律法のヨーロッパとの違いはもちろん、アジア音楽の中での、特異性をきわめて明確に規定する要素なのであるが、ここではまず前者について考えて見よう。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] English A: “For both of these, the differences between Japanese musical rules and those of Europe are of course the elements make Asian music seem so extremely peculiar.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1]

\u4e09\u5473\u7dda\u58f0\u697d shamisen.text: Japanese A: “この核音は、民謡よりもむしろ芸術音楽ことに能楽の謡や三味線声楽の長唄などでは非常にはっきりとした形で現われており、そのばあいの旋律は、ただある１つの核音をめぐって上下浮動するという状態である。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “These nuclear tones appear extremely clearly in Japanese art music, especially in the utai of nō music and shamisen vocal music like nagauta, even more than in folk songs. The melodies in those (art music) cases have the characteristic of revolving around only one nuclear tone, and bobbing up and down around it.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1] “Utai 謡, while etymologically meaning simply “song,” has come to refer specifically to the vocal music of the nō 能 theater tradition. It is accompanied by a hayashi 囃子 ensemble, which consists of a few drums and a flute.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 4] Japanese B: “箏と並んで近代邦楽器の代表、三絃とも言い、また文語では“さみせん”とも書く、胴と棹と棹上部 の海老尾とを本体とし、それに3本の絃, 駒, 3 個の糸巻(転軫, 転手) 等を添え、別に弾奏用と て撥が付属する、胴は花林”で作り、中央の少し ふくれた四角形の中空の箱で、その両端に猫(時と して犬)の皮を張る、棹は紅木、紫檀、樫などで作っ た真直な棒で長さは胴に当る所から上端の上駒 までが約62.5cm.” Tanabe (1975) [”三味線”, p. 85]

tone language.text: Source: “Qian Rong’s translation offers a new perspective to Western scholars on singing in tone languages because her article was not originally composed for an English-language audience, but addresses Mandarin text-setting for a Mandarin-speaking audience. Most English-language scholarship on text-setting in tone languages must introduce and explain the language and the music within the same text.” Carter-Ényì commentary (2024) [1] Definition: “A language which uses variations in pitch, in addition to different consonants and vowels, to distinguish words, e.g. Chinese.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “tone language”)

\u97f3\u697d\u5b66 ongakugaku.text: See 比較音楽学 hikaku ongakugaku  Japanese A: “核音の比較音楽学的意味については第４節でのべるが、西洋音楽一般についてはこれにあたるものを見ない。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 5] English A: “I will discuss the meanings of nuclear tones in comparative musicology in section 4, but in Western music, we do not generally see things like this.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3] Japanese B: “⾳ 楽 に つ い て の 学 問 的 ア プ ロ ーチ の 体 系 を 総 称 す る 概 念 。 ⾳ 楽 に 関 す る 理 論 的 研 究 は 古 代 ギ リ シ ア や 古 代 中 国 を は じ め と し て 歴 史 的 に も さ ま ざ ま な か た ち で お こ な わ れ て きた 。 し か し 、 遊 代 的 学 問 と し て こ の ⽤ 語 が ヨ ー ロ ッ パ に お い て 提 唱 さ れ 、 使 ⽤ さ れ 、 種 々 の 体 系 化 が 試 み ら れ は じ め た の は 1 9 世 紀 後 半 で あ っ た 。 そ の 当 時 か ら 、 ド イ ツ の 総 合 ⼤ 学 を 中 ⼼ に ⾳ 楽 学 の 講 座 や 学 科 が 創 設 さ れ は じ め 、 今 ⽇ に い た る ま で こ う し た 教 育 研 究 機 関 、 あ る い は 学 会 が ⾳ 楽 学 の 発 展 に 寄 与 し て き た 。 欧 ⽶ 諸 国 で も ⾳ 楽 学 の 概 念 や 体 系 に は 種 々 相 異 が あ り 、 そ の ち が い は 今 ⽇ で も か な り 鮮 明 な ⾯ も あ る が 、⾳ 響 学 ， * ⾳ 楽 ⼼ 理 学 ， * ⾳ 楽 美 学 ， * ⾳ 楽 社 会 学 ， * 民 族 ⾳ 楽 学 ， ” ⾳ 楽 教 育 学 ， ⾳ 楽 史 学 ，な ど の 諸 分 野 の ほ か 近 年 急 速 な 展 開 を 経 験 し つ つ あ る * ⾳ 楽 療 法 な ど の 実 践 的 理 論 な ど を 包 括 し て い る の が 実 態 で あ ろ う.” (Tomosha (2002), 120)

melismas.text: English A: “The author could not have composed a modinha, which would accept melismas and elongations of the text, to talk about surucucus (venomous vipers) in an iron cage in Largo da Sé or, the subtext of the song, to suggest a certain ironic criticism when speaking the refrain of “speculation” and “progress of the nation.”” (Stover (2024) [4.6]) Portuguese A: “O autor não podia compor uma modinha, que aceitaria melismas e um encompridamento do texto, para falar de surucucús numa gaiola de ferro no largo da Sé, e, principalmente sugerir uma certa crítica irônica ao falar no estribilho de "especulação" e "progressos da nação".” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “In “Canção da América,” the words expand by leaps with or without portamento, melisma, tremolo, the most diverse appoggiaturas, mordents and grupetos, highlighting the emotional content of the song: the heart cries for escape—the feeling trapped in the chest—and to reestablish the bonds of friendship you have to listen to your heart, no matter what happens. (Carvalho 1990, 325–30).” (Stover (2024) [5.7]) Portuguese B: “Em "Canção da América" as palavras expandidas por saltos com ou sem portamento, melisma, tremolo, appoggiaturas as mais diversas, mordentes e grupetos, realçam o conteúdo emocional da canção: o coração chora pela partida - o sentimento preso no peito - e para reestabelecer os laços de amizade tem-se que ouvir o coração, não importa o que aconteça. (p. 325-10).” (Ulhôa (1999))

Park (2024).text: Park, Joon. 2024. ““At One End of the Endless Universe”: Akira Nishimura’s Interview with Isang Yun.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

\u0444\u0438\u043e\u0440\u0438\u0442\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Тези песни могат да се нарекат безмензурн и (безтактови) и се отличават със съвършено волно движение (ad libitum) без определен ритъм. В безмензурните ни песни някои слогове са твърде много протегнати и правят декламацията неестествена. Друг сществен белег на тия песни са непрекъснатите сложни фиоритури (рулади).” Hristov (1925) (p. 39) English A: “These songs can be called unmeasured (unmetered), and they are distinguished by a completely free pulse (ad libitum) without a determinate rhythm. In our unmeasured songs some syllables are quite elongated, making the declamation unnatural. Another essential characteristic of these songs is the continuous use of complex fiorituri (roulades).” Goldberg (2024) [4.1]

\uc815 jeong.text: Korean A: “'하우프트톤'은 둘이 있는 경우도 많아요. 둘이 있으면 그것은 음양 관계를 갖지요. 예컨대 동(動)과 정(静)의 관계이기도 합니다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “It is often the case that there are two Haupttones. When there are two, they form a relationship of yin and yang. For example, it is also a relationship between motion (動) and stillness (靜).” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u89d2 ju\u00e9.text: Chinese: “《礼记·乐记》：“宫爲君，商爲臣，角爲民，徵爲事，羽爲物；五者不亂，則無怗懘之音矣。” Hanyu dacidian  (宫) English: Pentatonic pitch class 2 Synonymous terms: mi (sung jianpu 简谱), 3 (written jianpu 简谱), 工 (gongchepu 工尺谱) Lam (2024) Ex. 2.2 Lam (2024) Ex. 2.1

music theory.text: Source: “Around the world, music theory is commonly understood as knowledge cultivated by specialist musicians and scholars. It is also assumed to require analytical terminology supplemented with visual representations. However, even in performance traditions less concerned with explicit formulations of musical processes, musical theorizations can be embedded in the minds of the performers and their audience.” (Peiris (2024) [0.1]) Definition: “(The study of) the theoretical aspects of music and its notation, esp. as opposed to actual performance.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “music theory”)

Acorde.text: Spanish A: “La union de varios sonidos que juntos forman armonía. Hay varias especies de Acordes, de los cuales el mas perfecto es el que se compone de la primera del tono, la tercera, la quinta y la octava: tambien se llama Postura.” Palatín (1990) [p.38] (See also Acorde perfecto mayor) Spanish B: “Unión simultánea de tres, cuator ó mas sonidos conform á las leyes fisiológicas del oído, cuyos elementos se funden en un todo armonoioso sin que pierdan su propio carácter. Los acodres son de distintas especies. Pedrell (1890) [p. 4-5]  Spanish C: “De las palabra Latin ad y chorda, cuerda de un instrumento de música.” Lacál (1900) [p. 5]

\u4e0b\u884c\u6027 shimo kudarisei.text: Japanese A: “このようにな ります。しかし これよりももっ と動的な場合も あるし、もっと 静的な場合もあ ります。また上 昇性を持つ場合 と下行性を持つ 場合があります。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “But there are cases where it is more active or more static. Also, there are cases where it has a tendency upward and downward.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u8c03 di\u00e0o.text: Chinese A: “在宫调用语中一般用以表达 “调式”概念。魏、晋以后,宫、均、调三字渐渐支手八混用来表达“调高”概念,如民间的四调、民 间工尺七调。戏曲界另有习惯用法:元、明 黑。三以来对各均宫调式,皆称“宫”而不称“调”,仅 之一。将商、角、徵、羽诸调(调式)称为“调”。稍后, 細》中又合并宫声及商、角、羽诸声,用以统计各声途中不同宫调的总数,如二十八调、十三调(即十仅一三宫调)等。” Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (”调,” p. 80） Chinese B: “按某种音程关系的规格选择若干音律的乐音组成、并在音乐表演中使用的音列。在调作为音列的总概念之下，可有各个侧面的分概念。就音列内部各音之间的音程关系而言，用“音阶”一词来区分各种不同的规格，例如自然七声音阶，五声音阶等。但同一种音程关系规格的音列仍可置于不同的高度，因而，就音列各音的具体绝对音高而言，须用“调域”一词来区分各种不同的律位总体，例如A调单簧管、小工(D)调曲笛这类说法中的调名，是用来指乐器本位音所居的调域的。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) (调) English: “By convention, position gong, the root or origin of fifth generation, represents the entire pentatonic set (yun 均) regardless of the mode (diao 調) or final (tou 頭).” Lam (2024)

textura.text: English A: “What is quite prominent in sub-Saharan African music is the establishment of a temporal order based on the interaction of multiple parts that produce a polyrhythmic texture. The structure of its rhythmic organization is based on asymmetrical groupings of minimum time units or “fastest pulses,” as explained by Kwabena Nketia in The Music of Africa (1974). There is no vertical alignment at the beginning of the measure, as in European notions of meter [compasso].” (Stover (2024) [4.4]) Portuguese A: “O que é bastante proeminente na música africana, sub-saarana, é o estabelecimento de uma ordem temporal, baseada na interação de partes múltiplas que produzem uma textura polirítmica. A organização rítmica se estrutura a partir de agrupamentos assimétricos de unidades de tempo mínimas ou "pulso mais rápido", como explica Kwabena Nketia no seu livro The Music of Africa (1974). Não existe um alinhamento vertical dos inícios dos tempos, como nas noções europeias de compasso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

regularity.text: Source: “Maintaining the right balance between metrical regularity and the forces that challenge such regularity is key in many musical traditions, and, one might say, in artistic expressions in general: one needs a structure but also something that puts pressure on, or vitalizes, this structure.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [4]) Definition: “As a count noun: a regular or habitual occurrence or activity; something which conforms to a trend, pattern, law, etc.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “regularity” 2)

\uc544\uc7c1 ajaeng.text: English A: “Sanjo may be played with a variety of traditional Korean string or wind instruments, including gayageum 가야금 (twelve-string zither), geomungo 거문고 (six-string zither), ajaeng 아쟁 (bowed zither), and daegeum 대금 (bamboo flute).” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) Korean B: “사부(部) 소속 당악기(唐樂器)의 하나.① 아쟁은 도설(圖 說)에 나온다. 앞 뒷판의 제도는 대쟁(大事)과 같다. 아쟁은 오래의(五禮儀) 고취(鼓吹)와 종묘· 영녕전 등가에, 문소 전(文昭殿) 섭행(攝行)·친행(親行) 전상악(殿上樂)에, 성종(1469-1494) 때 전정헌가(殿庭軒架)에, 그리고 종묘ㆍ영녕전 등가에, 그리고 정전예연 여기악공배립(正殿禮宴女妓樂工排立) 및 학연화대처용무합설(鶴蓮花臺處 容舞合設)의 초입배열도(初入排列圖)·시종회무도(始終回舞圖)에 배열된 악기의 하나이다.” Song (2010) [p. 206]

anacruse.text: English A: “This may even be the reason why so many popular Brazilian songs have an instrumental introduction: to give the singer the tonality of the song and allow them to start with an anacrusis.” (Stover (2024) [5.3]) Portuguese A: “Esta pode ser inclusive a razão por que tantas canções brasileiras populares têm uma introdução instrumental: para dar ao cantor ou cantora o tom da música e permitír-lhe começar em anacruse.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Entrada no ar. Notas iniciais de um ritmo que precede ao início do compasso. Chama~se também ritmo anacrústico ou protético. Dá~se o nome de ritmo tético ao que tem início no primeiro tempo do compasso.” (Cosme (1957), 8).

dit/dik/jit.text: jit  English A: “These four strokes (and associated timbres) are termed “seed syllables” (bīja akṣara) and they are named as follows: tat—a damped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 8; see also Video 4), dit (or dik or jit)—a damped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 9; see also Video 5), ton (or tom or toṃ)—an undamped stroke on the lower drumhead (Example 10; see also Video 6), and nam (or naṃ)—an undamped stroke on the higher drumhead (Example 11; see also Video 7).” (Peiris (2024) [4.1]) English B: mnemonic syllable for a drum stroke (Peiris (2025))

dang.text: Balinese A: “Pukulan ngembat, artinya ngoktap (pukulan satu oktaf). Ngoktap artinya, dalam suatu tempat dari tepi ke tepi. Itu arti ngembat. Pukulan satu oktaf adalah pukulan yang berselang empat nada dalam gamelan palegongan yang menggunakan laras pelog lima nada, seperti yaitu 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Sedangkan dalam gamelan semar pagulingan yang menggunakan laras tujuh nada akan terlihat seperti berikut: 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong). Artinya pukulan berselang enam.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Ngembat means octave (ngoktap), from end to end. Playing an octave means an interval of four tones [not counting the octave tones] in the palegongan, which uses five-tone pélog, tuning, that is, tones 235612 (dong, deng, dung, dang, ding, dong). Whereas in gamelan semar pagulingan using the 7-tone scale it will be 23456712 (dong, deng, deung, dung, dang, daing, dong), an interval of six tones.” Tenzer (2024)  Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Dari 10 (sepuluh) nada yang dijiwai oleh Smara dan Ratih sebagai Dewa Percintaan bersumber pada 7 (tujuh) buah nada yang urutan nadanya sebagai berikut: ding, dong, deng, ndung, dung, dang, nding. Ketujuh nada di atas merupakan sumber bunyi dalam gambelan Bali dan menurut Prakempa bunyi (suara) itu disebut Genta Pinara Pitu (bunyi berjarak tujuh) (alinea : 7 - 10).” Bandem (1986) [p. 13]

Tangshi baike (1990).text: Tangshi baike dacidian 唐诗百科大辞典. Beijing: Guangming ribao chubanshe 北京:光明日报出版社, 1990.

Escala menor arm\u00f3nica.text: Spanish A: “He aquí la escala menor armónica, metamorfoseada.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22] English A: “Here is the harmonic minor scale, metamorphosed…” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 22] Spanish B: “El MODO MENOR de las escalas puede ser armónico, porque todas sus notas se prestan á ser notadas armónicamente, ó melódico, porque todos sus intervalos son gratos al oído. Constituyen el primero tres intervalos de un tono, uno de un tono y medio y tres de semitono, siéndolo dos de éstos por naturaleza y el último por forzosa alteración para conseguir la sensible y poder formar cadencia. Ej.: la, si, do, re, mi, fa, sol sostenido, do, donde se ve que hay intervalo de un tono y medio entre la nota superdominante y la sensible.” Lacál (1900) [p. 169]

groove.text: Source: “Based upon this distinctive character, Ulhôa makes the point that Brazilian popular song produces a circular feel (in contrast to what she calls the linear feel of much Western art music). However, when all the layers stress, for example, the first beat of a pattern, it may also produce a circular feel, in fact—see, for example, Snead’s analysis of how repetition in many African American musics makes the groove cut back to its own beginning (Snead 1984).” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [4]) Definition: “Groove is the result of a musical process that is often identified as a vital drive or rhythmic propulsion. It involves the creation of rhythmic intensity appropriate to the musical style or genre being performed. Groove is created within a piece of music by shifting timing and dynamic elements away from the expected pulse or dynamic level. A musician’s sense of pulse is subjective, not objective; musicians interpret and perform the passage of time and the presence of the pulse in slightly different ways. As musicians perform, the push and pull of those subjective interpretations adds tension to a performance and produces a sense of groove. Much modern audio recording and production software has a “humanizing” function to replicate that feeling of subjectivity, which helps subdue the otherwise robotic, or mechanical sounds of computer-generated music.” (Grove Music, “Groove”)

\u76e4\u6e09\u8abf banshikich\u014d (B).text: Japanese A: “そしてこと曲の主音が元来（h）であるから、hが重要な意味を持つのは当然としても、dもやはり重心がおかれているように見える。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 15] English A: “And because this piece’s tonic was originally banshikichō (B), it is natural that the pitch B would hold an important meaning, but the pitch D also seems to have been given a sense of importance.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [9.2] Japanese B: “*盤渉の音を宮(主音)とした音階、雅楽では 六調子の一で、律に属する、能の囃子にも用いられる。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 150]

anya.text: Igbo A: “ Egwu mụ ete aka, nwee nkeji dị iche iche. Doo anya, tọ ụtọ.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “My songs become longer, and have different sections, become clearer and sweet.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

\u0445\u0440\u043e\u043d\u043e\u0441 \u0.text: Bulgarian A: “По отношение на такта българската музика съдържа една особеност, която е чужда не само на западната музика, но и на музиката на съедните нам страни, както и на източната (персо-арабска) музика. Тая особеност се крие в образуването на редица тактове, служещи за основа на разнообразните наши танци. За основен (првичен) елемент (хронос протос) в тия тактове служи движение (време) с бързина около 400—432 на минута, т.е. движение, пет пъти по-бързо от пулса на възрастен човек.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “With regard to meter, Bulgarian music contains a feature that is foreign not only to Western music, but also to the music of our neighboring countries, as well as to Eastern (Persian-Arabic) music. This feature is hidden in the formation of a series of meters that serve as a basis for our diverse dances. Serving as a fundamental (primary) element (chronos protos) in these meters is a pulse (beat) with a tempo of around 400–432 per minute, i.e., five times faster than the heartrate of an adult person.” Goldberg (2024) [3.1]  Bulgarian B: “Хронос протос (гр. hrónos prótos, лат. tempus primum първично време) в словесната, музикалната и танцовата мет- рика единицата мярка за трайност, с ко- ято се измерва продължителността на срич- ките, тоновете и жестовете (тактово време на гръцки хронос, на латински темпус).” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 375-376]

capung manjus.text: English A: “The technique of playing gendér in the gamelan angklung is called capung manjus.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.8])  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Pukulan gendér angklung, capung manjus namanya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The ubiquitous angklung gamelan has a four-tone scale and instruments with but four keys—a single octave. Though its music can be complex the instrument is quick to navigate. Capung manjus means bathing dragonfly; an idiom describing a “water-skimming” quick bath for a person as well.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.7]) *Lexical field: Natural world  (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u559c\u5287 kigeki.text:
喜 + 劇 喜: joy, delight, pleasure 劇: drama, play 
 Japanese A: “最悪の環境―監獄の中で書いた作品は 驚くことに喜劇的な内容でした。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 59] English A: ““The circumstances were the worst, however, the opera I completed in the prison was a comedy.”” Park (2024) [6]

\u30b3\u30f3\u30c8\u30e9\u30d0\u30b9 kon.text: Japanese A: “それにつ いては、コントラバスの四つのピッチカ ートが準備になる。だから、どこが準備 か、どこが本当の音かということも、常 に相対的なわけです。そして、この冒頭 ではDの音が「ハウプト・トン」なんで す。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “About this tone [Bb], the four pizzicati by the contrabass prepares it. Therefore, it is all relative when it comes to determining what is a tone and what prepares the tone. And in this opening, the D tone is a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “［伊］ヴァイオリン属の最大の楽器で最低音域を受けもつ。全長約185cm。通常ヴァイオリン属に分類しているが、厳密にはヴィオール属との中間に位置する。4度間隔での調弦や、ネックの付け根でなで肩になった胴、平らな裏板，ドイツ式では手のひらを上に向けて弓を保持することなど、ヴィオール属の特徴をもっている（ただしヴァイオリン型の楽器もある）。※巻きは金属製の歯車ネジになってい る。記譜は実音より1オクターヴ高い。4本の弦は下1点ほ、下1点い、に、と音に調弦される。5本の弦を有するものもあり、その場合5本目は下2点は音に調談される。恐にはガットまたは合成繊維にクローム鋼の線ををまなものもあるか、スティール線にクローム調を巻いたものが多く使われる。” (Tomosha (2002), 252)

\uc0b0\uc870 sanjo.text: English A: “Pansori 판소리 and sanjo 산조 are small-ensemble genres of Korean folk music with many shared characteristics.(1) Pansori consists of a dramatic narrative performance by a sorikkun 소리꾼, a vocalist-narrator, and a gosu 고수, a drummer who provides rhythmic accompaniment on a barrel drum called a puk 북.” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) English B: scatterd melodies, virtuoso solo music with percussion accompaniment (Pyǒn (2012) 116) Korean B: 주로 남도소리의 판소리 가락을 장단이라는 틀에 넣은 기악독주 음악. 조선 말기(19c)에 발생하였다. 진양으로 시작하여 중모리, 중중모리, 굿거리, 어모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리(세산조시) 등 의 장단으로 이어지면서 점차 그 속도가 빨라지며, 일반적으로 장구 반주가 따른다. 가야금, 거문고, 대금, 해금, 아쟁 산조 등의 순으로 발생하였다. (Pyǒn (2012) 116)

\uc2dc si.text: Korean A: “'하우프트톤'의 경우, 음과 양의 상대시 변화는, 미세한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 시작하며 기대한 시간에 의해서 파악하는 방법에 이르기까지 여러 단계가 있습니 다. 거기에는 순간에 영원이 반영되고, 영원을 순간으로서 포착한 수가 있어요. 그것이 동양인의 '시'(時)에 대한 사고방식으로서, 서양인의 '시'의 사고방식과는 전혀 다른 점이지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 157] English A: “In the case of a Hauptton, the relative change between yin and yang can be understood through various steps from micro-timing or macro-timing. In it, a moment reflects eternity, and eternity can be captured as a moment. That is the Eastern way of thinking about time (時), which is completely different from the Western conception of time.” Park (2024) [4.1]

harmony.text: harmonia (Portuguese) 和音 héyīn (Chinese) Source: “Carrillo wrote his first music theory treatises in the 1910s, which were pedagogical and mostly staid, devoted to subjects Jadassohn had written about such as canon and fugue, orchestration, and harmony.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.2] Definition: “The combining of notes simultaneously, to produce chords, and successively, to produce chord progressions. The term is used descriptively to denote notes and chords so combined, and also prescriptively to denote a system of structural principles governing their combination.” (Grove Music Online, “harmony”)

gerantang joged bumbung.text: English A: “Gerantang joged bumbung style is called bramana ngisep sari; its sound is pangirik.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.14]) See gerantang  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang gagebug gerantang joged bumbung, bramara ngisep sari. Pangirik nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Gerantang joged bumbung refers to an ensemble of gerantang accompanying ngibing, a flirtation dance. Bramana ngisep sari means “beetle sips flower essence”; pangirik is a tickling sensation. The juxtaposed and somewhat incongruous imagery of beetle, flower, and tickling cunningly reveals the potential of ngibing, which in yesteryear led to more than flirtation.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.13])

\u6d44\u7460\u7483 j\u014druri.text: Japanese A: “１つ１つ例を上げるまでもなく、近世邦楽とよばれるもののうち、三味線を伴奏とする声楽は、一般にこの例と大差はない。民謡よりもはるかに明瞭な数小節にわたる１つの核音の支配は、このジャンルでは、唄であろうと浄瑠璃であろうとけっして珍しくない.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 8–9] English A: “Without even bringing up examples one by one, among recent Japanese music, vocal music accompanied by the shamisen generally does not differ much from this example. It is not at all rare in these genres, whether song or jōruri, for the control of a single nuclear tone to cross a few measures much more clearly than in folk song.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [6.1] English B: “Jōruri 浄瑠璃 is another genre of shamisen-accompanied vocal music. It leans more towards narration than towards song, and is often used to accompany puppet theater genres like bunraku 文楽—this emphasis on narration is why Koizumi contrasts it with “song” (uta 唄).” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [Footnote 13] Japanese C: “邦楽の広い様式の一、語り物に属する。初め 安土時代に才女小野お通が、牛若丸と浄瑠璃姫との情事を主材とした 長編の物語を作り、これを浄瑠璃姫物語12段とし、琵琶法師がこれ に作曲したのに初まり、桃山時代に至り沢住、滝野両検校がそれを三 味線音楽に移して世に弘めた、その後その門弟達がその様式を真似て いろいろの材料をとって新作を発表したので、それを一概に浄瑠璃と 総称した。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 92]

\u6839\u672c konpon.text: Japanese A: “"しかし、私の音楽が長時間緊張感を保っているということは、全くそのとおりなんです。私の音楽の根本をなしている線的な要素が、巧妙に持続性を持っており、そのナチュール自体が、持続の無限な可能性を持っているのです。たとえば能の音楽とか歌舞伎のように、何時間同じ線を聴いても絶対飽きない秘密がこれなんです." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: "But it is true that my pieces maintain tension for a long time. The foundation of my music, the linear element possesses a deft persistence. That “nature” [ナチュール] itself enables the unlimited persistence. For example, the secret of not being bored while listening to the same line for hours, like Noh [能] or Kabuki [歌舞技] is this." (Park (2024) [2.3])

ornamentos.text: English A: “The emphasis on the melody is so striking that all the notes that compose it are essential to the song’s identity, including those that would be considered surface-level ornaments in the European classical-romantic music that has so influenced popular Brazilian music. What could be considered superfluous for melodic evaluation, such as notes that are foreign to the basic harmonic structure of the song (grupetos, mordants, appoggiaturas) have a functional importance in popular Brazilian song.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “A ênfase na melodia é tão marcante que todas as notas que a compõem são essenciais para a identidade da canção, incluindo aquelas que seria consideradas ornamentos superficiais na música clássico-romântica européia que tanto influenciou a música brasileira popular. O que poderia ser considerado supérfluo para a avaliação melódica, como notas extranhas à estrutura harmônica básica na canção (grupetos, mordentes, appoggiaturas) têm uma importância funcional na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “ornatos. Certas notas ou grupos de notas que ornam a melodia.” (Cosme (1957) 85)

gangasa.text: English: “Balinese interlocking patterns are played by pairs of musicians and on some instruments may involve improvisation, though in a different way than the patterns in Part III (see Tilley 2019). But Geria only addresses a type called ubit-ubitan, played on the upper-register gangsa (metallophone family). Most gamelan have eight gangsa. In ubit-ubitan rhythm and contour are fully specified, though patterns may perch on any set of scale degrees depending on the surrounding musical context.” Tenzer (2024) [4.1]

sarira.text: Balinese A: “Hana sarira, apan sarira angingkup salwring swara, laras patutan, lwirnya, swara patut pitu.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “There is an essence encompassing all tones, tuning and modes, a 7-tone sound.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.3])

\u0442\u0430\u043a\u0442\u0430/takta.text: Bulgarian A: “По отношение на такта българската музика съдържа една особеност, която е чужда не само на западната музика, но и на музиката на съседните нам страни, както и на източната (персо-арабска) музика. Тая особеност се крие в образуването на редица тактове, служещи за основа на разнообразните наши танци. За основен (првичен) елемент (хронос протос) в тия тактове служи движение (време) с бързина около 400—432 на минута, т.е. движение, пет пъти по-бързо от пулса на възрастен човек.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “With regard to meter, Bulgarian music contains a feature that is foreign not only to Western music, but also to the music of our neighboring countries, as well as to Eastern (Persian-Arabic) music. This feature is hidden in the formation of a series of meters that serve as a basis for our diverse dances. Serving as a fundamental (primary) element (chronos protos) in these meters is a pulse (beat) with a tempo of around 400–432 per minute, i.e., five times faster than the heartrate of an adult person.” Goldberg (2024) [3.1]  See also: Bulgarian B: “Такт (лат. tactus букв. досег, допир, усещане, осезание, действие) в съвременната музика терминът Т. означава част от музикалното произведение, която започва на силно (теж- ко) метрично време и завършва през следващото силно. В нотното писмо. Т. се отделят един от друг стактова черта, която винаги стои пред силното ме- трично време. В началото на нотния текст, а често и на други места на текста се отбелязва размерът, който лежи в основата на Т., изразен с дробно число, наречен още тактов показател. Числителят на резмера сочи броя на метричните времена в/ Т., а знаменателят — нотната стойност, която отговаря на всяко метрично време. В ежедневната практика на музикантите понятието Т. често се смесва с понятието размер, вж. размер и метрум, неравноделни тактове.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 322]

tern\u00e1rios.text: English A: “In metric music of the European tradition, all parts tend to synchronize precisely; time is counted in regular pulsations, generally contained within binary or ternary measures, whose limits are represented by barlines, with an accent at the beginning of each measure.” (Stover (2024) [5.12]) Portuguese A: “Na música medida de tradição européia todas as partes tendem a se sincronizar precisamente; o tempo é contado em pulsações regulares, geralmente contidos em compassos binários ou ternários, cujos limites são representados por barras de compasso, com uma acentuação no começo de cada compasso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u8868\u73fe hy\u014dgen.text: Japanese A: “大部分の箇所では互に４度音程をなすこれら核音だけが、音階の主要音であり、抑制された旋律的表現が、これら核音の微妙なピッチの上下変化をもたらしている.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 11] English A: “In most places, only nuclear tones that make up the interval of a fourth with each other are the chief notes of the scale. Restrained melodic expression brings subtle changes of pitch to these nuclear tones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [7.2]

Gambuh.text: English A: “The bowed spike lute rebab and the bamboo end-blown flutes suling play the melody in the Gamelan Gambuh, an ensemble dating perhaps to as early as the fifteenth century, and commonly understood to be the crucial precursor of later gamelan composed of bronze keyed instruments and gongs. Gambuh, already rarely seen in Geria’s time, was nonetheless cultivated in the village of Pedungan, near to Geria’s home village Buagan, and at the Puri Pemecutan, where Geria trained, also very close by.” (Tenzer (2024) [1.1]) Balinese B: “Maka tatabuhan Gambuh, kayeki jajaranya. Yan gurnita patut pelog rumuhun, patut salendro ring untat, Iwirnya : dung, ndung, dang, ndang, ding, nding, dong, ndong, deng, ndeng.Lyan malih kayeki; dang, ndang, ding, nding, dong, ndong, deng, ndeng, dung, ndung. Lyan malih kayeki; ding, nding, dong, ndong, deng, ndeng, dung, ndung, dang, ndang. Lyan malih kayeki : dong, ndong, deng, ndeng, dung, ndung, dang, ndang, ding, nding.” (Bandem (1986), 72) English B( Chat-GPT Translation): “The Structure of Tatabuhan Gambuh (Musical Arrangement of Gambuh) This is the arrangement of Tatabuhan Gambuh (a traditional Balinese musical composition). If the melody follows the Pelog tuning as the main scale and Slendro tuning in its variations, the tonal sequence is as follows: These sequences outline the melodic patterns used in Gambuh, demonstrating the interplay between Pelog and Slendro scales in traditional Balinese music.”  See dang daing deng deung dong dung  Balinese C: “Gambelan Meladprana digunakan untuk mengiringi tari Gambuh ritual, baik berlangsung di sorgaloka maupun di istana para raja-raja.” Bandem (1986) [p. 15] Balinese D: “dramatari Bali yg tertua dan dianggap sbg sumber dr beberapa jenis drama tari Bali. Gambuh pagambuhan perangkat gamelan yg sebagian besar ricikan melodinya terdiri atas ricikan suling dg ukuran besar (garis tengah 3 cm dan panjang sekitar 100 cm), sbg pengiring tari gambuh.” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 142, Bidang Istilah Musik]

iber-iberan.text: English A: “Iber-iberan is a small bird such as a chicken or dove released to fly free during a cremation ritual, thus paralleling the human soul’s departure. The idea of lightness and freedom evoke the buoyancy and animation of semar pegulingan music.” (Tenzer (2024)), see semar pagulingan  English B: “The technique of playing trompong in gamelan semar pagulingan [a court ensemble playing a delicate and refined repertoire] is called iber-iberan. The names of the ways to play it are the same as those for number 1 above.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.2]) Balinese/Indonesian B: “Pukulan trompong semar pagulingan, iber-iberan namanya. Banyak jenisnya sama dengan nomor 1 (satu) di atas.” (Geria (n.d.)) *Lexical field: Natural world and cultural practice or unseen phenomenon (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u4e09\u9023\u7b26 san ren fu.text: 三 + 連 + 符 三: three 連: take along, lead, connect 符: token, sign, mark Japanese A: “この音 には装飾音が欠けています。しかし、三 連符の頭の休符がそれにかわる働きをし ます。それに続いてメリスマ的な要素が ありますね。これはもう少し発展した「ハ ウプト・トン」のあり方なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “There is no decorative tone for this. But the first rest of the triplet substitutes its role. It is followed by a melismatic element. This is a more developed figure of a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “連符の一種。本来 2等分される音符を3等分したもの。” (Tomosha (2002), 273)

Lee commentary (2024).text: Lee, Jiyeon. 2024. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4. (CHECK CITATION)

\u30e1\u30ea\u30b9\u30de(\u7684) merisum.text: Japanese A: “この音 には装飾音が欠けています。しかし、三 連符の頭の休符がそれにかわる働きをし ます。それに続いてメリスマ的な要素が ありますね。これはもう少し発展した「ハ ウプト・トン」のあり方なんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “There is no decorative tone for this. But the first rest of the triplet substitutes its role. It is followed by a melismatic element. This is a more developed figure of a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “つの音節を、いくっもの音で装飾性豊かに歌う歌唱形態.” (Tomosha (2002) 694)

fugue.text: Fuga (Spanish) Source: “Carrillo wrote his first music theory treatises in the 1910s, which were pedagogical and mostly staid, devoted to subjects Jadassohn had written about such as canon and fugue, orchestration, and harmony.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.2] Definition: “Imitative counterpoint in some fashion has been the single unifying factor in the history of fugue, but as compositional approaches to imitation changed so did the meanings and usages of the word ‘fugue’.” (Grove Music Online, “fugue”)

portamento.text: English A: “In “Canção da América,” the words expand by leaps with or without portamento, melisma, tremolo, the most diverse appoggiaturas, mordents and grupetos, highlighting the emotional content of the song: the heart cries for escape—the feeling trapped in the chest—and to reestablish the bonds of friendship you have to listen to your heart, no matter what happens. (Carvalho 1990, 325–30).” (Stover (2024) [5.7]) Portuguese A: “Em "Canção da América" as palavras expandidas por saltos com ou sem portamento, melisma, tremolo, appoggiaturas as mais diversas, mordentes e grupetos, realçam o conteúdo emocional da canção: o coração chora pela partida - o sentimento preso no peito - e para reestabelecer os laços de amizade tem-se que ouvir o coração, não importa o que aconteça. (p. 325-10).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Designa um ornamenta que consiste numa suava translação de um som a outro.” (Cosme (1957) 92)

\u897f\u65b9 x\u012b f\u0101ng.text: Chinese A: “我說要向西方乞靈，這亦是很容易喚起，何消你說這一類的答話。” Li (2024)  “西方的學者們對於音樂的研究，雖然是有許多獨到的地方，但是，因為各人的見解不同，所以你亦很不容易認定某一派的學說是對，某一派的學說是不對，因為不論那一派的學說，牠都是帶有一部分的真理，但是同時卻亦有許多不對的地方，你要把各派學說的短長略爲論列一下，恐怕既經要佔滿了這本小冊子的篇幅，所以我這裏祇好把那兩派各走極端的學說先拿來大略說一說。” Li (2024)  English A: “Tsing Chu (1934a) critiqued the contemporaneous view that the import of Western music into China was a form of cultural imperialism, and suggested that the Chinese should study Western music as a means of reforming [gaige] and/or improving [gailiang] national music. Elsewhere he had elaborated on concrete ways of reforming and/or improving national music in terms of scale, instrument, vocal techniques, and love (1931a, 1–11); see also Li 1930, 36–8. On the discussion of national music during Li’s time, see, for example, Zheng 1928; Xiao 1939.” Li (2024)  Chinese B: “犹西洋。指欧美各国.” Hanyu dacidian  (西方, 2)

derramar.text: English A: “By “spilling” [derramar] the structure of strong and weak beats through the bar and accepting the prosodic coherence or “magic of the word sung in the Brazilian way,” as Caetano Veloso says, we gain “fantasy,” vitality, and freshness.” (Stover (2024) [5.9]) Portuguese A: “Ao derramar pelo compasso a estrutura de tempos fortes e fracos e aceitar a coerência prosódica ou "magia da palavra cantada à moda brasileira", como diz Caetano Veloso, ganha-se em "fantasia", vitalidade e frescor.” (Ulhôa (1999))

m\u00fasica coreogr\u00e1fica.text: Portuguese A: “Mas o que me faz afirmar que a síncopa europeia é uma especulação prática de música erudita é não só a quase inexistência do movimento sincopado na música popular europeia (com exceção de portugas e ciganas {sobre estes ver Lavignac V}) como por ela não ser corrente mesmo na música coreográfica de criação erudita.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “But what makes me assert that European syncopation is a practical speculation of classical music is not only the almost nonexistence of the syncopated movement in European popular music (with the exception of Portuguese and Gypsy (Lavignac 1913)) as it is not common even in the choreographic music of the Western classical tradition.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

nomenclature.text: Source: “It is generally understood that gamelan music did not possess such a nomenclature then, or, at least, there is no record, oral or written, of one. Geria adapted words used to label formal components of poetry for instrumental music, and invented outright—employing a cunning diversity of metaphoric, symbolic, and evocatively descriptive labels—a cornucopia of terms for instrument functions and melodic patterns.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “The (frequently systematic) assignation of names; (Biology) the allocation of Latin names to species and other taxa. Also: the manner in which names are assigned.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “nomenclature”)

\u30d4\u30c3\u30c1\u30ab \u30fc\u30c8 pi.text: Japanese A: “それにつ いては、コントラバスの四つのピッチカ ートが準備になる。だから、どこが準備 か、どこが本当の音かということも、常 に相対的なわけです。そして、この冒頭 ではDの音が「ハウプト・トン」なんで す。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “About this tone [Bb], the four pizzicati by the contrabass prepares it. Therefore, it is all relative when it comes to determining what is a tone and what prepares the tone. And in this opening, the D tone is a Hauptton.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “ピッツィカート pizzicato［伊］擦弦楽器で弓を 使わずに指で弦をはじく奏法。pizz、と略記して指示し、ふたたび弓で演奏するときは arco と指示する.” (Tomosha (2002), 552)

quarter tone.text: Source: “Carrillo justified this sixteenth-tone limit for his microtonal system by arguing that it was practical. Within a single composition, he pointed out, sixteenth tones could be multiplied to form eighth tones, quarter tones, semitones, and whole tones, and so could be reconciled with a variety of microtonal and traditional instruments (Carrillo 1938, 24).” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.4]

\u4ecf\u6559\u7684\u306a\u54f2\u5b66 buk.text: 仏教 + 哲学 仏教: Buddhism 哲学: philosophy Japanese A: ““全くの無から何かの音が生まれる 無に終わるんです。それは仏教的な哲学 尹そうです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 56] English A: “This piece is born within nothingness [無] and ends as nothingness. That is the Buddhist philosophy.” Park (2024) [4.1]

canda praba.text: Balinese A: “yaning gebug selat siki, candrapraba ngaran,” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “If two keys separated by one in-between are struck it is called candra praba [moonlight];” (Tenzer (2024) [I.8])

\uc8fc\uc694\uc74c juyo-um.text: Korean A: “흐르는 속에 이 있고, 그 음을 둘러싼 음 모두가'주요음'이다.” (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146) English A: “Within a flowing line [流れる線], there is one important tone [音]. With this tone in the center, I call all sounds that surround it Hauptton [主要音].” (Park (2024) [1])

canto.text: Portuguese A: “Ato de emitir sons com o órgão vocal; inflexão da voz. (DM) A expressão "traz-me de canto chorado" (= importunar, aporrinhar) parece trazer a palavra canto no seu sentido musical. Castro Lopes (Origens dos anexins, prolóquios,., 1909, p. 59) explicou engenhosamente a expressão lembrando os cantos fúnebres "no velar c enterramento tradicionais dos de-funtos.""Entre povos antigos, c ainda modernamente em alguns, havia o costume de pagar a quem chorasse os mortos: eram principalmente mulheres as que c-xerciam este ofício, provavelmente por serem mais sensíveis, c terem as glândulas lacrimais no belo sexo maior facilidade na seereção da linfa pesa-rosa, prosaicamente chamada lágrima. Carpideiras, assim se denominavam as tais fornecedoras de choro e lamentações, palavra derivada do verbo car-pir, do latim carpere (desculpem) colher, arrancar, porque quem sente grandes dores arranca os cabelos, ctc.'Em muitos países, onde os enterros se lazem à mão, entoam os sacerdotes um canto lúgubre, um canto chorado, acompanhando o féretro até o cc-mitério. Desta religiosa e augusta solenidade parece que tirou o povo o si-mile, por ele aplicado, quando alguém anda sempre após outrem repetindo-lhe com voz lamentosa o mesmo pedido, que já mil vezes tem fei-10. A vítima de tal importuno representa o morto, atrás de quem vai o enfadonho suplicante entoando um canto chorado que é a fastidiosa e monótona repetição do mesmo assunto.” (Andrade (1989), 105)

polir\u00edtmica.text: English A: “Another type of temporal organization that marked and greatly influenced the formation of popular Brazilian music was the conception of African rhythm-temporal organization, which is polyrhythmic. In this conception, there are independent but intertwined parts. Each part repeats a rhythmic “phrase,” incommensurable with one another, which make sense precisely due to their interweaving. Traditional samba itself, as we can see in the first recordings with this name, was formed by the repetition of small melodic-rhythmic patterns.” (Stover (2024) [4.3]) Portuguese A: “Outro tipo de organização temporal, que marcou e influenciou muito a formação da música brasileira popular, foi a concepção de organização rítmo-temporal africana, que é polirítmica. Nesta concepção, se tem partes independentes mas entrelaçadas. Cada parte, repete uma "frase" rítmica, desencontrada uma da outra, que vai fazer sentido, exatamente, pelo entrelaçamento entre todas elas. O próprio samba tradicional, como podemos observar nas primeiras gravações com este nome, era formado pela repetição de pequenos padrões melódico-rítmicos.” (Ulhôa (1999))

agidibo.text: English A: “The Yoruba people have Agidibo, they have agidibo/Eh, it is in its own unique style/They are all the same type of instrument, the Zimbabweans call their own mbira/In Shona, in Zimbabwe they call it mbira/Yorubas call it Agidigbo.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]) Igbo A: “Eze: Haaa Ndị Yoruba nwekwara Agidibo, ha nwere Agidibo/Ee, ọ dị n'ụdị nke ya/Ọ bụkwa ofu ihe a e tu ndị Zimbabwe si nwe nke ha a na-akpọ mbira/Na Shona, na Zimbabwe, Mbira ka a na-akpọ ya/Na Yoruba, Agidigbo/Ndị be anyị nwe ya.” (Carter-Ényì (2024) [6])

g\u00e4\u1e6da beraya.text: English A: “The first set of sung verses presented here—in Paragraphs 9 and 12—belongs to the genre known as däkum ata, which is performed as an “offering of sound” (śabda pūjāva) during a Bera Pōya Hēvisi ritual. Each line in these verses contains eighteen poetic morae. Although this repertoire is more closely associated with dawula drums (Example 3), in the recording featured here—Videos 1 and 2—they are performed with gäṭa beraya drums (Example 4).” Peiris (2024) [8] Sinhalese A: “ගැටබෙරය : ගණේගොඩ රූකම් වලිනුත්, ගලපාත විහාරයේ උළුවස්සෙනුත් යාපහුවෙනුත් (අංක 28 දරන චිත්‍රය ) පනාවිටියේ ලි කැටයමකිනුත්, මුල්කිරිගල චිත්‍ර වලිනුත් මේ බෙරය දක්නා ලැබේ.” Godakumura (1970) [p. 16] English B: “Barrel-shaped drum (gäțabera): From the sculptures at Ganegoda, from those at Galapāta Vihara and at Yapahuwa (Fig. 28) from a wood-carving: t the Panăvițiya Ambalama and from a painting at Mulkirigala we have examples of this drum.” Godakumura (1970) [p. 26] Video Example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eJM5_kF_Qgk English C: type of drum (Peiris (2025)

\uc804\uc870\uc640 jeonjowa.text: Korean A: “우조의 경우, 하청은 떠는 기능을 갖고 있지 않고, 반종지하는 음이다. 하본청은 전조와 변조 에 기능하는 음으로서 그 역할이 작지 않고, 옥타브 위에서는 우조 특유의 씩씩한 느낌을 주는 핵심적인 음이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238-239] English A: “In Ujo, hacheong is the note of a half cadence, without the capacity for vibration. It plays a significant role in transposition and modulation and, when used above the octave, contributes to the distinctive and energizing quality of Ujo.” Kim (2024) [3.6]

\u9589\u3056\u3055\u308c\u305f\u97f3 toz.text: Japanese A: "だから、東洋の音楽はいつ始まってもいいし、いつ止めてもいいしという従来の伝統音楽の考え方で曲を書けば、そういう閉ざされた音の世界から開放されるのではないかと思います." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 53) English A: " I think one would be freed from the world of enclosed tones [閉ざされた音] if one composes with the traditional East Asian way of thinking that music can begin and end at any point in time." (Park (2024) [2.4])

gerantang.text: English A: “gerantang (an instrument made from a row of tuned bamboo tubes suspended in a frame),” (Tenzer (2024) [2.1])

Acorde disminu\u00eddo.text: Spanish A: “El disminuido, que tiene dos intervalos de tres semitonos, tendrá al metamorfosearse al duplo dos seis semitonos, y el resultado final será.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 24] English A: “The diminished triad, which has two intervals of three semitones, will have two intervals of six semitones when metamorphosed to the double, and the final result will be the following.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 24] See also Acorde, Pedrell (1890) [p. 5]

\u697d\u5668\u7de8\u6210 gakki hensei.text: 楽器: musical instrument + 編成: composition, organization, compliation Japanese A: “リズム・旋律法・多声性・楽器編成などあらゆる点でその他のジャンルと異なる” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 14] English A: “All aspects such as rhythm, melodic system, polyphony, and instrumental organization differ from other genres.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [8.2]

\u0410\u043a\u043e\u043c\u043f\u0430\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Акомпаниментът с тъпан или дайре напесни в този такт става по следния начин.” Hristov (1925) (p. 48) English A: “The accompaniment of songs in this meter with tŭpan or daire occurs in the following way.” Goldberg (2024) [5.16] Bulgarian B: “1) партия*, допълваща и съпровождаща главния глас (солото) в едно инструментално или вокално произведение. В епохата на предкласиката А. често се означавал само с цифрован бас*, което е давало твърде голяма свобода на акомпанятора (клавесинист, органист, лютнист и пр.). Под А. обикновено се разбира специално обособената партия на акомпаниращия инструмент (в инструментални пиеси, художествени песни, романси*, арии* и пр.) или на оркестъра (при соловите концерти), но А. може да бъде включен и в самата тъкан на произведението, предназначено за многозвучен полифоничен инструмент (пиано*, орган*, арфа*, китара* и пр.).” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 14]

igwe.text: Igbo A: “ I ya-anụ ihe, I nụ ka ọ si hazi ya, M kpọ egwu ya, kpọtaya, M wee kpọzie nhazia, Site na, nke mbụ, igwe nke mbụ, ruo n’igwe nke ikpeazu.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “You would hear something, how he tunes it (ubọ-aka). When I play his music, and play it well, I will now play the scale, from the first, the first prong, to the last prong.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

\u8f6c\u8c03 zh\u01d4an di\u00e0o.text: Chinese A: “调性音乐中，从某一调到另一调的交换称为转调。这种变换包括：①调中心音高的改变，②调式的改变，③调中心音高和调式同时改变。[…] 转调可以丰富乐曲的表现力，使乐曲在力度上和色彩上增加变化，并在发展乐思、构成曲式方面起重要的作用。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) (转调) Chinese B: “以一种曲牌为基础,根据不同需。 要和不同情况,在其中插入其它曲牌以增强其表现性能的一种曲式发展手法。转调系指曲调的转换而言(尽管其中也可能存在着调式和调的转换),与传统宫调术语中的“转调” 及现代音乐术语“转调”的涵义皆有不同。” Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (”转调,” p. 517) Chinese C: “音乐术语。在某调乐曲的中途临时转入他调。转调是音乐发展的重要手法之一，能丰富乐曲的表现力。也叫变调或移调.” Hanyu dacidian (转调, 2) English: “…the transformations from one pentatonic scale to another (Du 2019; Du and Qin 2007, 200–233). These transformations are known variously as xuangong 旋宮, modulation (zhuandiao/fandiao 轉調/犯調), or the theory of 60 modes (liushidiao 六十調). The terms collectively describe modal relations involving the cycles of five pentatonic positions, of twelve chromatic pitch classes, and of their product (12 × 5 = 60).” Lam (2024)

Lam (2024).text: Lam, Nathan L. 2024. “Pentatonic Xuangong 旋宮 Transformations in Chinese Music.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 1. https://mtosmt.org/issues/mto.24.30.1/mto.24.30.1.lam.html.

\u821e\u53f0\u6027 butaisei.text: Japanese A: “だから自分自身はそう考 えて曲を書いたけれども、それを切り離して聴いてほしいと思います。音楽には 全く描写的な要素はありません。また舞 台性も持っていません。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58-59] English A: “Therefore, even though I composed these pieces with narratives in mind, I wish the pieces to be listened to without consideration for them. There are no depictive elements in music, and also no theatrical [舞台性] elements.” Park (2024) [5.2]

\u58f0\u8c03 sh\u0113ngdi\u00e0o.text: Chinese: “音乐的曲调或诗文的节奏.” Hanyu dacidian (声调, 1) English: Rhythm. ”In Chapter 3 of A General Treatise on Music, Li (1930/1933, 24–37) discussed four foundational elements of Music: Rhythmus (shengdiao 聲調), Takt (jiepai節拍), Harmonie (heyin和音), and Melodie (qudiao曲調 or yuediao樂調). Li’s understanding of these elements echoed his thoughts on Music as a language of the upper realm.” Li (2024) [Footnote 28]

parox\u00edtonas.text: English A: “Brazilian Portuguese, like many other languages, uses syllabic stress as a means of phonological identification. One of the main characteristics of its accentuation patterning is the presence of a large number of paroxytonic words. This gives the language, and consequently the metric/prosodic structuring of its musical paradigm, an anacrustic tendency or feel.” (Stover (2024) [3.1]) Portuguese A: “O português brasileiro, como muitas outras línguas, usa o acento silábico como um meio de identificação fonológica. Uma das características principais de seu padrão de acentuação é a presença de um número grande de palavras paroxítonas. Isto dá à língua, e consequentemente ao paradigma musical para estruturação métrica/prosódica uma tendência ou sensação anacrústica.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\ub2e8\ubaa8\ub9ac danmori.text: Korean A: “자진모리伽倻琴散調는 대개 진양조, 중모리, 중중모리, 자진모리, 휘모리, 단모리 6樂章으로 되어 있고, 一般 的으로 羽調, 界面調, 平調를 使用하고 있다.” (Shin (2018) , 248) English A: “Gayageum sanjo typically comprises six movements: jinyangjo, jungmori, jungjungmori, jajinmori, hwimori, and danmori; it commonly utilizes Ujo, Gyemyeonjo, and Pyeongjo.” (Kim (2024)  [3.2]) English B: one of jangdan (Pyǒn (2012) 130)Korean B: 판소리나 산조, 민요, 농악 등의 민속악에 쓰이는 장단 중 가장 빠른 장단. 빠른 2소박 4박 장단으로 판소리에서는 주로 휘모리 라고 부르며, 산조에서는 단모리, 세산조시 등으로, 농악에서는 다드래기, 오방진, 휘모리 등으로 부른다.103 단몰이, 단몰이장단, 단모리장단 (Pyǒn (2012) 130)

d\u00e4kum ata.text: English A: “The first set of sung verses presented here—in Paragraphs 9 and 12—belongs to the genre known as däkum ata, which is performed as an “offering of sound” (śabda pūjāva) during a Bera Pōya Hēvisi ritual. Each line in these verses contains eighteen poetic morae. Although this repertoire is more closely associated with dawula drums (Example 3), in the recording featured here—Videos 1 and 2—they are performed with gäṭa beraya drums (Example 4).” Peiris (2024) [8] English B: “type of salutary musical piece” (Peiris (2025))

Composiciones musicales.text: Spanish A: “Por esta causa adopté tal término [metamórfosis] para designar las transformaciones melódicas, armónicas y rítmicas, a que pueden someterse las composiciones musicales.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] (See also Metamórfosis) English A: “I adopt the term in this way to designate the melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic transformations to which musical compositions can be subjected.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “La composición música por sus formas se divide en Vocal, Instrumental ó en ambas cosas reunidas.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 106]

acento forte.text:
acento + forte forte: strong, hard, heavy 
 Portuguese A: “Ora em nossa música americana (jazz, maxixe e em geral toda síncopa brasileira e mesmo no tango platino) o que se dá é um verdadeiro descolocamento do acento forte que passa do lugar teórico para um lugar onde ele não devia cair, verdadeira antecipação rítmica da thesis.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Now in our American music (jazz, maxixe, and in general all Brazilian syncopation and even in the Argentine tango) what happens is a true displacement of the strong accent which passes from the theoretical place to a place where it should not fall, a true rhythmic anticipation of the thesis.” Menezes (2024) [1.5]

gangsa kantil(an).text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “Yaning gagebug sarwa gangsa, kantil rswa ngaran.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “The gangsa parts, including the kantil, are called reswa.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.9]) Balinese C: “Mwah yan Smar Patangian, ndyata : kempul satunggal sawur-nya manyomanan ndung, kemong gantung sanunggal swaranya ndung, kajar sanunggal sawurnya ndung, gupek roro lanang wadon, rebab sanunggal, suling ageng roro, suling babarangan roro sama ngumbang ngisep, gender ageng sapasang, jegogan sapasang, jublag sapasang, panyacah sapasang, kantil sapasang, gangsa manengah sapasang, gangsa alit apasang, nging sama ngumbang gisep, gumanak tatiga, genta orag apancer alit, kecek tigang wungkul alit, kecek manengah kalih wungkul, kecek ageng sawungkul, jangkep kayeki.”  (Bandem (1986), 82) English C (Chat-GPT): “Smara Patangian Ensemble The Smara Patangian gamelan is more rhythmic and ceremonial, used in rituals and processions. It consists of: Thus, this ensemble is also considered complete (jangkep). This classification reflects the structural and tonal balance within different Balinese gamelan styles, each serving specific cultural and artistic purposes.”

\ud53c\uc544\ub2c8\uc2dc\ubaa8 pianisimo.text: Korean A: “우선 낮은 음에서 시작합니다. B음으로서, 이것은 어두운 음이지 요. 무에서 생겨납니다. 실은 이건 피아니시모이지만, 이건 암시이지 요. 아직 음이 아닌 거지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “First of all, it begins with a low pitch [Example 1]. With the Bb, it is a dark tone. It emerges from nothing. Although it is in pianissimo, it is an implication [暗示]. It is not yet a tone.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u81ea\u4f53\u306e\u79e9\u5e8f Jitai no.text: Japanese A: “ただ、そこにもちろん音楽をつくる、音楽を続けていくこと自体の秩序や軽然とした美学がなければならないわけです. そのひとつを私は東洋人として一番最初に見つけました。それが「ハウプト・トン」です。" (Yun (1984) - Japanese 54) English A: "However, there still needs to be its own organizing principles [自体の秩序] and polished aesthetics [整然とした美学] for making and sustaining sound. I discovered one of those principles first as an East Asian composer. That is Hauptton. " (Park (2024)  [2.4])

\uc9c4\ud589 jinhaeng.text: Korean A: “본청은 하청과의 4도 진행 및 상본청과의 2도 진행이 자주 나타나고, 평조길에서 종지음은 하청이되 본청으로 종지하기도 한다고 하였다. 상본청은 평조길의 가장 특징적인 음이며 여러 성질로 사용된다. 상본청이 여러 성질을 나타내는 점은 우조길에서와 동일한데, '우조에서와 같이 꿋꿋하게 내기도 한다'라고 한 것에서 드러나 듯, 이 음을 꿋꿋하게 내는 것은 우조의 성질이고, 평조의 성질로는 '흘러내리거나, 가볍게 떨거나, 계 면길의 다루와 같이 상청이 장식음으로 붙는 것'이 평조 상본청의 성질이라고 할 수 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 241] English A: “In Pyeongjo-gil, boncheong frequently appears in fourths sequences with hacheong and seconds sequences with sangboncheong; the cadential note in these cases is hacheong, but the sequences sometimes conclude with boncheong. The most recognizable note in Pyeongjo, sangboncheong, is employed in a variety of ways, similarly to Ujo. Sangboncheong in Pyeongjo “flows down, trembles softly, and has decorative notes like daru in Gyemyeon-gil;” in Ujo-gil, sangboncheong “has a firm timbre” (Baek 1996).” Kim (2024) [3.8]

\u0434\u0432\u043e\u0435\u043d \u0434\u0.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: double dactylic rhythm, “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6]

\ucd94\uc131 chuseong.text: Korean A: “이제 생각해 보아야할 문제는, 판소리에서 악조를 판별하는 데 있어서 구성음(출현음)을 중요 하게 볼 것이냐, 주요 선을 골격과 시김을 중요하게 볼 것이냐 하는 점이다. 그리고 이는 판소리 의 음악 특성이 고려되어야 한다. 궁중음악이나 양반들 풍류음악의 경우에는 음악 자체에 시김이 크게 강조되지 않는다. 농현과 추성, 퇴성 등을 하지만, 농현의 깊이가 깊지 않고, 추성과 퇴성의 정도 역시 마찬가지이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 247] English A: “The crucial consideration is therefore whether to prioritize the constituent notes or the primary melodic structure and sigim[sae] in identifying the mode in pansori, taking into account the musical attributes of pansori. Sigim[sae] is not a significant focus in court or aristocratic entertainment music. [When looking at instrumental court music’s modal theory by comparison,] the vibration of string, called nonghyeon 농현 [string play], is the shallowest, and chuseong 추성 [a slow rise in pitch] and toeseong have similar qualities.” Kim (2024) [3.32] English B: A kind of sigimsae (Pyǒn (2012) 176) Korean B: 밀어올리는 소리 (Pyǒn (2012) 176)

musical analysis.text: Source: “ In my experience, musical analysis—that is, analyzing the sound itself rather than a transcription of it—provides much deeper and truer insights than an analysis of transcriptions.” (Shumays commentary (2024) [3.3]) Definition: “A general definition of the term as implied in common parlance might be: that part of the study of music that takes as its starting-point the music itself, rather than external factors. More formally, analysis may be said to include the interpretation of structures in music, together with their resolution into relatively simpler constituent elements, and the investigation of the relevant functions of those elements. In such a process the musical ‘structure’ may stand for part of a work, a work in its entirety, a group or even a repertory of works, in a written or oral tradition. The relationship between the structures and elements proposed by analysis, and experiential, generative and documentary perspectives on music, has circumscribed analysis differently from time to time and from place to place, and has aroused debate. Less controversially, a practical distinction is often drawn between formal analysis and stylistic analysis; but this is unnecessary insofar as on the one hand any musical complex, no matter how small or large, may be deemed a ‘style’; and on the other hand, all the comparative processes that characterize stylistic analysis are inherent in the basic analytical activity of resolving structures into elements.” (Grove Music, “Analysis”)

\u5ba4\u5185\u697d\u66f2 Shitsunai.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1]) Japanese B: “ 小編成で演奏される音薬のジャンルをさすが、「室内」という用語は 19世紀とそれ以前とではその意味を異にする。バロック時代の*室内ソナタでは、「室内」は官を意味するが、19世紀以降では市民生活との結びつきを強くした。 .” (Tomosha (2002), 283)

\u0435\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0439\u0441\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “ В Сливенско, Ямболско, също в Болград играят особена пайдушка наречена ючата, ескийската, в Берковско като обикновено хоро, а в Брезнишко и Тpънско — „Четворка"” Hristov (1925) [p. 44] English A: “In the Sliven and Yambol regions, as well as in Bolgrad, they dance a specific paidushka, called yuchata or eskiiskata; in the Berkovitsa region paidushka is danced as a normal horo, and in the Breznik and Trŭn regions, as a “chetvorka.”” Goldberg (2024) [5.6]

legong.text: English A: “Gamelan pelegongan is an ensemble similar to semar pegulingan that accompanies the iconic legong dance genre] is called tadah rawit [this means “of small and beautiful character,” a resonance much like the characterization of semar pegulingan in II.2 above.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.5])  Balinese B: “Selanjutnya antara abad ke-16 - 19 yaitu pada pemerintah an raja-raja Bali seperti Bekung (1 Bali seperti Dalem Waturenggong (1460 - 1550), Dalem Bekung (1550 - 1580), Dalem Sagening (1580 - 1665), Dalem Dimade (1665 -1686) dan seterusnya, kesenian Bali berkembang mencapai puncak keemasannya yaitu dengan terciptanya berjenis- jenis tarian seperti Gambuh, Topeng, Wayang Wong, Parwa, Arja, Legong Keraton dan seni sastra klasik lainnya.” Bandem (1986) [p. 6-7] Balinese C: “tari putri yg ditarikan oleh dua atau tiga gadis, salah satu di antaranya ada yg berperan sbg condong, yaitu peran yg pertama kali tampil dipentas untuk memulai tarian” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 155, Bidang Istilah Musik]

regularidade.text: English A: “The last B articulates a hemiola on the final syllable of “cres-cer” and “A ro-sa,” at first with simultaneous attacks and then almost like an echo of “rosa.” Finally, the drums play a fill, before gradually returning to the metrical regularity of the accompaniment.” (Stover (2024) [5.6]) Portuguese A: “ O último articula uma hemiola abaixo da sílaba final de "cres-cer" e "A ro-sa", a princípio com ataques simultâneos e depois quase como um eco de rosa. Finalmente, a bateria toca uma virada, antes de gradualmente retornar a uma certa regularidade métrica do acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

Revoluci\u00f3n musical del \u201cSonido.text: Spanish A: “…y en mis “Leyes de metamorfosis” no se agrega ni se quita ni una sola nota de las que escribieron los autores, y eso no sólo en su parte melódica, sino también en la armónica y en la rítmica. En la rítmica y la melódica hay todo un mundo de posibilidades jamás presentidas antes de la revolución del Sonido 13.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 18] English A: “In my “Laws of Metamorphosis,” not a single note is added or removed from what the author wrote originally, neither in its melodic aspect, nor even in its harmonic and rhythmic aspects. In the rhythmic and melodic domains there is a whole world of possibilities never anticipated before the revolution of Sonido 13.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 18] English: “He [Julián Carrillo] offered perhaps his clearest explanation in Genesis de la revolución musical del “Sonido 13” (Genesis of the “Sonido 13” Musical Revolution) (1940), with a self-mythologizing narrative of uncertain validity. In 1895, Carrillo claimed, he took an acoustics class at the Conservatorio Nacional, where his professor told him that different pitches could be yielded by stopping a string at successive fractions of its length. […] Carrillo claimed that his supposedly unique discovery of the sixteenth tone would forever change Western music. He claimed…that he had “broken” (“romperlo”) the circle of twelve fifths, with a thirteenth pitch that lay outside its ambit (18).” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.4]

swara.text: Balinese A: “Hana sarira, apan sarira angingkup salwring swara, laras patutan, lwirnya, swara patut pitu.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: “There is an essence encompassing all tones, tuning and modes, a 7-tone sound.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.3]) Balinese B: “Ika rineka sinandyaken dasa swara Iwirnya : Panca Swara patut Pelog, mwang Panca Swara patut Slendro. Patut Pelog, Panca Tirta ngaran; patut Slendro, panca Gni ngaran. Panca Tirta peraganing Smara, Panca Gni peraganing Ratih. Marmanya Smararatih hana Sapta Swara ika carining pecampuhaning Dasa Swara wirnya : ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.” (Bandem (1986), p. 32) English B (ChatGPT Translation): “These are further symbolized as ten different types of sounds: The combination of Smara and Ratih creates Sapta Swara (Seven Tones), forming the harmonious blend of the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds): ding, dong, deng, ndeung, dung, dang, ndaing.”  Balinese C: “Iti swara ring pangider-ideran, inamet ring Swara Genta Pinara Pitu. Panca swara patut Pelog, panca swara patut Slendro. Iki inangge ring tabuh-tabuhan, mwang swara patut pitu. Apan Swapiaki wus pinarah ti denira Sang Kawi, marmanya hana Dasa Swara umungguh ring pangider-ideran. Mangkana wetnya.” (Bandem (1986), 42) English C (Chat GPT Translation): “These are the sounds in circular motion (swara ring pangider-ideran), embodied in the Seven Tones of the Sacred Bell (Swara Genta Pinara Pitu). The Panca Swara (Five Sounds) are aligned with Pelog, and the Panca Swara are aligned with Slendro. These are used in musical instruments (tabuh-tabuhan) and correspond to the seven musical tones. Since the system has been arranged by Sang Kawi (the sacred poet/sage), the Dasa Swara (Ten Sounds) are positioned within the circular motion of sound. Thus, this is how it manifests.”

Western music notation.text: Source: “A culprit, interestingly enough, is Western music notation: Hristov laments that “when transcribing these Bulgarian . . . songs into musical notation, Serbs, Croats, and Czechs have rendered them in distorted form, in the frameworks of regular European meters, when their true meters with few exceptions are quite different from European ones” ([1.2]).” (Boyd commentary (2024) [6])

fala cantada.text: English A: “From the hard prosody of the first recordings, where, most of the time, singers like Cândido das Neves and Baiano are heard trying to adapt new lyrics to existing melodic formulas, we move through a period of fluid and mischievous “spoken song” by songwriters like Noel Rosa and other samba musicians, voiced by singers such as Aracy de Almeida, Carmen Miranda, Nelson Gonçalves, Linda Batista, and others, to arrive, mainly through João Gilberto’s masterful conduction, at a kind of “sung speech,” an essential rhetoric of Brazilian sensibility—the distillation of several trajectories marked by different worldviews and ways of being-in-the-world.” (Stover (2024) [4.8]) Portuguese A: “Da prosódia dura das primeiras gravações, onde na maioria das vezes se escuta cantores como Cândido das Neves e Bahiano tentando adaptar letras criadas a fórmulas melódicas já existentes, passamos por um "canto falado" flúido e malandro de cancionistas como Noel Rosa e outros sambistas, na voz de cantores como Aracy de Almeida, Carmem Miranda, Nelson Gonçalves, Linda Batista e outros, para chegar, principalmente pela condução maestral de João Gilberto, a uma espécie de "fala cantada", uma retórica essencial da sensibilidade brasileira - a destilação de várias trajetórias marcadas por visões de mundo e de maneiras de ser-no-mundo diferentes.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u516d\u5341\u8c03 li\u00f9 sh\u00ed di\.text: English: “…the transformations from one pentatonic scale to another (Du 2019; Du and Qin 2007, 200–233). These transformations are known variously as xuangong 旋宮, modulation (zhuandiao/fandiao 轉調/犯調), or the theory of 60 modes (liushidiao 六十調). The terms collectively describe modal relations involving the cycles of five pentatonic positions, of twelve chromatic pitch classes, and of their product (12 × 5 = 60).” Lam (2024)  For further discussion, see also: 转调 zhǔan diào, 旋宫 xuán gōng

bin\u00e1rio.text: English A: “The most obvious example of this “overflow” [derramamento] is samba, where there is a binary measure, but with the accent transferred from the beginning of the measure to its second half.” (Stover (2024) [4.5]) Portuguese A: “O exemplo mais evidente deste "derramamento" é o samba onde se tem um compasso binário, mas com a acentuação transferida do início do compasso para a sua segunda metade.” (Ulhôa (1999))

offbeat timing.text: Source: “Hornbostel was identifying processes that would later be named (e.g. by David Locke 1982), among others, as offbeat timing, types of musical structures built on various rhythmic points or displaced from the regular metric pulse, common to various African musical styles. The process identified by Andrade in note #9, if applied to this example, would account for this incomprehension by Hornbostel.” Menezes (2024) [1.17] Definition: “Any impulse in a measured rhythmic pattern except the first (called the Downbeat ); the term is commonly applied to rhythms that emphasize the weak beats of the bar.” (Grove Music Online, “offbeat”)

vocable.text: Source: “This article aims to broaden common understandings of music theory through the lens of orally transmitted ritualistic verses from Sri Lanka, which are sung or recited along with drumming. I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2]) Definition: “A syllable or sound without lexical or referential meaning, vocalized as part of a song or sung melody.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “vocable”)

canto falado.text: English A: “From the hard prosody of the first recordings, where, most of the time, singers like Cândido das Neves and Baiano are heard trying to adapt new lyrics to existing melodic formulas, we move through a period of fluid and mischievous “spoken song” by songwriters like Noel Rosa and other samba musicians, voiced by singers such as Aracy de Almeida, Carmen Miranda, Nelson Gonçalves, Linda Batista, and others, to arrive, mainly through João Gilberto’s masterful conduction, at a kind of “sung speech,” an essential rhetoric of Brazilian sensibility—the distillation of several trajectories marked by different worldviews and ways of being-in-the-world.” (Stover (2024) [4.8]) Portuguese A: “Da prosódia dura das primeiras gravações, onde na maioria das vezes se escuta cantores como Cândido das Neves e Bahiano tentando adaptar letras criadas a fórmulas melódicas já existentes, passamos por um "canto falado" flúido e malandro de cancionistas como Noel Rosa e outros sambistas, na voz de cantores como Aracy de Almeida, Carmem Miranda, Nelson Gonçalves, Linda Batista e outros, para chegar, principalmente pela condução maestral de João Gilberto, a uma espécie de "fala cantada", uma retórica essencial da sensibilidade brasileira - a destilação de várias trajetórias marcadas por visões de mundo e de maneiras de ser-no-mundo diferentes.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B: “Canto em forma recitativa, onde o ritmo deve ser mantido como no canto vocal e a melodia falada, com entonações ascendentes e descentes, em glissando contínuo. Arnold Schoenberg foi o seu iniciador, aplicando-o em suas obras Pierrot Lunaire e Ode a Napoleão, etc.” (Cosme (1957), 25)

\uc131\uc74c seongeum.text: English A: “In this context, Shin’s study is significant for emphasizing the embellishments and seongeum 성음 (vocal timbre) that enhance emotional expression (regarding Lee’s theory) beyond the constituent notes (regarding Baek’s theory) when constructing modal theories of pansori, which are then applied to sanjo.” (Kim (2024) [0.3]) Korean B: “평조길의 틀은 그 키(key)를 높이고 성음(음색)을 씩씩하게 하면 그 구성음의 성질이 우조와 같은 씩씩한 느낌을 갖게 된다.” Shin (2018) [p. 246] English B: “Pyeongjo-gil elevates its key and intensifies its seongeum (vocal timbre), giving the qualities of the constituent notes energetic feelings similar to those of Ujo (Baek 1996, 58).” Kim (2024) [3.25] Korean C:  악기나 목소리의 발성상태. 판소리의 경우 길, 장단과 함께 음악의 3요소로도 불린다. 성음이 좋다, '성음이 나쁘다'로 표현된다. (Pyǒn (2012) 52) English C: a vocal sound (Pyǒn (2012) 52) Korean D: “소리의 높낮음. 무릇 악기는 율관(律管)을 써서 성음을 조정하는데, 종(鐘)과 경(磬)의 조음(調音)이 가장 어렵 다.” Song (2010) [p. 177]

\uc2dc\ub098\uc704 sinawi.text: Korean A: “판소리와 산조는, 하나는 성악곡이고 또 다른 하나는 기악곡이지만, 근본적으로 같은 음악으 로 이해된다. 그 이유는, 산조가 서남지역의 무속음악인 시나위에 기반하여 발생하였으되, 그발전 과정에서 판소리의 영향을 받았기 때문이다.” (Shin (2018) 248) English A: “Although pansori is vocal music and sanjo is instrumental music, they are considered to be fundamentally the same genre. This is because pansori influenced the creation of sanjo, which originated with sinawi 시나위 [improvised instrumental ensemble], shamanistic songs from southwest Korea.” (Kim (2024)  [3.2])

\uad6c\uc131\uc74c guseongeum.text: Korean A: “판소리 우조와 평조의 구체적인 구성음과 주음을 제시하고 있는 개론서는 김해숙·백대웅· 최태현 공저의 전통음악개론』과 김영운의 『국악개론』이 유일하다. 전통음악개론』은 백대웅 이 필자로 참여하고 있는 바, 백대웅의 판소리 악조 이론이 그대로 제시되었다.” Shin (2018) [p. 236] English A: “Only two publications—Kim, Baek, and Choe 1999 and Kim 2015—provide scale degrees [constituent tone] and tonics of Ujo and Pyeongjo in pansori. Baek’s pansori modal theory is presented in Kim, Baek, and Choe 1999, which he co-authored.” Kim (2024) [2.3, brackets added separately]

nyalimped.text: English: “Nyalimped means twisted, deformed. The gending is the same as in Nyalimput (#13), the polos and sangsih are perched on the same tones, and the 63 dyad occurs 11 times here as well, but in a more irregular configuration. Counting from the left it recurs at constantly changing gaps of 3, 2, 3, 4, 3, 3, 4, 3, 2, 3, and (wrapping to the beginning) 2 subdivisions. None of the foregoing examples are remotely as unpredictable as this.” Tenzer (2024) [4.15] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

Andrade (n.d.).text: Andrade, Mário. n.d. “Envelope 13.” Instituto de Estudos Brasileiros, Universidade de São Paulo. Arquivo Mário de Andrade.

Acorde aumentado.text: Spanish A: “Fáltanos el acorde aumentado. Como este acorde contiene dos intervalos de cuatro semitonos, al metamorfosearse al duplo tendrá dos de ocho semitonos.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 25] English A: “At last, we come to the augmented triad. As this chord contains two intervals of four semitones, it will have two intervals of eight semitones under metamorphosis to the double.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 25] See also Acorde, Pedrell (1890) [p. 5])

\u591a\u5fdc\u7684 ta y\u012bng mato\u00.text: Japanese A: "私の音楽はモニスティッシュです。というのは、私の音楽は複音楽的じゃないし、多応的な音楽ではありません。たとえばアロイス・ツインマーマン、彼のは多元的な音楽ですね。根源が違っている音楽的な要素が同時に流れて秩序を保ちつつ、対立しながら、ついにはそれらが和合して、皆楽的な大きな向上をするというものです." (Yun (1984) - Japanese 52) English A: "My music is monistic (monistisch). My music is not polyphonic or pluralistic. For example, Bernd Alois Zimmermann’s music is pluralistic. Elements from different roots flow together, maintain order, oppose, but ultimately come together to greatly elevate the music." (Park (2024) [2.1])

\u65cb\u5f8b\u69cb\u6210 senritsu k\u014.text: 旋律 senritsu: melody 構成: composition, construction, formation Japanese A: “また１つの核音の支配圏から脱して他の核音の圏に移るには、それだけの旋律構成上の力がなければならない。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 6] English A: “Also, in order to escape one nuclear tone’s sphere of control and move to another nuclear tone’s sphere, the melody must be strongly constructed [melodic construction].” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [3, brackets added separately]

\uac00\uace1 Gagok.text: Korean A: “그래요. 엄격한 아악의 음악 짜임새와 철학적 내용, 거기서 유창하게 흐르는 선적인 아름다움을 보여주는 이를테면 남도창이라 든가 가곡이라는 형식의 일련의 성악이 있는데, 그런 데서 많은 걸 배웠어요. 거기서 나아가 선적인 움직임에 대한 음악적 이론을 대체적으로 체계지은 것이지요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: “Yes. I learned a lot from A-ak’s strict organization and philosophical content, and vocal music’s smoothly flowing linear beauty, such as Namdo Chang and Gagok [가곡], or other vocal genres.(4) Based on these, I organized my own musical theory of linear motion." (Park (2024) [1.4]) Korean B: “1975년 장사훈과 한만영이 발간한 『국악개론』에서 판소리 우조에 대해 가곡의 우조나 3음 음계 계면조와 같이 정악 스타일을 판소리에 도입한 것이라 하며, 평조에 대해서는 우조와 조성 의 차이가 아니라 창법과 선을 형태의 차이로 설명하고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 236] English B: “Chang and Han 1975 claim that pansori’s Ujo incorporates jeongak styles, similar to gagok’s Ujo or the three-note scale, Gyemyeonjo. They specify that pansori’s Pyeongjo is distinguished from Ujo by its vocal style and melodic structure, rather than tonality.” Kim (2024) [2.2] Korean C: 시조시를 관현반주에 맞추어 남녀창으로 노래하는 성악곡. 여러 곡을 연창하여 한바탕을 이루는데 여창 15, 남창 24, 남녀창 27 곡으로 짜인다. 가곡의 원형은 '만대엽', '중대엽', '작대엽 인데 그 조종이 되는 곡은 '만대엽'이고 『양금신보」에 의하면 만, 중, 삭, 모두 '정과정곡'에서 나왔다고 하여 그 연원을 고려시대로 소급할 수 있다.
