'만대엽'은 영조 이전에 이미 없어지고 '중대엽' 은 『가곡원류』 시절에 없어지고, '삭대엽'에서 여러 가지로 변조 된 곡이 파생하고 농, 낙, 편 등 많은 곡으로 발전하여 현재와 같은 가곡 한 바탕을 형성하게 되었다. 조는 우조와 계면조로 구별되고 남창, 여창, 남녀창 등 3가지 형태로 연주된다. 5장 형 식으로 이루어져 있으며 기억만 연주하는 중여음+&과 대여음*곱이 있다. 장단은 16박과 10박 장단으로 되어 있다. (Pyǒn (2012) 102–103) English C: a kind of vocal music (Pyǒn (2012) 102)

\uac00\ucc3d\u00a0gachang.text: Korean A: “그것이 선생님 작품의 선적 어법의 밑바탕 이 되어 있군요. 미분음적인 미세한 흔들림으로부터 3 도 이상의 전음(숍)에 이르는 독특한 선의 움직임은 한국의 가창.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

micropolyphony.text: Source: “As such, I read Yun’s critique not as a reiteration of problematic East/West binaries, but as a differential way of thinking about musical structure, process, interpretation, and experience that has affinities with how other experimental logics address matters of time, indeterminacy, mobile forms, heterophony and micropolyphony, and much more.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.4]) Definition: “An extreme example may be found in the technique known as ‘micropolyphony’, employed in certain works by Ligeti, in which contrapuntal lines, comp. according to strict rules devised by the composer, are multiplied to such a degree that the definition of individual vv. is obscured.” (”Counterpoint,” The Oxford Dictionary of Music)

\u043d\u044f\u043a\u043e\u0433\u0430\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Това личи от запазените д о днес метрични и ритмични особености в нея , от чудните закономерности в строежа на тактове и периодите, които ни напомнят по-скоро някогашните тайнствен от отдалечените орфеични и питагорейски времена.” Hristov (1925) (p. 33) English A: “This is apparent from the metric and rhythmic features that are preserved in it to this day, from the wondrous regularities in the composition of its measures and periods, which remind us more of the once-secret numbers of distant Orphean and Pythagorean times.” Goldberg (2024) [2.2]

Cuartos de tono.text: Spanish A: “He aquí esta obra escrita originalmente en cuartos, octavos y dieciséisavos de tono, para los solistas.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p.27] English A: “Here is that work, written originally in quarter tones, eighth tones, and sixteenth tones for the soloists.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p.27] Spanish B: “Intervalo introducido en el genero enarmónica por Aristoxones el cual no se usa.” Palatín (1990) [p. 54] Spanish C: “Nombre poco apropiado, acústicamenta hablando, que dieron algunos teóricas al intervalo enharmónico existente entre una nota afectada por un sostenido y su inmediata superior bemolizada.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 125]  Spanish D: “Nombre que dieron algunos teóricos al intervalo enarmónico que existe entre una nota sostenida y su immediata superior bemolizada.” Lacál (1900) [p. 144]

\uc21c\uc218\uc131 sunsuseong.text: Korean A: “일체의 부조리를 극복하는 데에서 순수성을 본다.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 158] English A: “Purity comes from overcoming the contradiction within the whole”.” Park (2024) [5]

flow.text: Source: “Sometimes, music is almost irresistible in drawing the listener into its flow. The forces behind the enticing feel of Brazilian popular song is the topic of Martha Ulhôa’s essay on métrica derramada, the secret behind the magic feel that arises when the vocal part of the rhythmic dialogue of vocal and comp starts to wander off on its own.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [0]) Definition: “Any continuous movement resembling the even flow of a river and connoting a copious supply; an outpouring or stream; esp. of speech.” (Oxford English Dictionary “flow” 3a)

theorizing.text: Source: “In considering the differences between theorizing and knowing, my mind harks back to 1996, at which time I was having one of my early supervision meetings with linguist and ethnomusicologist David Hughes. When I discussed my first efforts to understand the comparative drum language grammars of the Nigerian bàtá and Cuban batá, David alerted me that just as we can speak a language without understanding much detail about its rules, many musicians can play to a high level without fully understanding the musical grammar of their musical system.” (Villepastour commentary (2024) [2.2]) Definition: “To construct a theory of or about.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “theorizing”)

ternary subdivision.text: ternários (Portuguese) Source: “Thus, in Brazilian music, some musical events respond to the metric accentuation of the established measure as a reference, while others respond to a displaced and oscillating point, which generates a music that we end up calling structurally syncopated, formed by the superposition of a second sliding rhythmic support point that is not exactly fitted into the theoretical binary or ternary subdivision.” Menezes (2024) [1.10]

kawat.text: Balinese A: “Piteges kawat, kawat ngaran iti swara kang lwih kukuh, apan kawat ingaranan otot, apan otot maka jalaraning swara, apa marmanyan roro angangge kawat, apa wetuning swara saking roro, swara wetu saking rengira sanghyang smara mwang sanghyang ratih,” (Geria (n.d.)  English A: “The significance of wire [for the two rebab strings]: wire gives a good and strong sound, because wire is muscular, the muscle brings forth sound. Why use two wires? The sound that comes from two sources, one from the Sang Hyang Semara and the other from Sang Hyang Ratih [manifestations of a love deity].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.6])

kama sraga.text: Balinese A: “smara ngaran laki, ratih ngaran wadu, swaraning smara ngaran kama nada, swaraning ratih ngaran kama sraga. Rikalanya anunggal swara ika, hana swara karenga ngararengih ngalup manis, kadi reng pangucapira sanghyang smara ratih, patemuan nira murda, ring murda panunggara nira sanghyang ardanareswari, apan sira wenang surup sinurup, ganti gumanti, matemahan ring windu nada candra.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: ““Semara” indicates male, “Ratih” indicates female, the voice of Semara is called kama nada, [kama = desire; nada = tone] the voice of Ratih is called kama sraga [sraga = form]. When these voices become one, there is a tinkling, sweet sound, like the vibrations of Sang Hyang Semara and Ratih’s words at their summit, at the highest realm of Sang Hyang Ardanareswari [a manifestation of Siva and his consort Parvati unifying male and female] because he can go in and out, again and again, on the tones of Windu Chandra [windu is a point, an essence; chandra can suggest brightness or the moon].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.6])

\u5929\u7a7a\u306e\u4e16\u754c tenk\u016.text:
天空 + 世界 天空: sky, air, the heavens 世界: world 
 Japanese A: “純粋な音自体を持って、人間の現世を超越した、そういう人間世界と天空の世界の中間、人間世界と天空の世界の接触といいますか、あるいは地 獄のというように、全く人間の現世の世 界とは離れて、超越した宇宙の問題を取 り扱った、そういう作品は他にもたくさ んあります。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 59] English A: “The realm that is in between the mortal world and the celestial world, or perhaps a contact between the two worlds. There are many other compositions that deal with a topic that is separate from the real world, such as purgatory and a transcendent universe.” Park (2024) [5.3]

palegongan.text: English: “Geria’s examples all apply to the trompong, an instrument forefronted in prestigious court gamelan—the palegongan, semar pagulingan, and the gong gdé. I show both the kepatihan (cipher notation) provided and my own modified 3-line staff for the trompong and, when needed, a single-line staff for jegogan. Geria notated his examples on particular pitches in a five-tone pélog, conventionally numbered 1,2,3,5, and 6. But they could be played at any transposition.” Tenzer (2024)  [3.1]

lirismo.text: English A: “A quality of characteristically melodic phrases is their lyricism. Even an instrumental phrase can have a melodic quality when its musical notes flow in a sequence of scale degrees relatively close to each other so as not to break the melodic movement. A lyrical melody usually has an undulating melodic contour. Leaps between notes are used economically, for emphasis or expression.” (Stover (2024) [2.4]) Portuguese A: “Uma qualidade de frases característicamente melódicas é o seu lirismo. Mesmo uma frase instrumental pode ter uma qualidade melódica quando as notas musicais fluem numa seqüência de graus relativamente próximos uns dos outros de modo a não quebrar o movimento. Uma melodia lírica tem um contorno melódico usualmente ondulado. Saltos entre as notas são usados de forma econômica, para ênfase ou expressão.” (Ulhôa (1999))

Modificaciones r\u00edtmicas.text: Spanish A: “No conozco ningún ejemplo en el cual se hayan operado modificaciones melódicas, armónicas y rítmicas, sin alterar los modelos, y con mi “Ley de metamorfosis” pueden efectuarse cambios en la melodía, en la armonía y el ritmo, sin agregar ni suprimir ni una sola nota.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20] English A: “I do not know any example in which melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic modifications have been used without altering the models. With my “Law of Metamorphosis,” changes in melody, harmony, and rhythm can be carried out without adding or removing a single note.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 20]

\ud558\uccad hacheong.text:
Kim (2024) Ex. 2–1 
 Korean A: “우조의 경우, 하청은 떠는 기능을 갖고 있지 않고, 반종지하는 음이다. 하본청은 전조와 변조 에 기능하는 음으로서 그 역할이 작지 않고, 옥타브 위에서는 우조 특유의 씩씩한 느낌을 주는 핵심적인 음이다.” Shin (2018) [p. 238-239] English A: “In Ujo, hacheong is the note of a half cadence, without the capacity for vibration. It plays a significant role in transposition and modulation and, when used above the octave, contributes to the distinctive and energizing quality of Ujo.” Kim (2024) [3.6] English B: “Baek states that hacheong in Pyeongjo does not vibrate much; he also states that hacheong in Ujo “does not have the function of trembling.” He adds that, among the varieties of Ujo in the Gagokseongujo section, "the vibrating nature sometimes shows in hacheong and sangboncheong, which is characteristic of Pyeongjo." Hacheong in Pyeongjo thus possesses a vibrating quality (Baek 1996, 47–48, 53, 56).” Kim (2024) [Footnote 14] Korean C:  English C: 1. name of the 5th string of the geomungo 2. name of a string of yanggeum 3. sound in lower range ( Pyǒn (2012) 97)

ethnocentric.text: Source: “This interview took place as a post-concert conversation between the two composers. The interview covers Yun’s compositional philosophy behind the Hauptton technique, in particular, its relationship to the Korean traditional music. The conversation continues to his comparison of Western classical and East Asian musics, which shows his ethnocentric tendency in describing them. He then provides a short analysis of his Flute Concerto (1977) from the Haupttone perspective. The interview concludes with a brief discussion of his imprisonment in South Korea and his message to the new generation of composers.” Park (2024) [1.3]

tulak.text: English: “Tulak is to refuse, and wali to return or go back. The opening 3-note pattern with a down-then-leap-up contour (162) repeats, but once the polos 6 in the middle is reached, matching the gending, the contour pattern inverts to up-then-leap-down(126; dotted box) and returns to its point of origin.” Tenzer (2024) [4.9] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

polca europeia.text: Portuguese A: “As síncopas europeias, desenvolvidas pelo afro-americano, nos deram o principal da prodigiosa riqueza rítmica que em nossa música se manifesta. Ao contato da polca europeia, que teve entre nós grande aceitação no Segundo Império, os negros brasileiros, da mesma forma com que os negros escravos da Colônia nos tinham dado o samba, nos deram o maxixe, nossa principal dansa de caráter urbano.” Andrade (2013)  English A: “The European syncopations, developed by African-Americans, gave us the main source of the prodigious rhythmic richness that manifests in our music. In contact with the European polka, which had great acceptance in the Second Empire, Brazilian blacks, in the same way that the enslaved blacks of the Colony had given us the samba, gave us the maxixe, our main urban dance.” Menezes (2024) [1.4] Portuguese B: “Dança em compasso binário, 2/4, andamento alegre, originária da Boêmia. Silva Leal, tratando da origem da dança, afirma que a polca, na Polônia, foi conhecida como mazurek, " que vem da Mazawia (...). O compasso da mazurek é em três tempos (...) as figuras e passos são uma série de movimentos complicados com certo sistema de volta, com menos rapidez do que a valsa, a cadência de um motivo em notas picadas em valores desiguais, que requerem grande energia e leveza para boa execução.” (Andrade (1989) 404)

parlando.text: English A: “However, with bossa nova, there was an aesthetic shift in the relationship between melody and harmony. Before the bossa nova “revolution,” harmony functioned mainly as support for a relatively autonomous melody. The emergence of bossa nova, with its emphasis on a “parlando” style and colloquial singing, as well as its use of complex harmonic progressions, represented a break with the romantic style of the time, which had become cliché. Bossa nova favored a cool and more restrained diction, with artistic and literary intentions.” (Stover (2024) [2.9]) Portuguese A: “Entretanto, com a bossa nova houve um deslocamento estético nesta relação entre melodia e harmonia na canção. Antes da "revolução" bossanovista a harmonia funcionava principalmente como suporte para uma melodia relativamente autônoma. O aparecimento da bossa nova, com sua ênfase num estilo "parlando" e canto coloquial, bem como seu uso de progressões harmônicas complexas, representou uma ruptura com o estilo romântico mais antigo. Nos anos sessenta, a expressão melodramática tornara-se cliché. Bossa nova privilegiava uma dicção mais "cool" e contida com intenções artísticas e literárias.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uac00\uace1\uc131\uc6b0\uc870 gagokseon.text: Korean A: “또한, 백대웅은 우조의 종류를 진우조, 평우조, 가곡성우조의 셋으로 정리하였다. 그 중 진우 조는 우조의 성격을 가장 분명하게 드러낸 것으로, 진우조에서는 특히 하본청과 상본청의 4도 골격(라-레)이 드러나며 분위기를 고조시키는데, 이는 청을 한 음 높이는 효과를 낸다고 하였 다.” Shin (2018) [p. 239] English A: “Furthermore, Baek assigns three subcategories to Ujo: Jin-ujo, Pyeong-ujo, and Gagokseong-ujo. Jin-ujo best expresses the nature of the Ujo; in particular, the fourth interval (la-re) between haboncheong and sangboncheong heightens the atmosphere with the impact of raising one step the tonic [cheong].” Kim (2024) [3.7]

\uc790\uccb4\uc758 \uc9c8\uc11c jache-ui.text: 자체: independent 질서 jilseo: order Korean A: "단 거기에 도 물론 음을 만들고 음악을 지속시켜가는 것 자체의 질서, 정연한 미학이 없어서는 안되지요. 그 한 가지를 나는 동양인으로서 맨 먼저 발견했지요. 그것이 '하우프트톤'입니다. " (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "However, there still needs to be its own organizing principles [自体の秩序] and polished aesthetics [整然とした美学] for making and sustaining sound. I discovered one of those principles first as an East Asian composer. That is Hauptton. " (Park (2024) [2.4])

Jali.text: Igbo A: “Ọ dị ọnọdụ ka, na Jali na Gambia dika dictionary. Ọ dị ka library. Ị kpaghaa ya na music, ọ gụsisiba.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6] English A: “The ‘Jali’ of Gambia are like a dictionary. He/she is like a library. Once they are asked to perform music, they render historical accounts.” Carter-Ényì (2024) [6]

\u5c0f\u7bc0\u306e\u7e26\u7dda kobushi n.text: Japanese A: “この例では小節の縦線は省いておいたが、上・下段のアナリーゼによる縦線と、小節の縦線とはある点では三者共に一致する。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] Japanese B: “複 数 の 拍 の ま と ま り 。 楽 譜 の う え で は 、 縦 線 （ ⼩ 節 線 ） で 区 切 ら れ る 1 ⼩ 節 に 含 ま れ る ⾳ 価 の 合 計 は 、 拍 ⼦ に よ っ て 定 め ら れ る 。 な お 、 * 弱 起 の ⼩ 節 は 、 最 後 の ⼩ 節 と あ わ せ て 完 全 な ⾳ 価 と な る 。 楽 譜 を ⼩ 節 に 区 切 る の が ⼀ 般 的 に な る の は 、 1 7 世 紀 頃 か ら で あ る 。” Tomosha (2002) [p. 319] English A: “In this example, I have omitted the bar lines, but the vertical lines based on the analyses above and below the notation, to a certain point, agree with where the bar lines would be.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.2]

pangirik.text: English A: “Gerantang joged bumbung style is called bramana ngisep sari; its sound is pangirik.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.14]) See gerantang  Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang gagebug gerantang joged bumbung, bramara ngisep sari. Pangirik nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “Gerantang joged bumbung refers to an ensemble of gerantang accompanying ngibing, a flirtation dance. Bramana ngisep sari means “beetle sips flower essence”; pangirik is a tickling sensation. The juxtaposed and somewhat incongruous imagery of beetle, flower, and tickling cunningly reveals the potential of ngibing, which in yesteryear led to more than flirtation.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.13]) *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

\u9f8d\u7b1b ry\u016bteki.text: 龍+笛 龍: dragon 笛: flute, pipe, whistle Japanese A: “譜３２は、古いもののうちでもとくに有名な雅楽の＜青海波＞から竜笛の旋律だけを抜きだしたものである.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 14] English A: “Example 32 extracts only the ryūteki melody from “Seigaiha,” a gagaku piece that is especially famous among the older ones.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [9.1] English B: “The ryūteki 龍笛 is a wooden transverse flute used in gagaku.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [Footnote 17]

concept.text: Source: “On one side, what looks like just the misdirection of language over the hidden referent of sexuality is also the presence of sexuality in the atmosphere of metaphor; on the other side, what looks like an irreducibly embodied sensation turns out to be recontained as a concept, which allows it to travel and mingle with other sensations-and-phenomena-turned-into-concepts.” (Wang commentary (2024) [2.7]) Definition: “Originally in Philosophy: a general idea or notion, a universal; a mental representation of the essential or typical properties of something, considered without regard to the peculiar properties of any specific instance or example. Later often (frequently with of): the meaning that is realized by a word or expression.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “concept” 1.2)

\u8b21 utai.text: Japanese A: “この核音は、民謡よりもむしろ芸術音楽ことに能楽の謡や三味線声楽の長唄などでは非常にはっきりとした形で現われており、そのばあいの旋律は、ただある１つの核音をめぐって上下浮動するという状態である。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 3] English A: “These nuclear tones appear extremely clearly in Japanese art music, especially in the utai of nō music and shamisen vocal music like nagauta, even more than in folk songs. The melodies in those (art music) cases have the characteristic of revolving around only one nuclear tone, and bobbing up and down around it.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [2.1] “Utai 謡, while etymologically meaning simply “song,” has come to refer specifically to the vocal music of the nō 能 theater tradition. It is accompanied by a hayashi 囃子 ensemble, which consists of a few drums and a flute.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [footnote 4] Japanese B: “謡曲ともいう、能楽に用いる声楽をいう、役者の動作 と離れて独立して行う場合をいう。” Tanabe (1975) [p. 15]

\u0442\u0430\u0440\u0430\u043d\u0442\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “При същата бързина на елементите от две тройни групи се получава един жив (бърз) 6/16 такт с две ударения. Ако всяка тройна група сметнем за триола, ще имаме в такъв случай вместо 6/16 един 2/8 такт (с два пъти аргументирани нотни стойности -- 2/4). Този такт служи за основа на обикновено живо българско хоро (рондо) подобно на тарантелата.” Hristov (1925) [p. 46] English A: “At the same tempo of elements, two triple groups produce a lively (fast) 6/16 meter with two beats. If we consider each triple group to be a triplet, we will have in this case a 2/8 meter instead of 6/16 (or with duply augmented note values, 2/4). This meter serves as the basis for the ordinary lively Bulgarian horo (rondo) similar to the tarantella.” Goldberg (2024) [5.9] Bulgarian B: “Тарантела (ит. tarantella от Тагап- то град в Южна Италия, фр. tarantelle) народен неаполитански танц в много бързо темпо, жизнерадостен характер, непрекъснато движение B осмини, B 6/8 или 3/8 такт. Разпространен е бил особено в Неапол през 18 в. и началото на 19 в. Изпълнявал се по двойки със съпровод на тамбурина* и кастанети*, а понякога и с пеене.” Chetrikov (1979) [p. 324]

\ubc1d\uc740 balgeun.text: Korean A: “Bb은 단지 준비의 음입니다. 그러나 D를 만들어내기 위해서는 장3도가 생겨납니다. 장3도는 밝은 음정이지요. 그래서 어두운 음으 로부터 밝은 음이 됩니다. 그건 조금씩 빛이 비쳐드는 것이지요.” Yun (1991) - Korean [p. 156] English A: “The Bb is just a tone for preparation. But, in order to create D, a major third is created. A major third is a bright interval. So, a dark tone becomes a bright tone. It is like light is peeking through little by little.” Park (2024) [4.1]

\u793c l\u01d0.text: Chinese A:  “中國人向來是樂與詩書禮並重的，像禮樂治天下這一類的話，舊日中國人亦不知道說了多少.” Li (2024) [1.4] 便把那些叫做什麼始平之章，景平之章，咸平之章，壽平之章，嘉平之章，永平之章，熙平之章，清平之章，太平之章，祐平之章，以及別的什麼平之章歌奏起來，又佐以什麼干羽之舞. Li (2024) [1.4] English A: “For the Chinese, Music has always been considered on an equal footing with Poetry (shi), Literature (shu), and Ritual (li), as evident in such stale expressions as “Ritual and Music rule the Heaven and the Earth.” Li (2024) [1.4] “Musicians and dancers could play and dance according to various ritual contexts like Shiping, Jingping, Xianping, Shouping, Jiaping, Yongping, Xiping, Qingping, Taiping, Youping, and so forth.” Li (2024) [1.4] Chinese B: “最初是指祭神时的器物和仪式，后演变为一种社会生活规范和道德规范。[…] 在历史发展中，礼作为社会的生活准则和道德规范，对中华民族精神素质的修养起了重要作用；但随着社会的发展，特别是在中国古代社会的后期，它严重束缚了人们的思想和行为，影响了社会历史的进步和发展。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) (礼) Chinese C: “《晏子春秋·谏上二》：凡人之所以貴於禽獸者，以有禮也。故《詩》曰：‘人而無禮，胡不遄死。’ 禮，不可無也。” Hanyu dacidian  (禮) Chinese D: “這樣離不開舞的音樂，因為實際上不過是禮的附庸，所以我們不能夠把牠當作是一種獨立的藝術。你們承認音樂是一種獨立的藝術，那末，你們便不能夠把牠當作是禮的附庸。” Li (2024) (See also: 音乐 yīn yuè)

\u58f0\u660e seimei/sh\u014dmy\u014d.text: Japanese A: “譜３０、３１はそれぞれ天台および真言の声明の例であるが、どちらも上下動の少い、どちらかといえば単調な旋律である.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 12] English A: “Examples 30 and 31 are examples of Tendai and Shingon chant respectively, but microtonal fluctuation is little in both, and both have simple melodies.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [8.1] Japanese B: “chanting of Buddhist hymns (usu. in Sanskrit or Chinese)” (Japan Dict https://www.japandict.com/声明#entry-2187150)

\u7b2c\u4e8c\u4e3b\u984c\u90e8 dai ni sh.text:
第二 + 主題 + 部 第二: second 主題: subject, theme, motif 部: part, portion 
 Japanese A: “「時」の考え方が形式観に反映した 例として西洋ではソナタ形式があります が、ソナタ形式ですと、第一主題部があ り、第二主題部がある。これらは対立し た区間であり、第二主題の部分は第一主 題と異なった時間を独自に形成するわけ ですから、瞬間に世界を持つ陰陽とは全 く異なるということですね。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “The Sonata form might be one example that reflects the Western formalistic view of time. In Sonata form, there are primary and secondary theme areas. They are contrasting sections that independently develop [the sense of] time. Therefore, it is completely different from yin and yang, which contain an eternity in a moment.” Park (2024) [4.2]

\u548c\u97f3 h\u00e9y\u012bn.text: Chinese A: “该术语在广义上指声音和意义的优美组合;在狭义上则有两种定义。即(1)与元音谐音(参见“元音谐音”条)相反,指词或音节中的辅音全部或部分相同,如pressed-past, shadow-meadow。[…] (2)指爱尔兰诗歌中的一种和音(uaithne),即两个词中相应的元音长度相同,相应的辅音或辅音组合同类,词尾的辅音也同类同质。” Shijie shixue (1999) (p. 224) Chinese B: “平和之音；和谐之音.” Hanyu dacidian  (和音) English: Harmony. ”In Chapter 3 of A General Treatise on Music, Li (1930/1933, 24–37) discussed four foundational elements of Music: Rhythmus (shengdiao 聲調), Takt (jiepai節拍), Harmonie (heyin和音), and Melodie (qudiao曲調 or yuediao樂調). Li’s understanding of these elements echoed his thoughts on Music as a language of the upper realm.” Li (2024) [Footnote 28]

contraponto.text: English A: “In the Brazilian conception of song, the melody is the starting point for the composition, with the rhythmic and harmonic accompaniment acting as elements of melodic support. Harmony, in this conception, expands the expressive possibilities of melodic singing, with the accompanying instruments able to create other melodies in counterpoint to the main melody, responding to or opposing it.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “Na concepção brasileira da canção, a melodia é o ponto de partida para a composição, sendo o acompanhamento rítmico e harmônico elementos de suporte melódico. A harmonia, nesta concepção, amplia as possibilidades expressivas do canto melódico podendo os instrumentos acompanhantes criar outras melodias em contraponto à melodia principal, respondendo ou contrapondo-se a ela.” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese B:  Portuguese C: “O têrmo, derivado do latim, punctus contra punc-tum (nota contra nota) - significa a arte de entrelaçar melodias vertical-mente. Faz parte integrante do estudo da composição musical, ao lado da har-monia.” (Cosme (1957) 35)

\u7dda\u7684\u8a9e\u6cd5 sen-teki goh\u0.text: Japanese A: “そ れ が 、 先 ⽣ の 作 品 の 線 的 な 語 法 の も と に な っ て い る わ け で す ね 。 微 分 ⾳ 的 な 細 か い 揺 れ か ら 3 度 以 上 の シ ェ イ ク に ⾄ る よ う な 、 独 特 な 線 の 動 き は 、 韓 国 の 歌 唱 の ⽅ 法 か ら ⽣ み 出 さ れ た も の と 考 え て い い わ け で す ね .” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "That underlies your linear [線的] musical language [語法]. It would be reasonable to say that the characteristic linear movements, ranging from fine microtonal tremors to tremolos wider than a third, come from the Korean singing [歌唱] style." (Park (2024) [1.4])

Biamonte commentary (2024).text: Biamonte, Nicole. 2024. “Commentary.” Music Theory Online 30, no. 4.

articula\u00e7\u00e3o.text: English A: “In music of the classical-romantic European tradition, the articulation of the phrase can be inferred from the written score, at least in its most obvious aspects, such as duration, metric placement, harmonic rhythm, cadences, melodic direction, and so on. However, much of the musical meaning only emerges during the moment of performance. In performance, and especially in the case of popular song, singers use their interpretative skills to articulate and highlight the emotional content of each song.” (Stover (2024) [5.11]) Portuguese A: “Na música de tradição européia clássico-romântica, a articulação da frase pode ser inferida na partitura escrita, pelo menos nos seus aspectos mais óbvios, como duração, colocação métrica, ritmo harmônico, cadências, direção melódica, etc. Entretanto, muito do significado musical só emerge durante o momento da performance. Na performance, e, principalmente no caso da canção popular, cantores usam sua habilidade interpretativa para articular e salientar o conteúdo emocional de cada canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u0413\u0440\u0443\u043f\u0438\u0440\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Групировката на пъpвичните елементи е неправилна 2 + 3 или порядко 3+2.” Hristov (1925) (p. 42) English A: “The grouping of the primary elements is an irregular 2+3, or more rarely, 3+2.” Goldberg (2024) [5.3]

transliteration.text: Source: “This article aims to broaden common understandings of music theory through the lens of orally transmitted ritualistic verses from Sri Lanka, which are sung or recited along with drumming. I have chosen to present audio recordings of these verses being performed (some including video), along with transliterations and translations, to illustrate the ways in which the oral transmission and performance of such lyrics involves different modes of theorizing—such as knowledge of how conventional poetic meters can be sung, shared understandings of how to interpret vocables as drum strokes, and the association of different drum timbres with cosmological references.” (Peiris (2024) [0.2]) Definition: Transcription, “The arrangement, or (more loosely) modification, of a composition for some voice or instrument other than that for which it was originally written; an instance of this, a transcribed piece.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “transcription”)

\u82b8\u8853\u6c11\u8b21 Jutsu Min Utai.text: Japanese A: “そ し て 韓 国 に は 厳 格 な⽴ 場 を と る 雅 楽 ⾳ 楽 と は 別 に 、 宮 廷 ⾳ 楽 で も 寺 院 ⾳ 楽 で も な い 、⼀ 般 ⼤ 衆 と 上 流 社 会 が 共 有 し て き た 、 西 洋 に ⾒ ら れ る よ う な 知 識 社 会 で 楽 し ん で き た ⾳ 楽 世 界 が ま だ あ り ま す 。 そ れ か ら ま た 芸 術 歌 曲 、芸 術 民 謡 と い い ま す か 、 そ う い う も の が あ り ま す " (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: "In addition, there is a vernacular musical tradition in Korea that is neither court music nor ritual music, which had been enjoyed by both the commoners and the aristocrats, similar to the musical sphere you would see in Western intellectuals. In addition to A-ak, which takes a strict stance, there are Korean art songs and folk music." (Park (2024) [1.3]) See also: 民謡 min’yō

\u540c\u97f3 d\u014don.text: 同+音 oto  同: same, identical, equal Japanese A: “これは笛であるため、音程の跳躍がはなはだしいが、それを筝曲のばあいのように、オクターヴを同音と考えて見ると、案外旋律的な動きとなる.” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 14] English A: “Because this melody is for a flute, the intervallic leaps are extreme, but as in the case with koto music, if you think of octaves as equivalent, its movement becomes surprisingly conjunct.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [9.2] Japanese B: “⼥ 声 の み 、 男 声 の み の 組 み 合 わ せ 。 「 混 声 」 に 対 す る 語 。 と き に は ソ プ ラ ノ の み 、 な ど の よ う に 1 つ の 声 種 の 場 合 も い う 。” (Tomosha (2002), 447)

\u0437\u0430\u043a\u043e\u043d\u043e\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Това личи от запазените д о днес метрични и ритмични особености в нея , от чудните закономерности в строежа а тактове И периодите, които ни напомнят по-скоро някогашните тайнствен от отдалечените орфеични и питагорейски времена.” Hristov (1925) (p. 33) English A: “This is apparent from the metric and rhythmic features that are preserved in it to this day, from the wondrous regularities in the composition of its measures and periods, which remind us more of the once-secret numbers of distant Orphean and Pythagorean times.” Goldberg (2024) [2.2]

\u0441\u043f\u0438\u0442\u0440\u0438\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “Сравнени с ритмическите форми на обикновените правилни тактове, нашите неправилни тактове се явяват по отношение на някои свои вторични части в рационално отношение по време (хронос алогои).” Hristov (1925) [p. 40] English A: epitrite, “Compared with the rhythmic forms of ordinary regular meters, our irregular meters appear in the ratio of some of their secondary part to have an irrational ratio over time (chronos alogoi).” Goldberg (2024) [4.6]

\u97f3\u697d ongaku.text: 音 oto +楽 gaku  Japanese A: “このどちらもが、日本の音階と旋律法のヨーロッパとの違いはもちろん、アジア音楽の中での、特異性をきわめて明確に規定する要素なのであるが、ここではまず前者について考えて見よう。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] Japanese B: “語 源 的 に は 中 国 語 の「 ⾳ 」 は 声 ⾳ ， 「 楽 」 は （ 打 楽 器 ⾳ を あ ら わ す が 、 そ の 合 成 語 の 「 ⾳ 楽 」 が 英 語 の 「 ミ ュ ー ジ ッ ク 」 に 対 応 す る ⽤ 語 と な っ た の は 明 治 以 降 と い っ て よ い 。 も と も と 「 ミ ュ ー ジ ッ ク 」 は ラ テ ン 語 （ ム シ カ ） 、 さ ら に は ギ リ シ ア 語 （ ム シ ク ⼀ ） に さ か の ほ る こ と が で き 、 ⽂ 芸 ， ⾳ 楽 、 舞 踊 、 歴 史 、 天 ⽂ な ど を つ か さ ど る い わ ゆ る 詩 の ⼥ 神 （ ミ ュ ー ズ ） た ち の 技 芸 を 意 味 し て い た 。し か し 、 古 代 か ら の 数 千 年 の 時 間 の 流 れ 、 お よ び 世 界 の 諸 民 族 の 多 様 性 の な か で 、 ⾳ 楽 の 捉 え⽅ は 千 変 万 化 の 様 相 を 呈 し て い る 。 現 時 点 で は ⼈ 間 の 声 ⾳ お よ び 楽 器 ⾳ の 組 み 合 わ せ に よ っ て 実 現 さ れ る 芸 術 な い し ⼈ 間 の 表 現 ， 表 出 活 動 とし て と ら え ら れ て い る 。” [Tomosha (2002) [p. 120] English A: “For both of these, the differences between Japanese musical rules and those of Europe are of course the elements make Asian music seem so extremely peculiar.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1]

ngecog.text: English: “This pattern is kabelet (stuck) at first, and then it ngecog (jumps). The jumping is the iterated leap over a scale tone: 3 to 6 (skipping 5) in the sangsih and 5 to 1 (next octave, skipping 6) in the polos, though their composite creates a stepwise line as the slanted rectangles show. This pattern is thus longer than previous ones and contains no internal repetition of its initial motive as all previous ones do.” Tenzer (2024) [4.8] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

gestos ret\u00f3ricos.text: English A: “These rhetorical gestures, as well as the spaces between musicians’ attacks or note endings in a musical performance, contribute greatly to making people move their bodies in specific ways and to hearing the “grain” of the song.” (Stover (2024) [5.8]) Portuguese A: “Estes gestos retóricos, bem como os espaços entre os ataques ou finais de nota dos músicos numa performance musical contribuem enormemente para fazer as pessoas moverem seus corpos de maneira específica, e para escutar o "grão" da canção.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc2dc\uae40\uc0c8 sigimsae.text: English A: “Sigimsae 시김새 refers to the sophisticated vocal techniques and idiomatically stylized ornaments, which serve as the initial prerequisites for singing, from which the emergence of creative expression with nuanced shading arises (Lee and Lee 2007, 121).” (Kim (2024)[0.4]) Korean B: “이보형은 1998년 "판소리와 산조에서 우조와 평조의 개념수용에 관한 고찰"이라는 글에서 판소리에 우조·평조 계면조라는 악조명을 사용하게 된 시점과, 이들 용어의 개념을 간략히 정리하였다. 그리고 판소리 우조와 평조에 대한 상세한 이론은 2002년 "판소리와 산조에서 우조와 평조 연구"10라는 글에서 제시하고 있는데, 판소리 우조와 평조의 구성음·시김새·선 을 골격·각 음의 기능 등을 구체화하였다.” Shin (2018) [p. 241] English B: “Lee 1998 summarizes pansori mode names’ history, such as Ujo, Pyeongjo, and Gyemyeonjo, and briefly organizes these concepts. He presents a thorough conceptualization about Ujo and Pyeongjo in pansori, including the constituent notes, sigimsae, melodic structures, and functions of each tone, in Lee 2002.” Kim (2024) [3.2]   Korean C: 어떤 음이 소리의 변화를 동반하여 한 음의 변화된 모양새를 일 걷는 말. 시김새의 종류에는 크게 흔드는 소리(떠는 소리: 요성), 흘 러내리는 소리(뛰는 소리 포함: 퇴성), 밀어올리는 소리(추성), 구르는소리(전성) 등이 있다. 식음새, 시금새 (Pyǒn (2012) 54-55) English C: ornament tune (Pyǒn (2012) 54)

rebab.text: English A: “The bowed spike lute rebab and the bamboo end-blown flutes suling play the melody in the Gamelan Gambuh, an ensemble dating perhaps to as early as the fifteenth century, and commonly understood to be the crucial precursor of later gamelan composed of bronze keyed instruments and gongs.” (Tenzer (2024) [1.1]) English B: “The rebab is made of wood, from coconut shells, parchment from stomach lining, from wire, from [horse] hair; it has feet, there is a body, there is skin, there is a back, there is a torso, there are two hands, and there is a head.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.1]) Balinese B: “Ikang rebab kawangun dening taru, dening babasar, dening pasu, dening kawat, dening rambut; hana suku, hana sarira, hana wijang, hana wungkur, hana angga, hana tangan roro, mwang hana murda.” (Geria (n.d.)  Balinese C: “Iti swara Angkus ring Rebab, kang ing tatabuhan sa-Weda, Mantra, Çru-Katekatekeng sar-pinaka dasarin.” (Bandem (1986), 48) English C (ChatGPT Translation): “These are the Angkus sounds in the Rebab (a traditional stringed instrument), which are present in musical instruments, as well as in the Vedas, Mantras, and Çru (sacred chants). They serve as the fundamental essence of all melodic structures and sacred recitations.”  Balinese D: “instrumen yg dibuat dr batok, ditutup kulit, bersenar dua helai, dimainkan dg cara digesek, berfungsi sbg pembawa melodi” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 167, Bidang Istilah Musik]

\u65cb\u5f8b\u6cd5 senritsuh\u014d.text: 旋律 senritsu+法 法: law, rule Japanese A: “このどちらもが、日本の音階と旋律法のヨーロッパとの違いはもちろん、アジア音楽の中での、特異性をきわめて明確に規定する要素なのであるが、ここではまず前者について考えて見よう。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 1] English A: “For both of these, the differences between Japanese musical [melodic] rules and those of Europe are of course the elements make Asian music seem so extremely peculiar.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [1.1, brackets added separately]

sangsih.text: English: “Geria’s cipher notation is given, as well as modified staff notation using two two-line staves with the ubit-ubitan above and the slower moving gending line below. On the ubit-ubitan staff the stems-down part is known as polos (basic). The stems-up part is the sangsih (different or complementary). As most Balinese music has an end-accented character, the staff notation places the beginning of a four-note group apart and unbeamed at the end of each pattern. The three tones that complete it on repeat are shown at the beginning.” Tenzer (2024) [4.2] English B: “To introduce some cross-cultural perspective, Example 3 reproduces my typology of ubit-ubitan patterns, based also on sensitivity to contour but differently than Geria (Tenzer 2000a, 225; Tenzer 2000b). I separate ubit-ubitan into two collections, ubit telu (ubit “three”, shown at left) and ubit empat (ubit “four”, shown at right). This is such a quotidian distinction for Balinese that Geria did perhaps not even consider invoking it. In ubit telu patterns, three contiguous scale-tone pitches are used, and the polos and sangsih parts always share the middle pitch. In ubit empat a fourth pitch is added such that each part has its own two pitches, and when the low part sounds its lower pitch, the high part always sounds its higher one. This generates dyads that protrude from the texture as cross-rhythms when patterns repeat. Aside from this, though, the collections of ubit telu and ubit empat patterns are identical from the standpoint of the contours of the lower three pitches in each.” (Tenzer (2024) [5.3]) Balinese C: “1) ricikan bilah dr perunggu; 2) gangsa berbilah sepuluh dg suara menengah, berfungsi sbg pembawa lagu pd gong kebyar” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 165, Bidang Istilah Musik, “pemadé”]

\u043d\u0430\u0440\u043e\u0434/narod.text: Bulgarian A: “Странно ще е това чужденец, познаващ малкия български народ само от великата световна война като герой в подвизиТози малък, но корав народ с колкото славна, толкова и печална история, кален от векове сред бури и неволи, пази като съкровища, унаследени от векове, предавани от поколение на поколение, множество самобитни, безизкуствени творби на невидимото тоново изкуство музиката, която със своите оригинални метрични, ритмични и тонални особености е не по-малко интересна от новооткритите египетски археологически паметници.” Hristov (1925) (p. 33) English A: “To any foreigner who knows of the small Bulgarian nation only from its heroic exploits and suffering during the great world war, the title of this article will be strange. This small but tough nation with such a glorious and sorrowful history, tempered by centuries among storms and woes, guards like treasures, inherited for centuries, handed down from generation to generation, a multitude of self-originating, artless works of the invisible tonal art of music, which with its original metric, rhythmic, and tonal characteristics is no less interesting than the newly discovered Egyptian archaeological monuments.” Goldberg (2024) [2.1] **народ/narod often translates to “people”

Tanabe (1975).text: Tanabe, Hisao, Hōgaku Yōgo Jiten. Shohan. Tōkyō: Tōkyōdō Shuppan, 5019.

knowing.text: Source A: “In considering the differences between theorizing and knowing, my mind harks back to 1996, at which time I was having one of my early supervision meetings with linguist and ethnomusicologist David Hughes. When I discussed my first efforts to understand the comparative drum language grammars of the Nigerian bàtá and Cuban batá, David alerted me that just as we can speak a language without understanding much detail about its rules, many musicians can play to a high level without fully understanding the musical grammar of their musical system.” (Villepastour commentary (2024) [2.2]) Source B: “For, only recently (recently? But it seeps through, as a structure of feeling, the emergence with which we are concerned at the moment), a central component of the moral distinctiveness of an intellectual middle class (what Nadine Hubbs (2014, 2) calls the “narrating class”) was the positive imperative toward culturally other “knowledges.” By contrast, what one was supposed never to do was to presume to speak of “ethnic” artefacts based solely on one’s specializations or expertise in Western knowledge.” (Wang commentary (2024) [1.3]) Definition: “The acquisition of, or fact of having acquired, knowledge or understanding; comprehension; †expertise, skill, command” (Oxford English Dictionary, “knowing”)

bichromatic.text: Source: “Möllendorff reasoned, would suffice for many hundreds of years before any need to divide them further (Möllendorff 1917, 12). His bichromatic piano occupied a middle ground between Mager’s (and later Ivan Wyschnegradsky’s) use of two manuals and Carillo’s metamorphoser pianos by including quarter tones between the white and the black keys of an otherwise conventional manual (Möllendorff 1917, 15).” Bauer commentary (2024) [2.1]

\u0432\u0440\u0435\u043c\u0435/vreme.text: Bulgarian A: “По отношение на такта българската музика съдържа една особеност, която е чужда не само на западната музика, но и на музиката на съседните нам страни, както и на източната (персо-арабска) музика. Тая особеност се крие в образуването на редица тактове, служещи за основа на разнообразните наши танци. За основен (първичен) елемент (хроноспротос) в тия тактове служи движение (време) с бързина около 400—432 на минута, т.е. движение, пет пъти по-бързо от пулса на възрастен човек.” Hristov (1925) [p. 37] English A: “With regard to meter, Bulgarian music contains a feature that is foreign not only to Western music, but also to the music of our neighboring countries, as well as to Eastern (Persian-Arabic) music. This feature is hidden in the formation of a series of meters that serve as a basis for our diverse dances. Serving as a fundamental (primary) element (chronos protos) in these meters is a pulse (beat) with a tempo of around 400–432 per minute, i.e., five times faster than the heartrate of an adult person.” Goldberg (2024) [3.1] Bulgarian B: Beat = “удар, време, основна ритмична пулсация в афроамериканския фолклор, джаза и популярната музика.” (Iliev (1996), 76)

Samudragh\u014d\u1e63a.text: English A: “As defined in the thirteenth century poetic treatise Elu Saňdäs Lakuna (“Characteristics of Sinhala Poetic Meter”), this poetic meter is named Samudraghōṣa (Sin. sound of the ocean) (Sorata 2004 [1963], 56). While the Samudraghōṣa poetic meter has been used in many genres of Sinhala versification (Makulloluwe 2009 [1969], 33–49), musicologist C. de S. Kulatillake has observed that it is rare in ritual repertoire (1976b, 9), making this example rather unusual.” Peiris (2024) [16] English B; “type of poetic meter” (Peiris (2025))

tonicization.text: Source: “In my experience, the nuances of sound in actual music (precise tunings, rhythmic nuance, and melodic vocabulary) lead to feelings of tension, expectation, and tonicization that cannot be conveyed in written transcription. Furthermore, the feelings of which notes are tonicized and which are notes of tension are aurally, culturally conditioned by experience.” (Shumays commentary (2024) [3.2]) Definition: “The act of establishing a new key centre, or of giving a degree other than the first the role of tonic. This is accomplished by emphasizing the crucial properties of that tonic, in particular its fourth scale degree and leading note, both of which are part of its dominant 7th chord.” (Grove Music, “Tonicization”)

\u53cc\u97f3 shu\u0101ngy\u012bn.text: Definitions: Chinese: “在畲族地区，每年农历八月十五日至次年二月初三是歌唱活动频繁季节。民间俗语称“八月十五歌门开，二月初三关歌门”。在此期间举行各种各样的“赛歌”活动，“双音”则以独特的演唱风格和较难的演唱技巧受到歌手和群众的特殊喜爱. “双音”的演唱是在男女声对唱基础上发展而成。往往在对唱的高潮时进入重唱。歌手多为一男一女，也有每一声部二三人的情况。三人以上演唱时，因各人的即兴发挥，而可能形成三、四声部的重唱。歌手中女子多用假声；男子真、假声皆可。歌手对歌一般在异性与同辈人之间进行.” Zhongguo minjian (2006)  English: “I refer to this type of score as “shuāngyīn Vocal Notation雙音唱譜 (Double-Tone Notation),” which includes both musical notes and words plus IPA.” Qian (2024)  “Therefore, using shuāngyīn Vocal Notation not only allows the sounds of chàngcí to be notated for non-phonetic scripts, but also puts both the chàngqīang and the chàngcí in the form of a universally recognized symbolic system.” Qian (2024)

n\u0101gasinnam.text: English A: “Taking the five instruments– dawula drum (double headed cylindrical drum), other drums, horanǟwa (small quadruple-reed shawm), nāgasinnam (larger shawm),and däkkiya drum (hour-glass shaped variable tension drum)” (Peiris (2024) [6.6]) Sinhalese A: “dawul bhēri horanǟ nāsinnam däkki mepasa gattayi – räňgu” (Peiris (2024) [6.6]) English B: “type of wind instrument” (Peiris (2025))

\uacc4\uba74\uc870 Gyemyeonjo.text: Korean A: “1975년 장사훈과 한만영이 발간한 『국악개론』에서 판소리 우조에 대해 가곡의 우조나 3음 음계 계면조와 같이 정악 스타일을 판소리에 도입한 것이라 하며, 평조에 대해서는 우조와 조성 의 차이가 아니라 창법과 선을 형태의 차이로 설명하고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 236] English A: “Chang and Han 1975 claim that pansori’s Ujo incorporates jeongak styles, similar to gagok’s Ujo or the three-note scale, Gyemyeonjo. They specify that pansori’s Pyeongjo is distinguished from Ujo by its vocal style and melodic structure, rather than tonality.” Kim (2024) [2.2] Korean B: “향악(鄉樂)에 사용된 선법(旋法)의 하나. ① 악조총의(樂調總義)에 의하면, *계면조는 중국 5조(궁조·상조·각조·치조·우조) 중 우조(羽調)가 속칭 계면조이다"라고 설 명되었다. 당비파(唐琵琶)의 산형(散形)에서 계면조는 5조 중의 우조라고 설명되었다.” Song (2010) [p. 38] English C: “1. one of the modes 2. a melodic style of sad tune” (Pyǒn (2012) 17) Korean C:  (Pyǒn (2012) 17)

Relaciones de los intervalos.text: Spanish A: “Podrían incluirse, si acaso, en el campo de las metamorfosis, las imitaciones por movimiento contrario, pues éstas, aunque no alteran las relaciones de los intervalos, son, sin embargo, diferentes del tema que imitan.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] English A: “Imitations by contrary motion could perhaps be included within the domain of metamorphosis, because although they do not alter intervallic relationships, they nevertheless differ from the themes they imitate.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [p. 15] Spanish B: “Dicese de la que existe entre los dos sonidos que forman un intervalo. Es justa ó consonante cuando el intervalo constituye una consonancia mayor ó menor. Es falsa ó disonante cuando este intervalo es diminuto.” Pedrell (1890) [p. 395]

tone row.text: Source: “In the marginalia shown in Example 9 [Insert Example 9 here], Carrillo examined Schoenberg’s Wind Quintet in terms of its tone row, re-notating three row permutations and identifying their pitch classes. Carrillo further observed, in two marginal comments, how these row permutations segregated even- from odd-numbered pitch classes, and thus WT0 from WT1. He used his observation to contrast Schoenberg’s compositional theory with his own.” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.9] Definition: “An ordered succession of elements to be used as basic material in a composition. The term is most frequently applied to an ordering of the 12 pitch classes, but it may also be used of a succession of fewer or more than 12 pitch classes, or of successions of pitches, durations, dynamics, time points, timbres and so on.” (Grove Music Online, “Series [row, tone row, note row]”)

melodic vocabulary.text: Source: “In contrast with this view, it is evident to practitioners of oral traditions that melody is built from melodic vocabulary stored in memory. This melodic vocabulary is as arbitrary as the sounds of spoken language or the constituent elements of any communication system (as demonstrated by Claude Shannon in The Mathematical Theory of Communication (1949) and in the field of Information Theory and contemporary telecommunication and computer science)—that is, culturally chosen and passed on as a shared language within social groups.” (Shumays commentary (2024) [3.7])

\u30d5\u30a1\u30f3\u30bf\u30b8\u30fc fan.text: Japanese A: “自分で音楽を考え る、ファンタジーをつかむという自由だ けがそこにあったのです。身体的な条件 は極度に悪くても、そのファンタジーを つかむ自由はありました。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 60] English A: “There existed only freedom to think about my music and to unfold my fantasy. Even though my physical condition was extremely poor, I had the freedom to unfold fantasy.” Park (2024) [6.3]

nada.text: Balinese A: “smara ngaran laki, ratih ngaran wadu, swaraning smara ngaran kama nada, swaraning ratih ngaran kama sraga. Rikalanya anunggal swara ika, hana swara karenga ngararengih ngalup manis, kadi reng pangucapira sanghyang smara ratih, patemuan nira murda, ring murda panunggara nira sanghyang ardanareswari, apan sira wenang surup sinurup, ganti gumanti, matemahan ring windu nada candra.” (Geria (n.d.)) English A: ““Semara” indicates male, “Ratih” indicates female, the voice of Semara is called kama nada, [kama = desire; nada = tone] the voice of Ratih is called kama sraga [sraga = form]. When these voices become one, there is a tinkling, sweet sound, like the vibrations of Sang Hyang Semara and Ratih’s words at their summit, at the highest realm of Sang Hyang Ardanareswari [a manifestation of Siva and his consort Parvati unifying male and female] because he can go in and out, again and again, on the tones of Windu Chandra [windu is a point, an essence; chandra can suggest brightness or the moon].” (Tenzer (2024) [I.6]) Balinese B: “Suara-suara (bunyi) itu dibentuk menjadi 10 (sepuluh) nada yaitu 5 (lima) nada yang disebut laras Pelog dan 5 (lima) nada disebut laras Slendro. Nada-nada itu mempunyai kaitan dengan Panca Tirta dan Panca Geni, dua sumber keseimbangan hidup manusia.” Bandem (1986) [p. 13]

\uc720\ub3d9\uc801 yudongjeok.text: Korean A: “이보형이 정리한 판소리 평조의 특징은 중중모리장단의 평조 대목에 나타나는 특징으로, 그 는 '중중모리-평조'라고 적음으로서 다른 장단의 평조 대목과 구별하였다. 구성음에서 mi와 fa는 유동적인 음으로, mi로 적을 수도 있고, fa로 적을 수도 있는, 다시 말해 창자들이 조금 높게 부를 수도 조금 낮게 부를 수도 있는 음으로 해석하였다. 이는 백대웅의 우조, 평조 이론과 가장 크게 차이를 보이는 부분으로, 이 음은 백대웅의 우조와 평조 이론에서 '상청'음에 해당하 는 음인데, 백대웅은 상청의 반음 높고 낮음에 따라 우조와 평조를 구분하였다. 그러나 이보형 은 이 음을 유동적인 것으로 파악하였고, 출현 빈도가 많은 중요음이 아닌 관계로 이 음의 높고 낮음이 악조를 변별하는 데 영향을 끼치지 않는다고 보았다.” Shin (2018) [p. 243] English A: “Lee’s Pyeongjo in pansori has the same features as Pyeongjo sequences in jungjungmori jangdan; to set it apart from the other Pyeongjo scenes, he refers to it as “jungjungmori-Pyeongjo.” According to Lee, mi and fa are flexible constituent notes; depending on the pansori performer, these notes could be sung a little higher or lower. This is where Lee’s theories of Ujo and Pyeongjo diverge most prominently from Baek’s. These flexible notes [mi or fa] are sangcheong in Baek’s Ujo and Pyeongjo theories. Baek distinguishes Ujo and Pyeongjo based on whether sangcheong is a high or low half step. Lee, however, considers these notes (mi or fa) fluid; whether they are high or low does not affect the mode because they are not important or frequently appearing notes.” Kim (2024) [3.17]

\u7d14\u7c8b\u6027 junsuisei.text: Japanese A: “高い意味での純粋性―全ての不条理を 克服してそこに純粋性を見出す。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 58] English A: “Purity comes from overcoming the contradiction within the whole.”” Park (2024) [5]

\u4f1d\u7d71\u97f3\u697d dent\u014d onga.text: 伝統: tradition, convention 音楽 ongaku: music Japanese A: “これはヨーロッパの調性音楽が、次第に従来の長・短調組織からぬけだして、自由な音語を使うようになってから、もっともひろい意味での調性の中心になる音という意味に使われていたものを、伝統音楽のばあいに適用したものと解することができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “It is understood that Mr. Itō applied the word “central tone” as something commonly used in Japanese traditional music, in the same way European [tonal] music used it in a free pitch language after it gradually began to pull away from its original major- and minor-key organization of tonal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4, brackets added separately] Japanese B: “東洋 の伝統音楽にこの原型があります。常に そのモデルは相対性を持っていて、一つ のものが常に中心になり、原則的にはこ うなるんです。” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English B: “East Asian traditional music has its original model. One element always becomes the center because this model always possesses relativity. This is how it goes, at least in principle.” Park (2024) [4.1]

compasso.text: English A: “One of the basic principles of European rhythmic construction, which was in the process of being developed at the time of the discovery of Brazil, as Manuel Veiga would say, is the concept of meter (compasso), or the metric verticalization of musical structure.” (Stover (2024) [1.2]) Portuguese A: “Um dos princípios básicos da concepção rítmica europeia, em processo de estruturação na época do achamento do Brasil, como diria Manuel Veiga, é a concepção de compasso, ou verticalização métrica da estrutura musical.” (Ulhôa (1999)) English B: “One of the basic principles of European rhythmic conception is the notion of the measure [compasso], or the metric verticalization of musical structure (Copland 1974).” (Stover (2024) [4.2]) Portuguese B: “Um dos princípios básicos da concepção rítmica européia, é a noção de compasso, ou verticalização métrica da estrutura musical (Copland 1974).” (Ulhôa (1999)) Portuguese C: “ Portuguese D: “São conjuntos ou séries de movimentos que se reproduzem simètricamente.Os compassos mais usados são: o binário; o ternário; o qua-ternário. As frações também se denominam signos de compassos. Escrevem-se os compassos logo após a clave, da maneira seguinte: o numerador coloca-se sôbre a terceira linha da pauta; o denominador, sob essa mesma linha.” (Cosme (1957) 33)

Indeterminacy.text: Source: “As such, I read Yun’s critique not as a reiteration of problematic East/West binaries, but as a differential way of thinking about musical structure, process, interpretation, and experience that has affinities with how other experimental logics address matters of time, indeterminacy, mobile forms, heterophony and micropolyphony, and much more.” (Stover commentary (2024) [1.4]) Definition: “Much the same as aleatory, but specially the principle by which the composer grants greater freedom to the perf.” (”Indeterminacy,” The Oxford Dictionary of Music)Aleatory: “Music that cannot be predicted before perf and/or music comp. through chance procedures.” (”Aleatory,” The Oxford Dictionary of Music) Aleatory: “Music that cannot be predicted before perf and/or music comp. through chance procedures.” (”Aleatory,” The Oxford Dictionary of Music)

\ud3c9\uc870 Pyeongjo.text: English A: “A typical example of this is the conflicting and overlapping definitions provided by gugak (the national music of Korea) scholars of the modes: Ujo is described as a pentatonic scale comprised of a-c-d-e-g with little vibrato or glissando (Lee and Lee 2007, 134);(6) Pyeongjo is defined as a pentatonic scale of g-a-c-d-f but with vibrato or ornamentation causing the f to fall to or be pitched closer to e (Lee and Lee 2007, 134).” (Kim (2024) [0.2]) Korean B: “한국음악학에서 판소리 악조에 대한 논의는 오랜 기간 여러 학자들에 의해 시도되었다. 그러 나 여전히 공통의 합의가 이루어지지 못하고, 여러 다른 악조론으로 음악을 분석하고 있다. 그 중 가장 대표적인 판소리 악조론은 백대웅과 이보형의 이론으로, 계면조에 대해서는 이견이 없 으나, 이들의 서로 다른 우조와 평조에 대한 해석이 후속 학자들에 의해 활용되고 있다.” Shin (2018) [p. 234] English B: “Although Korean musicologists have long debated the melodic modes in pansori, there is a lack of consensus regarding the identification of the pansori modes, which they have attempted to define based on different modal theories. The theories of Baek Daewoong (1974–2011) and Lee Bohyeong (b. 1937) are the representative views of pansori scales. While Baek and Lee concur on the criteria for Gyemyeonjo, they diverge on the modes for Ujo and Pyeongjo.” Kim (2024) [1.1] Korean C: “① 평조는 중국 5조 즉 궁조(宮調)·상조(商調)·각조(角調)·치조(微調)ㆍ우조(材調) 중 치조가 속칭 평조라고 설명되었다. 당비파(唐琵琶)의 산형(散形)에서 평조는 5조 중의 치조 라고 악조총의(樂調總義)에 설명되었다.” Song (2010) [p. 375] Korean D:  English D: 1. key notes in middle register 2, a kind of mode, 3. normal tempo 4. joyful style (Pyǒn (2012) 95)

\u9577\u30fb\u77ed\u8abf\u7d44\u7e54 ch\.text: Japanese A: “これはヨーロッパの調性音楽が、次第に従来の長・短調組織からぬけだして、自由な音語を使うようになってから、もっともひろい意味での調性の中心になる音という意味に使われていたものを、伝統音楽のばあいに適用したものと解することができる。” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 7] English A: “It is understood that Mr. Itō applied the word “central tone” as something commonly used in Japanese traditional music, in the same way European music used it in a free pitch language after it gradually began to pull away from its original major- and minor-key organization of tonal music.” Hynes-Tawa (2024) [4] Japanese B: 長調“調 性 ⾳ 楽 に お け る 調 の ⼀ 種 で 、 「 短 調 に 対 す る も の 。 * ⾧ ⾳ 階 で 作 ら れ た 楽 曲 を 「 調 の 曲 」 と い い 、 そ の 楽 曲 は ド 旋 法 （ ⾧ 旋 法  の 特 徴 を ⽰ す 。” (Tomosha (2002), 416) 短調: “調 性 ⾳ 楽 に お け る 調 の ⼀ 種 で 、 「 ⾧ 調 」 に 対る も の 。 * 短 ⾳ 階 で 作 ら れ た 楽 曲 を 「 短 調  の曲 」 と い い ， そ の 楽 曲 は ラ 旋 ( 短 旋 法) の 特 徴 を ⽰ す 。” (Tomosha (2002), 400)

precolonial.text: Source: “Prakempa is an artifact of precolonial culture wherein a mix of languages (Balinese, Old Javanese, and Sanskrit) and intertextually-related expressive genres (music, dance, theater, visual arts) were widely but unequally pervasive in village, court, and priestly realms of society.” (Tenzer (2024) [0.5]) Definition: “Relating to a time prior to colonization; occurring or existing before the colonial period of a country.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “pre-colonial”)

kesa mura.text: See gambang  English A: “Gambang style is called kesa mura; its sound is banyu maga.” (Tenzer (2024) [II.13]) Balinese/Indonesian A: “Tandang gagebug gambang, kesa mura. Banyu maga nama suaranya.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “As well as being an instrument, in Bali gambang also names an ensemble usually comprising four gambang and two bronze metallophones. Kesa mura means irregular and free, which likely connotes the fact that gamelan gambang music is not regulated by gongs and conventional gong structures. Banyu marga means flowing water, suggesting the continuous rippling texture of gamelan gambang music.” (Tenzer (2024) [2.12]) *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)

body gestures.text: Source: “A vocalist sings to a drum player’s accompaniment. The vocalist performs three artistic acts: singing, speech, and body gestures. The drummer controls the flow of the music through rhythmic patterns.” Lee commentary (2024) [3] Definition: “Manner of carrying the body; bearing, carriage, deportment.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “gesture”)

worldview.text: Source A: “Throughout the document, the nationalistic agenda that underlies Hristov’s writing is apparent, illustrating the type of interconnectedness between music theory and worldview that Philip Ewell (2020) identifies in writings by Hristov’s Austrian contemporary, Heinrich Schenker.” (Goldberg (2024) [0.3]) Source B: “Much of this socially, culturally, and politically informed work, including my own, has focused on how the discipline of music theory has historically aligned itself with a worldview that oppresses people marginalized by race, gender, sexuality, class, disability, and other identity markers (Conlee and Koike 2021a, 2021b; Momii 2021; Boyd 2023; Ewell 2023; Lett 2023; Yust 2024); and/or has shown the potential for music theory to challenge dominant worldviews and the oppressive hierarchies therein (Hannaford 2021; Lumsden 2022; Stover 2022; Yu Wang, 2023).” (Boyd commentary (2024) [1]) Definition: “A largely unconscious but generally coherent set of presuppositions and beliefs that every person has which shape how we make sense of the world and everything in it. This in turn influences such things as how we see ourselves as individuals, how we interpret our role in society, how we deal with social issues, and what we regard as truth.” (Oxford Reference)

\u66f2\u724c q\u01d4 p\u00e1i.text: Definitions: Chinese A: “传统填词制谱用的曲调调名的统称。俗称“牌子”。[…] 曲牌的文字部分须“倚声填词”，多作长短句，少用齐言。” Zhongguo da baike (2020) (曲牌) Chinese B: “俗称“牌子”。戏曲、散曲的曲调调名之总称。其命名或源于前人词曲佳作之调名,或以地名,或以其节拍特点,或以乐曲体式结构,或以少数民族语言之音译,或以民歌时调之曲名等等,总数有数千种。每一曲牌均有规定的曲调、唱法、句数、字数、平仄、押韵等基本定式。其文字部分须“倚声填词”,多作长短句,少用齐言。曲牌在戏曲中有改用乐器伴奏者,演变为器乐曲牌.” Zhongguo wenxue (1997) (p. 1862) Chinese C: “每一曲牌都有专名,如《水龙吟》、《太平令》、《转调货郎儿》、《山坡羊》、《节节高》等,现存曲牌多达数千个。大部分来自民间,有一部分则由词发展而来,这就是有些曲牌名与词牌名相同的原因。此外,还有一些专供演奏的曲牌,大多只有曲调而无曲词。1961年3月22日,陈毅在《在戏曲编导工作座谈会上的讲话》中建议演出戏曲,“不仅要写字幕,也要把唱腔、曲牌写上去”,“这样也可以提高观众的欣赏能力”。(《党和国家领导人论文艺》,第111页).” Maozedong wenyi (1993) (p. 336) For further discussion, see also: Zhongguo gudian (1991) (p. 272),  Zhongguo yinyue (1984) (”曲牌,” p. 321) English: “…shows an excerpt of the qupai 曲牌 (fixed tune) called “Shuilong yin” 水龍吟 (“Water dragon chant”) played by the Hua 滑 family band from Yanggao, Shanxi province (Jones 2007, 91–99)” Lam (2024)

whole tone.text: Source: “Carrillo justified this sixteenth-tone limit for his microtonal system by arguing that it was practical. Within a single composition, he pointed out, sixteenth tones could be multiplied to form eighth tones, quarter tones, semitones, and whole tones, and so could be reconciled with a variety of microtonal and traditional instruments (Carrillo 1938, 24).” Cannon-Brown (2024) [2.4] Definition: “The interval equal to the sum of two semitones.” (Grove Music Online, “whole tone”)

time-line.text: English A: “As Simha Arom explains in his work on polyrhythm in Central Africa (1994), there is no regular pattern or intermediate level (such as measures and downbeats) between the pulse level and the musical period. This period, often formed by the addition of rhythmic patterns of varying size, can be externalized through claps that mark the dance steps or by a guide instrument that plays what is known as a time-line.” (Stover (2024) [4.4]) Portuguese A: “Como explica Simha Aaron no seu trabalho sobre poliritmia na Africa central (1994), não há um padrão regular nem níveis intermediários (como compassos e tempos fortes) entre a pulsação e o período musical. Este período, formado muitas vezes pela adição de padrões rítmicos de tamanho variado pode ser externalizado através de palmas que marcam os passos da dança ou por um instrumento-guia que toca o que se conhece como "time-line".” (Ulhôa (1999))

kajar.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “Niyan gagebug kajar, kajar ngaran amangku irama, eka laksana ngaran, mwang prana canda ngaran.” (Geria (n.d.)) English B: “As for kajar [a small gong held in the lap or placed on a stand that sounds the main beat; the root word ajar means both learn and teach], it oversees the rhythm, alone among the instruments; it is the breath and guide of music (prana canda).” (Tenzer (2024) [I.9]) Balinese C: “Kecuali lagu Wiranata, kedua lagu yang lainnya kini mash populer di kalangan para penabuh yang biasa memainkan Gong (Gong Gede). Di samping pembahasan mengenai lagu-lagu di atas, pada ringkasan yang sama, naskah Prakempa menyinggung pula tentang arti simbolis dari instrumen gong (sebagai sorga), kempul (sebagai perkumpulan segala yang bersifat suci) dan kajar (sebagai irama atau guru segala tabuh) (alinea : 32).” Bandem (1986) [p. 20] Balinese D: “gong kecil bergaris tengah 16 cm dr perunggu, permukaannya setinggi 1,5 cm dg lebar 6 cm, berfungsi sbg mat” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 150, Bidang Istilah Musik]

m\u00fasica cl\u00e1ssico-rom\u00e2ntica.text: English A: “The emphasis on the melody is so striking that all the notes that compose it are essential to the song’s identity, including those that would be considered surface-level ornaments in the European classical-romantic music that has so influenced popular Brazilian music. What could be considered superfluous for melodic evaluation, such as notes that are foreign to the basic harmonic structure of the song (grupetos, mordants, appoggiaturas) have a functional importance in popular Brazilian song.” (Stover (2024) [2.7]) Portuguese A: “A ênfase na melodia é tão marcante que todas as notas que a compõem são essenciais para a identidade da canção, incluindo aquelas que seria consideradas ornamentos superficiais na música clássico-romântica européia que tanto influenciou a música brasileira popular. O que poderia ser considerado supérfluo para a avaliação melódica, como notas extranhas à estrutura harmônica básica na canção (grupetos, mordentes, appoggiaturas) têm uma importância funcional na canção brasileira popular.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\u4f5c\u54c1\u8868\u3092 Sakuhin-hy\u014.text: Japanese A: “先生の作品表を拝見いたしますと、オペラ、管弦楽曲、室内楽曲、声楽曲と、膨大な数に上っているわけですけれども、それらの作品はいわゆる西洋楽器、それから西洋の形態でつくられているものがすべてのように思います。われわれ日本の作曲家は邦楽器を用いることも多いのですが、先生は韓国の伝統楽器、あるいは東アジアの伝統楽器のための作品をお書きになったことはないのですか。” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 50) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

\uad00\ud604\uc545\uace1 gwanhyeon-aggog.text: 관현: orchestra; symphony 악곡: composition; music; song  Korean A: “선생님의 작품일람표를 보면 오페라•관현악곡 • 실내악곡• 성악곡 등 방대한 수에 달하고 있습니다만 그 작품들은 소위 서양악기 그리고 서양의 형태로 되어 있는 것이 전부인 듯합니다. 우리 일본 의 작곡가는 우리 악기를 쓰는 경우도 있습니다만, 선생님은 한국의 전통악기를 위한 작품을 쓰신 적은 없으신지요? “ (Yun (1991) - Korean, 146–147) English A: "When looking at your list of compositions, I find numerous operas, orchestral music, chamber pieces, vocal pieces, and so on, but they all seem to be composed for so-called “Western” instruments and in “Western” configuration. For Japanese composers, there are some compositions written for Japanese traditional instruments. Have you composed a piece for traditional Korean instruments?" (Park (2024) [1.1])

\u9806\u6b21\u9032\u884c junjishink\u014.text: 順次: sequential, in order + 進行: moving forward, onward movement Japanese A: “しかし、この旋律が順次進行を主体とする声楽と本質的にちがった種類のものではなく” Koizumi Fumio (1958) [p. 9] English A: “However, this melody is not essentially different from vocal melodies that make most of their material from conjunct motion.” [Hynes-Tawa (2024) [6.2]

\u5357\u9053\u5531 Minami Michi ch\u00e0.text: Japanese A: “ そ の ひ と つ に 、 南 道 唱 と い いま し て 、 南 韓 国 あ た り を 中 ⼼ と し て 発 展し た 朗 々 と 歌 う 民 族 ⾳ 楽 が あ り ま す 。 そこ か ら 私 は と て も 影 響 を 受 け ま し た.” (Yun (1984) - Japanese, 51) English A: “One of them is called Namdo Chang [남도창, 南道唱], which is folk music that features a clear and loud voice and has been passed down in the southern Korean region. I have been greatly influenced by that genre." (Park (2024) [1.3])

\ub2e4\uc6d0\uc801\uc778 dawonjeog-in.text: 다원: pluralism Korean A: " 나의 음악은 단원적(monistisch)입니다. 내음악은 사 음악적이 아니며 다원적인 음악이 아닙니다. 예를 들면 알로이 스 추머만의 음악은 다원적인 음악이지요. 근원을 달리하는 음악 요소가 동시에 흐르면서 질서를 유지하고, 대립하면서도 마침내는화합하여 음악적으로 크게 향상한다는 것이지요. " (Yun (1991) - Korean 149–150) English A: "My music is monistic (monistisch). My music is not polyphonic or pluralistic. For example, Bernd Alois Zimmermann’s music is pluralistic. Elements from different roots flow together, maintain order, oppose, but ultimately come together to greatly elevate the music." (Park (2024) [2.1])

tango platino.text: Portuguese A: “Ora em nossa música americana (jazz, maxixe e em geral toda síncopa brasileira e mesmo no tango platino) o que se dá é um verdadeiro descolocamento do acento forte que passa do lugar teórico para um lugar onde ele não devia cair, verdadeira antecipação rítmica da thesis.” Andrade (n.d.) [Nota no. 9] English A: “Now in our American music (jazz, maxixe, and in general all Brazilian syncopation and even in the Argentine tango) what happens is a true displacement of the strong accent which passes from the theoretical place to a place where it should not fall, a true rhythmic anticipation of the thesis.” Menezes (2024) [1.5] Portuguese B: “Dança com canto popularizada nas Américas Central e do Sul a Espanha no início deste século, caracterizada polo ritmo 4/8Maria Mercedes Griffin afirma que em meadosdo século passado três danças de fórmula rítmica semelhantes contribuíram para a fixação do tango: o tango de Andaluzia (Espanha), a habanera (Cuba) que na Espanha foi muitas vezes confundida com o tango, e a milon-ga, de Buenos Aires (Argentina), que sofreu influência dos ritmos negros. A milonga, originalmente uma forma lírica, passou a ser dançada depois de sua mistura com a habanera; foi esta a dança que sobreviveu à passagem do século, sendo conhecida como tango. (DM-MẢ)” (Andrade (1989) 501)

\u0440\u0438\u0442\u043c\u0438\u043a\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “ще се дойде до заключение, че както тоналностите, така и ритмиката, за която става д у м а в старогръцката теория на музиката, са запазени на Балканския полуостров, особено в българските и македонските песни.” Hristov (1925) (p. 34) English A: “…one will come to the conclusion that both the tonalities and the rhythmics that are treated in ancient Greek theory of music are preserved on the Balkan peninsula, especially in Bulgarian and Macedonian songs.” Goldberg (2024) [2.6]

g\u012b.text: English A: “In contrast, poetic meters labelled as gī (blank verse) were known for having different amounts of morae between lines in a couplet (Kulatillake 1976b, 3). Further, there is historical precedent for regular sivpada verses being paired with irregular gī verses, suggesting that the pairing of Sinhala sivpada quatrains with irregular non-lexical phrases might indeed have been following an established technique of poetry composition.” Peiris (2024) [19] Sinhalese A: “කවි නොවන වගන්තිය.” Carter (2011)  English B: “category of poetic meter” (Peiris (2025))

Zhongguo baike (1990).text: Zhongguo baike da cidian 中国百科大辞典. Beijing: Huaxia chuban she 北京:华夏出版社, 1990.

\u7dda sen.text: Japanese A: “また「ハウプト・トン」は断続的に切れ切れの形で現れることもあります。と もかく様々な線となって現れますが…” Yun (1984) - Japanese [p. 57] English A: “Also, a Hauptton sometimes intermittently appears in the shape of little pieces. In any case, it appears as various lines.” Park (2024) [4.1] Japanese B: “五線譜の5本の水平線。下から上に、第1線，第2線，第3線，第4線、第5線とよ ぶ.” (Tomosha (2002), 365)

jegogan.text: English A: “Then he briefly covers instruments of a large bronze gamelan, presumably a gamelan gong kebyar: kajar, a small mounted gong; the family of metallophones (from low to high register) possessing a single-octave-range jegogan, jublag, and panyacah; those with a two-octave-range giying, gangsa pemadé (not explicitly mentioned) and gangsa kantil(an); and last but not least, the hanging gongs, the kendang (drums) and cengeceng (cymbals).” (Tenzer (2024) [1.2]) Balinese B: “yaning jegogan pamangku swara ngaran, guru.” English B: “Whereas the jegogan manages the [core, scaffolding] melody, that is to say is its guru.” (Tenzer (2024) [I.9]) Balinese C: “Mwah yan Smar Patangian, ndyata : kempul satunggal sawur-nya manyomanan ndung, kemong gantung sanunggal swaranya ndung, kajar sanunggal sawurnya ndung, gupek roro lanang wadon, rebab sanunggal, suling ageng roro, suling babarangan roro sama ngumbang ngisep, gender ageng sapasang, jegogan sapasang, jublag sapasang, panyacah sapasang, kantil sapasang, gangsa manengah sapasang, gangsa alit apasang, nging sama ngumbang gisep, gumanak tatiga, genta orag apancer alit, kecek tigang wungkul alit, kecek manengah kalih wungkul, kecek ageng sawungkul, jangkep kayeki.”  (Bandem (1986), 82) English C (Chat-GPT): “Smara Patangian Ensemble The Smara Patangian gamelan is more rhythmic and ceremonial, used in rituals and processions. It consists of: Thus, this ensemble is also considered complete (jangkep). This classification reflects the structural and tonal balance within different Balinese gamelan styles, each serving specific cultural and artistic purposes.” Balinese D: “gangsa yg memakai nada terendah di gamelan, berbilah lima, dimainkan dg panggul karet” Kamus Budaya Bali (2016) [p. 149, Bidang Istilah Musik]

d\u00e4kum.text: English A: “The text of this däkum ata piece in which the narrator witnesses/salutes their superiors is reminiscent of the historical practice of däkum (literally, “seeing”) in eighteenth-century Sri Lanka. In this tradition, tenants of a feudal lord would gather to pay respect to him by presenting gifts (Obeyesekere 1967, 220) as part of “a chain of däkum ceremonies binding subordinates of various types to superordinate personnel above them who in turn paid homage to persons of superior rank” (Roberts 2004, 61). Given how the patterning of the pantheon in Sinhalese-Buddhist cosmology can be seen to resemble some of the relational principles of the historical state (Obeyesekere 1966), it is not surprising that this “offering of sound” given to the supernatural Buddha and deities (along with the monarch and teacher) reflects the tribute-paying däkum practices of the mundane world.”  Peiris (2024) [10] English B: “witnessing” (Peiris (2025))

teleology.text: Source: “Of course, it moves forward without being goal-directed as in Western art music’s linear, teleological musical forms, which Ulhôa tends to use as a foil to the métrica derramada feel.” (Danielsen commentary (2024) [4]) Definition: “The branch of knowledge or study dealing with ends or final causes; the study of phenomena which may be explained in terms of intention, design, or purposiveness rather than by prior causes.” (Oxford English Dictionary, “teleology”)

\uc7a5\uad6c janggu.text: English A: “Partly derived from pansori, sanjo was originally an improvised solo instrumental form accompanied by a drum, usually a janggu 장구; today, sanjo presents a fully predetermined melody, omitting improvisation.” [Kim (2024) [0.1])

gagaboran.text: Balinese A: “Di bawah ini adalah semua ubit-ubitan palegongan yang berpokok misalnya di dalam gagaboran atau di dalam lalonggoran dan kale, atau pangecet.” Geria (n.d.)  English A: “Below are palegongan-style ubit-ubitan for gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet contexts.” Tenzer (2024) [4.3] “Gagaboran, lalonggoran, kale, and pangecet are the names for different kinds of gong-cycle forms in dance pieces of the gamelan palegongan repertoire.” Tenzer (2024) [4.4]

two-step.text: Source: “The pattern also appears in Example 5 ([1.19]), a transcription of Amerindian music transcribed by the French musicologist Marguerite Béclard d’Harcourt, who identifies the pattern with Indigenous and Black musics, as well as cakewalks, two-steps, and tangos.” Biamonte commentary (2024) [5] Definition: “A fast ballroom dance of American origin. It became popular in the 1890s, particularly when danced to Sousa's The Washington Post (1889). It spread to Europe about 1900, and remained popular until replaced by the one-step and foxtrot shortly before World War I; indeed, the term ‘two-step’ was often used for the foxtrot in Europe during the 1910s. The steps, to a quick–quick–slow rhythm in each bar, were done with a gliding skip similar to that of the polka.” (Grove Music Online, “two-step”)

assim\u00e9tricos.text: English A: “What is quite prominent in sub-Saharan African music is the establishment of a temporal order based on the interaction of multiple parts that produce a polyrhythmic texture. The structure of its rhythmic organization is based on asymmetrical groupings of minimum time units or “fastest pulses,” as explained by Kwabena Nketia in The Music of Africa (1974). There is no vertical alignment at the beginning of the measure, as in European notions of meter [compasso].” (Stover (2024) [4.4]) Portuguese A: “O que é bastante proeminente na música africana, sub-saarana, é o estabelecimento de uma ordem temporal, baseada na interação de partes múltiplas que produzem uma textura polirítmica. A organização rítmica se estrutura a partir de agrupamentos assimétricos de unidades de tempo mínimas ou "pulso mais rápido", como explica Kwabena Nketia no seu livro The Music of Africa (1974). Não existe um alinhamento vertical dos inícios dos tempos, como nas noções europeias de compasso.” (Ulhôa (1999))

fluir.text: English A: “Song melodies would not be syncopated, the ambivalence emerging from their counterposition with the accompaniment, which would accentuate the beat. Instead, the melodic flow would be non-metrical, its accentuation driven by a “musical fantasy, pure virtuosity, or prosodic precision … a subtle compromise between recitative and strophic singing” (36).” (Stover (2024) [1.6]) Portuguese A: “As melodias das canções não seriam sincopadas, a ambivalência emergindo da contraposição com o acompanhamento, que acentuaria o tempo. O fluir da melodia seria não-métrico, a acentuação sendo dirigida por uma "fantasia musical, puro virtuosismo, ou precisão prosódica ... um compromisso sutil entre o canto recitativo e estrófico" (p. 36).” (Ulhôa (1999))

\uc77c\uccb4 ilche.text: Korean A: "그래서 선생님 작품이 마무리에 가까워짐에 따라 그것이 높은 차원에서 융합되어 일체의 것이라는 점을 아주 강하게 드러내 는, 그런 감동적인 코다를 항상 들을 수 있다고 봅니다만, 그렇게 느껴도 좋은 겁니까?" (Yun (1991) - Korean 150) English A: "For this reason, toward the end of your works, they [the seemingly conflicting elements] are fused in a higher dimension and strongly express their bodily unity [一体]. That seems to be the reason why I always hear deeply moving codas." (Park (2024) [2.2])

\u0445\u0443\u0434\u043e\u0436\u0435\u04.text: Bulgarian A: “неправилните тактове, които покрай обикновените правилни тактове са главна основа на нашата музика, значително се отличават от известните в художествената европейска музика неправилни тактове. Последните се образуват от равни части, на брой 5 или 7, които се подразделят на двойни или тройни по-малки части […] В нашата народна музика неправилният такт се образува от равни първични времена (хронос протоси), неделими на по-малки части, и противно на европейските неправилни тактове тук тези неделими части се свиват в по-големи части чрез съединение на две или три от тях (кратки и удължени тактови части).” Hristov (1925) [p. 39-40] English A: “The irregular meters that, alongside the usual regular meters, are one of the main foundations of our music, differ significantly from the irregular meters that are known in European art music. The latter are formed from equal parts, 5 or 7 in number, which are subdivided into smaller duple or triple parts […] In our folk music irregular meter is formed from equal primary elements (chronoi protoi) that cannot be divided into smaller parts, and contrary to European irregular meters, here these indivisible parts are bound together into larger parts by combining two or three of them (short and elongated metric parts).” Goldberg (2024) [4.3-4.4]

\u0432\u0442\u043e\u0440\u0430 \u0433\u0.text: Bulgarian A: “Друга група тактове имат за основен (първичен) елемент (хронос протос) два пъти по-бавно движение: А=200 - 216М М или : = 100 - 108 М.М. Тях ще наречем втора група тактове.” Hristov (1925) [p. 38] English A: “Another group of meters has as a fundamental (primary) element (chronos protos) a pulse twice as slow:  = 200–216 M. M. or  = 100–108 M. M. We will call them the second group of meters.” Goldberg (2024) [3.4]

\ud615\uc2dd\uad00\uc5d0 hyeongsiggwan-e.text: Korean A: “"일본의 작곡가들은 종래 작곡의 재료(Material)는 현대적 일지라도 어쩐지 낡은 서양의 전통적인 형식관에 따르고 있는 게 아닐까요. " (Yun (1991) - Korean 151) English A: "Perhaps Japanese composers follow the old Western traditional formalism even though the compositional materials [マテリアル] might be modern." (Park (2024) [2.3])

non-tertian harmony.text: Source: “For Hába, “tonality” was coextensive with diatonicism, and thus contained non-tertian harmonies, if not chromatic notes (Hába 1927, 75). The generation of microtonal divisions followed from the “law of division” found in the sixth octave of the overtone series, but can also be found in much music of the past, as well as in folk repertoires.” Bauer commentary (2024) [3.2]

tens\u00e3o.text: English A: “The intensity, which Tatit would call passionate tenseness, is intensified by the “participatory discrepancy” between solo and accompaniment.” (Stover (2024) [5.6]) Portuguese A: “A tensão, que Tatit chamaria de tensividade passional, é intensificada pela "discrepância participativa" entre solo e acompanhamento.” (Ulhôa (1999))

\ub300\uae08 Dae-gum.text: Korean A: “그게 이번에는 기악곡으로 옮겨가는데, 모든 기억 곡은 먼저 성악곡으로부터 이어받아 그것을 발전시킨 것이라고 해도 좋겠지요. 예를 들면 '대금'이라는 횡적을 길게 한 형태 의 한국 민족악기가 있는데, 그걸로 연주하는 가락은 가창을 이어받 은 것이지요. 그런데 거기에는 선적인 음악의 묘미가 있어요.” (Yun (1991) - Korean 148) English A: “And it also expands to instrumental music. One could say that all instrumental music is developed by continuing ideas from vocal music. For example, a flute-like instrument made with bamboo [橫笛] called Dae-gum is one of the Korean traditional instruments. Melodies played by that instrument are inherited from singing. They have their own charm of linear music." (Park (2024) [1.5]) English B: “Partly derived from pansori, sanjo was originally an improvised solo instrumental form accompanied by a drum, usually a janggu 장구; today, sanjo presents a fully predetermined melody, omitting improvisation. Sanjo may be played with a variety of traditional Korean string or wind instruments, including gayageum 가야금 (twelve-string zither), geomungo 거문고 (six-string zither), ajaeng 아쟁 (bowed zither), and daegeum 대금 (bamboo flute).” (Kim (2024) [0.1]) Korean C: “대금(大笒) 죽부(竹部) 소속 향악기(鄉樂器)의 하나. 대금의 우리말은 것대. ① 대금은 오례의(五 禮儀)의 종묘·영녕전 등가와 현가 및 고취(鼓吹) 와 전정헌가(殿庭軒架)에, 성종(1469~1494) 때 전 정헌가와 전정고취(殿庭鼓吹) 및 종묘·영녕전 등 가에, 전부고취(前部鼓吹)·전후고취(殿後鼓吹)·후 부고취(後部鼓吹)에, 정전예연여기악공배립(正殿 禮宴女妓樂工排立)에, 문소전(文昭殿) 및 연은전 (廷恩殿) 섭행(攝行) 전정악(殿庭樂)과 전상악(殿上 樂), 그리고 봉래의(鳳來儀)의 초입배열도(初入排 列圖) 및 학연화대처용무합설(鶴蓮花臺處容舞合設)의 초입배열도·시종회무도(始終回舞圖)에 배열된 악기의 하나이다.” Song (2010) [p. 87]

oles-olesan.text: English: “Oles-olesan is swiping or wiping, an apt description of the repeating pattern 32.23. in the polos. The mallet’s path on the keys needs a lateral wrist motion leftward for 32 and rightward for 23— just as one would move the hand back and forth with a cloth or paint brush, or glide a finger across a phone screen.” Tenzer (2024) [4.10] *Lexical field: Actions or perceptions (Tenzer (2024), Ex. 2)
